But he and his three brothers were forced to leave their land because they could no longer make a living there. ``Shortages forced us to buy seeds, fertilizers and pesticides at exorbitant prices,'' he said as he shared a lunch of bread and cheese with two other workers on a Tehran construction site. ``But when we demanded higher prices for our products we were forced to sell at officially designated rates _ at a loss,'' he complained. ``After living with dignity under my father's roof, I don't like this life.'' To lure farmers back to their villages, a massive land reform program, snarled in the bureacratic morass for years, is being pushed through Parliament. The program aims to force large land-owning government organizations to break up their holdings. Redistribution of land has been a political football since the revolution, with radicals campaigning for breaking up the vast estates once owned by the shah's acolytes and conservatives insisting they should be left alone. Officials agree that the birth rate should have been checked years ago and believe it will be years before it can. Just three years ago, the government was offering incentives to families to produce children for the ``jihad,'' or holy war, against Iraq, which has a population one-third Iran's.

DOC.HEAD: President Pushing GOP Candidates, Space Mission
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Bush remarks at Hunt fund-raiser scheduled 1:25 p.m EDT; will be led
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto WX17
DOC.TEXT: President Bush is heading south for the latest in a series of road trips to boost Republican election efforts, and to make a pitch for his moon-and-Mars exploration proposal. Bush was stumping in Alabama today for Gov. Guy Hunt and in North Carolina on behalf of Sen. Jesse Helms. In Huntsville, Ala., he planned to attend a reception to help Hunt's re-election bid. Tickets sold for $250, $500 and $1,000. While in Huntsville, Bush scheduled a stop at NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center. Aides said he would use the occasion to urge Congress to approve his $300 million request for the moon-Mars program in next year's budget. The sum is part of Bush's 1991 budget request for $1.27 billion in overall space exploration money, including existing programs. The president announced last July a goal of putting a manned spacecraft on Mars by 2019 and return manned missions to the moon. The plan suffered a setback in Congress last week when the House Appropriations subcommittee that handles the National Aeronautics and Space Administration slashed the $300 million request from its budget draft. Bush's one-day Southern swing emphasized election-year politicking, however. He has spent an increasing amount of time on the road across the country to help raise money for his party's Senate and gubernatorial candidates. Hunt, serving his first term as Alabama governor, faced minor opposition in his primary race and is in good shape to face the winner of the June 26 Democratic runoff race between teachers association lobbyist Paul Hubbert and state Attorney General Don Siegelman. The Democrats have been slicing one another up. Siegelman has accused Hubbert of being a special-interest lobbyist whose efforts hurt the cause of education. Hubbert has charged Siegelman with fiscal irresponsibility and made veiled references to Siegelman's admission that he smoked marijuana when he was young. From Alabama, Bush heads to Charlotte, N.C., to attend a fund-raising dinner for conservative stalwart Helms, who faces a close race against Democrat Harvey Gantt, a former mayor of Charlotte. A recent Charlotte Observer poll found Helms trailing Gantt by a few percentage points. Encouraging news for Gantt, who is black, was in the 35 percent support he got from white voters polled. Helms was backed by 50 percent of the whites, and Democratic strategists calculate that Gantt needs nearly 40 percent of the white vote to beat Helms. Democrats are hoping to portray Helms as a right-wing extremist out of touch with his constituents' needs. Helms has sent out a fund-raising letter alleging Gantt's campaign is backed by ``the powerful homosexual political lobby ... the so-called arts community, the ACLU (American Civil Liberties Union) and the union bosses.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Objects to New Cuts in C-17 Program
DOC.TEXT: The Air Force says a further proposed cut in purchase of C-17 transport planes will cause ``irretrievable damage'' to a program that congressional investigators charge is over budget and behind schedule. The General Accounting Office, citing delays and manufacturing problems with the C-17 program, urged lawmakers on Tuesday to go beyond the cuts Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed in April. Cheney called for slashing the total program from 210 to 120 planes and reducing the budget request for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 from six planes to two. Based on that cut, the Air Force said Tuesday the cost of the wide-body C-17 plane, which will replace the current C-141 aircraft, will be $249 million each. The overall program would cost slightly more than $30 billion. Officials of the GAO, an investigative arm of Congress, told a Senate Armed Services subcommittee that Congress should consider further reductions in the fiscal 1991 buy and advance purchase for six planes in fiscal 1992. ``This could provide an opportunity to further reduce concurrency in the program by having the Air Force limit production commitments until the critical elements of a realistic and achievable flight test program are completed and any identified problems resolved,'' said Nancy R. Kingsbury of the GAO. She did not say whether GAO was recommending that the Air Force purchase no C-17s or just one next year. The Air Force plant representative assigned to the manufacturer, McDonnell Douglas Corp., believes the company cannot product the aircraft to ``either budgeted cost or planned schedule,'' Ms. Kingsbury told the projection forces subcommittee. The Air Force representative concluded that the absence of an organized system at the manufacturer resulted in late designs, shortages of parts, late deliveries and unacceptable quality, the GAO said. These problems caused a delay in the first flight of the aircraft from August 1990 to at least June 1991 and an 11 percent increase in cost _ from the $37.5 billion to $41.8 billion for the original plan of 210 planes. Air Force Maj. Gen. Stephen Croker said any additional cuts in the program along the lines of zero production in fiscal 1991 would cause ``irretrievable damage to the C-17 program.'' Croker, director of strategic and airlift programs and special operations forces, said he agreed in part with the GAO's assessment but questioned the implications that delays on the first plane will continue throughout the program. ``By the ninth aircraft, the program will be as little as two months late. By the 12th aircraft, the program will be on schedule,'' said Croker, who added that the manufacturer has made significant improvements since November. But Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., the subcommittee chairman, questioned whether lawmakers can accept the Air Force's assessment that ``everything is hunky-dory'' based on recent changes by the McDonnell Douglas. Croker argued that by abandoning the current plan for two planes in fiscal 1991, the government will lose much of the project's work force. In addition, he said, parts already under construction would have to be stored with some likely to disintegrate. The GAO proposal ``does not improve employee learning. ... It does save dollars in fiscal 1991, but those costs will be greater in 1992,'' the general said.

DOC.HEAD: Cheney: Budget Cuts Mean Forcing Out 600,000 Employees
LaserPhoto WX16
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: About 600,000 military and civilian workers would be cut from the Pentagon's payroll if the armed forces are reduced by one-fourth over the next five years, says Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Even under President Bush's military spending plan _ criticized on Capitol Hill as far too high _ a smaller military is coming, Cheney told reporters Tuesday as he compared several options for military cuts. ``Even under the president's program, we're still going to have to take some steps that probably will result in forcing people out who would like to stay,'' the secretary said. ``We are not going to have as large a military in the future as we have today, and somehow you've got to shrink the force to get there.'' Cheney, attempting to stave off even more severe budget-cutting proposals from the House and Senate, argued at budget negotiations that a 25 percent cut in forces could save $8.6 billion over five years. This would result in retiring six active-duty Army divisions, 111 Navy ships and 11 Air Force tactical fighter wings. It would remove 442,000 men and women from the military's 2.1 million active duty ranks over the next five years, as well as civilian workers and members of the National Guard and reserves, he said. ``The total, if you add it up ... is almost 600,0000 military and civilian personnel,'' Cheney said. Cheney's proposal would reduce the fiscal 1991 defense budget Bush submitted in January from $303.3 billion to $302 billion. Over five years, it would cut $8.6 billion from Bush's proposal. The secretary charged that House and Senate plans could end up closing up to half the U.S. military's installations around the world and lay off more than 1 million of the Pentagon's 3.1 million civilian and military work force. The House's proposal to cut Pentagon spending to $295.4 billion would require a 35 percent cut in troop levels, while the Senate Budget Committee plan for a $293.9 billion level would force a 50 percent slash in force strength, the defense chief said. Such cuts would ``do serious damage'' to the nation's military, Cheney contended, arguing that the result would be ``unbalanced forces ... units that are undermanned in some key areas.'' Cheney's figures dissatisfied many congressional Democrats who attended the budget talks. They contended that the numbers amount to a savings of only about 10 percent. Rep. Les Aspin, chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, argued that Cheney could have made different decisions in the structure of the military that could have yielded savings of 18 percent to 27 percent. ``They have made a set of policy choices to get there that I think are awfully cautious,'' Aspin, D-Wis., told reporters. ``It's quite clear from this exercise that we are nowhere near an agreement on the budget.'' Cheney, for his part, insisted his numbers were meant as an illustration, not an offer to budget negotiators. But he acknowledged they represent the clearest outline yet made public of how the Pentagon can shape its forces in response to the reduced Soviet threat and the lessened chance of a land war in Europe amid the collapse of the Warsaw Pact. The defense budget is seen as a major source of savings as the negotiators search for $45 billion to $60 billion in new taxes or spending cuts before fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1.

DOC.HEAD: Study: Vietnam Military Dogs Had Almost Twice as Many Testicular Tumors
DOC.TEXT: Dogs exposed in Vietnam to the same chemical sprays as U.S. soldiers developed almost twice as many tumors of the testicles as military dogs that served only in the United States, federal investigators report. In a study published today in the Journal of the National Cancer Institute, researchers said the increased number of testicular cancers among canine veterans of Vietnam may predict the development of such tumors among American servicemen who served in the same country. ``The dog is a sentinel model for man,'' said Howard M. Hayes, a National Cancer Institute researcher and coauthor of the report. ``He could be used to foretell the risks for exposure to the same chemical insults'' encountered by soldiers in Vietnam. Hayes and his coauthors examined autopsy records for dogs that served with American troops in Vietnam from 1968 to 1973. They also examined autopsy records of dogs that served in Vietnam and later died elsewhere. These records then were compared with those of military dogs that served only in the United States, Japan, Korea and Thailand. Hayes said the dogs serving in Vietnam had 80 percent more testis tumors of all kinds than did dogs that served only in the United States. The Vietnam dogs also had 90 percent more seminomas, a malignant tumor of the testis. Dogs serving in Korea, Japan and Thailand had fewer of both types of tumors than did the U.S. dogs. To further verify the risks, Hayes said his group examined records of 96 male dogs that served in Vietnam and died elsewhere between 1974 and 1978. These records were compared with those of dogs that served only in the United States and died during the same period. ``We observed the 96 Vietnam veteran military working dogs to have significant excess risk for seminoma, which supported the findings in the earlier period,'' the report said. Additionally, the study showed that dogs that served in Vietnam had 70 percent to 100 percent more testicular dysfunction than did dogs that served only in the United States. Hayes said about 99 percent of the military dogs in the study were German shepherds, a breed that has a predisposition to testicular tumors. As a result, he said, the dogs ``may be a particularly sensitive sentinel for exposures leading to increase seminoma risk in man.'' Dogs in Vietnam, Hayes said, served side-by-side with infantry troops and were exposed to the same chemical sprays, such as the herbicide Agent Orange, as were the soldiers. Unlike most of the humans, however, the dogs' tours in Vietnam were not limited to one year. Additionally, Hayes said the dogs in Vietnam were treated several times with tetracycline, an antibiotic used to control a tick-borne parasitic disease. The tetracycline, the study said, ``may have contributed to the increased risk of testicular problems.'' Veterans' groups have contended for years that soldiers who served in Vietnam have experienced more cancers and other ailments as a result of their exposure to chemical sprays while in Vietnam. Agent Orange, an herbicide widely used to defoliate the jungle, has come under particular attack by veterans' groups as the cause of cancers and skin ailments. The Department of Veterans' Affairs announced earlier this year that it would provide compensation to Vietnam veterans who have non-Hodgkin's lymphoma or soft-tissue sarcoma, two cancers that have been associated with chemicals in Agent Orange. Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., a special adviser to Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski, said in an interview that there now is no compensation provided to Vietnam veterans who develop testicular cancers. He said the new study may cause tumors of the testis to be considered as possibly service-related illnesses for Vietnam veterans. ``I've already recommended that testicular cancer be included and this (the Hayes study) is powerful evidence in support of it,'' he said. Zumwalt had a son who served in Vietnam and later died of cancer, which Zumwalt attributed to Agent Orange.

DOC.HEAD: Congressman Demands Explanation on Charge Against Neil Bush
With PM-S&L Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A senior House Banking Committee member is demanding that federal regulators spell out their charges against President Bush's son, Neil, in the $1 billion collapse of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. Neil Bush is a former director of the Denver thrift, which failed in 1988. The Office of Thrift Supervision noted that it said in January it was bringing administrative charges against Bush, and had since done so. But it would not give details. ``No law or regulation prevents the agency from revealing the charges,'' Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., said Tuesday during the latest hearing by the House Banking Committee on the failure of Silverado. ``Can any agency of the United States fairly and impartially investigate the son of the president of the United States?'' Annunzio asked. ``It should make those charges public.'' An unsigned, undated internal OTS document released by the committee alleged that Bush ``willfully breached'' his duty as a director and recommended that he be barred from the industry. But William Fulwider, a spokesman for the regulators, said the document cited by Annunzio was a draft. After it was written, he said, the agency found there was not sufficient evidence to support a prohibition and a less serious cease and desist order was proposed. Bush, 34, denied any wrongdoing in voluntary testimony before the committee on May 23. The panel had been probing whether his business interests in Colorado conflicted with his role as a director of Silverado. He called allegations of conflict of interest ``frivolous.'' Fulwider said a cease and desist order against Bush had been proposed by OTS _ which said in January it would do so _ but the proposal of the order was not made public. Such an order would bar Bush from engaging in future actions that would involve a conflict of interest, Fulwider said. ``There is no question that we have brought charges,'' he said. He declined to say where the proposed order stands in the agency's procedure. He did not say why his agency had not detailed its accusations against Bush. Five other former officers and directors of Silverado, including former chairman Michael R. Wise, have consented to orders banning them from the financial institutions industry. The OTS document alleges that Bush failed to disclose his business relationships to the other directors, including the fact that one of his business partners, developer Kenneth Good, had committed to invest more than $3 million in Bush's oil exploration company. At the same time, it said, the directors were being told that Good probably would not be able to fully repay his loans from Silverado. Bush has said he abstained on all directors' votes involving Good.

DOC.HEAD: Massive Security Operation Mounted for Mandela Visit
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Subs 3rd graf, ``Mandela, 71 xxx to CORRECT age from 72 to 71
DOC.TEXT: Even as a free man, Nelson Mandela can't escape the constraints of security. The State Department's Office of Diplomatic Security is mounting its largest-ever protective operation for the African National Congress leader who spent 27 years in South Africa behind bars. Mandela, 71, arriving in New York today, spent part of his time in jail on Robbin Island, a notorious prison off the coast of Cape Town. Treacherous seas make escape virtually impossible. Although Mandela is not an official government visitor, taxpayers will be picking up the tab for the blanket of security, said Meg Ravnholt, a department spokeswoman. She did not give a cost estimate. The law gives Secretary of States James A. Baker III the right to approve security for visiting dignitaries who are private citizens, such as Mandela, Solidarity leader Lech Walesa and the Queen of England. ``Just the sheer number of people who are turning out for these events would qualify him for protection,'' Ravnholt said. For about a month, agents _ trained in methods similar to the Secret Service _ have fanned out across the country to arrange security for Mandela. He will visit eight cities in 11 days. The agents will handle everything ``from the moment he lands until the moment he leaves,'' Ravnholt said. One of the biggest security challenges comes today when thousands turn out for a ticker-tape parade through lower Manhattan. A ``Mandela mobile'' _ a flatbed truck with a bulletproof glass-enclosed area large enough for Mandela, his wife, Winnie, and four aides _ was specially designed for the parade through lower Manhattan. Undercover agents were being sent into the crowd, and rooftops along the way were being guarded by uniformed Emergency Service Unit sharpshooters, said police sources who spoke on condition of anonymity. Mandela will also speak at public rallies in Harlem and Yonkers during his four-day stay in New York, where authorities have mounted ``Operation Topaz'' with 12,000 officers. The cost is expected to be in the $2 million range. ``I don't think there is one worst security problem,'' said police spokesman Capt. Robert Cividanes. ``You look at the areas that he's going to be in; is there one worst? That's difficult to say.'' During his public appearances, police and federal agents will form a 75-foot security zone around the silver-haired statesman to keep him at a safe distance. After arriving at John F. Kennedy Airport, Mandela was being escorted by 40-car motorcade from the Queens airport to Brooklyn to meet with students at Boys and Girls High School. Officials said streets and roads would be closed hours before Mandela's 40-car motorcade travels on them, and the department's six helicopters would be used to sweep over the route. In Washington, Mandela's second stop, police officials refused to give details about the security operation. But a number of jurisdictions will be involved, including U.S. Park Police and police officers who guard the Capitol building where Mandela will address Congress. Christine Dolan, a spokeswoman for the national Mandela welcoming committee, said the group is leaving all security to the State Department. She said she did not know whether Mandela's entourage would include personal bodyguards.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Heroine Joins Strikers in Renewing Call for Greyhound Boycott
DOC.TEXT: Rosa Parks, whose refusal to move to the back of a bus started a 381-day bus boycott 35 years ago in Montgomery, Ala., joined striking Greyhound drivers in their call for a boycott of the nation's only coast-to-coast bus line. Mrs. Parks and Jesse Jackson led some 300 protesters Tuesday on a three-block march from a Greyhound bus terminal to the capital's historic Union Station near Capitol Hill. Union drivers from Detroit, Boston, Philadelphia and other cities chanted ``Drop Dead Fred'', carried banners and signs condemning the company's refusal to resume contract negotiations and accused Greyhound chairman Fred Currey of trying to bust their union in the 3{-month strike. Mrs. Parks, 77, clasped Jackson's arm during the march before speaking briefly to protesters and calling for the boycott. Jackson said the bus drivers' battle was similar to the civil rights struggle of the 1960s and reminded him of Martin Luther King Jr.'s message of years ago. ``Better that we walk in dignity than we ride in shame ... Just as we got social justice together, we must get economic justice together,'' Jackson told the cheering union drivers gathered at the station. Jackson, carrying a sign that read ``Support Greyhound Drivers, Street Heat Now,'' occasionally flashed a thumps up sign to construction workers and pedestrians watching the march.
DOC.HEAD: Harassment Not Grounds for Retaliation, Says State Department
DOC.TEXT: The FBI has documented at least 25 cases of harassment and intimidation of Chinese students by their own government in the United States, but the State Department does not believe that is grounds for sanctions against Beijing, a department official says. Rep. Stephen Solarz, D-N.Y., reacting to information given in a closed-door FBI briefing, called the administration's position ``shocking'' and bluntly told the official: ``I'm not sure we're living in the same universe.'' Solarz said the briefing clearly showed a consistent pattern of intimidation that requires sanctions under a law he wrote nine years ago. The Bush administration has announced its intention to renew most-favored-nation trading status for China, almost exactly a year after Beijing's bloody crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in and around Tiananmen Square. Kent Wiedemann, director of the State Department's office of Chinese affairs, said the contacts with students involved relatively few of the Chinese Embassy and consular officials in the United States and represented ``a very sporadic pattern.'' ``They were mostly in 1989, in the summer and fall, and have dwindled to basically nothing by the beginning of this year,'' Wiedemann told a joint hearing of Solarz's Asia subcommittee and the human rights subcommittee of the House Foreign Affairs Committee. The contacts usually involved threats or implied threats of consequences for students when they return to China, or to their families, if they continued pro-democracy activities, he said. But they were ``sufficiently few in number and sufficiently indirect as to not be a consistent pattern'' as the law defines it, he said.
DOC.HEAD: EPA Chief Will Recommend Veto If Jobs Aid Provision Stands
DOC.TEXT: William K. Reilly, administrator of the Environmental Protection Agency, says he will recommend that President Bush veto clean air legislation if the final bill contains a jobs protection amendment when it reaches the White House. ``I consider it bad environmental policy, bad social policy and bad economic policy,'' Reilly said Tuesday in discussing a provision that would assist workers who lose their jobs because of the tougher air pollution requirements. Both the Senate and House are preparing for a conference committee to work out differences in largely similar bills to strengthen federal clean air laws for the first time in 13 years. One of the differences involves an amendment in the House bill that would allow for $250 million to be spent in added unemployment compensation and retraining for workers if forced out of their jobs by the new legislation. The administration says this could force industry spending well above the $21 billion or so annually called for by the Senate version, partly because it would be extremely difficult to tell whether a job had been lost because of the provisions of the legislation. Reilly said his objections to this jobs proposal, sponsored by Rep. Bob Wise, D-W.Va., were strong enough that he would recommend that the president veto the entire bill if that section is not removed by the conference committee. The jobs issues is certain to be one of the main battles in the conference committee debate. An aid package in the Senate sponsored by Sen. Robert Byrd, D-W.Va., lost by only one vote. Byrd's amendment would have helped only coal miners while the less costly Wise amendment expands the assistance to workers in all industries.

DOC.HEAD: Office Shootings Stir Gun Debate
DOC.TEXT: The massacre of eight people by a man with a rifle could undercut the powerful gun lobby at a time when Florida voters are considering a constitutional amendment imposing a three-day wait on handgun purchases. ``Anytime you have a tragedy, those people with hidden agendas see any and every emotional opportunity to try to justify their erroneous position and try to deprive the people of their rights,'' said Marian Hammer, spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association's Florida branch. The debate over the amendment on November's ballot intensified after James Edward Pough, 42, a day laborer, killed eight people Monday with a semiautomatic rifle before taking his own life with a revolver at an auto loan agency. Police said Pough also killed two people on the street Sunday with the rifle. ``How many messages do we send to the Congress? How many to the state Legislature?'' Jacksonville Mayor Tommy Hazouri said Tuesday. ``If it means seeking changes ... we're going to do that.'' State Rep. Ron Silver, chairman of the House Criminal Justice Committee, said the fact the waiting period is being settled by a referendum rather than a vote in the Legislature shows many lawmakers still fear the NRA's clout. But he added that polls indicate heavy support for the amendment, and he said passage could give legislators confidence to pass other gun-control laws. ``I think Florida is waking up,'' Silver said. California passed an assault weapons bill in 1989 in the aftermath of the Stockton, Calif., schoolyard spree by a drifter with an AK-47 assault rifle who killed five children and wounded 30 other people. President Bush approved an import ban on assault weapons and a Senate bill would extend the ban to domestic manufacture of four weapons identified as used mainly in drug violence. Florida has tackled gun legislation several times in recent years. A 1987 law removed gun registration from county control in favor of statewide registration rules. A law taking effect Oct. 1 requires gun sellers to check all applicants through a crime computer in Tallahassee. But lawmakers on a study commission on assault weapons failed to agree on which weapons should be banned. U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson, a Democrat running for governor, has called banning assault weapons a priority. ``It is harder to rent a car in Florida than it is to buy an AK-47,'' he said during a debate Monday before he knew of the shooting spree. A Nelson aide needed less than 10 minutes to walk into a Miami gun shop and come out with an AK-47 and ammunition last month. Gov. Bob Martinez, a Republican seeking re-election, said Tuesday the law requiring a background check by gun dealers is a responsible step, ``but at the same time we must maintain the freedom to own guns which have useful sporting purposes.'' Pough's .30-caliber semiautomatic rifle would be banned under New Jersey's month-old law on assault weapons, considered the nation's toughest, because its clip held more than 15 rounds. Nelson wants a seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases. Democratic front-runner Lawton Chiles also supports a waiting period. Now, gun purchasers are required to have some identification, such as a driver's license, and fill out a questionnaire on arrests, mental illness and drug use. But there is no way for merchants to confirm the information other than by investigating on their own. It is illegal in Florida for a convicted felon to own a handgun. But technically, Pough wasn't a convicted felon. In 1971, he was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a man; he pleaded guilty to aggravated assault and was sentenced to five years' probation, court records show. After probation, his record was wiped clean. That made it legal for Pough to own a gun under Florida law. ``It's a loophole we need to plug up,'' Jacksonville Sheriff Jim McMillan said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Up In Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,087.76, up 47.38 points, or 0.15 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Against Purported Heirs in Spindletop Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge ruled that thousands of purported heirs to the Spindletop oilfield fortune have no claim to the land or the estimated $200 billion generated since the first gusher blew there in 1901. U.S. District Judge Howell Cobb's ruling Tuesday was the latest in a series of lawsuits brought by would-be heirs against oil companies that have developed the tract that brought about the Texas oil boom at the turn of the century. Cobb ruled in favor of Amoco Production Inc., Mobil Oil Corp., Phillips Petroleum Co., Texaco Inc. and Chevron Inc. The lawsuit was filed by four relatives who claimed kinship to Pelham Humphries and asked for $200 billion. The relatives had sought to have their case declared a class-action suit on behalf of numerous other heirs. Brown Peregoy, representing 3,000 members of the Humphries Heirs Trust Association, contended Pelham Humphries received a grant to the Spindletop property from the Mexican government in 1835 and left no will. The judge ruled, however, that Humphries conveyed the grant to William Inglish, whose heirs conveyed it to William McFaddin in 1883. ``This court desperately desires that the ghost of Pelham Humphries will no longer haunt the halls of the United States court system,'' Cobb wrote. ``The Pelham Humphries litigation is over. ... Requiescat in pace (rest in peace).'' Spindletop, still an active oilfield, caused a boom that moved the oil industry from the North to the Southwest. Its first six wells produced more oil in their first year than had been produced in the United States up to that time. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals held in favor of the oil companies in the 1950s and 1960s. The judge will decide later whether to order the plaintiffs to pay legal fees as a penalty for bringing claims that the oil claims said had been decided already.

DOC.HEAD: Turkish Girl Who Received New Eyes Going Home
DOC.TEXT: A 9-year-old Turkish girl is going home four years and seven operations after coming to the United States for treatment of a birth defect that left her eyes covered with skin. Dilek Erdogan is still blind, but acrylic implants have made her look more like other children and given her the confidence she lacked when her face had just a nose and a mouth. ``When she coming here, you can no touch her,'' said Matt Deletioglu, the Turkish native and former Chicago restaurateur who has made the girl's treatment a personal crusade. ``She fill with fear. She shaking. ... You touch her and she scream and scream. ``Now,'' he said, ``she look like normal human being, like other child. She now believing in herself. She wants to walk with you.'' Dilek, who lives in an apartment a half block from Deletioglu's house, will rejoin her father in Istanbul with her mother, Guldane, and her 7-year-old brother, Ozan, by the end of June, Deletioglu said. ``I am very happy,'' Dilek said. ``I am going home. Miss father, I miss grandfather, grandmother and aunt. I miss my home.'' Dilek was born with skin covering her eyes, a condition called cryptophthalmos, or hidden eye. Deletioglu, a native of Antioch, Turkey, decided to help Dilek after he saw her picture in a newspaper from his homeland. Two doctors at the University of Illinois Hospital, Allen Putterman and Joel Sugar, agreed to donate their services, leaving only hospital bills to be paid by Deletioglu or through donations. Putterman surgically built eye sockets and an eyelid for the girl two years ago, but doctors were unable to restore her sight. The left eye was badly scarred and was replaced with an artificial one. An operation to implant a cornea in her right eye failed because she had no iris or pupil. Putterman said Tuesday that doctors had considered another procedure that would have allowed her to see shapes and forms. Called kerotoprosthesis, it would involve implanting something like a little telescope into the eye. But he said the implant could have become infected, and that could threaten the whole eye. ``Hopefully, in the future, somebody will develop something that will allow her to see without the risk of the eye being infected and completely lost,'' he said. The surgeon also said it was promising that Dilek's eye sockets are still intact. ``That, I think, allowed her to get into the social world ... go to school ... be accepted by her peers,'' he said. ``That was a very big step for her.'' Dilek is more like a normal, happy child than before the operations, said Deletioglu. She attends special education classes in a city school. She laughs and plays. Deletioglu said he was unsure of the cost of Dilek's treatments, but he said more than $20,000 came from Armitage Baptist Church. On Sunday, Dilek visited the church to thank God and the 300 members present for their love and moral support. ``Everyone was crying over there,'' said Deletioglu. Dilek's family hopes to return in 10 years if doctors have developed a procedure to implant real eyes by then. Meanwhile, Deletioglu said, he hopes to stay in touch with the girl who is now like a daughter to him. ``At least now she has confidence with herself,'' he said. `At least she have good start now.''

DOC.HEAD: Government Opens Flood-Relief Centers
With PM-Flash Floods-History
DOC.TEXT: Homeowners, a barkeep and bikers who lost vintage Harley-Davidsons were among flood victims who reported to a disaster relief center after a flash flood that killed at least 21 people. Thirteen people were still listed as missing. The Army Corps of Engineers today planned to begin removing about 15 acres of debris backed up on the Ohio River at the Hannibal Dam and Locks, about 25 miles south of here. Workers for various agencies handed out about 100 aid applications Tuesday. Bruce Connor, 33, said he and two other members of the Sentinels Motorcycle Club came to apply for money to replace Harley-Davidsons. The club is in the backwoods along Pipe Creek, which was deluged by rain Thursday. ``Some of those bikes were collectors' items, probably worth a lot of money. We had Harleys from the 1920s and 30s, bikes my father and his father had, and tools they used to work on them,'' Connor said. Gene Neiditch of the Federal Emergency Management Agency said the Sentinels may qualify for relief if the motorcycles were for transportation and work, but not if they were luxuries. Ken Gibbons, 41, who crawled into his attic to escape a 25-foot wall of water, said that his losses totaled $300,000 but that he could recover only about $10,400 in government grants. ``They send money freely overseas to other countries, but don't want to do anything to help people here,'' Gibbons said. He vowed never to work again so he wouldn't have to pay income taxes. His greatest loss, he said was his bar, the 3 K's Night Club. ``I've had that 15 years,'' he said, ``and everybody in this town came down there for entertainment.'' Neiditch said the first relief checks could be received in two weeks. The agency estimated 700 homes were damaged or destroyed.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Challenger Facing Spotlight In New York
DOC.TEXT: Republican Pierre Rinfret, the political neophyte challenging the re-election bid of Gov. Mario Cuomo, is starting out on the defensive amid reports he exaggerated his academic and political credentials. Rinfret, who heads an international economic consulting firm, has presented himself as holding a doctorate and having turned down offers to join President Nixon's Cabinet. But The New York Times on Tuesday reported that Rinfret never earned a doctorate, and that some former Nixon administration officials were unaware of any offers of Cabinet posts. Rinfret, 66, was nominated at the state GOP convention last month. The millionaire economist was chosen after an 11-month effort by the GOP to persuade better-known Republicans to run against the popular two-term Democrat. Even Rinfret's political affiliation has been a source of controversy. It was not until last week that he registered as a Republican. While Rinfret had earlier told reporters and GOP leaders that he was a Republican and had voted in Republican primaries, election board records dating to 1976 showed Rinfret wasn't enrolled in any party. He said he had made a mistake. On Tuesday, the Times reported Rinfret never earned a doctorate even though he has used the title ``Dr. Rinfret'' on resumes, legal documents and biographies. A biography Rinfret distributed at the GOP convention last month cited him 13 times as ``Dr. Rinfret.'' However, a biography distributed last week by Rinfret had replaced all ``Dr. Rinfret'' references with ``Mr. Rinfret.'' Rinfret said he had been told by a French diplomatic official that the diploma he received from the University of Dijon in France in 1946 could be called a doctorate. University officials said it was the equivalent of an American master's degree. Rinfret said that even if the Dijon diploma isn't a doctorate, he can claim the title because he received an honorary doctor of laws degree from Pepperdine University in 1973. In response to the newspaper report that several top Nixon aides were unaware Rinfret had been seriously considered for any Cabinet positions, the candidate Tuesday produced a statement from Nixon in his defense. ``As president I had hoped that he would join my administration as a member of the Council of Economic Advisers or later as a member of my Cabinet,'' said the statement. The candidate canceled his only scheduled public appearance Tuesday, a fund-raising dinner in Albany to benefit state Assembly Republicans. Aides to Cuomo wouldn't comment on the flap. Other New York gubernatorial candidates did. ``It matters. It matters a great deal,'' said Conservative Party candidate Herbert London. ``It's a question of character and a question of what this person is actually bringing to the table in the way of credentials.'' ``He has what we euphemistically called in the Marine Corps `hoof-in-mouth disease,''' said Louis Wein, the Right-to-Life Party candidate. Wein is circulating petitions in an attempt to challenge Rinfret in a Sept. 11 primary for the GOP nomination. Assemblyman John Faso, an Republican named Rinfret's campaign manager Monday, said he wasn't certain if the newspaper report would have any lasting impact. ``It doesn't help it, but it's important to get these things out of the way in June rather than in September,'' Faso said.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Rebels Insist on Military Cuts to Bring Peace
DOC.TEXT: Opening a new round of peace talks, Salvadoran rebel leaders are sticking to their longstanding demands that the rightist government slash its military and rid the ranks of alleged death squad leaders. Speaking to reporters before Tuesday's opening session, guerrilla commander Shafik Handal called the issue of a reduced Salvadoran military ``the Gordian knot that needs cutting to bring peace to our country.'' Col. Mauricio Vargas, spokesman for the government of President Alfredo Cristiani, declined comment on Handal's statement. The U.N.-mediated discussions, expected to last eight days, are aimed at moving closer to a goal negotiators proposed in Caracas, Venezuela last month _ a September cease-fire in El Salvador's 10-year-old civil war. Rights groups estimate 73,000 people have been killed since the war began in October 1979, most of them suspected leftists slain by death squads. Since then, the United States has been supporting a succession of governments with military and economic aid now averaging more than $1 million a day. El Salvador has about 55,000 military personnel, dominated by right-wing officers. Alvaro de Soto, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar's personal representative, who is mediating the talks between the leftist Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and the government in this mountain resort outside Mexico City, said the discussion has been cordial and respectful. David Escobar, legal adviser for the government delegation, said the first session ``is on a good track, where both side are presenting their viewpoints with optimism.'' Rebel Commander Roberto Canas described them as ``just normal.'' Canas said the guerrilla front also demanded punishment for those responsible for a series of political slayings by rightist death squads during the country's decade-old civil war. Escobar said six issues were on the list _ armed forces, human rights, economic problems and reforms in judicial, electoral systems and in the constititution. ``I don't think that we're going to arrive at spectacular agreements like a cease-fire or incorporation of the guerrillas into civilian life'' at the Mexico meeting, Escobar said. ``Anyway we have until Sept. 15 to live up to the Caracas accords.'' During five days of talks last month in Venezuela, the two sides agreed on an agenda and a tentative calendar to negotiate an end to the war, committing themselves to try for a cease-fire by mid-September. Talks with the Cristiani government in June and September 1989 broke off when the guerrillas mounted attacks on San Salvador in November in which more than 2,000 people were killed. Three rounds of peace talks under the Christian Democratic administration of the late President Jose Napoleon Duarte in 1984 and 1987 ended in deadlock.

DOC.HEAD: Ravaged Area Began as Rail Stop
With PM-Flash Floods
DOC.TEXT: Folklore holds that this village along the Ohio River got its name from railroad conductors who suggested that passengers get off on the shady side of the tracks. A pamphlet found in a library says James Leasure planted evergreens along the road to his farm and hung a sign reading ``Shady Side'' at his gate opposite the railroad platform in the 1870s. ``Eventually it became known as the Shadyside stop,'' said Belmont County coroner's investigator Chuck Vogt. ``It's just a nice, middle-class America town.'' But it's also a town that has seen hard times, even before last week's flash flooding killed at least 21 people and left 13 missing. The southeastern Ohio county lies in the coal and steel country of the Appalachian foothills. Its heavily wooded hills are dotted with bedroom and retirement communities for the mills and mines of Wheeling, W.Va., and western Pennsylvania. ``Because of the closing of many, many coal mines and the reduction and closing of some steel mills, the population has been declining,'' said Martins Ferry Library Director John W.P. Storck. ``The average age in Belmont County is increasing, too.'' Figures from the 1980 census show Belmont County's population grew from 80,917 in 1970 to 82,569 in 1980, but the figures are still below the 1940 peak of 95,614. Figures from the 1990 census are not yet available, but are expected to reflect a further decline, Storck said. Shadyside, classified as a city until the 1980 census, had to be reincorporated as a village because its population count of 4,300 was 700 below the Ohio cutoff for a city. Figures in a 1989 report compiled by Washington-based Woods & Poole Economics Inc. show the average age of the county's residents is about 32.7 years, compared with the statewide average of 29.9. The report predicts the average will increase to 37.4 in 1995 and 41.1 by 2010. But there has been little change in the character of Shadyside residents, said Sandy Wallace, who grew up in Bellaire and reports on the area for the Martins Ferry Times-Leader. Everybody knows everybody else, ``and that's why this flood has become such a devastating emotional issue,'' she said. ``There's this quality of giving and openness, a very close-knit and neighborly situation,'' she said. ``And that's something that I've noticed has really come to the fore in the past few days.'' Donations of food, clothing, technical assistance and labor for the backbreaking process of debris removal came from all over southeastern Ohio, western Pennsylvania and northern West Virginia. So much clothing was donated that authorities ran out of storage space.

DOC.HEAD: Truck-Train Collision Kills Three
DOC.TEXT: A tanker truck loaded with alcohol ran the lights at a rail crossing one block from its destination and was rammed by a freight train, exploding in a fireball that killed three crewmen, authorities said. ``I would say they suffocated from the fire but I can't prove that,'' said fire Capt. Lester Blaylock. The truck driver, John Gilboy, 25, of Englishtown, N.J., was cited for failing to stop at a railroad crossing and illegal possession of alcohol for an unopened can of beer found in the truck cab Tuesday, authorities said. Gilbey, who suffered minor injuries, was freed on $280 bail. Paul DeFalco, president of the tanker truck's owner, Linden Bulk Transport of Linden, N.J., said Gilboy agreed to a blood-alcohol test. The tanker was carrying ethylhexanol, used for making a solvent, to the Haywood Co. in this town of 10,000 residents 40 miles from Memphis. The collision with the 89-car CSX Corp. train occurred in an industrial section. Authorities said the train was within the 30 mph speed limit, and the warning lights apparently were working. ``Apparently he didn't see the signal or something,'' said Ed Ellington of the Haywood County Emergency Management Agency. Killed were John Ed Sharp Jr., 48, of Jackson; Willie Thomas Carter, 57, of Eva, and Chesley Serl Winters, 44, of Paris. Eleven firefighters overcome by heat and fumes were treated at a hospital and released.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Inventory of Stolen German Art Treasure
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ordered an inventory of medieval artwork believed stolen by a U.S. soldier from a German mineshaft during World War II and stashed in a small-town bank vault in Texas. U.S. District Judge Sidney A. Fitzwater ordered Tuesday that the time and place of the inspection be kept secret to protect the inspectors and the objects, which have been valued in the millions by German art experts. The Lutheran cathedral in Quedlinburg, East Germany, is suing to recover the artwork from the First National Bank in Whitewright and the family of Joe T. Meador. Meador, a former Army lieutenant, is believed to have stolen the objects and stashed them in his hometown of Whitewright, about 60 miles north of Dallas. The treasure disappeared in 1945 from a mine shaft in Quedlinburg, a castle town occupied by U.S. troops at the end of World War II. Meador died of cancer in 1980, and his family put the objects in the bank for safekeeping, said branch President John Farley. Farley said he never knew the art had been stolen and had been trying to mediate the dispute over its ownership. ``We wanted to do what was right,'' he said. Government officials have said it is unclear whether charges can be brought in the case because of statutes of limitations on thefts of art. The judge on Tuesday dictated the circumstances of the inventory down to the type of flash to be used in photographing the items, the placement of the cameras and a requirement that all inspectors wear cotton gloves. The lawsuit alleges at least 14 objects were taken by Meador, including a silver, ivory and gold reliquary from the 9th or 10th century, a 10th century Byzantine rock-crystal flask and an ivory comb inlaid with precious stones. Also listed as stolen are two manuscripts, one from about 1300 and the other from 1515, bound in precious metals and encrusted with gems. Meador's brother and sister, Jack Meador of Whitewright and Jane Meador Cook of Mesquite, have refused to comment. Farley said the bank will ask to be dropped from the lawsuit because First National never claimed to own the relics.

DOC.HEAD: Antiquities Owned by Bankrupt Ex-Billionaires Sold Off
DOC.TEXT: A 2,500-year-old Greek vase and two ancient silver coins brought record prices at a court-ordered auction of antiquities owned by the one-time billionaire Hunt brothers. The 18-inch-tall vase from about 510 B.C. sold for $1.76 million Tuesday at Sotheby's. The old record for an ancient vase sold at auction was $493,000. The gleaming black vase depicts the death of Kyknos in battle with Herakles, or Hercules. It was reconstructed from a vase fragment signed by Euphronius, one of the most important Greek artists of the period, said Sotheby's David Redden, an expert in the field. Nelson Bunker Hunt and brother William Herbert Hunt, heirs to an oil fortune, lost more than $1.5 billion in an alleged attempt to corner the silver market a decade ago and sought bankruptcy reorganization. The Dallas businessmen were ordered to sell off their possessions to pay their creditors, the biggest of which is the Internal Revenue Service. R. Carter Pate, the trustee in charge of liquidating Nelson Bunker Hunt's estate, expected all the sales, which will be held through 1991, to raise between $20 million and $25 million. But Tuesday's sale of 164 vases, coins and bronze figures generated $20 million alone, Sotheby's said. The record-setting Greek coins were the Decadrachm of Agrigentum, from about 465 B.C., which sold for $572,000, and an Athenian decadrachm, circa 465 B.C., which sold for $528,000. The Athenian coin, with the goddess Athena on one side and an owl on the other, had set the previous record for a coin sold at auction in 1974 when it went for $272,000. The Agrigentum coin is one of eight known specimens of its kind, Sotheby's said. It shows an eagle and four horses being driven by sun god Helios on one side and two eagles perched over a dead hare on the other. A coin struck by Brutus to commemorate the assassination of Julius Caesar in 44 B.C. sold for $99,000. One side notes the day of the murder, the Ides of March, and the method, daggers. The other side bears a picture of Brutus. Dealers from Europe, Japan and the United States were among those bidding. Many items sold for two and three times their presale estimates. On July 21, 600 items owned by Bunker Hunt _ including bronze sculptures of bulls, Indians and horses and porcelain birds and waterfowl _ will be auctioned in Texas. An auction of sports paintings formerly owned by Bunker Hunt also is planned.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``Anytime you have a tragedy, those people with hidden agendas see any and every emotional opportunity to try to justify their erroneous position and try to deprive the people of their rights.'' _ Marian Hammer, spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association's Florida branch, on sentiment toward gun control since the massacre of eight people Monday by a man with a rifle.

``Your collection becomes your wife, your children, your mistress. ... It owns you and limits your options. In a certain benign way, it enslaves you.'' _ Peter P. Cecere, on the $175,000 he spent buying folk art, antiques and an oddball assortment of gewgaws and kitsch during 22 years.

``Once again, the error is being made that French is no longer a universal language because it is too difficult. English has become a spoken language around the world, despite the fact that its spelling is unchanged and often without logic.'' _ The Societie des Agreges, an association of university professors, criticizing new spelling changes in the French language approved by the government of France.

DOC.HEAD: Government Scraps Segregation Law; Rightist Calls For Open War
DOC.TEXT: The country's white Parliament has repealed a segregation law that for decades allowed public and private facilities to exclude blacks. The repeal of the Separate Amenities Act on Tuesday was the latest in a series of reforms by de President F.W. de Klerk since he came to power last year. The changes have angered conservative whites who oppose the idea of sharing power with the black majority. The Separate Amenities Act, passed in 1953, gave government and privately owned enterprises the right to reserve facilities such as parks, hotels, swimming pools, libraries, toilets and recreation centers for whites only. Not affect by the act are neighborhoods and schools, the main institutions still segregated under the government's apartheid laws. Tony Leon, an anti-apartheid member of Parliament who voted to scrap the measure, said 37 years of segregated facilities had given the country a ``disfigured human landscape.'' Jan Hoon of the pro-apartheid Conservative Party opposed repeal of the measure, saying it was another step down the road to black rule. In major cities such as Johannesburg, Cape Town and Durban, public facilities have been integrated for years. But in hundreds of smaller towns and villages, there have been no public facilities for blacks or vastly inferior segregated ones. At Parliament in Cape Town, de Klerk's ruling National Party and the anti-apartheid Democratic Party outvoted the Conservative Party to scrap the law, 105-38. The mixed-race and Indian chambers of Parliament voted unanimously for repeal. The country's 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs. De Klerk in February promised to scrap the Separate Amenities Act. He says he wants to end racial discrimination and negotiate a new constitution that will bring blacks into the national government. However, he opposes a one-man, one-vote, majority-rule system, saying it would replace white domination with black domination. The president envisions a mechanism that would give whites veto power on major policy decisions. De Klerk has promised that next year the government will amend the Group Areas Act that segregates neighborhoods by race. He opposes full repeal of the measure and appears to favor a system that would allow some neighborhoods to be integrated and others to remain segregated. The government has given no indication it plans to integrate public schools, although many private schools are multiracial. Since taking office in September, de Klerk has legalized dozens of black opposition groups, permitted peaceful protests, freed scores of political prisoners, suspended the death penalty, and ended segregation on beaches and in hospitals. The latest change came a day before black nationalist leader Nelson Mandela was to arrive in the United States. He is in the midst of a foreign tour, urging countries to continue sanctions against South Africa's government until it ends apartheid. Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress, was freed from prison in February after serving 27 years for plotting against the South African government. De Klerk has argued that the reforms show that his country is changing and he has urged foreign countries to lift economic sanctions.

DOC.HEAD: Famed Soviet War Photographer Dead at 77
DOC.TEXT: Dmitri Baltermants, a famed Soviet photographer best known for his pictures of World War II battlefields, has died at age 77, a Soviet magazine reports. Ogonyok, the glossy weekly that has carried many of Baltermants' photos in recent years, did not specify the cause or date of death in a black-bordered box dedicated to his memory. ``Dmitri Nikolayevich's work was one of the most vivid and honest testimonies on the 20th century, '' Ogonyok said in this week's editions. ``This person loved us very much and did everything he could to help us see and understand life better.'' Among the best-known of Baltermants' work was a 1942 photo of Soviet women grieving over the frozen bodies of soldiers in the Crimea. It was titled ``Searching for Loved Ones at Kerch.'' Baltermants continued working virtually up until his death, shooting many of the country's main political events. Ogonyok did not list Baltermants' survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Some Progress Reported As Trump Loan Talks Continue
DOC.TEXT: Donald Trump's major bank leaders have tentatively agreed to give him a little breathing room, The New York Times reported today. The four lead banks agreed to lend him $65 million and defer interest and principal payments on about $850 million of the $3 billion in debt the developer ran up in building his real estate and gambling empire, the newspaper said. But the package would be secured by nearly every asset in Trump's empire, and the agreement hinges on getting other lenders, particularly Japanese banks, to agree, the newspaper said, citing unidentified people involved in the talks. Trump has about $1 billion in junk bond debt in addition to roughly $2 billion in bank debt and is said to be in a cash crunch. His lenders are worried his properties aren't generating enough cash to handle his debts. Trump missed a roughly $43 million payment due last Friday on junk bonds used to finance the purchase of Trump Castle, one of his three Atlantic City hotel-casinos, but he has a grace period for making the payment. The banks and Trump's spokesman, Dan Klores, refused to comment on the talks. The four banks are Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp. and Bankers Trust Co. The developer also has not yet made a $30 million debt payment due Manufacturers Hanover Corp. The restructuring plan is aimed at helping Trump to keep making debt payments while waiting for his assets to rise in value so some could be sold. His assets, which include hotels and office and apartment buildings in New York, have fallen in value because of the slumping real estate and casino markets. His Trump Shuttle also has posted disappointing results.

DOC.HEAD: Accord On Open Borders Between Five European Countries
DOC.TEXT: France, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Luxembourg have agreed to allow people to move freely across their shared borders in a pact hailed as a model for the entire 12-nation European Community. The five countries signed the agreement Tuesday, and it will include East Germany after the expected reunification if the two Germanys. The required ratification by the nations' parliaments may take two years. The long-awaited accord was in the works sinced 1985. Its signatories agreed to end border checks, have a common visa and asylum policy and share data on illegal aliens, suspected criminals and missing persons. ``Our agreement is a model ... for the free movement of people in the (European) Community,'' Dutch Deputy Foreign Minister Piet Dankert told reporters on behalf of the signatory nations. Yet he doubted all 12 of the European Community's nations were ready to remove their borders after Dec. 31, 1992, when the countries are to merge their economies to create a single barrier-free market. The 12 EC states have not even reached agreement on how to handle asylum-seekers. Negotiations are to open this week with Italy, which wants to join the Schengen accord, named for this village on the Luxembourg-German-French border where it was signed. Under the accord, the five signatory nations will: _Remove internal border checks for their citizens and legal residents and let legally admitted people from outside the five nations move within their boundaries for three months without a visa. _Apply a joint policy to prevent ``asylum shopping,'' whereby refugees go from one nation to the next to get residency visas. _Intensify cooperation between police and justice officials and allow police to chase suspected criminals across national boundaries. _Simplify extradition procedures and harmonize gun-control legislation. _Share information on people wanted or missing or who are considered dangerous. Such a databank will also keep tabs on such items as stolen cars and passports. The Schengen agreement primarily benefits passenger traffic. On road transport, the five EC nations pledged to keep border checks ``at the lowest possible level'' by removing some of the red tape that hampers road transporters. The agreement allows any state to revert to full-fledged border checks on national security grounds. Reflecting the sensitive nature of dropping border controls, Tuesday's signing ceremony was three years behind schedule. In past negotiations, the issue has encountered several hurdles, ranging from Luxembourg's refusal to water down its bank secrecy laws to concerns elsewhere that the computer databank may lead to an invasion of privacy.

DOC.HEAD: Evening News Folds After Little More Than a Month
DOC.TEXT: The Kansas City Evening News, a modest new tabloid in a city that recently lost its afternoon daily, is calling it quits today after 27 issues. Publisher Stephen F. Rose on Tuesday blamed the paper's demise on city officials who refused to allow teen-agers to hawk the tabloid on the street. ``We were forced to make a very painful decision, to go down in history as perhaps the only paper to close while making money,'' Rose said. ``We simply wouldn't be making any money if we had to convert to home delivery.'' Rose launched The Evening News on May 14, two months after the afternoon Kansas City Star merged with the morning Kansas City Times to form the morning-only Star. Rose put startup costs at $250,000. Analysts had predicted The Evening News would have a difficult time in a city dominated by Star, which has a daily circulation of about 300,000. The Evening News, with 10 full-time employees, averaged 32 pages a day and used mostly wire service reports on national and international news. Rose, president of a family-owned group of 18 suburban weekly papers, was the sole investor. Tuesday's announcement came only a week after Rose had said the 50-cent tabloid _ sold on the street and at newsracks and in stores _ was selling 15,000 copies a day and making several thousand dollars a week in profit. But Rose said that some suburbs had ordinances against street sales, and that Kansas City also cracked down on the street hawkers, ticketing one and forcing others off medians. City officials cited safety and traffic concerns. ``I think the safety issue was overblown, although I understand the concerns of city officials,'' Rose said. ``The fact is, hawkers are utilized all over the country, successfully and safely.'' The Evening News was the second unsuccessful attempt to start a metropolitan newspaper in the Kansas-Missouri area in recent months. Ralph Ingersoll II launched the St. Louis Sun in September but closed it in April, citing low circulation.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Team Ousted From World Cup
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to CLARIFY that it is first U.S. appearance in championship series; PICKS UP 7th graf pvs, `In 1994 ..'
DOC.TEXT: The United States, making its first appearance in the World Cup soccer championships in 40 years, was eliminated in the first round without winning a game. The U.S. team fell 2-1 to Austria on Tuesday, finishing with an 0-3 record and getting outscored 8-2 overall. ``Eventually, we'll be able to knock off a top team and surprise some people,'' said U.S. player Eric Wynalda. ``That might be 1994 or 1998. But I thought we could do it now.'' Argentina, the defending champion, is favored to win the cup, the highest prize in the world's most popular sport. The championships begin with 24 teams divided into six groups. The four teams in each group play each other, with the best two advancing to the next round. The United States, which hasn't advanced past the first round since 1930 and hadn't taken part in the championships since 1950, was expected to lose all three games, and did; it fell 5-1 to Czechoslovakia in the opener and then lost 1-0 to the Italians. In 1994, the United States will host the World Cup finals, which are held every four years, alternating between Europe and the Americas. After Tuesday's game, the U.S. team took half a lap around the field, thanking the American fans with waves and shouts. ``If anything, we found out we're closer than we thought,'' midfielder Tab Ramos said. ``We always knew we were far behind. If anything, we ended by a high note.''

DOC.HEAD: Scientists Break Down `World's Most Wanted Number'
DOC.TEXT: Researchers have broken down a 155-digit number into three numbers that cannot be further divided, raising concerns about the safety of computer programs used by banks and the military. Scientists at Bell Communications Research in Morris Township said Tuesday they came up with three factors of the number, dubbed ``the world's most wanted number,'' after using about 1,000 computers during a five-week period. One of the factors is seven digits, one 49 and the third is a 99-digit number. Arjen Lenstra, a member of Bellcore's technical staff, worked with Mark Manasse, of Digital Equipment Corp. of Palo Alto, Calif., to break the number down. Lenstra says the effort shows that tampering with certain computer messages encoded in 150-digit numbers is possible. ``The fact that we are able to figure this number (shows) that others are less safe than previously thought,'' Lenstra said. But the significance of the development for major institutions _ such as banks and the military _ that use large numbers to encode computer messages was downplayed by David Kahn, author of ``The Codebreakers.'' Kahn said that in most code systems both the sender and receiver of information have the same system and key. In the widely used cryptographic system the research applies to, the encoding and decoding keys differ. The keys are related mathematically through a number that is usually the product of two large prime numbers. The product is in the open, but the primes are kept secret and the system depends for its security on the difficulty of factoring large numbers, according to Kahn. The lab's breaking down of the 155-digit number indicates that the second system can be factored down more quickly than previously believed, Kahn said. But for practical purposes, the system is mostly used to enable one computer to recognize another. An official with the American Bankers Association, which represents about 95 percent of U.S. commercial banks, said he was not alarmed by the Bellcore breakthrough. Most banks use the Data Inscription Standard and ``I know of no one who has ever broken that code,'' said Al Belisle, chairman of the association's systems security committee.

DOC.HEAD: Activists Kick Off AIDS Conference with March on INS
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Conference formally opens at 7 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto FX3
DOC.TEXT: A thousand demonstrators drawn by today's opening of the Sixth International Conference on AIDS marched on immigration offices to protest a U.S. policy barring AIDS-infected people from entering the country. Eight arrests were made during the protest Tuesday, in which demonstrators unleashed a smoke bomb at the Immigration and Naturalization Service offices. ``The policy has people riled up and angry,'' said Jorge Cortinas, a member the group that organized the protest, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power. The marchers shouted the group's slogan, ``Act up, figIDS.'' The march, which snaked through the Financial District like a rowdy gay pride parade, preceded a five-day meeting that has attracted 10,000 researht back, fight Achers, health-care providers and officials from around the world. The police-escorted marchers danced and kissed in same-sex pairings as they proceeded along Market Street, the city's main thoroughfare. At barriers in front of the INS building, police stood, batons in hand. The officers donned riot helmets when a flag was burned. Several protesters who tried to break through police lines were tackled, handcuffed and carted off. Eight were charged with misdlthough some members are attending the conference, the group plans protests throughout the meeting to call attention to what member Arawn Eibhlyn calls the ``complete lack of government response'' to the epidemic. Also Tuesday, Elizabeth Taylor made her first public appearance since a nine-week battle with pneumonia to announce a new, international AIDS outreach effort by the American Foundation for AIDS Research. AmFAR plans to sponsor workshops to train AIDS fighters in East and Central Africa, Latin America, the Caribbean and Southeast Asia.

DOC.HEAD: Shots Fired in Protest of Teen-Ager's Death
DOC.TEXT: Scores of residents of a poor neighborhood fired shots and hurled bottles and bricks at cars, venting anger over what they said was footdragging by police in responding to a teen-ager's hit-and-run death. Twelve people were arrested and six residents suffered minor injuries during the two-hour melee Tuesday night, authorities said. Several shots were fired from the crowd of at least 100 people that gathered at the intersection where 16-year-old Chris Crawford was struck and killed by a car Monday night, said. The shots apparently were fired into the air, and no one was hit, police said. Police said they fired no shots. State and county police and prison officers were sent to help city police control the crowd. Police used dogs to help clear the streets. The disturbance stemmed from the death of Crawford and the wounding of his cousin Michael Cain, 17. Crawford's death resulted from a confrontation among some 30 youths, police said. Cain said he and Crawford were assaulted as they stood near a video arcade. Cain said his cousin was forced into the street, then hit by a car. Cain said he was shot in the side as the vehicle passed. He was treated at a hospital and released. Crawford's death brought accusations from some residents who say police respond faster to calls from more affluent neighborhoods. Vince Wodard, a neighborhood resident, said police took more than an hour to reach the scene. ``We called them on 911, and they didn't come,'' he said. Mayor Robert Behler said the first squad car arrived within 30 seconds after police dispatchers received a call for help. About two hours before the incident, Anthony T. Gooden, 20, of Gary, was arrested on murder charges in Crawford's death, Drake said.

DOC.HEAD: Rebels Attack Airstrip, Naval Base
DOC.TEXT: Tamil rebels launched counter-attacks today from their stronghold in northern Sri Lanka, fighting bitter hand-to-hand battles with government troops in the third day of a full-fledged civil war. Military officials said rebels bombarded a military airfield and a naval base near the city of Jaffna but suffered heavy casualties in a second futile attempt to seize an army garrison housed in a 200-year-old fort. Jaffna, about 190 miles north of Colombo, is the headquarters of the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelem, the main rebel militia. The military officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, had few details of casualties, but said four rebels were killed when the naval base at Karainagar, northwest of Jaffna, came under rebel attack. At least two soldiers were killed when rebels pounded the Palali airfield, 10 miles north of Jaffna, with mortars and rockets, they said. In their attempt today to seize the Jaffna military garrison, the rebels suffered ``heavy casualties,'' the officials said. The Tigers had on Tuesday launched a failed assault on the 200-year-old Dutch fort where the garrison is located. Tiger rebels used armor-plated bulldozers today to break down the doors of the fort and attempted to scale its 20-foot walls, the officials said. Bitter hand-to-hand fighting ensued. Soldiers used helicopter gunships and armored cars to repulse the attack, officials said. About 1,000 people are believed to have been killed since the Tigers repudiated a year-long cease-fire with the government on June 10 and overran police stations in the Tamil-dominated north and east. Deputy Defense Minister Ranjan Wijeratne has said at least 600 rebels have been killed in the fighting. Another 392 rebels, soldiers, policemen and civilians have also died, according to reports compiled from Tiger sources, military officers and residents. In the east, government troops bombed and burned deserted rebel bunkers around the port city of Batticaloa, military officers said. The rebels withdrew from the city on Monday, a day before government troops took it over. The troops killed a Tamil woman and her 10-year-old child while advancing into the city, said Batticaloa residents contacted by telephone. On Tuesday, the army made significant advances in the east, dislodging rebels from several cities and freeing at least two army camps that been under seige by rebel forces. As the attacks intensified, rebels were seen fleeing the cities and towns into the jungle where they were expected to prepare for what could be another bloody guerrilla war. The counter-attacks today were seen as an attempt by the rebels to kick the army out of the north and allow for the establishment of a secure base for anti-government operations. The rebels took control of all major towns in the northern and eastern provinces after Indian peackeeping troops withdrew from Sri Lanka in March. The Indian forces had failed to disarm the Tigers during a 32-month occupation. Government forces and Tiger rebels jointly patrolled the streets of the towns while leaders of both sides held a series of meetings to decide on the political future of the regions. The talks had not made much headway when the fighting resumed. Tamils, who make up 18 percent of Sri Lanka's 16 million people, claim they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the population. The Sri Lankan armed forces, police and government are also dominated by the Sinhalese. Before this month's fighting, at least 11,000 people had been killed since Tamil militants began fighting for an independent nation in 1983. In 1987, India brokered a peace accord between the two sides and sent its peacekeeping force. But the Tigers reneged on the accord and turned their guns on the Indians. In May 1989, the government negotiated a cease-fire with the rebels and requested that the Indians pull out.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Sets Trial on Mapplethorpe Exhibit
DOC.TEXT: An art gallery and its director must stand trial in September for displaying two Robert Mapplethorpe photographs that include nude or semi-nude children, a judge has ruled. Hamilton County Municipal Judge David Albanese also said Tuesday he plans to hear more evidence before deciding whether the Contemporary Arts Center and director Dennis Barrie also must face obscenity charges for displaying five sexually graphic pictures. ``I was hoping it wouldn't go to trial. But now that it is going to trial, I feel very confident ... we will win,'' Barrie said after a hearing. ``I know that what we are doing is right, and we will be vindicated in court.'' Albanese refused defense requests to dismiss the two misdemeanor charges against Barrie and the gallery. ``This court will try to make a decision of what, in Ohio, constitutes the definition of obscenity,'' the judge said. ``Obscene material is not protected by the First Amendment. This case is not about the rights of the curious to view an exhibition.'' A county grand jury indicted the gallery and Barrie on April 7, the day the seven-week exhibition ``Robert Mapplethorpe: The Perfect Moment'' opened to the public. If convicted, Barrie faces up to six months in jail and $1,000 in fines on each charge. The Arts Center faces up to $5,000 in fines on each charge. The indictment's first count, set for a jury trial Sept. 24, charges Barrie and the gallery with illegal use of a minor in material involving nudity. The charge involves a picture of a boy with his genitals exposed and a picture of a girl with her genitals exposed. On the second charge, pandering obscenity, Albanese said he wanted to conduct an evidentiary hearing Aug. 20 before deciding whether it should go to trial. The prosecution is asking Albanese to limit the case to the pictures named in the indictment. The defense contends the court must consider the 175-photo exhibit as a whole, including its portraits and pictures of flowers. ``This court is not presumptuous enough to believe that it has the background and information necessary to try to rationalize whether these pictures can be taken as a whole or independently,'' Albanese said in ordering the Aug. 20 hearing. Barrie said more than 81,000 people saw the exhibit before it closed May 26. In his ruling, Albanese said he considered the Contemporary Arts Center to be a gallery rather than a museum, and noted that a museum is permitted more latitude in displaying art. One defense request to dismiss the charges argued that Ohio obscenity law specifically exempts material exhibited for artistic or educational purposes. ``This court will not pre-try the case in pretrial motions,'' Albanese said in a written copy of his ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Castro Said To Seek Meeting with Bush in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: A leading Japanese newspaper reported today that Cuban President Fidel Castro has asked Japan to arrange for him to meet President Bush at Emperor Akihito's coronation ceremony in November. The mass-circulation Asahi Shimbun, quoting unnamed sources in the government and governing Liberal Democratic Party, said Cuba has asked Japan to arrange such a meeting with a view toward improving relations between Havana and Washington. The paper said, however, that it was not yet known whether Bush would attend the Akihito coronation. However, a Foreign Ministry official said the ministry has not received any Cuban request for Japan to help arrange a Cuba-U.S. summit. It also has received no official reply on who will represent Cuba at the coronation ceremony, said the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. An official of the Cuban Embassy in Tokyo, also requesting anonymity, said, ``We have not received any official confirmation of whether President Custro will come to Tokyo and we have had no confirmation about the reported request'' to Japan.
