Quoting a governing party official, the Asahi said the Cuban government unofficially informed Japan recently that Castro would attend the emperor's coronation, scheduled for Nov. 12. If confirmed, the request for a Castro-Bush meeting could signal a major policy change by Cuba, which has held to a hard-line position during the current East-West reconciliation. Cuba and the United States broke diplomatic relations in 1961. The U.S. invasion of Panama in December and the start of anti-Castro broadcasts in March have sharpened the chill between them. Japan, which recognized the Castro government in 1959, maintains good relations with Cuba.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Lash Kansas; Dry Weather in West
DOC.TEXT: Light rain fell along the New England coastline early today and a wave of severe thunderstorms lashed the Midwest. In the West and much of the South, dry weather with mostly clear skies prevailed. Rain was expected in the Ohio and mid-Mississippi valleys. Rain also was likely across the Great Lakes and northern Midwest regions. Temperatures were expected to soar today into the 100s in the desert Southwest, from Arizona to northern Louisiana and and southern Arkansas. Hot and muggy weather was likely across the Deep South and east Texas. Much of the Plains were expected to have a respite from the heavy rains and thunderstorms that have drenched the region recently. Storms pummeled sections of Kansas late Tuesday and early today, unleashing tornadoes, hurricane force winds and rain. The storms overturned mobile homes, leveled trees, damaged property and left more than 40,000 people without power. ``It was like a bomb went off,'' said forecaster Mark Bogner of a wave of storm cells that exploded over the state. Three Wichita television stations and at least eight radio stations lost their transmission. The storms followed a hot day Tuesday in Wichita, where a high of 105 degrees was recorded. The nation's high on Tuesday was 111 degrees at Thermal, Calif. DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES Merrill and Walz which were included in PM-Deaths for Tuesday. FIXES spelling in overlines for Cuppett and Wetherill. ADDS time element for Wetherill. A PMs seperate moved on Baltermants as a0485.
DOC.TEXT: Dmitri Baltermants, a Soviet photographer best known for his pictures of World War II battlefields, has died at age 77. Ogonyok, a glossy weekly magazine that has carried many of Baltermants' photos in recent years, did not give the cause or date of death. Among the best-known of Baltermants' work was a 1942 photo of Soviet women grieving over the frozen bodies of soldiers in the Crimea.

Sayde Tisch Busch, matriarch of the Tisch family and mother to the presidents of CBS Inc. and Loews Corp., died Monday at Victoria Hospital. She was 91. Mrs. Tisch Busch was the mother of Laurence A. Tisch, president and chief executive of CBS, and chairman and co-chief executive officer, with his brother, of Loews Corp. Preston Robert Tisch is president and co-chief executive officer of Loews Corp., and a former U.S. postmaster general. Sayde Brenner married Al Tisch, a New York City clothing manufacturer, in 1920. By the mid-1950s, the family operated 12 East Coast hotels, and as it grew, acquired stock in Loews Theaters Inc. Al Tisch died in 1960. His widow married S. Harry Busch of Knoxville, Tenn., in 1969.

Erik Wold, chief of Associated Press operations in Norway for nearly 19 years, died Tuesday of a stroke at age 63. Wold joined the AP in Oslo in 1953 after working as a free-lance correspondent for Norwegian newspapers. He became news editor of the Oslo bureau in 1964 and was named chief of bureau in 1971. He was a veteran correspondent for AP at Olympic Games and world and Nordic skiing championships.
Wold is survived by his wife, Randi; a brother; four children and seven grandchildren.

Roy McDonald, who built the Chattanooga News-Free Press from a free weekly newspaper into one of Tennessee's most distinctive papers, died Tuesday at age 88. McDonald started the Free Press in 1933 as an advertising circular delivered door-to-door at no charge. In 1936, it became a daily paper, and three years later McDonald bought the financially troubled Chattanooga News to create the current paper. Survivors include his wife, Elizabeth McDonald, and five children: Frank McDonald, the newspaper's president; Helen Exum; Betsy Anderson; Dr. Martha McDonald, and Nancy Reinke.

Raymond Huntley, an actor who specialized in roles debunking pompous officialdom, died Friday in Westminster Hospital at age 86. The cause of death was not disclosed. He made his mark as a bank manager in the 1949 movie ``Passport to Pimlico.'' His other movies included the sharply satirical farce ``I'm Alright Jack'' in 1959, ``Room at the Top'' in 1958, and ``Hostile Witness'' in 1968. One of his best-known roles was that of Sir Geoffrey Dillon, the crusty family lawyer in the TV series ``Upstairs, Downstairs.'' He also had his own series, ``Uncle Charles,'' in which he played a bachelor uncle, and ``That's Your Funeral,'' a comedy about morticians.

Palmira Henry, a fashion model for more than 20 years, died Sunday of a cerebral hemorrhage at age 44. Ms. Henry, known by her professional name Pal, was associated with the fashion house of the designer Adolfo for much of her career. Adolfo fitted all his clothes on her and used her in his advertisements.

David Earle Cuppett Jr., a former judge and prosecutor, died Monday at the University of Viriginia Hospital at age 77. Cuppett was elected prosecutor in Grant County in 1936. He was elected a circuit judge in 1960 and retired in 1976.

Helmuth Naumer, a German-born landscape painter whose subject was the American West, died Saturday of cancer at age 82. Naumer's best-known works are a series of pastels of Pueblo communities he painted in the 1930s under the sponsorship of the Works Progress Administration.

St. Clair Drake, former professor of anthropology and sociology at Stanford University, died at his home Thursday. He was 79. Drake, who had suffered two strokes this year, founded the African and Afro-American Studies program at Stanford. He was the author of ``Black Folk Here and There,'' published in 1987, and had been working on a second volume of the book for publication this year.

Edward H. Wetherill, an organist, conductor and composer of choral works, died of a heart attack Monday at age 63. Wetherill composed more than 25 sacred choral works and 40 organ compositions. He was guest organ recitalist in 1976 for a series of bicentennial concerts, and also performed at Westminster Abbey in London.

Max Chambers, a former newspaper editor and publisher, died Monday of injuries suffered in a car accident. He was 89. Chambers founded the Preston News & Farmer in 1937. He edited and published the newspaper for 43 years, retiring in 1980.

Paul Giovanni, an actor, writer, composer and Tony-nominated director, died Sunday at age 57. He died at Cabrini Medical Center. The cause of death was not disclosed. Giovanni was nominated for a Tony Award for best director in 1978 for ``The Crucifer of Blood.'' He wrote the thriller play ``Seance'' and composed music for a production of Shakespeare's ``Twelfth Night.''

Barbara Cason, a veteran actress best known as comedian Garry Shandling's mother on television's ``It's Garry Shandling's Show,'' died Monday at her home of heart failure. She was 61. Ms. Cason's stage credits included New York productions of ``Marat Sade'' and ``Oh, Coward!'' She appeared in films such as ``Cold Turkey'' and ``Heretic II.''

DOC.HEAD: A Look at Reforms in South Africa Since September 1989
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Here is a brief chronological look at the progress of reform in South Africa's apartheid system of racial separation:

Sept. 6 _ President F. W. de Klerk launches a series of reforms, allowing peaceful demonstrations and the opening of segregated beaches. Oct. 15 _ Six African National Congress leaders imprisoned for more than 25 years, including Walter Sisulu, are released. Two weeks later, the first legal ANC rally in 30 years is held.

Feb. 2 _ President de Klerk legalizes the ANC and more than 60 other opposition groups, suspends the death penalty, and eases emergency restrictions. Feb. 11 _ Nelson Mandela is released after serving 27 years in prison. May 2-4 _ The ANC and the South African government hold their first talks, and agree to work together to end violence and negotiate a new constitution. June 7 _ President de Klerk ends the national state of emergency, except in violence-torn Natal province. June 19 _ President de Klerk repeals the Separate Amenities Act. The act, passed in 1953, gave governments and privately owned enterprises the right to reserve facilities for whites such as parks, hotels, swimming pools, toilets and recreation centers.

DOC.HEAD: Labor Party Heads For Peres-Rabin Showdown
DOC.TEXT: A leadership struggle between archrivals Shimon Peres and Yitzhak Rabin has erupted in the center-left Labor Party, and a leading Laborite said today that Peres' continued leadership is increasingly in doubt. The first step in a showdown could come at a meeting Thursday of the party's 140-member Leadership Bureau. ``Tomorrow's meeting could be very important concerning the Peres-Rabin confrontation,'' party spokesman Shmuel Elgrabli said in a telephone interview. Peres, 66, and Rabin, 68, have been rivals for most of their careers. They grew up in politics as proteges of Israel's feuding founders, with Peres following David Ben-Gurion and Rabin following Golda Meir. The latest struggle flared following Peres' failure to form a government after toppling Labor's coalition with the right-wing Likud bloc in March. The split between the parties stemmed from a dispute about Middle East peace moves. Rabin, defense minister in the last government, has since mustered support from disgruntled Laborites relegated to Parliament's back benches when Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir formed a right-wing Cabinet on June 11. Opinion polls show the Israeli-born Rabin the favorite choice for prime minister. He owes much of his popularity to his iron-fisted policies against the 30-month-old Palestinian uprising in the occupied territories. Rabin, also a former army chief of staff, announced on June 12 that he sought Peres' ouster. Even Peres' staunchest allies have shifted support to Rabin. The most recent is former Education Minister Yitzhak Navon, who told Israel radio today that ``it isn't a matter of personal revenge against Shimon Peres, but of clearly viewing which of the two in the existing circumstances could win more public support.'' Other party leaders also have considered challenging Peres, according to Israeli reports. Among names that have been mentioned are Economics Minister Gad Yaacobi and former Energy Minister Moshe Shahal. The Polish-born Peres has rejected appeals to step down, claiming he is not solely responsible for Labor's failings. Labor spokesman Elgrabli said Thursday's weekly bureau session would likely set the stage for a showdown between the two leaders. Bureau members were expected to vote on proposals to hold a party membership census needed before a vote for chairman, Elgrabli said. An attempt to block the census could put off the contest. Rabin also could use Thursday's meeting to further his campaign while Peres is in the United States. In other developments today: _ Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip staged a general strike, marking a month's passing since the massacre of seven Arab laborers by a lone Israeli gunman outside Tel Aviv. _Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Israel would renew cooperation with the United States if Washington rules out PLO participation in the Middle East peace process. The remark, in a speech to a meeting of the World Zionist Organization, came amid increasingly chilly U.S.-Israeli relations that have followed Shamir's scuttling of a U.S.-backed peace plan.

DOC.HEAD: Bulgarian Officials Investigating Umbrella Murder
DOC.TEXT: Bulgarian officials have met with the Scotland Yard detective investigating the 1978 killing of a Bulgarian exile who was stabbed with a poisoned umbrella in London, Scotland Yard said today. Police Inspector Pamett Spasov and Botyo Botev, an official in the criminal department of the Bulgarian militia, met Thursday and Monday with Detective Chief Superintendent Derek Willison, a police spokesman said on condition of anonymity. He said the Bulgarians did not bring any new information, but will examine Scotland Yard's data ``and contact us if they feel there is any further information we could follow up on.'' Scotland Yard said the file remains open on the bizarre murder of Georgi Markov, a defector who worked for the BBC Radio's Bulgarian-language service. Markov was killed by poison injected through an umbrella tip as he waited for a bus on Sept. 29, 1978. Britain suspects Markov was killed by agents of Bulgaria's then hard-line Communist government, and has pressed Sofia to take responsibility. Markov's British-born widow, Annabel, claims Todor Zhivkov's government had her husband assassinated. The government that succeeded Zhivkov in November has offered to cooperate in an investigation.

DOC.HEAD: Strike In Territories A Month After Massacre
DOC.TEXT: Palestinians in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip staged a general strike today marking a month's passing since the massacre of seven Arab laborers by a lone Israeli gunman outside Tel Aviv. ``We will never forget the heroes of Black Sunday,'' said a slogan painted in green on a wall along the main street of Gaza City. It referred to the victims of the May 20 attack and was signed by the Moslem fundamentalist movement Hamas, or ``Zeal.'' The murders in the Tel Aviv suburb of Rishon Letzion set off a series of riots in which 18 Palestinians were killed, most in army gunfire. Two Israelis were slain in Arab revenge attacks. In Gaza today, only a few hundred Palestinian workers left their homes to go to jobs in Israel, according to Arab reports. The victims in the Rishon Letzion killings were all Gaza laborers waiting for day jobs in Israel. In the West Bank city of Nablus, two Palestinian youths in the Wad al-Tufah quarter stopped cars and levied $10 fines against drivers who were defying the strike call. Witnesses said the youths were handing out receipts for the fines on forms signed by the PLO-backed United National Leadership of the Uprising. Soldiers arrested the two youths, the witnesses said. In most areas of Gaza, the West Bank and Arab east Jerusalem, traffic was sparse and virtually all shops were closed in response to the strike order, according to Arab reports. The general strike was called by the uprising's underground leadership. A communique issued last week ordered the 1.7 million Palestinians in the territories to raise black flags and to turn off lights and sound whistles for 15 minutes starting at 9 p.m. The communique was the 58th issued since the start of the Palestinian uprising in December 1987. During the revolt, 717 Palestinians have been killed by Israeli soldiers and civilians, and 45 Israelis have been killed by Palestinians. Palestinians have killed 224 other Palestinians believed to be collaborating with Israel. On Tuesday, a court ordered Ami Popper, a 21-year-old Israeli, held for another 10 days in jail on charges he murdered the seven Palestinians in Rishon Letzion and wounded 10 others. A date will be set for trial once his lawyer reviews the evidence. Popper was arrested the day of the slayings and charged on Monday after a psychiatric panel found him fit to stand trial. Authorities maintained after his arrest that he was ``deranged'' and upset by an unhappy love affair.

DOC.HEAD: Explosions Rock U.S. Aircraft Carrier, 16 Injured
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 4 grafs to move up Japanese city demanding that ship be barred from port until safety confirmed. Pick up 3rd pvs, `The fire...' Deletes redundant grafs 11-12.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: Two explosions rocked the U.S. aircraft carrier Midway today during flight operations at sea, injuring 16 crew members and leaving one missing, the Navy said. At least seven were seriously hurt. A fire that broke out at the time of the first explosion was later extinguished and the 980-foot-long ship was steaming under its own power about 125 miles northeast of Tokyo, the Navy said in a statement. The Navy's Public Affairs Office said the ship would not return tonight to its port at Yokosuka, near Tokyo, and a decision would be made Thursday on whether it needs to come in. Yokosuka city demanded that the Midway be barred from the port until its safety had been confirmed and the causes of the fire clarified, city spokesman Ryutaro Koizumi said. The demand was relayed to the Foreign Ministry. The fire broke out in a parts storeroom four decks below the carrier's flight deck, and was confined to the storeroom, said Petty Officer 2nd Class Frank Mowry of the Public Affairs Office at the Navy base at Yokosuka. Mowry was unsure what caused the fire and explosions, or how long the fire burned. But he said that 1{ hours after the first fire broke out, firefighters were moving into the storeroom to extinguish it. Among the injured, he said, five were flown to Yokosuka. One was in critical condition, two in very serious condition, one in guarded condition and one in stable condition. Four others, who were seriously burned, were taken by helicopter to the U.S. air base at Yokota, west of Japan, and then to two separate Japanese hospitals, Mowry said. He had no immediate information on the other seven injured crew members. The Navy said no deaths had been reported aboard the ship, which had 4,500 people aboard including fliers and aviation crews. The 51,000-ton carrier was launched in 1943 and was later extensively modernized. The Navy statement said the first explosion occurred at 12:23 p.m., about half an hour after smoke had been reported. Firefighters were called, and a second explosion occurred about an hour later, it added. ``The cause and extent of the explosion and fire are unknown at this time,'' it said. The Navy said the Midway was conducting routine flight operations at the time. Kyodo News Service said the Japan Council Against Atomic and Hydrogen Bombs, a private anti-nuclear organization, had demanded that the Japanese government refuse to let the Midway enter Yokosuka. Japanese news reports said there had been concern in Japan because the Midway was capable of carrying nuclear weapons. Japan, the only nation ever attacked with atomic bombs, bans all nuclear weapons from its territory. Critics contend that U.S. ships have brought nuclear weapons into Japanese ports, but the government says the United States would have to ask Japan's permission and never has done so. As a matter of policy, the United States refuses to comment on the location of its nuclear weapons. The last major blaze aboard a U.S. warship was May 8, when fire broke out before dawn on the guided-missile destroyer USS Conyngham during routine operations in the Atlantic about 100 miles southeast of Norfolk, Va. One crewman was killed and 18 other sailors were injured in the fire, which broke out in the engine roome, officials said. The cause is under investigation. At the time, it was the worst shipboard blaze since a string of accidents prompted the Navy to suspend operations for a two-day safety check in November.

DOC.HEAD: Two Killed in Treatment Plant Explosion
DOC.TEXT: An explosion ripped through a wastewater treatment plant today, killing two workers. The 3:10 a.m. explosion might have been caused by a gas leak, said William Schatz, attorney for the Northeast Ohio Regional Sewer District. Authorities were investigating. ``The explosion was in a rather limited area. There is extensive damage, but it shouldn't affect the treatment process. They've got to get in and clear some of the debris,'' Schatz said. The explosion caused about $1 million in damage, he said. Schatz identified the victims as plant operator Mark Swiger, 24, and Robert Angiocchi, 54, a supervisor. The plant in suburban Cleveland is one of three wastewater treatment plants operated by the district, which serves Cleveland and its suburbs.

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Inaugurated; U.S. Boycotts Ceremony
LaserPhotos BUC1,3,4,5
DOC.TEXT: Former high-ranking Communist Ion Iliescu, whose leadership has been tarnished by violent attacks on opponents, took the oath of office as president today and swore to uphold democracy and human rights. Iliescu's heavy-handed tactics _ especially in calling in miners last week who beat suspected government critics _ have alienated leaders in Western capitals. U.S. Ambassador Alan J. Green Jr. boycotted the inauguration, although the ambassadors of all other major Western nations attended. Green returned from Washington on Monday saying the democratic process in Romania had come to a halt. An opposition leader, Ion Ratiu, praised the American action, calling it ``the most eloquent way the U.S. could show its condemnation of the vigilante tactics that Mr. Iliescu generated last week.'' No major protests were reported today, although some university students and teachers were on strike. The government this week arrested several opposition leaders but offered to talk with other activists. ``I swear faithfulness to the Romanian people and to their ideals of freedom and prosperity,'' Iliescu told Parliament and foreign diplomats during the ceremony in the Atheneum Concert Hall in downtown Bucharest. ``I swear to observe the country's laws, to defend democracy (and) the fundamental human rights and freedoms, the sovereignty and the territorial integrity of our homeland,'' he said. In his first decision as president, Iliescu appointed Petre Roman as premier. Roman, 44, a former engineering professor, has been interim premier since the bloody December revolution that toppled dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Iliescu, 60, a high-ranking Communist official in the late 1960s, was formally declared president by Alexandru Birladeanu, chairman of the Senate, the Parliament's higher chamber. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front took power in the December revolution and won the May 20 election by a landslide. Critics say the Front, which counts many former Communists among its leaders, is little more than the old repressive regime in disguise. Last week, police attacked peaceful anti-government protesters to break up a 53-day vigil on a central square. Rioting followed in which government buildings were attacked and Iliescu appealed to the miners. The miners attacked people suspected of being government critics and ransacked the offices of opposition parties and their newspapers. In his inauguration speech, Iliescu blamed last week's unrest on ``extremist political groups'' who he said were ``organized and coordinated according to a scenario for destabilization.'' But he also criticized the miners _ he had personally thanked them on Friday _ for ``breaking into public institutions, (opposition) party headquarters and private homes, and for roughing up people'' who were innocent. ``We registered excesses, violations of some institutions ... attacks on some citizens,'' Iliescu said. ``We uneqivocally dissociate ourselves from the actions which transcended the legal framework.'' This week, the government is at once talking to opposition groups and detaining their leaders. Lawmakers have authorized police action to stop any new street demonstrations. Anti-government protesters gathered this week in University Square. Demonstrators were forcibly removed from the square last week. A communique carried by the state Rompres news agency said Interior Minister Viorel Doru Ursu and the Romanian Information Service _ the new intelligence agency that replaced Ceausescu's feared Securitate _ had invited student organizations and intellectuals to discuss ``problems of common interest.'' Parliament's lower house on Monday gave police and soldiers the authority to clear University Square of protesters. The upper chamber, in a separate measure, urged police to take ``immediate action'' against unauthorized protests. On Tuesday, the Interior Ministry arrested two opposition figures, Dumitru Dinca and Nica Leon, leader of the small National Democratic Party. It said Dinca had been charged with ``larceny and instigation toward committing major crimes,'' while Leon was detained under a warrant accusing him of ``destruction of public property.'' The two were being held as part of an investigation into the June 13 breakup by riot police of the University Square sit-in and the subsequent unrest. The government has claimed ``fascists'' were trying to overthrow it but has yet to produce any evidence. Some Romanians have speculated that the violence was provoked to give the government the opportunity to silence or at least intimidate the opposition. On Monday, authorities detained Marian Munteanu, a student leader severely beaten by pro-government miners last week. Munteanu was taken to a police hospital on charges of instigating violence. That led his wife, Claudia, to seek refuge at the home of Dutch Ambassador Coen F. Stork. Government opponents seek the ouster of Iliescu and the other former Communists who hold top posts in the National Salvation Front. They have also demanded an independent television station.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Soviet Uzbekistan Debates Independence Declaration
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to CORRECT that Tass now saying parliament merely discussing, sted approved, declaration of independence; Picks up 10th graf, `Meanwhile, the ...'
DOC.TEXT: The parliament of Uzbekistan began discussing a declaration of independence today, becoming the first of the five Soviet Central Asian republics to consider breaking with Moscow, the official Tass news agency reported. The Supreme Soviet of Uzbekistan debated a measure that would establish the republic as a separate country responsible for its own domestic and foreign policy, Tass said. The arid, poverty-stricken Central Asian republics of the Soviet south have suffered from repeated outbreaks of ethnic unrest, but until now have not followed the parliamentary struggle for secession waged by the three Baltic republics in the northwest. Moscow imposed economic sanctions and an oil and gas embargo on Lithuania after it declared independence on March 11. Latvia and Estonia followed suit by declaring a transition period to independence. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has denounced Lithuania's independence declaration as illegal and has demanded that it be suspended. Uzbekistan, a cotton-growing republic of 20 million people, has the best-organized popular movement in the region, Berlik, and is seen as a center for activism in largely Moslem Central Asia. Tass said initially that Uzbekistan's declaration of independence was approved by a majority of Supreme Soviet members, but it later issued an advisory withdrawing the report. Alexander Snasten, an editor at Tass' world service, said discussion of the measure had begun but that it had not been approved. ``The declaration stipulates Uzbekistan's state sovereignty, its independence and the supremacy of republican laws on its entire territory,'' Tass said. It said the measure would put ``all issues of domestic issues of domestic and foreign policy under the authority of Uzbekistan.'' The declaration suggests the Soviet Union would be treated like a foreign country, saying Uzbekistan would ``determine the nature and foundations that underlie its future economic, cultural and other relations with the U.S.S.R. and other states.'' Tass said many deputies had argued that the declaration should wait until a new federal treaty is worked out among the 15 Soviet republics, but were overruled. Meanwhile, the parliament of Soviet Georgia, pressed by hunger strikers, convened a special session today to discuss legal steps for securing independence for the Caucasus republic, Tass reported. On March 9, the Georgian Supreme Soviet condemned the republic's annexation by the Soviet Union and urged negotiations on independence, becoming the fourth of the 15 Soviet republics to begin a parliamentary struggle for secession. The Supreme Soviet convened a month ahead of scheduled in response to demands from hunger-striking university students in the Georgian capital of Tbilisi, the Soviet news agency said. The dozens of students ended their hunger strikes last week after their demands on the session and its agenda were satisfied, said Valerian Khukhunashvili, a Moscow-based Georgian activist. The session that opened today was to discuss bills on the transition to independence, elections, citizenship, economic independence and other measures. Georgia, a mountainous republic of 5.3 million people, was occupied by the Red Army in 1921 and subsequently signed treaties incorporating it into the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Former Revenue Director Pleads No Contest to Attempted Misconduct
DOC.TEXT: Florida's former top tax collector pleaded no contest today to a charge of attempted official misconduct and was sentenced to a year's probation. Katie Tucker also agreed to pay $500 in court costs. She resigned from her job as state Revenue Department director in February in the face of certain dismissal by Gov. Bob Martinez and the independently elected Cabinet. Circuit Judge F.E. Steinmeyer III modified the probation to allow Ms. Tucker, 46, to carry out her duties as a reserve officer in the Coast Guard. Ms. Tucker had been charged with official misconduct by falsifying documents, a third-degree felony that carries a maximum five-year prison sentence. The misdemeanor charge to which she pleaded no contest could have meant a year in jail. The charge stemmed from a state investigation into whether she had singled out the businesses owned by Donald G. Resha for auditing. Resha lost a 1985 race for the presidency of the state AFL-CIO to Ms. Tucker's husband, Daniel Miller. Ms. Tucker declined to make a statement to the court and refused to comment after the proceeding.

DOC.HEAD: Justice Clears Way for Surgery for California Boy
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court justice has cleared the way for court-ordered corrective surgery for a 6-year-old California boy born with clubfeet and a dislocated hip. Justice Sandra Day O'Connor refused to set aside rulings that the surgery may be performed on Kou Xiang without the consent of his parents, Hmong immigrants from the hill region of Laos. O'Connor's denial was dated Tuesday but not disclosed until today. An emergency request submitted in behalf of Kou's father, Ger Xiang of Fresno, said the surgery ordered by a state judge would violate religious freedom and parental rights. Ger Xiang and his wife, Houa Vue, believe their family would be punished by spirits for tampering with their son's deformities. According to court documents, they believe the boy was born with clubfeet as punishment for some wrong committed by another relative. Fresno County Judge Lawrence O'Neill in February ordered the corrective surgery after officials of the county's Department of Social Services sought such help. Kou has said he does not want the surgery. Medical testimony during a two-day hearing before O'Neill indicated the boy would lose movement in his legs and be wheelchair-bound by adulthood without the surgery. Waiting until the boy is old enough to make his own decision would decrease the chances of success, according to the medical testimony. The judge postponed the effect of his order to let the boy's father appeal. Two state appellate courts rejected those appeals. In the emergency request acted on Tuesday, lawyers for Ger Xiang said county social services officials ``cannot demonstrate a compelling state interest sufficient to override (the family's) religious ... beliefs.'' The request said the ``series of unwanted, major surgical operations'' should not be forced on Kou and his family. The case is Ger Xiang vs. Superior Court, A-892.

DOC.HEAD: Assailed By Critics, Gorbachev Hints At Leaving Party Post
DOC.TEXT: Under fire from Communist hard-liners, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that he might soon leave his post as party leader. ``Tomorrow, or after 10 days or 12 days, there may be another general secretary or chairman of the party,'' Gorbachev told the largely anti-reform delegates at a conference of the Russian republic's Communist Party. He did not say if he might resign or if he expected to be ousted from the party job. Giving up that position legally should not affect his five-year term as president of the Soviet Union. There has been speculation for months that Gorbachev's long-range strategy is to shift the key leadership positions from the party to the government. His appeal appeared to be an effort to gain support at the fractious meeting. Conservative delegates have attacked him for diminishing their influence. Politburo member Yegor Ligachev _ without mentioning Gorbachev _ criticized him indirectly for retaining the job of party general secretary after his election earlier this year to the new post of Soviet president. ``It is impossible to run the party, this guiding force, without devoting full time to it,'' Ligachev, the most prominent Soviet hard-liner, told the congress. Gorbachev did not rebut the conservative criticism, but said his accusers were poorly informed and disrespectful. ``The comrades seem to suspect the general secretary of the Communist Party of some vacillation, hesitation, and so forth,'' he said angrily. ``Some of the comrades are being too casual with the general secretary, with the president of the country.'' ``Before expressing opinions, and especially accusations, you have to know a whole lot and understand it, and not just speak off the cuff,'' Gorbachev said. The delegates at this week's meeting will form the majority of delegates at the national party congress opening July 2, which is expected to make considerable changes in the party leadership. The Foreign Ministry spokesman, Gennady Gerasimov, when asked by reporters whether Gorbachev would be elected then, said: ``We'll see at the congress. It will add suspense to your lives.'' Gorbachev came under heavy fire for his reforms at Tuesday's opening session. A Siberian hard-liner speaking for his regional Communist organization urged Gorbachev and the entire leadership to resign for taking the party out of decision-making. Other delegates won applause for criticizing Gorbachev's reforms, which have ended the Communist monopoly and transferred its power to the government. The conference, considered a dress rehearsal for the key national party congress, also voted by an overwhelming majority today to condemn a legislative proposal that would liquidate party cells in the army, KGB and government. By a 2,008-to-398 margin, the conference delegates approved a resolution saying the decree ``would weaken Communist influence in society,'' and strengthen ``reactionary elements.'' The vote was described as a rebuff to Boris N. Yeltsin, who calls for even more radical reforms than Gorbachev in his position as the new president of the Russian republic. Yeltsin heads the republic's parliament, which gave preliminary approval Monday to a ``Decree on Power'' that calls for party cells in the government, security police and armed forces to be liquidated. The vote strongly indicated that hard-liners would similarly battle Gorbachev's liberal program at the Soviet Communist Party Congress. The Russian party conference also moved today to form a separate Communist Party of the vast Russian republic. The formal decision to create the party, which would require a two-thirds majority from among the 2,700 delegates, was expected to be taken later in the day. The Russian Communist Party, which would remain within the framework of the national party of more than 18 million members, was absorbed by the central party 65 years ago. Of the 15 Soviet republics, only Russia has not had its own party, in part because Russians dominated the national party. Russia contains three-quarters of the Soviet territory.

Here are excerpts from recent editorials in newspapers in the United States and abroad. June 16 Bangor (Maine) Daily News on flag burning: The American flag, which has been shot at, set afire, sunk with foundering ships, vilified, belittled and scorned, remains a flawless symbol of the United States. The flag remains unscathed not because of its material but because of the freedoms and responsibilities it represents. By protecting the material of the flag through a constitutional amendment, we risk weakening those freedoms and responsibilities. The Supreme Court's 5-4 ruling making unconstitutional a law that would prohibit flag burning looked beyond the emotional support for the flag to the freedom for Americans to express dissent and to challenge the government. Though burning the flag is an ugly act that many would call a type of political pornography, this is not a question of taste but of rights.

June 14 The Keene (N.H.) Sentinel on flag burning: Thomas Jefferson and James Madison, the principal authors of the Bill of Rights, believed that the key to maintaining a free society was to cultivate a respect for liberty, but not necessarily a respect for every manifestation of liberty. The distinction is important. Jefferson and Madison understood that the exercise of freedom would inevitably result in the expression of very unpopular opinions. President George Bush and Reps. Chuck Douglas and Robert Smith (both R-N.H.) are among contemporary politicians who don't seem to understand that concept. With unbecoming arrogance, they are proposing to improve upon the work of Jefferson and Madison. They want to pass a constitutional amendment to amend the Bill of Rights for the first time in the country's history.

June 14 The Plain Dealer, Cleveland, on flag burning: The Constitution protects Americans' right of political dissent, even if they express their protest in ways the majority may deplore. With its reasoned defense of the First Amendment's guarantee of free expression, the Supreme Court ... should have put a stop to the demagoguery over an emotional non-issue: the phony furor over flag burning. ... No other nation has an absolute guarantee of its citizens' freedoms. If the right of free expression is to remain intact, mainstream Americans must tolerate dissent, even in its most eccentric or offensive forms. Yet a momentary scare about flag burning has incited opportunists to cheapen the meaning of patriotism. The more-loyal-than-thou posturing _ stage-managed by the White House in a deplorable effort to sway votes in this election year _ foreshadows another campaign season of flag-factory rallies and mass recitations of the Pledge of Allegiance. Such flag fanaticism has become worse than a mere frivolity: It now threatens to shred the Constitution itself.

June 13 The Free Press, Mankato, Minn., on flag burning: Here we go again. The Supreme Court again overturned a federal law prohibiting flag burning. This ruling means that now we're sure to see a constitutional amendment barreling down the Congressional pike to make flag burning illegal. Let's hope sanity prevails on Capitol Hill, and our representatives vote down this wrong-headed move. Few, if any, have ever been swayed because somebody else torched a flag. To the contrary, such acts are found by the vast majority of us to be repulsive. So why not make this exception to free speech? Because the right of free speech has importance and value as one of the fundamental rights of our political system. The First Amendment protects unpopular speech; popular speech needs no shield. The flag has importance and value _ but only as a symbol of our system. Free speech is the more important right in our system. It may be too much to hope that the demagogues of the Republican Party will let this issue drop. But we can hope, as we do, that Congress will reject the flag burning amendment.

June 15 The North Jersey Herald and News, Passaic, N.J., on the legal reaction to flag burning and rap group 2 Live Crew: This is scary. As eastern Europeans and Soviet citizens struggle to emerge from an oppressed past to a democratic future, some Americans are ready to turn back the clock more than 200 years on our own Bill of Rights. In Fort Lauderdale, Fla., a federal judge declared a rap album by the group 2 Live Crew, ``As Nasty As They Want to Be,'' obscene and prohibited its sale. A grandstanding sheriff in Broward County ordered the arrest of a store owner for selling the record, then busted band members for performing songs from the album, even though the concert was adults-only. Meanwhile, in our nation's capital, lawmakers have turned an irrelevant non-issue into the nation's top priority. The problem? A few jerks in Podunk might burn the American flag as a statement of protest. So President Bush and Congress, in a cynical appeal to patriotism, want to tamper with the U.S. Constitution. Short of yelling ``fire'' in a crowded theater, Americans must not give in to the temptation of shutting up people whose statements we may find objectionable. Those who would have government censor the public can look to point east to see the consequences.

June 19 Commercial Dispatch, Columbus, Miss., on sobriety checkpoints: The U.S. Supreme Court was right on target the other day when it ruled that law enforcement checkpoints are a reasonable means to combat drunken driving. These checkpoints are a small inconvenience considering the more important benefits _ helping to keep drunk drivers off our highways. ... The real effectiveness of these checkpoints is deterrence. Critics argue these programs cannot be proven to be more effective than other techniques. But local and state law enforcement officials were quick to note ... that checkpoints do work. They're convinced of it. So why shouldn't local authorities have the right to decide whether such techniques will be used on their roads. Pertaining to charges these interruptions are simple harassment by government, the key word as far as Bill of Rights' protection goes is ``unreasonable.'' But to us it would seem far more reasonable to be concerned about the bloodbath linked to drunken driving all across our nation _ 23,000 deaths in 1988, according to U.S. Department of Transportation figures. ... It just makes good sense that our lawmen should have among their preventive arsenal the right to conduct sobriety checkpoints.
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: UNDATED: body count.
DOC.TEXT: June 19 The Hindustan Times, northern India, on space exploration: President Bush last month set the deadline for a manned mission to Mars: 2019, the 50th anniversary of the first Apollo manned landing on the Moon. Like President Kennedy before him, Bush is apparently challenging the nation to spend large resources and to risk lives to go to another world. ... NASA, set up by the Eisenhower administration in 1958, succeeded magnificently by putting 12 men onto the Moon by December 1972. Can it repeat a far more complex and spectacular feat to the red planet in less than 29 years? In fact, is a manned journey to Mars even technically feasible? The red planet is hundreds of times farther away than the Moon. The voyage would probably take some two to two and and a half years to complete _ 50 times longer than the longest Apollo mission and to achieve it would require technical advances on three fronts which are far from being accomplished. First, the effects of prolonged weightlessness have yet to be overcome; secondly, reliable closed cycle space habitats (spaceships adequate enough for six to eight people to live and work in without being resupplied) have to be built; and thirdly, a giant rocket, with ten times more propulsion power than the Saturn V Moon rocket would be required. Since the decommissioning of Saturn V, the U.S. has lacked a heavylift rocket. The prohibitive cost, estimated at an additional $15 billion a year on top of the expense of present space activities, doubtful technical feasibility and lack of political will all make the Mars manned journey a dream less likely to become a reality.

June 14 Al-Ahram, Cairo, on Israel-PLO: The United States is still arousing doubts around the future of the American-Palestinian dialogue because of what the American adminstration has repeated about the PLO not outrightly condemning the failed Palestinian commando raid on the shore of Tel Aviv. The American threat arouses a number of questions: First: The United States brings up the subject of cutting off the dialogue as though the dialogue was the aim resulting from the Palestinian concesssions in 1988. Second: Anyone who has followed the results of the dialogue between the two sides up to now will easily realize that there is no positive result. The U.S. could not even obtain initial Israeli approval of the Baker plan, which the PLO had reservations over. Third: American insistence on a PLO condemnation of the raid provokes the issue of equal treatment, and specifically a request from Israel for a condemnation of the terrorist acts it practices against the Palestiniaian people. Fourth: Just as the PLO is asked to condemn an act it has not perpetrated, so should Israel be requested to condemn violent acts it has not perpetrated, such as those against PLO members in many countries. The American threat to cut off the dialogue with the PLO has no gravity, neither as concerns the value of the dialogue nor as concerns the justice of the request, especially after the formation of a government of war in Israel.

June 14 Le Figaro, Paris, on Algeria's local elections: The fundamentalists' victory in the local elections marks the second Algerian revolution. But the adversary was still France _ yesterday because it was the colonizer, today because it represents the successful economic model of the West. In Algeria, revolution is first of all revulsion. As the first expression of their identity, the Algerians experimented with socialism. ... Now Algerians seem tempted by a second dead end, that of fundamentalism. Despairing of the future that was vainly promised them through socialism, they are turning toward the past. They want to take refuge in a faith which, for each complicated question, gives a simple answer.

June 16 Kenya Times, Nairobi, Kenya, on continued civil war and famine in Ethiopia: Millions have continued starving to death and relief supplies from various donors have been the only thing that has kept many going. And still this relief food does not reach the needy people easily due to the heavy fighting going on in some strategic areas. But really, can Ethiopia afford to divert its attention from meeting the needs of the people to fighting a bloody, endless and devastating war? Is it not time the war came to an end?

June 16 Straits Times, Singapore, on the future of Canada: The threat of national disintegration leads to the larger, and perpetual, question of a Canadian identity. Canadians are said to have a problem defining themselves in a way that distinguishes them sufficiently from U.S. Americans, the penetrative vigor of whose civilization is enhanced by geographical proximity, economic logic and ethnic links. Much of the problem, one suspects, stems from Canadians trying to do something which they need not do. The existence of countries, like that of human beings, does not need to be justified. The real question is to ask what would happen to Canadians' identity complex if the country were to disappear. What would replace it? What surer identity awaits the doubting Canadian? If there is none, is it not better to look within the nation and examine the links which are there, however problematic these might be, rather than seek the sense of self either through divisiveness at home or distinctiveness abroad? This sounds negative, and necessarily so, for ethnic identity in all multicultural societies is a negative starting point. The whole point is to move beyond that line, creating an identity in the very act of looking for one. For countries, again like children, are not just born but grow.

June 18 The Independent, London, on Eastern Europe: In Romania, the government of the National Salvation Front has behaved in a fashion virtually indistinguishable from that of the Ceausescu regime it overthrew. In Bulgaria and in Yugoslavia, too, a revival of nationalism and the rudiments of democracy have not yet brought back anything recognizable as the rule of law. ... European governments ought certainly to make plain their disapproval to ... (Ion) Iliescu, and underline it in the most effective way by stating that no aid will be forthcoming to governments that send licensed bullies to beat up their citizens.
DOC.HEAD: End Editorial Rdp
Flooding Sweeps Away Illinois Rescue Worker; 30 Hurt in Kansas
DOC.TEXT: Heavy rains caused flooding in Illinois, where a rescue worker was dragged off a collapsed bridge and was missing today, and vicious storms pummeled parts of Kansas, authorities said. Flooding shut down roads in several counties near Springfield and Peoria in central Illinois. National Weather Service meteorologists said at least 4 inches of rain had fallen in several counties in the area since 1 a.m. A Washburn Fire Department rescue worker was swept away by flood waters on state Route 26. The worker, whose identity was not immediately known, disappeared after stepping out of an ambulance on a collapsed bridge, according to Illinois State Police Dispatcher Peggy Dehnbostel. State Emergency Services and Disaster Agency officials, whose Springfield offices were flooded, said today they were still unable to determine where else flooding had occurred. In Kansas, several counties were lashed by tornadoes and sheets of rain. The storms overturned mobile homes, leveled trees, damaged property and left more than 40,000 people without power. ``It was like a bomb went off,'' Mark Bogner of WeatherData Inc. said of the dozens of storms cells that exploded over the prairie from Dodge City and Pratt east to Butler County. The violent night followed a hot day in Wichita. A record high of 105 a poor Dona Violeta.'' Mrs. Chavarria's husband, Jose, is a bricklayer who brings home $20 a month, slightly more than she earned as a grade school teacher. Her teaching papers were lost they moved here recently from Esteli, so they decided she should open the store. Many people seem to share the guarded optimism of Mrs. Chavarria and the neighbor, but there also is a ``show me'' attitude that good times are not just around the corner. Nicaraguans voted the Sandinistas out Feb. 25 and inflation still is high nearly two months after Mrs. Chamorro's pro-American government was inaugurated. Inflation reached 36,000 percent in 1988, then declined to 1,800 percent in 1989. Francisco Mayorga, president of the central bank, now gauges it weekly. His figures were 47 percent for the first week of May, then 17 percent, 12 and 11 for the next three. Mayorga, who was educated at Yale and devised Mrs. Chamorro's economic recovery plan, accused the Sandinistas of using the two-month transition period to undermine the new government. He said they spent money wildly and printed more to cover the deficit. President Bush signed a $300 million aid package May 26. The first $60 million arrived quickly and, between May 25 and May 31, the black market price of a dollar declined from 310,000 cordobas to 290,000. ``The exchange houses are supplying dollars again; that's why it went down,'' said Jose Gutierrez, one of two dozen currency dealers on a street near the Mexican Embassy. Gutierrez and his colleagues wave wads of cordobas at passing motorists, and police look the other way. Another sign of improvement is a 20 percent increase in planted farm acreage over last year, Mayorga said. Food production fell steadily under the Sandinistas. On the negative side, Nicaragua's currency has been devalued frequently since Mrs. Chamorro took office. The parallel exchange rate, which governs most dollar transactions, had gone from 70,800 cordobas to 226,600 by May 31. Some Chamorro supporters are beginning to grumble. ``Maybe we would have been better off under the Sandinistas,'' said Julio Gonzalez, 33, who runs an auto repair shop with his cousin. Former President Daniel Ortega, he said, ``had the economy more or less under control.'' What does he expect to happen now? ``Maybe we'll see an improvement in six months, a year, but it better happen. Just like we knocked down Somoza, we knocked down the Sandinistas. Well, we can knock down this government too.'' The Sandinista revolution overthrew the late President Anastasio Somosa in July 1979. Rolando Perez Sanchez, a 29-year-old Sandinista union leader, listened with skepticism to Gonzalez, his friend and neighbor. ``It's not going to happen,'' he said, shaking his head. ``This government if full of bourgeois who will hoard all the capital and leave the workers the crumbs. ``What we have to do is what Daniel said _ rule from below to defend the conquests of the revolution.'' ``Ruling from below'' took the form of a crippling strike by public employees in May, after which the government gave broad concessions to unions. Mrs. Chamorro has had to proceed carefully because of the militant Sandinista opposition. Her government plans to review confiscations of property under the Sandinistas and continues to trim the huge bureaucracy, firing public employees. Sandinista threats of more strikes if the firings continued have not materialized, and their protest marches draw smaller crowds. If economic improvement continues, the Sandinistas could lose the leverage of being the defenders of worker's buying power. Another Sandinista rallying point, the Contra rebels, might disappear once the guerrillas demobilize. ``I'm like St. Thomas; I'll have to see it to believe it,'' Gonzalez said. For Mrs. Chavarria, who has three small children, abolition of the two-year draft for boys of 16 is great progress. ``You don't know what a relief this is for us mothers,'' she said. ``As for the rest of it, we'll have to wait. At least we eat every day.''

DOC.HEAD: Office Shootings Stir Gun Debate
DOC.TEXT: The massacre of eight people by a man with a rifle could undercut the powerful gun lobby at a time when Florida voters are considering a constitutional amendment imposing a three-day wait on handgun purchases. ``Anytime you have a tragedy, those people with hidden agendas see any and every emotional opportunity to try to justify their erroneous position and try to deprive the people of their rights,'' said Marion Hammer, spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association's Florida branch. The debate over the amendment on November's ballot intensified after James Edward Pough, 42, a day laborer, killed eight people Monday with a semiautomatic rifle before taking his own life with a revolver at an auto loan agency. Police said Pough also killed two people on the street Sunday with the rifle. ``How many messages do we send to the Congress? How many to the state Legislature?'' Jacksonville Mayor Tommy Hazouri said Tuesday. ``If it means seeking changes ... we're going to do that.'' State Rep. Ron Silver, chairman of the House Criminal Justice Committee, said the fact the waiting period is being settled by a referendum rather than a vote in the Legislature shows many lawmakers still fear the NRA's clout. But he added that polls indicate heavy support for the amendment, and he said passage could give legislators confidence to pass other gun-control laws. ``I think Florida is waking up,'' Silver said. California passed an assault weapons bill in 1989 in the aftermath of the Stockton, Calif., schoolyard spree by a drifter with an AK-47 assault rifle who killed five children and wounded 30 other people. President Bush approved an import ban on assault weapons and a Senate bill would extend the ban to domestic manufacture of four weapons identified as used mainly in drug violence. Florida has tackled gun legislation several times in recent years. A 1987 law removed gun registration from county control in favor of statewide registration rules. A law taking effect Oct. 1 requires gun sellers to check all applicants through a crime computer in Tallahassee. But lawmakers on a study commission on assault weapons failed to agree on which weapons should be banned. U.S. Rep. Bill Nelson, a Democrat running for governor, has called banning assault weapons a priority. ``It is harder to rent a car in Florida than it is to buy an AK-47,'' he said during a debate Monday before he knew of the shooting spree. A Nelson aide needed less than 10 minutes to walk into a Miami gun shop and come out with an AK-47 and ammunition last month. Gov. Bob Martinez, a Republican seeking re-election, said Tuesday the law requiring a background check by gun dealers is a responsible step, ``but at the same time we must maintain the freedom to own guns which have useful sporting purposes.'' Pough's .30-caliber semiautomatic rifle would be banned under New Jersey's month-old law on assault weapons, considered the nation's toughest, because its clip held more than 15 rounds. Nelson wants a seven-day waiting period on handgun purchases. Democratic front-runner Lawton Chiles also supports a waiting period. Now, gun purchasers are required to have some identification, such as a driver's license, and fill out a questionnaire on arrests, mental illness and drug use. But there is no way for merchants to confirm the information other than by investigating on their own. It is illegal in Florida for a convicted felon to own a handgun. But technically, Pough wasn't a convicted felon. In 1971, he was charged with manslaughter in the shooting death of a man; he pleaded guilty to aggravated assault and was sentenced to five years' probation, court records show. After probation, his record was wiped clean. That made it legal for Pough to own a gun under Florida law. ``It's a loophole we need to plug up,'' Jacksonville Sheriff Jim McMillan said.

DOC.HEAD: Man Sentenced in Case of Mistaken Identity
DOC.TEXT: A man was jailed Wednesday until at least the year 2014 for a bungled contract killing in which the wrong man was shot. Justice Barry Beach, in imposing the stiffest sentence possible, called Roy Anthony Pollitt an evil man. ``You have demonstrated you are a person without pity and are quite incapable of remorse,'' the judge said. Pollitt, 38, was convicted this month of the murder of Lindsay Simpson on Sept. 18, 1984. He pleaded innocent. Prosecutors said Pollitt was hired by another man to kill a confessed heroin supplier, Alan Williams. But Williams heard of the plot and left his house, even though he was aware that Simpson, his brother-in-law, was due to arrive there, Beach said. Pollitt shot Simpson after he arrived with his wife and 8-month-old daughter, according to the prosecution. Mrs. Simpson testified that her husband got out of the car, argued with Pollitt and insisted he was not Williams, but was shot in the back of the head.

DOC.HEAD: Water-Skier Injured During TV Stunt
LaserPhoto SYD1
DOC.TEXT: A water-skiing stuntman was seriously injured Wednesday when a stunt being filmed for a U.S. television production went wrong. Geoff Carrington, 30, who holds several world records for water-skiing, was to hit a ramp and soar over the speedboat towing him. The boat was then to lift off from a second ramp and fly into a specially constructed bait shop near the edge of the water. Several practice runs went well, but during the actual filming the boat slowed unexpectedly as it hit the second ramp. This threw Carrington off-course and into a pier. A medical team treated Carrington for more than 15 minutes before he was airlifted to the Gold Coast Hospital, where he was undergoing treatment for internal injuries. The attempted stunt, which also called for the bait shop to explode with pyrotechnics when hit by the speedboat, was one of six stunts planned for a Fox Television special. The speedboat driver, Warren Chapman, was in shock after the incident. Police were investigating the incident.

DOC.HEAD: Love-Crazed Donkey Bites Master to Death
DOC.TEXT: A male donkey separated from its mate by its master bit the man to death Wednesday, Iran's official Islamic Republic News Agency reported. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, said the donkey was so incensed when its master, Bashir Khedmat, separated him from his female companion that it went for Khedmat's throat. The animal was clubbed to death by farm workers, the agency said. It said the incident occurred in the village of Owj-Tappeh in northwestern Iran.

DOC.HEAD: Two Americans on Rebel Assassination List
DOC.TEXT: Two Americans were among 140 people on assassination lists seized recently from Communist rebels, military sources said Wednesday. The lists were discovered during a five-day military operation that began Friday in Manila's suburbs of Paranaque, Las Pinas and Taguig. Ten suspected members of the Alex Boncayao Brigade, the Manila wing of the Communist New People's Army, were arrested during the raids, the military said. Col. Ajerico Kagaoan, chief of the Philippine Constabulary's intelligence unit, said troops found lists containing ``the identities of foreign nationals, civilian officials and ranking officers as liquidation targets ... in the next six months.'' Kagaoan did not elaborate on the nationalities of the foreigners. But intelligence officers, speaking on condition of anonymity, said they included two American businessmen employed by a firm in Taguig. Others on the list were mostly Filipino military personnel, including at least four colonels, the sources said. They refused to give the Americans' names but said the U.S. Embassy and the intended victims were notified. U.S. Embassy spokeswoman Victoria Middleton would not comment on the report. Eight Americans have been slain by Communist rebels since April 1989. Six were either military or military-affiliated personnel.

DOC.HEAD: Aid Urged for Small Business in Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: Businessmen and former government officials asked Congress on Wednesday to provide a ``modern Marshall plan'' to help small businesses and boost U.S. exports to Eastern Europe. Saying the United States is losing ground to Western European entrepreneurs, they endorsed legislation to set up centers to develop small business in Poland, Hungary and Czechoslovakia and a corps of American volunteers to train individuals. ``The original Marshall plan primarily benefited the U.S. as the war-devastated economies of (Western) Europe were resuscitated, and tremendous export markets developed for U.S. companies,'' said D. Bruce Merrifield, an assistant secretary of Commerce in the Reagan administration. ``This `modern' Marshall Plan will be equally beneficial for all concerned,'' he said. The Marshall plan sent billions of dollars in U.S. government money into the industry of western Europe in the 1940s and 1950s. He called for passage of the bill introduced by Rep. John L. LaFalce, D-N.Y., chairman of the House Small Business Committee. M. P. Kobelinski, Small Business Administrator under President Carter, American businesses have been too slow to move into Eastern Europe. ``I travel to Poland often and witness the literal invasion of potential foreign investors, scores of Japanese, German, Italian, Swedish, French and Korean businessmen and the very small smattering of American business representatives,'' he told the committee. He suggested the federal government's Export-Import Bank encourage small loans in Eastern Europe to buy American equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Celebrates Her 109th Birthday
DOC.TEXT: Nina Rust rode an elephant and an airplane on previous birthdays, but this year she took it easy. It was, after all, her 109th year. The Roseburg woman went to the Wildlife Safari animal park in Winston for her birthday Monday and had lunch at the White Rhino restaurant overlooking a pond and an island providing habitat for white gibbon apes. On her 99th birthday, she went to the animal park to take her first elephant ride. She decided the ride was a bit bumpy and has never duplicated the feat. On her 100th, she had her first airplane flight In 1982, at age 101, she drove back to Lincoln, Neb., with her daughter, Phyllis McMeekin of Roseburg, for a family gathering. They then flew to Philadelphia and toured several Eastern states. When she turned 103, ``Dear Reader,'' a book about Rust's life was published. It was written by McMeekin, with whom Rust has lived for the past 35 years. Also in 1984, Rust's first great-great-great-grandchild was born. Although not a first, Rust danced with her son-in-law and another man on her 105th birthday during a party at the Senior Center. Later in the year, McMeekin caught Rust crocheting and reading at the same time. When she commented on it, Rust said, ``I can't waste any time.'' Her 106th year brought her first ride on a motorcycle. Her grandson took her on the ride around the trailer park where Rust lives. Upon dismounting the motorcycle, Rust announced, ```There, I've done one more thing I'd never done in my life,''' McMeekin recalled. While Rust was 107 years old, she had a lens implant in her right eye, which improved her vision so she could continue crocheting granny squares. During the 2{ years that ended June 1989, Rust crocheted nearly 1,900 granny squares. During the past year, a book titled ``One Hundred over 100,'' was published and included an article about Rust. The author, Jim Heynen, interviewed Rust when she was 106 years old. In the interview, she and Heynen played Scrabble and Rust won by about 20 points. In the book, Heynen describes her as the kind of person who will hoard the ``U'' letter squares when she knows her opponent has the ``Q.'' Scrabble, Anagrams and Aggravation have long been Rust's favorite games. She also enjoys word puzzles and reading. Her hearing has deteriorated in the last few years, so she doesn't visit with people as much as she used to. In past years, McMeekin said Rust and her oldest daughter would reminisce for hours. Rust was born June 18, 1881, in a sod house in Hainesville, Neb. She and her husband were married in Butte, Neb., and they had 12 children. All but one are still living. Daughter Emma Nelson, of Norfolk, Neb., died in 1989 at age 77. The other children range from age 87 to 65. Rust has 211 descendants. Besides her children, there are 36 grandchildren, 86 great-grandchildren, 74 great-great-grandchildren and four great-great-great-grandchildren.

DOC.HEAD: `Like Fixing A Dam,' Witness Describes Crack Use Coverup With Mayor
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: Marion Barry and Charles Lewis agreed to cover up their crack cocaine use at a Washington hotel when police began closing in on them, Lewis testified today at the mayor's drug and perjury trial. Lewis said that he and the mayor smoked crack cocaine together in Lewis's hotel room on three nights in December 1988. Police were alerted after Lewis offered cocaine to a hotel maid. Lewis said he found out about the subsequent police investigation from a Washington Post reporter who came to his hotel room looking for the mayor. Testifying for a second day at Barry's trial, Lewis described a telephone conversation with the mayor immediately after finding out about the police probe. ``It was ... like fixing a dam,'' said Lewis. ``We have a problem. We need to fix it. We need to get our stories straight.'' Lewis feared the telephone was bugged, so he and the mayor spoke in code, Lewis said. ``I said ... `you didn't see any drugs, did you?,''' Lewis testified. The mayor replied, ``No, none,'' Lewis testified. Just hours before, Barry had delivered a pipe for smokingays earlier, Lewis testified, the mayor and Lewis smoked crack in the hotel room while watching Monday Night Football. Barry had sent Lewis $100 to buy crack by dispatching the mayor's security guard with the money. The convicted drug dealer served time in prison after pleading guilty to conspiring to distribute cocaine to Barry and others. On Tuesday, Lewis testified that Barry helped assemble a makeshift crack pipe and used cocaine and marijuana repeatedly in the Virgin Islands and Washington, D.C. ``How many packets (of crack) did you and Mr. Barry smoke during his trip to the Virgin Islands'' in March 1988, Assistant U.S. Attorney Judith Retchin asked Lewis as testimony opened Tuesday. ``I would say somewhere near two dozen packets,'' Lewis replied. ``Who smoked more, you or Mr. Barry?'' Retchin asked. ``The mayor did,'' said Lewis. ``He smoked more than I do.'' Lewis is the government's chief witness against the District of Columbia mayor, who watched closely and gave a tight-lipped smile several times during the testimony. Lewis told a U.S. District Court jury that Barry came to his Washington hotel room on Dec. 16, 1988, and dropped rocks of crack cocaine from a matchbox onto a table. The mayor said that when he ``was in the Virgin Islands, I take care of him; when I was in D.C. he takes care of me,'' said Lewis, who was born in the islands. Barry is charged with 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor cocaine conspiracy charge and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. He could face up to 26 years in prison and fines of $1.85 million if convicted on all counts at the trial, which is expected to last several weeks. Barry's wife, Effi, sat in the front row of U.S. District Court during the day. In opening statements earlier Tuesday, Assistant U.S. Attorney Richard Roberts opened the trial charging that the three-term mayor was ``smoking crack and using cocaine all over town for years.'' Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy countered that Barry was a victim of entrapment. He said the trial would reveal ``the depths to which the government was willing to go and did go'' to bring down the mayor of the nation's capital.

DOC.HEAD: WASHINGTON TODAY: White House Negotiates by Veto Threat
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with today's House vote to override Bush's veto of the Hatch Act revisions; picks up 7th graf, No. 13 ...
DOC.TEXT: Forget President Bush's reputation for caution and compromise. He's been wielding his veto pen more frequently and with more success than most recent presidents. The score stands at Bush 11, Congress zero. But lawmakers aren't giving up; the House voted today by a more than 3-to-1 margin to override Bush's veto of revisions to the Hatch Act easing restrictions on political activities by federal workers. Ten of Bush's 11 vetoes were in his first year in office; by contrast, Presidents Reagan and Carter only vetoed two measures apiece in their first years, and were sustained in each of those instances. ``We've been very lucky,'' Bush recently told a White House audience. ``We may take one on the chin. ... But generally, the Republican side has stayed together.'' The Bush shutout has emboldened the White House to engage in what some critics suggest is negotiation-by-veto-threat on a range of bills. Veto No. 12, on the Hatch Act prohibition, could be the first to be overridden by Congress if the Senate goes along with today's 327-93 House vote. No. 13 _ a threatened veto of bill Congress passed last week requiring companies to give employees up to 12 weeks' unpaid leave for family emergencies _ is waiting in the wings. No. 14 could be the Civil Rights Act of 1990, which Bush aides say would lead to hiring quotas. And No. 15 could be the National Affordable Housing Construction Act, which the administration complains would spend too much on public housing. Aides to Reagan rarely talked publicly about a veto in advance. Bush aides do it all the time. Some Bush aides suggest the veto threats themselves are behind Bush's successful track record. Fred McClure, Bush's chief lobbyist in Congress, said that vetoes ``are not something we do haphazardly. We sort of let everybody know up front.'' Over the course of his eight-year term, Reagan vetoed 78 bills and was overridden nine times. In his four years, Carter vetoed 31 bills and was overridden twice. While outdistancing Reagan and Carter, Bush's brisk pace doesn't come close to that of President Ford _ who vetoed 28 bills in his first year and 66 in his 2{ years in office. In all, Ford was overridden 12 times. But the all-time record goes to Franklin D. Roosevelt. From 1933 when he took office to his death in office in 1945, Roosevelt vetoed 635 bills. Only nine were overridden. Richard Nixon, president from 1969 to 1974, vetoed 43 bills; five were overridden. Lyndon Johnson, president from 1963-69, vetoed 29 bills _ and none was overridden. Bush piled up his 11-0 record even though both chambers of Congress are in the hands of opposition Democrats. When the House overwhelmingly voted to override Bush's veto last winter of a bill to extend U.S. visas of Chinese students, the odds seemed to be that the Senate would follow suit. But, after a heavy lobbying campaign, the Senate upheld Bush's veto _ with three votes to spare. Last week the Senate upheld Bush's Amtrak veto by a scant two votes. ``We never said it would be by a landslide,'' said Chief of Staff John Sununu. It requires a two-thirds vote in both chambers to override a veto. In the 100-member Senate, where Republicans have more clout than in the House, Bush needs 34 votes to sustain a veto. Sen. Alan Simpson, R-Wyo., Bush's chief vote counter as minority whip, said the hardest Bush veto to sustain may be the Hatch Act revision, which passed both chambers by more than the requisite two-thirds majorities needed to override. The vote was 334 to 87 in the House; 67 to 30 in the Senate. The bill would allow federal employees to participate in partisan politics for the first time in more than a half-century. Bush said it would lead to politicizing the federal work force. ``We have 33 votes and a pool of four to fish in,'' said Simpson. But, he was reminded by a reporter, Bush doesn't have much of a reputation for catching fish. ``Oh, yes he has,'' Simpson said. ``He's got 11 vetoes that have all been sustained. So I think he's probably very successful fishing in the great congressional pool.'' ``Now, Islamorada (Fla.) is a different matter,'' Simpson said of one of the president's favorite fishing haunts.
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Tom Raum covers the White House for The Associated Press.

DOC.HEAD: Dissident Says Police Took Him On ``Vacation'' For 3 Weeks
DOC.TEXT: One of three outspoken government critics who disappeared three weeks ago said Wednesday he spent the time ``vacationing'' under police supervision _ fishing, riding horses, and even getting a sunburn. ``The whole thing is all really comical,'' Gao Xin said several times, shaking his head and laughing. He said he was unable to explain why he was allowed to return home Tuesday night after being taken away by police the night of May 30. On May 31, Gao and two other dissidents had been scheduled to hold a news conference announcing an open letter demanding freedom for political prisoners. Gao was the second of the three to resurface. He was brought home late Tuesday. Zhou Duo returned Monday morning. The whereabouts of Hou Dejian, a well-known folk singer born in Taiwan, remains unknown. Taiwan's official radio station reported that Hou arrived in Taiwan on Wednesday but did not say whether he had been expelled from China. Gao, 34, told The Associated Press in an interview in his home in Beijing that he spent the past 20 days ``resting and having fun'' in the outskirts of Beijing accompanied by several policemen. He said he had not seen Hou or Zhou since the day before the planned news conference, and had no idea what had happened to them. The three were the only Chinese to continue publicly appealing for democratic reform after last year's military crackdown on the pro-democracy movement. With police permission, they separately gave many interviews to foreign reporters about their activities during the movement and their hopes for China's future. The three men and university lecturer Liu Xiaobo staged a hunger strike in the final days of the massive pro-democracy movement to protest the imposition of martial law in Beijing. When troops moved into Tiananmen Square on the night of June 3-4, the four negotiated with soldiers for safe passage from the square for the protesting students. All except Hou were arrested soon after. Gao was released in December, Zhou in May. Liu remains in prison without charge. In their open letter to Chinese leaders, the three asked specifically for Liu's release. The news conference was to coincide with the one-year anniversary of the day they decided to stage their hunger strike, Gao said. The night before the news conference, uniformed police went to Hou's home, where Gao was spending the night, and took the two men away separately, Gao said. After questioning him through the night and most of the day about the letter and the news conference, the police suggested he leave Beijing until after the anniversary of the June military crackdown passed, he said. ``They said it was best I not be around during this sensitive period, and I couldn't refuse them,'' Gao said, adding that the police made it clear that he was not being investigated or detained. ``They were very polite and treated me as an equal,'' he said. ``I wasn't beaten or mistreated in any way.'' They took Gao to Miyun, a suburb about 50 miles outside Beijing where he spent so much time outdoors that he got a bad sunburn. ``I learned to fish and to ride horses _ things I've never had the chance to do before,'' Gao said. He said he was not watched very closely, had his own room, and was allowed to read books and newspapers and to write letters.

DOC.HEAD: House Votes to Overrides Bush Veto of Hatch Act
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs.
DOC.TEXT: The House voted overwhelmingly today to override President Bush's veto of legislation broadening the rights of millions of federal workers to participate in political campaigns. The 327-93 vote was well over the two-thirds majority needed to override the veto. The House action sets up an expected showdown Thursday in the Senate, where a close vote is expected. Bush vetoed the bill last Friday, saying it ``would inevitably lead to repoliticizing the federal work force'' and destroy the neutrality of civil servants fostered by the 1939 Hatch Act. The Democratic-controlled Congress has failed to override any of Bush's previous 11 vetoes. The bill would remove prohibitions that make it illegal for an estimated 3 million federal and postal workers to attend political conventions as delegates or speak at rallies on behalf of candidates. It would allow them for the first time to hold party offices and solicit contributions from co-workers on behalf of federal employee union political action committees while off the job. But it would continue to bar federal workers from taking leaves of absence to run for public elected office or solicit campaign funds from the public on behalf of candidates. ``Unlike all other workers or their neighbors for that matter, federal workers cannot legally take part in the most routine political activities, such as displaying yard signs or a bumper sticker, or stuffing envelopes,'' said Rep. William Ford, D-Mich., one of the bill's chief sponsors. Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo., recalled that early in her career she resigned a job as an attorney for the National Labor Relations Board after learning that ``I could not go to a caucus that my husband was holding in our living room.''
