Opponents, however, echoed Bush's suggestions in his veto message that, without the current Hatch Act protections, federal workers will be coerced into supporting candidates of one party or the other. Rep. Frank Wolf, R-Va., said the United States has developed the finest non-partisan and professional civil service in the world with the help of the law. ``Times have changed but the facts that made the Hatch Act necessary have not changed,'' said Wolf. ``Human nature has not changed. Whatever is permitted will become expected.'' The bill originally passed the Senate 67-30. Administration officials were lobbying to win over enough Republicans who supported the bill to sustain the veto. The heaviest pressure, according to congressional sources, was being focused on Republican Sens. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, Arlen Specter of Pennsylvania and Alfonse D'Amato of New York. All supported passage of the bill in May. More than half of the House's 176 Republicans, including GOP Leader Bob Michel of Illinois, bolted from the administration to support the veto override. The original law was passed in response to evidence that enrollees in job-creating public works programs of the New Deal era were being required to donate to Democratic campaigns.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Bishops to Meet for Retreat and Fun in the Sun
DOC.TEXT: More than 200 U.S. Roman Catholic bishops are meeting here this week for a private retreat. The gathering at Jesuit-run Santa Clara University comes as debate escalates over what tactics the National Conference of Roman Catholic Bishops should use to persuade Catholic politicians to fight abortion. The retreat, which begins Thursday and runs through June 27, is billed as a week of prayer, reflection and workshops around the topic of ``Bishop as Priest, Prophet and Leader.'' The clergy also will have time for pool-side sunbathing, golf and a Sunday picnic at a beach, organizers say. But it is likely that the recent controversy over abortion in politics will come up in the private talks. Cardinal John O'Connor of New York last week suggested in a church newspaper column that Catholic politicians who promote abortion rights ``must be warned that they are at risk of excommunication.'' He later said he never threatened to excommunicate anyone.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors End Meeting Looking to Renew Their Clout
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with mayor's ending meeting, endorsing lobbying agenda. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: The nation's mayors wrapped up their annual meeting today with a pledge to hold Washington accountable to city voters and signs of potential discord among their ranks. The talk was of bipartisanship as the U.S. Conference of Mayors installed Republicans in the organization's No. 1 and No. 3 posts. But in the middle is Boston Mayor Raymond Flynn, who made it clear that he wanted the mayors to take an aggressive stance against the Bush administration. ``This is the time to rock the boat,'' Flynn said. Colorado Springs Mayor Robert Isaac, the new president of the conference, said he hoped to strike a more cooperative relationship with the administration. ``We want to restore the partnership,'' he said. Democratic and Republican mayors alike said it was time for mayors to use their local political organizations against members of Congress who do not support cities. ``We're entitled to help from the federal government,'' said Atlanta Mayor Maynard Jackson. The mayors began their meeting five days ago with high hopes of drafting an urban agenda that counts on billions of dollars from the federal government. But they since have received word from two influential members of Congress that cities are unlikely to receive much, if any, of the peace dividend expected from cuts in defense. That message angered the mayors, who view Washington as increasingly indifferent to urban America's needs, and many vowed to bypass the Congress and take their case to the people. At the center of the populist appeal is the argument that Washington has ignored cities and their poor residents while doling out billions to rescue the savings and loan industry. After a decade of being told that the budget deficit prevented any new help for cities, the mayors point to the S&L bailout as proof Washington can find money when it has to. Now, the mayors say, they must improve their lobbying to make their voices heard in Washington. Some mayors are threatening to cause political trouble for members of Congress who do not go to the mat for cities. ``It is hard for us at times to speak with one voice,'' said Mayor Sharpe James of Newark, N.J. ``But the bigger problem is that mayors have allowed the Congress to become fat cats, smug, secure, assured of their positions. They're not fighting the real fights anymore.'' The meeting concluded with the formal endorsement of a broad new domestic lobbying agenda that calls for major increases in federal funding for housing, education, anti-drug, anti-poverty and other urban programs. New York's David Dinkins and Flynn believe a populist appeal can sway voters to support the mayors' agenda. ``We, the mayors of urban America, must send a message to Washington that only after we have housed our people, only after we have educated our young people, only after we have repaired our roads, and only after we heal our sick can we commit to the extravagant bailout of a corrupt system,'' Dinkins said Tuesday. ``Never underestimate the people,' said Flynn. One of the newer faces among the mayors, Milwaukee's John Norquist, said the mayors and their organization share the blame for the declining effectiveness in Washington. Too often, Norquist said, the mayors' appeals sound like requests for handouts. ``Pity doesn't get you much,'' he said. ``Pity usually leads to contempt.''

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Strip Ship Ready for Waters
DOC.TEXT: A Canadian cruise ship has come up with a new gimmick to attract passengers _ nude dancers. But U.S. officials say the Wayward Princess had better not live up to its name. If it strays onto the U.S. side of the border, the Princess could get busted. Canadian owner Jacques Beauchamp said sinking business led to his venture, which will operate six nights a week on the Detroit River between Detroit and Windsor, Ontario, and in Lakes Erie and St. Clair. ``Hey, it's going to be a fun thing to do, as long as the ship remains a clean ship,'' Beauchamp said Tuesday. The ship, which will serve alcohol, will feature male and female nude dancers on two different decks, said Beauchamp, 50, a Windsor cruise operator for the past six years. The cruiser, which will charge a $5 cover when anchored and $10 on the water, will be equipped with shades so passing boaters can't peep. If the Wayward Princess, licensed by Canada, crosses international waters, Beauchamp could be fined or imprisoned under Michigan's misdemeanor obscenity laws, said Police Officer Dan Smith of the Detroit Harbormaster's Section. ``Heck, this is something new,'' Smith said. ``But he'd probably be ticketed or arrested for indecent exposure.'' Windsor's licensing commissioner, Ronald Reaume, said the establishment met Ontario laws. ``Personally, I'd rather not see it. But we're not there to license the morality of the situation.'' Canadian police fought the licensing and said it will be difficult to enforce laws and ensure security aboard the 110-foot, 325-capacity vessel. ``Is our boat going to follow Jacques Beauchamp's boat just waiting for trouble to start?'' asked Windsor police Inspector Glenn Stannard. Beauchamp said he intends to run a tight ship. ``They say the first guy to start something could be very successful.''

DOC.HEAD: Nixon Birthplace Gives Vast Presidential Library Needed Perspective
DOC.TEXT: When the $21 million library documenting the life of Richard M. Nixon opens next month, the 37th chief executive will be flanked by ex-Presidents Reagan and Ford, and President Bush. The gathering will mark the first time since Bush's 1988 election that the four Republicans have joined together. ``This will be a truly historic occasion,'' library director Hugh Hewitt said in describing plans for the July 19 dedication ceremony. Former first lady Pat Nixon will also make her first public appearance in more than a decade, Hewitt said Tuesday during a media tour. The Nixons celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary on Thursday. The Richard M. Nixon Library & Birthplace, 30 miles southeast of Los Angeles, will be the first of two presidential libraries to open in Southern California. Reagan's library is set for a February opening in Simi Valley. The Nixon library, completed on schedule and under budget, rises prominently in the hilly community among homes valued up to $700,000. Unlike other presidential libraries, the 52,000-square-foot Nixon library won't be operated with taxpayer dollars. The sterile confines of the library offer a nostalgic look at Nixon, offering visitors paying $3.95 apiece a glimpse into the life of a man many consider a primary architect of domestic and world events. When visitors see the tiny home where Nixon was born, included on the library grounds, they will gaze at the piano he took lessons on as a child, the highchair he ate in as a baby and the bed on which he was born. The house is a kit-style home built in 1912 by Nixon's father, Frank. Other features of the Spanish-style library: _A 293-seat theater, where audiences will view the 28-minute film ``Never Give Up: Richard Nixon in the Arena.'' _An old television set showing Nixon's ``Checkers'' speech. _Monitors broadcasting the Nixon-John F. Kennedy television debates from the 1960 presidential election. _A world leaders room with life-size statues of Charles De Gaulle, Winston Churchill, Leonid Brezhnev and Nikita Khrushchev, among others. _The Domestic Gifts Room, showing some of the 30,000 items given the Nixons while they were in the White House. Included in the exhibit are Irving Berlin's original score of ``God Bless America'' and a pistol given Nixon by Elvis Presley. _The Watergate Hall, the second-largest display on the tour, including the Watergate tapes with such selections as John Dean's ``cancer in the White House'' declaration. ``The president has never shied away from a full and fair treatment of Watergate,'' Hewitt said. Nixon, who lives in Upper Saddle River, N.J., resigned the presidency Aug. 9, 1974, after revelations about his role in a botched burglary at Democratic headquarters at Washington's Watergate building during his 1972 re-election campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Banks See Sluggish Growth, Flat Inflation
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. economy is continuing to grow sluggishly although the construction sector appears to be weakening, according to a Federal Reserve survey released Wednesday. ``The tone of district reports suggests continued slow growth in the economy with little change in the underlying inflation rate,'' said a summary of the survey of the 12 Fed district banks. The survey, completed June 8, was similar to three polls conducted earlier this year that found slow but continued economic expansion with moderate inflation. It was conducted by the Cleveland district bank for use at the July 2-3 meeting of the central bank's Federal Open Market Committee, which establishes U.S. monetary policy. The Fed has kept a tight grip on credit to slow the economy and lessen inflationary pressure. Some officials and economists believe the economy has slowed too much and could slide into recession if the Fed does not loosen its grip. One sign of sluggishness, the survey found, was ``very little growth, if not a decline, in real consumer spending for durable and non-durable goods this quarter from last.'' Consumer spending accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity and has been a driving force for the economy for much of the last eight years since the last recession. ``Recent behavior in retail sales and reports from retailers in several districts indicate that sales have been slow in recent months and are expected to remain so in the short term,'' the summary said. Retail sales, about half of consumer spending, fell in May for the third consecutive month, the Commerce Department reported last week. The last time retail sales declined for three straight months was in the fall of 1981, during the last recession. The Fed said it was unclear how much unusual weather and other temporary factors contributed to the sales softness. ``Both residential and non-residential construction have been edging downward in recent months in most districts and indicators of future construction suggest further softening,'' the survey found. ``An underlying problem in commercial construction is an apparent excess supply of new office space in many parts of the country,'' particularly downtown Manhattan and in metropolitan areas of the Dallas district, the report said. Credit demand appears to be easing, but real estate, consumer and business loans are still growing, although at reduced rates, it said. ``Lenders are reported to have tightened standards especially for real estate loans, but there is still little information that suggests credit restraint is spreading to other markets,'' the survey found. It reported that manufacturing production has been relatively flat for several months. This sector has been particularly affected by the Fed's high-interest rate policies since many of its products are purchased with loans. However, several districts reported they expect manufacturing to strengthen despite softness in some industries including defense, building construction machinery and apparel. Automobile and related industries have been a drag on manufacturing in the Atlanta district, but Chicago and Cleveland respondents noted some strengthening in production that should add to total output this quarter and perhaps next. ``In contrast, the aerospace industry is a source of strength in several regions of the country (Boston, Minneapolis and San Francisco) and the energy sector is expanding (Dallas and Kansas City),'' it added. The survey found indications of continued growth in capital goods industries, another area of strength in recent months. ``Prospects for a good harvest this year should be improved as a result of ample rainfall in previously drought-stricken regions of the country,'' the survey found, ``but cool, wet weather has delayed planting by as much as several weeks.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Has Been on Grueling Schedule for Four Months
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's delayed arrival in the United States on Wednesday for lack of rest was not surprising considering the grueling schedule he has kept since being released from prison. The 71-year-old African National Congress leader is on his third international tour in four months. Between trips, he has kept up a non-stop routine of meetings with colleagues and opponents in South Africa and criss-crossed the country, appearing at rallies in every major city. Before leaving June 4 on the current six-week, 14-nation tour, Mandela spent a week in the hospital, getting rest as well as a check-up. During an extensive physical examination, a cyst was discovered on his bladder and he underwent an operation seven days before boarding the plane. As a former amateur heavyweight boxer, Mandela prides himself on being in exceptional physical condition for his age, and he worked hard at staying in shape during the 27 years he spent jailed for his action against South Africa's government. But many of those years were spent at hard labor with inadequate diet. Black prisoners were given one thin blanket and forced to wear short pants through much of the winter during Mandela's first years at Robben Island prison. ``I feel on top of the world,'' Mandela said at a June 2 hospital news conference. Journalists, however, said he looked tired. From the moment he stepped through the prison gates Feb. 11, Mandela has kept a schedule that leaves little time for rest. After a motorcade from the prison to the center of Cape Town, he waited hours to give his first speech from a balcony at City Hall. The next day he subjected himself to a lengthy international news conference and hours of meetings with ANC organizers and leaders. On Feb. 13, he flew to Johannesburg and presented himself to more than 100,000 people at a rally in Soweto, the black township outside Johannesburg. He wanted to go home to live in the tiny brick house he had rented in the township for 40 years. But after weeks of constant attention from neighbors, tourists, and journalists peering over his back wall, he moved into a hilltop mansion that his wife, Winnie, built in 1987. Still, Mandela has seldom had time alone with his family. He is constantly surrounded by bodyguards, aides and ANC officials. From Feb. 14 to 23, Mandela participated in all-day meetings with journalists, diplomats, churchmen, old friends and new anti-apartheid officials. He sat in his garden or his house and greeted visitors from morning until late at night for 10 days straight. On Feb. 25 he flew halfway across South Africa to address more than 100,000 people in sweltering Durban, then returned to Bloemfontein for an afternoon rally. Two days later, he made his first international tour since 1962, visiting exiled ANC members and holding talks with leaders in five African countries and in Sweden. He was elected to his old post as deputy president of the ANC and returned home with the added duties and expectations the title brought. The non-stop interviews and briefings continued until March 12, when the ANC announced that meetings with Mandela would be granted on a more selective basis. He flew to Namibia for the neighboring country's independence celebrations on March 21. He apologized to the U.S. and Soviet foreign ministers for making them come to him to talk because his schedule was so tight. Back in South Africa, he attended rallies March 23 and 26; visited hospitalized black marchers wounded by police March 28; and participated in two rallies at opposite ends of the country on March 29 and April 1. After three more rallies in three cities, Mandela met with President F.W. de Klerk in Cape Town on April 5, and then flew to Lusaka, Zambia, to consult with the ANC National Executive Committee on April 8. On April 11, he gave a news conference in Johannesburg; on April 14 flew to London for a concert in his honor; and on April 17 attended Zimbabwe's independence celebrations. He returned to Johannesburg April 21, and the next day flew to his homeland, Transkei, for visits with relatives _ and two more rallies. From May 2-4, Mandela led the African National Congress in talks with the government in Cape Town. During May, he made another tour of African nations, held three news conferences and three more rallies before entering the hospital.

DOC.HEAD: Honecker, in Rare Statement, Denies His Government Harbored Terrorists
DOC.TEXT: Former East German leader Erich Honecker denied Wednesday that his government harbored terrorists and blamed the charges on a campaign against the ``good reputation'' of his regime. The 77-year-old Honecker, in a rare public statement, defended what he said was his Communist government's pursuit of peace and battle against terrorism. ``Nothing in these accusations corresponds to reality,'' Honecker said in a statement released through the East German government news agency, ADN. His denial came after authorities arrested nine reputed members of the notorious Red Army Faction, a leftist group blamed for a series of bombings and killings in West Germany. All the suspects had phony identities and some said they were aided by members of Honecker's secret police. Some had been fugitives more than a decade. All were arrested during a two-week stretch beginning June 6 after West German authorities and East Germany's current democratic government launched a hunt for terrorist suspects. Honecker's comments were the latest entry in the furious debate over the terrorist ties of the old regime and the sinister espionage war between two nations about to unify. Western authorities have long alleged the East German government harbored, supported and perhaps trained terrorists. The West German newspaper Die Welt said Wednesday that East Germany's secret police knew in advance and ``tolerated'' a 1986 bomb attack on a West German disco by Libyan terrorists. Two U.S. soldiers and a Turkish woman were killed and 229 people were injured. Honecker defended his Stalinist government, which used the vast secret police network to maintain his iron-fisted rule for nearly two decades until it was toppled in October during the peaceful anti-Communist revolution. ``With the current campaign, apparently the good reputation of the (German Democratic Republic) as a stronghold of peace and the easing of tensions in the world is being undermined,'' the statement said. He said the campaign seeks to ``negate the peaceful relations between the German states'' that Honecker said he championed. East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel said Monday that harboring West German terrorists was the ``personal hobby'' of Honecker and his ousted security chief, Erich Mielke. The Red Army Faction waged a deadly terrorist war against West German capitalism and NATO in the 1970s and 1980s. The most recent victim, Deutsche Bank chief Alfred Herrhausen, was killed in a bombing attack in November. ``Like every other citizen, I have followed the arrests of the terrorists and their supporters in the press, radio and television,'' Honecker's statement said. ``As former chief of state of the (German Democratic Republic) I would like to declare before the German and international public that I and the former (Communist) party and state leadership of the GDR sharply condemned every form of terrorism on political and humanitarian grounds, and also took part in the struggle against international terrorism.'' Honecker is in failing health and living in a hospital in the town of Beelitz. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere, meanwhile, chided West German politicians for demanding that Honecker and other members of his government be extradited to West Germany to face charges allegedly committed during Honecker's leadership. He said anything that happened during Honecker's regime ``must be cleared up here and not elsewhere.'' ``We are still two sovereign states,'' he said in an interview Wednesday with the West German newspaper Bild. The two German states are to merge their economies July 2 and perhaps unify fully by year's end. But questions remain to be worked out over the vast differences in the legal systems of two countries. East Germany has turned down West German extradition requests for captured terrorists suspects in an apparent tiff over jurisdiction, and it remains unclear where they will be prosecuted.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: ``L.A. Law'' star Richard Dysart believes everybody should be treated equally by the law, and he has filmed two TV spots for the Oregon State Bar Association to say so. Dysart, who plays senior partner Leland McKenzie on the NBC-TV series, was in Lake Oswego on Tuesday filming the pubic service announcements. ``All of us, rich and poor, should receive fair treatment under the law,'' he says in one. In an interview, Dysart said the justice system is ``so complex that everyday I think thousands of people give up.'' Dysart said he thinks the public announcements will let people know what is available for them. ``You're telling somebody that justice is equal, and if they don't have money ... there is assistance,'' he said. The bar's Tel-Law program is a collection of recorded legal information messages prepared by lawyers. Each message is three to nine minutes long and provides basic information about a wide range of topics, including taxes, insurance and family law.

Sen. Strom Thurmond wants a $25 refund _ even if the money might be water over the dam. The 87-year-old Republican from South Carolina has requested a refund for a water deposit he paid in 1938 to the town of Lexington for some property he sold last year. The senator's staff mailed a letter, including the original receipt for the deposit, to the Lexington County treasurer seeking a $25 refund. The letter arrived last week, Mayor Eli Mack said Tuesday. Lexington is a town of 3,000, 13 miles west of Columbia. ``I was real amused, How in the hell can anyone save a receipt for 52 years,'' Mack said. ``This is the first request to go back that many years. I think it's rather cute.'' Thurmond, whose net worth is more than $2 million, believes he is entitled to the $25 because he sold the property, said his spokeswoman, Pam Montgomery. ``He needs money like anyone else,'' she said. Mack said Thurmond will have to live without the $25. Water deposits cannot be refunded, he said.

President Roh Tae-woo's only son was married at the presidential palace Wednesday morning in a ceremony conducted by Prime Minister Kang Young-hoon. Roh Jae-hon, 25, a student at the University of Chicago, was married to Shin Jung-hwa, a 22-year-old music student. The 200 guests included politicians, business associates and friends of the families. The bride is the daughter of Shin Myung-soo, president of Dongbang Corp., a large food company whose main product is cooking oil. Korean news reports said the couple expected to go to the United States in late June and would live in Chicago until Roh finishes his studies.

Former President Carter was met by protesters when he arrived at a low-income neighborhood to help build seven homes for impoverished families. About a dozen pickets who spoke to Carter before he and his wife, Rosalynn, started working on the project Tuesday objected to the number of homes that will be built on the 1{-acre site in southeast San Diego. About 200 volunteers are working on the project, which several neighborhood residents tried to stop in court because they believe the new homes would increase traffic congestion and lower property values. A Superior Court judge last week declined to grant an injunction that would have stopped the project. Carter said he was sympathetic to the residents' concerns, but added that he believes the project is worthwhile. ``I think that within a few months these concerns ... will be over and gone and forgotten,'' Carter said. ``They will find that they have seven wonderful new neighbor families and the community will accept them.'' Habitat for Humanity, based in Americus, Ga., has sponsored projects in more than 600 communities in 30 countries. The Carters have been involved in the organization since 1982.

DOC.HEAD: Boy Killed in Ramming, Chase on Freeway
DOC.TEXT: A boy died when he was thrown from a truck that was rammed at least eight times on three highways by another pickup during a terrifying 25-mile chase, police said Wednesday. Brandon Caldwell, 7, died after his 26-year-old uncle, Jeffrey Smith, lost control of the vehicle south of Dallas. Mark Dee Pluff, 31, of Dallas, has been charged with murder, attempted murder and driving while intoxicated, Police Sgt. Jim Chandler said. Police have no determined why Pluff, driving a pickup, rammed Smith's pickup twice on Interstate 635 north of Dallas about midnight. ``Smith decided that he was going to try to outrun the suspect'' and he started traveling southbound on Interstate 35, where Pluff rammed him at least three more times, Chandler said. Smith got to Interstate 30, where Pluff rammed the truck another three times. The last time, Smith lost control and the truck ran down an embankment, Chandler said. ``Brandon was thrown from the vehicle as it was rolling down the embankment,'' Chandler said. The boy was pronounced dead about 40 minutes later at Baylor University Medical Center, where Smith was listed in critical condition. Pluff remained at the accident scene and was arrested. He was taken to the Lew Sterrett Justice Center. Chandler said there was no indication that Pluff knew the victims or that Smith did anything that set Pluff off. Smith told police: ``If anything did occur, it was strictly an unintentional act.''

DOC.HEAD: Police Use Water Cannon on Striking Workers
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police used a water cannon to disperse hundreds of striking municipal workers Wednesday after chasing them down the street and ordering them repeatedly to end their illegal gathering. The approximately 400 workers were outside the Cape Town Civic Center when they were ordered to leave by police. They have been on strike for eight days, demanding higher pay. The water fired by police was mixed with a chemical substance that affects the eyes and skin. The South African Municipal Workers Union wildcat strike had been declared illegal by the Supreme Court. Earlier, 56 municipal workers were arrested by police outside the court, where a judge was considering whether to bar them from the Civic Center. Strikers staged a sit-in at the center earlier this week. The judge's decision was postponed until Thursday. In Johannesburg, meanwhile, 27 union leaders refused to leave the Department of Manpower regional offices they have occupied since Tuesday. The workers, affiliated with the Congress of South African Trade Unions and the National Council of Trade Unions, are demanding that the government introduce changes in the labor law before Parliament closes Friday. They want clauses in the controversial Labor Relations Act removed or amended. The Labor Relations Act has been the subject of a number of work stoppages, protests and union-initiated consumer boycotts in the past two years. Unions claim it undermines their ability to strike. The union groups and major employer organizations agreed Monday that it was possible to resolve conflict ``through discussion and compromise.'' The agreement was sent to Minister of Manpower Eli Louw with a request that he put the changes into legislation before Friday. ``We intend to embark on a program that will cause major chaos in the economy. This is an acid test of government's commitment to negotiations, a test of their good faith,'' said Jay Naidoo, general-secretary of the nation's largest labor federation, the Congress of South African Trade Unions. The African National Congress National Executive Committee is meeting for the first time in 30 years in South Africa. The committee began a two-day meeting in Johannesburg Wednesday in which it was expected to discuss the ANC's position on the process of negotiations. ANC official Chris Hani said the organization's armed struggle would continue, but it wished to contribute to a climate for a peaceful settlement. ``None of us want to destroy South Africa _ we don't like violence. I believe President (F.W.) de Klerk doesn't like violence. But we believe that together we must sit down and create a situation where we can say goodbye to violence,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Maine Man in Hot Water After Landing Huge Sturgeon
DOC.TEXT: A man who caught an Atlantic sturgeon roughly the size of basketball great Wilt Chamberlain had the fish seized by the state, and could be sentenced to a year in prison and fined $1,000. Roy Mann, who started out thinking Monday was his lucky day, ended up charged with fishing without a commercial license and illegally setting a net. Wildlife officials are also burned up because the sturgeon was pregnant and lots of babies were lost. Mann, 24, of South Berwick, caught the 300-pound sturgeon in the Salmon Fall River, which is overseen jointly by Maine and New Hampshire. He described the fish as the ``catch of the day, the year, the century.'' But his bragging caught the ear of local officials. They arrested him and called in the Maine Marine Patrol, who seized the fish. ``I'm not happy at all,'' said Jonathan Wright, New Hampshire Fish and Game Department Warden. ``A lot of potential sturgeons are dead.'' The big fish contained more than 30 pounds of eggs, officials said. Mann, undaunted by getting caught himself, continued to tell his big fish story. ``I started tugging. I thought it was a snapping turtle or a good-sized fish,'' he said. Mann said he had to borrow a rope from a nearby sewage treatment plant to pull the ``giant monster'' in and then hit it in the head with a hammer to kill it. The fish at 7-feet-8-inches, was 6 inches longer than Chamberlain, and outweighed him by 25 pounds during the basketball star's playing prime. Louis Flagg, the division director of the Maine Department of Marine Resources, said the fish was big by sturgeon standards, although they have been known to grow to 12 to 14 feet and weigh 1,000 pounds.

DOC.HEAD: Rock Star Stevie Nicks Wants to Adopt Baby
DOC.TEXT: After 15 years on the road with the tumultuous group Fleetwood Mac, singer Stevie Nicks says she has one regret: not having a baby. ``I'd like to be sharing all these experiences, and that makes me really sad. But I figure God has a plan, and if I'm meant to have that baby, I'll have her. Or him. And, if I'm meant to adopt one, I'll adopt it,'' Nicks, 42, says in the July 9 issue of US magazine. Her 15 years with Fleetwood Mac has been a fun-filled romp that had her romantically linked to numerous rocks stars _ including ex-Eagles member Don Henley. One rock star she wouldn't identify once summoned her to his side by sending a private jet to pick her up after one of Fleetwood Mac's concerts. ``I didn't join Fleetwood Mac until I was 27, and I never indulged in drugs of any kind, nothing. I didn't even drink,'' she said. ``And then all of a sudden, bang! Overnight I was in this gargantuan rock and roll band, of which half the members were English and used to spending at least three hours a day at the pub.'' ``You know at my age, what I've been through, I should look 65 years old. I feel like I look pretty good. And, uh, the excessive part of it no long exists in my life, and hasn't for four years.''

DOC.HEAD: Carter's Too Busy Helping Out to Collect Award
DOC.TEXT: Former President Carter was a no-show Wednesday when awards for public service were handed out. He was busy in Mexico helping build homes for poor people. ``I suppose that's as good a reason not to be at this little gathering as one could have,'' said Jody Powell, who was Carter's White House press secretary. Powell, in a ceremony at the Supreme Court, accepted in Carter's behalf the American Institute for Public Service's Jefferson Award for the former president's efforts for ``world peace, free elections in Nicaragua, and the needs of the homeless.'' National awards were also presented to: _Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, ``for helping restore democracy in Panama, and for strengthening America's image around the world.'' _Jaime Escalante, the Los Angeles high school mathematics teacher whose work with disadvantaged students was celebrated in a movie, ``for his special ability to inspire students to achieve national excellence.'' _Anne Donahue, executive director of Covenant House in California, ``for her tireless efforts in behalf of the homeless.'' Carter and his wife, Rosalynn, were in Tijuana, Mexico, where they were due on the job at 7 a.m., after spending the night in a tent, to work on a house being built by Habitat for Humanity. They have donated a week of their time to such work every year since 1984, four years after Carter, seeking a second term, was defeated by Ronald Reagan. Habitat for Humanity, a nonprofit Christian-oriented enterprise based in Americus, Ga., constructs housing for the poor and homeless in the United States and abroad. Recipients make interest-free mortgage payments. The Carters arrived Sunday in Tijuana, where Habitat is building 100 homes. They spent Tuesday in nearby San Diego, Calif., where the organization is building seven houses. ``President Carter is a skilled carpenter, so he does everything from roofing to putting up dry wall to whatever is required,'' Lloyd Mayer, press officer of the organization, said by telephone from Americus. ``And Rosalynn has become pretty adept at carpentry herself.'' Trip Pomeroy, Habitat's coordinator of public relations in San Diego, said by telephone that 1,220 construction volunteers were working on the San Diego and Tijuana projects. The Carters will take part in dedication of the houses on Saturday. ``On each site they have been assigned, like every other volunteer, to a particular crew and a particular house,'' said Pomeroy. ``They work extremely hard as a matter of fact.'' The former president and first lady worked on similar projects in New York in 1984 and 1985, Chicago in 1986, Charlotte, N.C., in 1987, Pittsburgh and Atlanta in 1988 and Milwaukee in 1989. Baseball Hall of Fame star Hank Aaron, a member of the institute's board of selectors, made the presentation to Carter, citing among other things his work for the housing group and the conflict resolution program at his Carter Center in Atlanta. ``Because of him, world leaders are talking to each other,'' Aaron said. ``Because of him, there are a few less homeless people in the world.'' The ceremony was held before a standing room only audience in the court's East Conference Room, lighted by crystal chandeliers and lined with portraits of past chief justices. Justice Byron White congratulated the winners.

DOC.HEAD: Newest Nation Wants One-Time Grants, Not Loans, to Build Economy
DOC.TEXT: The world's newest nation, Namibia, joins the queue of the world's poorest countries Thursday in asking prospective donor countries for start-up financing to build a new economy. Namibia approaches the U.N.-sponsored donors' conference in New York as a bad candidate for international aid, not because it is too poor but because, on the surface, it appears rich. Grants, not loans, will be the theme of Namibia's plea. President Sam Nujoma and other government officials want to redirect social spending toward the vast majority of poor people without borrowing huge amounts of foreign money. They want one-time grants to use as start-up funds for self-generated development of their country, which became independent from South Africa on March 21. With only 1.3 million people in a country almost as large as western Europe, Namibia has an annual per capita income of $1,200, making it the richest country in sub-Saharan Africa. But the majority of Namibia's people live in poverty, and 5 percent _ the whites _ have most of the wealth. Namibia has the highest number of tarred roads per capita in the world, and the best ratio of hospital beds per person in Africa. Water is clean in most places, the telephones work, and its public administration is on par with the developed world. It's constitution had been praised by leaders throughout the world as one of the most democratic documents ever devised, and its government and people are _ at least for the present _ committed to a multi-party democracy and a mixed economy. The United Nations, which shepherded Namibia to independence by supervising its elections last year, and the World Bank have said the fledgling nation has the potential to become a model for peace and prosperity in Africa. But illiteracy stands at 60 percent. Housing is scares, teachers are underqualified, and aside from commercial farmland, the rural areas are virtually undeveloped. Thirty percent of the population is unemployed. Armed ex-soldiers of the former colonial army and the guerrilla forces of the now-ruling party are posing an increasing threat to civil order. The new government says it is under severe pressure to ``address the equity problem at an acceptable pace to the hitherto disenfranchised and neglected majority without jeopardizing growth'' or further neglecting its highly developed infrastructure. Independence itself has brought new expenditures, such as United Nations membership fees, embassies and the creation of a central bank and new currency by 1992. The government also faces a severe inherited fiscal problem. To serve its white constituency, the South African government created an excessively overstaffed public administration. It financed the wage bill and public debt through higher taxes. That was at the expense of public investment, which has steadily shrunk to minimal levels over the past decade and is partly responsible for the current depressed economy. The Namibian government, together with the World Bank and the United Nations Development Program, have devised a one-time investment program consisting of 83 individual priority projects totalling $400 million to set the stage for future self-sustained development. The World Bank has recommended that most of the aid be given as direct grants, so as not to give the new country a foreign debt problem at its birth. But direct grants are normally allocated only to the world's least developed nations, and so far, Namibia has failed to qualify as one of those.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists to Converge on Northern California
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with picketing. Picks up 4th graf, `Environmentalists say...'.
DOC.TEXT: A small group of environmentalists and labor activists picketed today outside a logging mill, kicking off a series of ``Redwood Summer'' protests against the cutting of California's grand redwoods. About 35 to 40 environmentalists and members of the International Workers of the World gathered at the Louisiana Pacific plant's front gate to protest clear-cut logging and exportation of logs to Mexico for cheaper processing. ``I feel strongly about this. I came up here to make a strong statement that I support the environment,'' said one picket, David Solnit, 26, a carpenter from San Francisco, 220 miles to the south. There was one pro-company demonstrator, Duane Plant of Eureka, who was carrying a sign that read, ``Say No to Terrorist. Stop Earth First!'' ``They scare me,'' Plant said. ``I am afraid of getting hurt. I am afraid of my kids getting hurt. I can't believe they're not violent.'' The picketing was to be followed by rallies in this tiny coastal community near Eureka. The events are part of a Redwood Summer series of protests planned for Northern California by the group Earth First! Environmentalists say the protests were inspired by the Freedom Summer of 1964, when civil rights activists converged on Mississippi. Mainstream environmental groups have distanced themselves from the demonstrations; the Sierra Club has refused to endorse the plans and the Wilderness Society has denounced them. Both timber industry and environmental sources refused to estimate how many protesters would participate. ``There will be rallies, there will be a labor picket line in the morning, there may be some civil disobedience,'' said Mickey Dulas, spokeswoman for the Northcoast Environmental Center in Arcata. ``But we are committed to non-violence.'' The protests have raised tensions along the state's rugged North Coast, where the economy is based largely on timber and tourism. Tensions were heightened by a May 24 bomb blast in Oakland that injured Earth First! leaders Judi Bari and Darryl Cherney in a car. It has not been determined whether they were victims of a bomber or were transporting the explosive when it went off.

DOC.HEAD: East German Church Determined to Recover Lost Treasures
DOC.TEXT: The Rev. Friedemann Gosslau said his heart soared when he heard that medieval artworks belonging to his church are believed to be in a Texas bank. He has complete faith priceless objects that disappeared in 1945 at the end of World War II will be found and restored to his 500-member parish and Quedlinburg's 12th-century cathedral. ``We must defend the interests of the church. When the pieces are here again, we will show them, but this time we'll need help with security,'' Gosslau said with a smile. The treasures, among Germany's most famous artworks, are the subjects of an international struggle. The Lutheran church in Quedlinburg has filed suit in Texas to try to recover a collection that includes a silver, ivory and gold reliquary from the 9th or 10th century, a 10th-century Byzantine rock-crystal flask with sides shaped like birds, and an ivory comb inlaid with precious stones. It is believed the works were taken to Whitewright, Texas by the late Joe T. Meador, a former Army lieutenant who served in Quedlinburg in 1945. During the war, the objects were removed from the Romanesque cathedral to a mine shaft to keep them safe from Allied bombing. They disappeared in 1945. Gosslau came to Quedlinburg 25 years ago and learned about the missing works by studying cathedral archives. ``I thought maybe we'd find traces and then convince the people to give the pieces back peacefully. I dreamed of it, but I never counted on it,'' Gosslau said in an interview in his home. The Lutheran minister said it was always thought the missing pieces could have been taken by ordinary Germans during the chaotic end of the Third Reich; by Nazi SS forces who seized the cathedral at the start of the war; or by the American soldiers who occupied the town. Then in May there was news that a private West German foundation that searches for stolen artworks had recovered a 9th-century illuminated manuscript of the Four Gospels. ``We had no idea where it was. It's fantastic news and it's sure it comes from the church because it is described in the inventory,'' Gosslau said. A second illuminated manuscript also noted in church archives was recovered in June. Full details of how those works were recovered have not been made public and they have not been returned to the church. A federal judge Tuesday ordered the First National Bank of Whitewright to open its vault for inventory by the cathedral. ``We were proud of what we have, and about what we didn't have anymore,'' Gosslau said. ``The cathedral treasure is small, but it is exquisite.'' He would like any pieces found in Texas to join the rest of the treasure that is kept in glass cases in the cool stone vault constructed in the Middle Ages to hold the priceless objects. The part of the collection still in Quedlinburg is a dazzling display that includes a Syrian vase brought back by crusaders, a 4th-century translation of the Bible, and a 13th-century gem-encrusted illimunated manuscript. In the Middle Ages, the vault guard was a nun trained to watch over the works, which were used in services that the royal family attended. Tourists taking the cathedral's guided tour are allowed to look at the treasure vault, a small room with tiny windows at the top of a staircase on the edge of the nave. During a tour this week, the guide did not mention the lost treasures. Nor were they mentioned in the small guidebook to the church on sale at the entrance. The town had no chance to seek recovery of the lost valuables once it became part of East Germany in 1949. Contact was limited until the country's former Communist leaders opened the country's borders last year. ``We knew the crates were broken into and some things taken away. But we didn't know where they went,'' said Walter Gold, the city's cultural adviser. ``Because the world was divided, we had no contact with the West so we couldn't do anything about it.'' The remains of Heinrich I, Germany's first king, and his wife Mathilde are buried inside the cathedral. Heinrich I died in 936. While the cathedral is still state property, Gosslau maintains that according to old laws the treasure belongs to the parish and should be returned to the vault.

DOC.HEAD: Nelson Mandela Arrives in New York For U.S. Tour
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to update with ticker-tape parade. Picks up 10th graf, `Mandela's arrival. DELETES grafs 14-15, `Among the..., and grafs 19-20, `In New York...', to remove outdated material.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5, XJFK1, XJFK2
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela, a freedom fighter who became one of the world's most celebrated political prisoners, arrived in the United States today looking for money and moral support for his battle against apartheid. Mandela, accompanied by his wife Winnie, waved to a cheering crowd as he stepped off an airplane at John F. Kennedy International Airport. They stopped at a Brooklyn high school before a ticker-tape parade up Broadway to City Hall. During a welcoming ceremony, the African National Congress leader called for a continuation of economic sanctions against his homeland and offered a word of thanks to his American supporters. ``The sanctions should be maintained,'' Mandela said. ``We are saying so because sanctions were introduced for the purpose of dismantling apartheid, and are making sure that every South African _ black and white _ is able to determine his own future.'' New York City is the first stop of Mandela's 12-day, eight-city U.S. tour. He was greeted by his daughter, Zenani; Gov. Mario Cuomo, the Rev. Jesse Jackson; Mayor David Dinkins; entertainer Harry Belafonte; and hundreds of supporters and well-wishers. ``It is a great privilege for me to welcome you and Mrs. Mandela. You honor us with your presence,'' Cuomo told Mandela. Mandela and his wife were given scarves in the ANC colors of black, green and gold, which they put around their necks. ``I sincerely feel very strong and encouraged, because if in our struggle we receive the support of the youth of the world, then our cause can never fail, can never be lost,'' Mandela told the 10,000 packed into the high school's football field. Mandela rode along the parade route in what police called the Mandelamobile, a flatbed truck with a bulletproof box on the back. Thousands of police and federal and state agents protected him. Mandela's arrival in New York was pushed back nearly two hours because trip organizers said the 71-year-old leader needed more rest. Some private meetings scheduled for tonight were also canceled. Mandela is in the midst of a six-week tour of 14 nations in Africa, Europe and North America that began June 6 _ one day after he was discharged from a Johannesburg hospital after surgery to remove a cyst from his bladder. Along with the festivities celebrating the end of Mandela's 27-year imprisonment in South Africa will be meetings with business, religious and political leaders. Mandela, making his first U.S. visit, is scheduled to speak at the United Nations and meet in Washington with President Bush. His message: keep the economic sanctions and international pressure in place until the white South African government gives up its monopoly on power and ends all vestiges of racial segregation. Mandela's release from prison Feb. 11 was part of a program of social reforms by the government of President F.W. de Klerk that included legalizing the ANC and other anti-apartheid groups. De Klerk also has opened talks with black groups on giving a political voice to the country's 28 million blacks. South Africa's 5 million whites control the government and economy. In Canada on Tuesday, Mandela appealed to students at a Toronto high school to raise funds to help black youth in his South African homeland. He said they get an education ``far inferior to whites,'' and that those who have spoken out ``have have been crushed with force'' by the white-minority government. On the eve of his arrival, about 100 protesters gathered at the mayor's official residence to condemn Mandela's pro-Palestinian comments. But the protest leader, Rabbi Avi Weiss, tempered his criticism with kind words for Mandela's anti-apartheid leadership. Another controversy surrounded the concert and rally Thursday at city-owned Yankee Stadium. Tickets to the fund-raiser for the ANC were $5 to $500. Rock promoter Bill Graham pulled out as organizer, citing disagreements with city officials. Tour organizers, in turn, blamed Graham for poor ticket sales. About 20,000 of 45,000 tickets had been sold by late Tuesday. Also planned were a street rally in Harlem on Thursday, breakfast with business leaders Friday at the World Trade Center and a $2,500-a-person fund-raiser Friday night, catered by actor Robert De Niro's restaurant. Mandela leaves Saturday for Boston. The trip continues with stops in Washington, Atlanta, Miami, Detroit, Los Angeles and Oakland, Calif. He leaves the United States on July 1.

DOC.HEAD: Newborn Tips the Scales at 14 Pounds, 3 Ounces
DOC.TEXT: Allen James Roughton entered the world in a big way. He tipped the scales at 14 pounds, 3 ounces after being delivered by Caesarean section at Queen of the Valley Hospital at 11:40 a.m. Tuesday. Allen was far less than the 22-pound babies listed in the Guinness Book of World Records, but ``he's the largest I've ever had in my practice,'' said Dr. Henry Moghtader, a 32-year veteran who delivered Allen two weeks before the due date because of his weight. The parents, Bryce, 32, and Laura, 31, have already nicknamed him Pudge and say he may have already outgrown his baby garments. ``We have packages of (newborn size diapers) that will have to go back to the store,'' the father said. ``We're using mediums on him now.''

DOC.HEAD: Document Carried Off by Tornado 33 Years Ago Turns Up in Mail
DOC.TEXT: Thirty-three years after being swept away by a tornado, John Hook's birth certificate arrived in his mother's mail. ``It was thrilling,'' Martha Hook said. ``I called John right way, and I was just shaking. I said to him, `Isn't it a blessing that now you know you were legitimate, and now we have the truth.''' The certificate confirmed what John Akeley Hook already knew _ that he was born on April 1, 1934, in Omaha, Neb. It had been carried away along with many other items from the Hook household in a tornado that struck Fargo on June 20, 1957. ``We lost anything that was loose,'' said Mrs. Hook, who was out of town at the time of the storm. ``It was just sucked out and went sailing.'' Last week, she received a letter from Ruth Swanson, a former Fargo resident who now lives in Moorhead, Minn. Inside was her son's birth certificate _ torn and dirty but still legible, even to the baby's footprints and Mrs. Hook's thumbprints on the back. In the enclosed letter of explanation, Swanson said she was cleaning out old papers recently when ``I came across an old envelope of pieces of paper that landed in our back yard the night of the tornado that struck Fargo some 30 years ago. ``It may not be of any importance at this late date, but I thought you should be the judge.''

DOC.HEAD: Two Networks Refuse `Simpsons' Ads
DOC.TEXT: ``The Simpsons'' may be the best-known, most hyped family on television. But you won't see them on ABC or NBC. Both networks have refused to air commercials featuring the animated characters selling Butterfinger candybars. Now the two networks say they also won't show an upcoming Burger King ad campaign starring the bug-eyed family. Of the Big Three, only CBS approved the advertisements. All three prohibit commercials featuring actors on the set of competing shows, but CBS has issued a statement saying animated characters are OK, as long as they don't mention the name of their program. ``The Simpsons'' show is broadcast by Fox network.

DOC.HEAD: Pentagon Delayed Discovery of Mexican Border Drug Tunnel
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `Pentagon spokesman....', to include full quote from Hart and to remove attribution of six week delay to him.
DOC.TEXT: Delays at the Pentagon held up discovery of a Mexican border drug smugglers' tunnel for six weeks, allowing cocaine to pour through the passage into Arizona, according to a published report. Just days after finding the northern end of the passage in Douglas, Ariz., federal agents intercepted a shipment of more than one ton of cocaine. ``Nobody thought there was a delay,'' Pentagon spokesman Maj. Doug Hart said, according to today's editions of the Los Angeles Times. ``It went through regular channels.'' Despite a high-profile Administration effort to use the military in drug interdiction, the Pentagon's slow response raised questions about the effectiveness of the policy. ``They announce that drugs are a major national security threat and then this takes six weeks?'' the Times quoted an unidentified official as asking. ``What the heck is going on here?'' Customs officials said they couldn't say how much cocaine passed through the tunnel between mid-March, when agents in Arizona asked for military assistance in finding the passage, and late April, when the equipment arrived. The tunnel, which led to Agua Prieta, Mexico, was found in mid-May and the shipment of more than one ton of cocaine was stopped a few days later. Thomas McDermott, the U.S. Customs Service agent in charge of the inquiry, said the tunnel was probably ``a major artery'' for northward-bound drugs. The Customs Service learned of the tunnel in November but could not find it. In March, the agency learned of a seismic detection device being developed by the military, and asked for help from Joint Task Force Six, a new military group for border narcotics missions. The Custom Service's request, labeled urgent, was passed up the chain of command from the task force to the Joint Chiefs of Staff, the nation's highest military office. Stanley E. Morris, deputy director of the Office of National Drug Control Policy, called the lag unfortunate, but said top-level Defense Department review is needed to guard against missions that might unnecessarily anger the Mexican government or deplete military stocks. ``As folks become more comfortable with what we're doing, I think it won't have to go up to Joint Chiefs of Staff level,'' said Col. Thomas C. Carter, deputy commander of the joint task force. The task force may operate only on the 300 miles of the 1,900-mile U.S.-Mexico frontier that is public land. Military patrols along the rest of the border must be conducted by the National Guard.

DOC.HEAD: On Premier's Orders, Language Guardians Do Some Finetuning
DOC.NOTE: EDS: SUB 12th graf, `There will...' to replace dashes with parenthesis to avoid garble. ^By ELAINE GANLEY
DOC.TEXT: The guardians of French, who spend much of their time defending the purity of their mother tongue, have conceded it contains ``absurdities, uncertainties and anomalies'' and issued 15 pages of spelling corrections. The government-requested overhaul proved that spelling is ``a national psychodrama,'' the daily newspaper Liberation said. Premier Michel Rocard, who requested the spelling review last year, on Tuesday accepted the changes submitted by the High Council on the French Language. He ordered that the new spellings be taught in all schools starting next year. He also ordered a meeting of dictionary specialists, publishing houses, the press and all those dealing with the written word to find the best way to make the new spellings the norm. ``It was never a question that the government legislate in such matters. The language belongs to those who use it,'' Rocard said. ``But it is up to the government ... to favor that usage which appears most satisfactory.'' Anticipating a collective shudder from the citizenry, the High Council offered reassurances. The new spellings would, for example, change no more than two words on two full pages of Proust's ``La Pleiade.'' Small comfort to schoolchildren, parents and teachers, said an association of university professors, who predicted that some words would have two different spellings for years to come. ``Once again, students, parents and teachers will be disoriented and finish by accepting no rules at all,'' said the Societe des Agreges. ``Under the pretext of correcting fancied anomalies, new ones are being introduced.'' The High Council said it was not reforming the language, only making ``certain rectifications of absurdities ... uncertainties ... and anomalies'' that ``troubled the experts themselves.'' The five categories of changes affect the hyphen, accent marks, the plural form of compound words, accordance of the past participle in reflexive verbs and a potpourri of anomalies. The hyphen, much used in French, is going out of style, according to the sages, who are all but discarding it. Even the hyphen used in English words like ``cow-boy,'' ``strip-tease'' or ``week-end'' will disappear. There will be fewer circumflexes (
DOC.HEAD: ) in the new French. The
DOC.TEXT: ``accent grave,'' the left to right slash above certain letters, will be ``generalized,'' removing the many exceptions under which it is applied. More drastic changes do away with the feminine ``e'' or plural ``s'' when according past participles with reflexive verbs _ in certain cases. And the second half of compound words, when plural, will always end in ``s,'' while the first half will lose the ``s.'' The Academie Francaise, whose 40 ``immortals'' are the ultimate arbiters of the French language, approved the changes, along with the Councils of the French Language of the French Communities of Belgium and Quebec. The French language has always been a reverent issue here, and successive governments have tried to stamp out Anglicisms and other impurities, sometimes resorting to fines for offenders. Last week, President Francois Mitterrand, a vociferous defender of his mother tongue, complained that English was supplanting French in the European Community. Mitterrand said ensuring the place of French as an official EC language was a top priority of his government, and added that France was prepared to help the EC ``enable its employees to acquire the linguistic competence needed to perform their missions.'' But the university professors said the spelling changes would defeat that cause. ``Once again, the error is being made that French is no longer a universal language because it is too difficult. English has become a spoken language around the world,'' the group said, ``despite the fact that its spelling is unchanged and often without logic.''

DOC.HEAD: Walesa: `I Will Have To Be President'
DOC.TEXT: Lech Walesa said in an interview Wednesday that he must become president to preserve Poland's new democracy and prevent his former allies in Solidarity from forming a dangerous power monopoly. The union leader challenged his former friends in Warsaw who now oppose him to start a separate ``center-left'' political party, and relinquish using the broad label of Solidarity. ``I do not want to be president. (But) I will have to be president,'' Walesa said in the interview in Gazeta Wyborcza, Poland's largest newspaper. As president, Walesa said, he would not oppose the government of Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki, but he would use presidential decrees to ``put the problems of our country in order.'' Specifically, he would intervene to stop holdover Communist officials from purloining state property they still control. Walesa said he is waging political war because he is in ``deadly fear'' that a new power monopoly is being formed by his former Solidarity allies who control the government, parliament and media. ``Now I will create ... a war at the top. It is a war that I want to win,'' Walesa said. ``What is really needed right now is patience,'' responded Solidarity parliamentary leader Bronislaw Geremek, one of the former allies targeted by Walesa. Asked by Radio Solidarity about Walesa's comments, Geremek said Poland's success ``is possible only when we have patience and hope.'' ``I think that Mr. Walesa at the moment is unaware that by means of his way of thinking, way of talking, declarations, he creates danger for this very weak democracy we have achieved in Poland,'' Geremek said. In recent months, open conflict has erupted between Walesa at union headquarters in Gdansk and the East bloc's first non-Communist government in Warsaw. The government was created by Solidarity and led by Mazowiecki, who like Geremek was among Walesa's closest advisers for nearly a decade. Walesa says his motive is political pluralism, the framing of distinct parties to push the reform process faster now that a united Solidarity no longer faces a united Communist foe. ``I am in deadly fear of a monopoly, not of my friends but of their successors _ that once again I will be in prison and my children, for sure, because every monopoly ends up like that,'' Walesa said. A new political group, the Center Alliance, backs Walesa for president. On Tuesday, Walesa met with Peasant Party representatives who could offer substantial support. Like Walesa, the Center Alliance says it wants to speed change in Poland and accuses Mazowiecki's government and Geremek's parliament caucus of acting too slowly to oust former Communists from positions of power. Government supporters, including many long-term Solidarity figures, are trying to form a counter-alliance out of local Citizens Committees that ran Solidarity's parliament campaign last year. The still-unnamed federation rejects political labels but advocates stability and unity to support the government while dramatic economic reforms are under way. It wants to calm fears among Westerners considering investment in Poland. The continued presence in the government of President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the former head of the now-dissolved Communist Party, symbolizes the dispute. The general who declared martial law against Solidarity was given the post to smooth the transition in once-historic reform agreements now overtaken by the breadth of change in Eastern Europe. Jaruzelski's term runs to 1995, but a new constitution could change that date. It is widely expected that presidential elections will occur no later than next spring. Although nominally in charge of the army, Jaruzelski has been a largely ceremonial head of state and has done nothing to block the Mazowiecki government. But Walesa said that ``we need a president with an axe: decisive, sharp, forthright.'' ``If this axe is supposed to undercut this fledgling Polish democracy, I would be against it,'' Geremek said. Walesa also alluded to suggestions printed in Gazeta Wyborcza that he is not refined enough to be president. ``Criticism that I do not know how to talk with presidents?'' Walesa asked. ``I have talked to them and they want to talk with me.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bush Suspends Dialogue with PLO
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Combines pvs
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today suspended an 18-month dialogue with the Palestine Liberation Organization, saying the group had failed to forcefully condemn an unsuccessful May 30 terrorist attack against Israel. Bush said the United States cannot maintain contact with the PLO ``as long as this terroristic act is sticking in our throat.'' He called on the PLO to ``satisfy us that those who are responsible'' would be disciplined. Bush conceded that his decision might prompt renewed violence in the region. He said he hoped that wouldn't be the case and added, ``I would like to see the peace process move forward.'' ``We've given the PLO ample time to deal with this issue,'' Bush said at a news conference at the Marshall Space Flight Center. Bush has called on PLO Chairman Yasser Arafat previously to condemn the May 30 raid. He said a general PLO statement denouncing attacks against civilians was ``not sufficient'' to meet U.S. terms for a continuation of the diplomatic talks. ``At any time the PLO is prepared to take the necessary steps, we are prepared to resume the dialogue,'' he said. Bush called on all parties in the Middle East to eschew violence and said, ``I would like to see the peace process move forward.'' Bush called the May 30 attempted attack a ``seaborne terrorist infiltration'' and said, ``the size of the force and the geographic target strongly indicated that civilians would have been the target.'' Bush had urged Arafat to disavow the assault and to discipline those who sent two speedboats filled with Palestinian fighters toward Tel Aviv, where they were spotted by radar and intercepted by the Israeli navy 20 miles offshore. The Palestine Liberation Front, a faction of the PLO headed by Abul Abbas, claimed responsibility for the attack, in which four guerrillas were killed and 12 captured. At the same time, Bush said the dialogue begun in the final months of the Reagan administration had contributed ``to progress in the peace process.'' He said the United States is prepared to resume contacts with the PLO one day. ``We are committed to a comprehensive settlement,''he said. He added that any peace process must recognize Israel's security and Palestinian rights. Bush recently wrote Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir, who heads a newly formed government, in an effort to revive the process. Through an emissary, Israeli Cabinet Secretary Eliakim Rubinstein, the government in Jerusalem has promised to pursue peace with the Arabs. On other subjects, Bush: _ Said he does not plan a ``bold new initiative'' to help the ailing Soviet economy. He said his administration stands ready to talk with allies who reportedly favor a costly plan to assist Mikhail S. Gorbachev's program of economic reform. _ Defended his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, for his comments on Tuesday critical of Democrats on the savings and loan bailout issue. He said Fitzwater was ``responding to a couple of shots across my bow'' on the subject. He said he hopes to work with Congress to fix the difficulties, and said ``active prosecution is under way'' of those who violated the law. _ Said he would tell Nelson Mandela next week that American sanctions against South Africa will remain in place until conditions fixed under law are met. He also paid a tribute to South African President F.W. de Klerk ``for what he's done'' to start dismantling apartheid. ``He's come a long way,'' Bush said. The Israeli Embassy issued a statement praising Bush's suspension of the PLO talks. ``Israel believes that the administration's decision will enhance and promote the peace process and will encourage those Palestinians seeking peace with Israel to seize upon this opportunity to begin a direct dialogue with Israel,'' the embassy said. In New York, the PLO envoy to the United Nations said he would reserve comment on reports the United States will sever its dialogue with the PLO until the government makes an official announcement. Zehdi Labib Terzi, permanent observer of what the United Nations calls Palestine, said he could not respond until he reads the official statement. U.N. officials said that Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar would not comment in advance of the official announcement. The United Nations considers the PLO to be the sole legitimate representative of the Palestinian people. Rep. William Broomfield, R-Mich., the senior Republican on the House Foreign Affairs Committee, said Bush's decision was ``the only one he could have made under the circumstances.'' ``America must let Arafat know that the PLO can't talk peace and wage war at the same time,'' he said in a statement. ``President Bush was wise to suspend rather than terminate the talks. Arafat should know that the United States is still willing to cooperate in the search for peace, but not under the barrel of a gun.'' The dialogue with the PLO was established by the Reagan administration in December 1988 after Arafat, at the urging of the United States, disavowed terrorism and recognized Israel's existence. Talks have been held since then outside Tunis, the PLO headquarters, between PLO officials and Robert Pelletreau Jr., the U.S. ambassador to Tunisia. The State Department, in a report to Congress in March, said the PLO was adhering to its commitment. Palestinian groups have launched nearly 30 border and rocket attacks against Israel since the talks began. But, the report said, ``we have no evidence in those cases or any others that the actions were authorized or approved by the PLO Executive Committee or by Arafat personally.'' Abbas is a member of the committee. A number of talks were held by Pelletreau with PLO officials since May 30. But U.S. peacemaking efforts in the Middle East have been stalled for months over Israeli objections to the American formua for negotiations. The 1988 U.S. opening to the PLO boosted the prestige of Arafat and his organization. In putting together a framework for negotiations the Bush administration consulted with the PLO, mostly through Egypt.

DOC.HEAD: Tight Democratic Runoff For Governor Heated By Name-Calling
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Republican Gov. Guy Hunt billed President Bush as the feature attraction at a fund-raiser Wednesday, but for Alabama voters the real show now is the broiling Democratic gubernatorial runoff. It has been a free-swinging, name-calling, political slugfest, replete with whiffs of marijuana smoke and allusions to Adolf Hitler and a convicted child molester. Beneath blazing skies, state teacher lobbyist Paul Hubbert and Attorney General Don Siegelman have exchanged rhetorical blows since the June 5 primary when Hubbert led Siegelman by 49,000 votes. The winner of Tuesday's runoff will move on to the November election against Hunt, the first Republican governor of Alabama in 112 years. Siegelman struck first following the primary when he accused Hubbert of defending incompetent teachers, including a convicted child molester, and making ``worthless promises'' that would double the state budget and cost $10 billion in new taxes. Hubbert, in turn, linked Siegelman rhetorically to Hitler and to Jane Fonda, who is still reviled by many Alabamans for her anti-war protests during the Vietnam War. He also indirectly reminded voters that the state attorney general admitted smoking marijuana briefly in college. Hubbert began carrying a mop and buket on the campaign trail, saying it was time for Siegelman to clean up his act. On the eve of Bush's arrival in Huntsville for the Hunt re-election fund-raiser, Hubbert and Siegelman called a truce, at least temporarily. The temperature was 98 degrees at the state capital, but in nearby Prattville the two Democratic runoff opponents talked coolly of Democratic unity. The setting was an Autauga County Democratic Club forum. ``No matter what the outcome, I pledge I'm going to get behind the Democratic ticket,'' said Hubbert. ``I hope to lead it, but if not I'm going to get behind it.'' ``I know that Paul Hubbert and Don Siegelman are going to do what we can to make sure there is a Democratic Party victory in November,'' said Siegelman. Hubbert, 54, and Siegelman, 44, are depicted by Hunt as liberals. But both have stressed their conservatism while calling for more progressive and dynamic leadership in Montgomery. And both have relied heavily on negative advertising. Siegelman is making Bobby Sanders the Willie Horton of the Alabama runoff. Horton is the convicted Massachusetts murderer who unwittingly played a prominent role in the 1988 presidential race. Sanders, convicted of sodomizing teen-age boys in Tennessee, was provided legal counsel by the Alabama Education Association in 1985 when he fought his firing as a teacher in Huntsville. Sanders was entitled to the counsel through his membership in the teacher organization. But Siegelman repeatedly has raised the case in ads and speeches. ``Many of our children are going without books, science labs and decent facilities,'' said Siegelman. ``Yet we have to spend our taxpayer money to keep child abusers out of classrooms. Mr. Hubbert, that's dead wrong.'' Hubbert said Siegelman's tactics bring to mind Hitler's ``big lie'' tactic of boldly repeating a falsehood until it is accepted as truth. In another campaign salvo, Siegelman said Hubbert's promises would cost Alabama taxpayers $1 billion in new taxes over four years. To that, Hubbert said, ``One must wonder what he was smoking that may have caused him to come up with those numbers.'' That was a thinly disguised allusion to Siegelman's marijuana admission. Siegelman spokesman Rick Dent called it a ``cheap shot.'' Hubbert also pointed out that Siegelman received a 1986 campaign contribution from a group that included Ms. Fonda; Siegelman said he sent the money back. Dr. William Stewart, a political science professor at the University of Alabama who is co-author of a 1988 book on Alabama politics, said the 1990 runoff is not unusual in its viciousness. But he said it could hurt the Democratic nominee in the general election. ``The level of rhetoric has reached the point where the main beneficiary, in my opinion, is Guy Hunt,'' Stewart said.

DOC.HEAD: Grave Robbery Tied to Dungeons and Dragons Game
DOC.TEXT: Five men have been charged with robbing a grave and using the body of a suicide victim as the centerpiece for a black-robed ceremony in a fantasy game of Dungeon and Dragons. The men were arrested Monday and Tuesday, and charged with stealing the body of 20-year-old Steven Glen Morgan, Columbia County Sheriff Tom Tramel said. Morgan's body, missing one leg, was found last month in a wooded area in adjacent Union County. Morgan's mother later found the leg, propped against a tree in the same woods, authorities said. Tramel said investigators do not think the leg was intentionally separated from the body. Tramel said the five gathered frequently to play Dungeons and Dragons, a fantasy game in which players pretend to be characters with great strength or magical powers as they participate in a quest of their own devising. ``We believe that the motive was due to their involvement with Dungeons and Dragons, which they have been involved in for quite some time and that became very serious,'' Tramel said. Dungeons and Dragons game was developed as a board game in 1973 and became popular in the early 1980s. Detractors say the way the game is sometimes played is dangerous because it can blur distinctions between fantasy and reality. Morgan's mother, Dorothy Morgan, said Tuesday that one of those arrested had called her to say her son's body had been taken to a house near Lake City where about 30 to 40 people dressed in black robes held a ceremony. She did not identify the caller. ``At one point, he called me and told me to keep my mouth shut because Glen belonged to them now,'' she said. ``God will see that they will pay,'' she said. Arrested were Leon Jody Thompson, 21; Charles Vincent Womack Jr., 23; Thomas Christian Cox, 21; Joseph R. Pottgen, 21, and Frederick Day, 19. All live in the Lake City area, about 60 miles west of Jacksonville in north Florida. They were charged with disturbing the contents of a grave _ a felony that carries a five-year maximum sentence _ and were being held Wednesday in the county detention center pending court appearances. The turning point in the case was when a person who witnessed the grave robbery talked to officials, said investigator Russ Williams. His name is being withheld, Tramel said, because he fears for his life. Investigators are trying to determine whether there is a link between the Morgan grave robbery and another grave robbery in the area last October. That body was found in a field by a farmer before anyone knew the grave had been disturbed. Authorities are not sure what the suspects did with the body or how it got to Union County. They also do not think the five knew Morgan before he died in December from a self-inflicted gunshot wound.

DOC.HEAD: Georgia, Uzbekistan Chart Course Toward Independence
With AM-Soviet-Party, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The parliaments of Georgia and Uzbekistan took cautious steps toward sovereignty on Wednesday but followed a different path than the one blazed by the Baltic republics. They were the latest challenges to face President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who has been offering greater autonomy in an effort to persuade the Soviet Union's increasingly restive republics to remain within the fold. Uzbekistan's Supreme Soviet passed a ``Declaration of Sovereignty of the Uzbek Soviet Socialist Republic within a Renewed Soviet Federation,'' the official Soviet news agency Tass reported. It was the first of the five Soviet Central Asian republics to move toward a break with Moscow. The ``Renewed Soviet Federation'' referred to in the declaration does not currently exist.
