Gorbachev has spoken often of revamping the relationship between the Soviet government and the republics. Last week he offered to establish a new, looser union of ``sovereign states'' joined under a treaty. Some 1,240 miles away, the Georgian Supreme Soviet decided to create a legal mechanism for restoring the republic's independence, Tass reported. Neither step was as radical as the declarations of independence approved by the Soviet Baltic republics, but they showed how the spirit of breaking from central rule is spreading across this vast, multi-ethnic country. Gorbachev imposed economic sanctions against Lithuania after it declared its independence March 11. He called the declaration illegal and demanded it be suspended. Some deputies of Uzbekistan's parliament, meeting in the republican capital Tashkent, wanted to postpone consideration of the sovereignty declaration until the new union treaty is completed, Tass said. But they were overruled and the declaration was approved by a majority. ``The declaration proclaims Uzbekistan's state sovereignty and the supremacy of republican laws on its entire territory,'' Tass said. ``The declaration puts all issues of domestic and foreign policy under the authority of Uzbekistan.'' The Tass report made clear Uzbekistan is not considering seceding from the Soviet Union, but one Uzbek official said no options were being ruled out. ``If it (the union) doesn't support the well-being of the workers, doesn't get us out of the crisis, then we will be obliged to think it over with deputies,'' Uzbek Premier Sh. Mirsaidov told Soviet television. Uzbekistan, a cotton-growing republic of 20 million people, is home of the region's best-organized grassroots political movement, Berlik, and is a center for activism by the majority Moslem population. There are many sources of discontent with Moscow. The economy, environment and ethnic relations among people in the arid region have suffered from central Kremlin rule. Unemployment is the highest in the nation, overfertilization has polluted waterways and ruined crops and ethnic tensions are boiling over. Georgia's Supreme Soviet decided to form a commission to create a legal mechanism for restoring the independence the republic lost after Red Army troops occupied the area in 1921. Tass said lawmakers in the mountainous republic of 5.3 million people also gave preliminary approval to a law on economic independence and appealed to the Russian federation's legislature to establish ties with it as a sovereign government. On March 9, the Georgian Supreme Soviet condemned the republic's annexation by the Soviet Union and urged negotiations on independence, becoming the fourth of the 15 Soviet republics to begin a parliamentary struggle for secession. Wednesday's session was held a month ahead of scheduled in response to demands from hunger-striking university students in the Georgian capital of Tbilisi, Tass said.

DOC.HEAD: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.: few questions.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, about your announcement _ Q: Mr. President _ Bush: Yes, John. Sorry, Norm. Q: doesn't your announcement of today, coupled with Secretary Baker's words that the Israelis should call the White House when they are serious, mean that the U.S. position on the peace process in the Middle East is dormant right now? Bush: John, it's not moving forward right now, and the offer still stands. I have sent a letter to Prime Minister Shamir. I have very specifically asked questions that relate to seriousness about the peace process. But I would like to see the peace process move forward. Nothing herein should indicate anything different, because here we are simply taking (inaudible) shot at terrorism. Norm, excuse me. I forgot my protocol here. Q: Marlin seemed to have lit a fairly short political fuse with his comments on the S&L bailout in accusing the Democrats of having had a big part in that mess. Are you ready to play that game this election year and blame the Democrats for a problem that others have laid on years of permissive regulation by the Reagan administration? Bush: Norm, you're almost getting me into the fight by the way you ask the question. But no, I'm not going to _ (chuckles) _ no, I want to get the savings and loan problem solved. And Marlin, properly, seeing a couple of shots across my bow from certain distinguished members of the United States Senate, decided not to acquiesce in those attacks without some response. What he did was appropriate. But, what I'm trying to do is not respond to individuals and to simply keep moving forward on this _ on this process, and not try to be out there saying here's who's to blame and here's who's not to blame. But, it was interesting because I think you're right _ a spark seemed to be ignited there _ and I think more important than continuing to pour fuel on that spark is to work cooperatively with the Congress in trying to get this mess solved. And of course, that is a part of what will be discussed in the budget process. I would say to the American people on this one, the obligation is to protect the depositor _ that's what our obligation is. And another obligation is to prosecute those who have broken the law, and there has been an active prosecution under way. I talked with Dick Thornburgh at lunch yesterday. I got some impressive numbers of the numbers of cases that are _ that are being followed up on now, and I expect we'll see plenty more. So, protect the depositor, put those that are guilty into the dock where they belong, and see that they are, you know, brought to responsibility for what they've done. Q: Do you, in retrospect though, agree with the argument that deregulation or unregulation of the savings and loan, the financial industry, occurred too quickly, went too far in the '80s? Bush: Well, I think _ in looking back, I think some of the excesses of the loan policies are rather obvious. Basically, we made some proposals, I think, in that task force that I headed that might have corrected some of the abuse. But, I don't want to _ I don't want to argue in favor of reregulation of industries. But, I will say that I think some of the loan policies instituted after the changes were made were foolish and were certainly ill-advised. And the result is a pounding for the original purpose of the S&Ls, which was financing _ primarily financing housing in this country. Yeah, John? Q: Is it true that none of our allies, with the exception, of course, of the Israelis, wanted you to suspend these talks with the PLO? And you said you have given the PLO enough time. I mean, why now? I mean, is there some reason to toughen in today? Bush: No, I don't think of any reason today. And I didn't set it, you know, in my mind, X numbers of days. But, John, I think there will be a lack of agreement with what I've done here on the part of our strongest allies. And I know this is true on the part of some of the most reasonable and moderate Arab states. But I would simply remind them of the conditions upon which the dialogue started in the first place. And I would also remind them that if they look at this statement and remedial action is taken, the dialogue, from the U.S. side, can promptly be restored. Jerry?
DOC.NOTE: MORE

DOC.HEAD: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.: restored. Jerry?
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President, at the same time you're having this trouble with the PLO you've also got a new Israeli government that has an avowed policy of settling in the West Bank more rapidly than it's been settled in the past. How are you going to deal with that government? What's your policy going to be on aid for that government, specifically on housing guarantees for Soviet immigrants? Bush: Well, Jerry, I think I probably _ my position on settlement in the territories is probably as well known as anything. And our policy is not to have new settlements, and our policy is certainly not to finance new settlements. Is that responsive, or was there another part to your question? Q: There's a specific question now, though, of whether we'll provide housing guarantees for Soviet immigrants of ($100 million?). Bush: Well, but not to settle in the _ in the post _ '67 territory _ in the territories, beyond the '67 lines. Q: Are you going to seek specific new guarantees from this new government that that won't happen _ Bush: Well, I will, and I hope I'm successful. But I think they _ they _ there is no question that the Shamir government knows my position on this, knows the standing position of the United States. Here, and then Jim. Q: Mr. President, as you know, Nelson Mandela arrived in the United States today, and you're going to meet with him next week. What are you going to tell him on the sanctions question? And second, the second part, there have been reports, oh, some weeks ago that the United States Central Intelligence Agency was involved in a process that led to a rift many years ago. And there have been suggestions that you should apologize on behalf of the United States government and the American people. Will you do that? Bush: No. I will take my leadership on that question from Mr. Mandela, who put it very well when he said, ``Let bygones be bygones,'' and that is not to agree with or disagree with the charge. On the second point _ your first, my second _ the sanctions, under the law, cannot be lifted until certain additional steps are taken by South Africa. Let me be very clear _ I salute Mr. de Klerk for what he's done. He's come a long, long way. And I salute Mr. Mandela for his approach to de Klerk. I think that demonstrates a willingness to talk that few of us might have predicted a couple of years ago. But there still are things that have to be done under our law in order to lift the sanctions. And I've listed them here, but anyway, you don't want to go into the details on it, but if you do, I'd be glad to click them off for you. But in any event, there has to be progress. And I'd like to find a way to show Mr. de Klerk that we, the United States, are grateful for this new approach that is having South Africa evolve to a much more open society and hopefully one day to one which is color blind in terms of participation in the political process. But I can't lift the sanctions under existing U.S. law. But I'm looking forward to talking to Mr. Mandela about this. There are black leaders in South Africa that disagree with him on this question of sanctions. The foremost of those that come to mind is Mr. Buthelezi, but _ with whom I have talked about this question. And I historically have not felt that certainly adding to the sanction base would help at all, and I had some original reservations about a sanction approach. But I will say that it seems to _ if you can credit sanctions with the evolution of _ towards democracy in South Africa, I'd have to say, well, it seems to be, you know, there are some good things to it. But it's delicate, because I want to find a way to show our appreciation to de Klerk, and yet I don't want to pull the rug out from under Mr. Mandela.

DOC.HEAD: An Evolving Relationship, In the Words of Participants
With AM-Bush, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
The changing relationship between the United States and the Palestine Liberation Organization has evolved in four steps, illustrated by the words of American and Palestinian leaders:
``We totally and absolutely renounce all forms of terrorism, including individual terrorism, group and state terrorism.'' _Yasser Arafat, Geneva, Dec. 14, 1988.
``Arafat met the conditions of the United States and we will go forward with a dialogue, not negotiations, but a dialogue. ... Let's see how things evolve.'' _Vice President George Bush on then-President Reagan's decision to open talks with the PLO, Dec. 15, 1988.
``We are against any military action that targets civilians, whatever form it may take.'' _PLO statement June 11, 1990, following the foiled May 30 attack on an Israeli beach.
``We've given the PLO ample time to deal with this issue.'' _President Bush, June 19, 1990, in suspending talks with the PLO because the United States found the PLO's statement on the beach assault to be insufficiently strong.

DOC.HEAD: HUNTSVILLE, Ala.: Mr. Mandela.
DOC.TEXT: Q: Mr. President _ Q: Mr. President, are you _ Bush: Oh, Jim. Sorry, we'll come back. You're standing up. I can't see you. Q: Mr. President, are you planning to support a G-7 initiative to offer economic aid to the Soviet Union at next month's economic summit? And if so, what has caused you to change your mind on that? Bush: No, I'm not planning to do that, and I expect, though, that matter may be discussed. And yet, I want to see perestroika continue. I haven't changed my view that economic reform is important, and I recognize that support from the West can well _ can well help the economy. But there is an awful lot of reform that has to take place in the market and the distribution systems. There's some political problems that we have that I've discussed very frankly with Mr. Gorbachev, not the least of them $5 billion a year going down to Cuba. So we've still got some problems there, but discount the fact that we are planning some bold new initiative. On the other hand, I'm perfectly prepared to talk to our allies on any subject, and I think that will probably be one of them. Q: Well there are reports that President Mitterrand would propose such a plan. Is that _ Bush: Well, the Germans are interested, too, and I'm not saying we're not interested, but I am saying there are some formidable obstacles. Yeah, Jim? Q: Back on the PLO, one of the theories passed around in your own administration was that the intent of this terrorist attack was to derail the peace process. Are you at all concerned that by suspending the dialogue you're playing into the hands of the hard-liners like Abu Abbus? And is there also a danger _ Bush: Yes. Let me stop you there, just to respond, so I don't get _ forget the question. Yes I am concerned about that. Go ahead. (Scattered laughter.) Q: Well, if you're so concerned about it, then why did you _ why did you take this action? Bush: Well, because we had to weigh the whole question and the question was complicated by the fact that there were three specific undertakings, one of which, a very important one in my view, has clearly has been violated. So _ but _ it's not an easy call, because I know some feel that the PLO dialogue is totally unproductive, and as I indicated in this statement, I don't. And the question up here was, well, do our allies _ will they agree with the steps that I've taken here in Huntsville today? And the answer is, no, some of them will not agree, because they do feel that the dialogue has kind of helped calm things in some parts of the Middle East. So _ so, what the answer to it is, is for the PLO to take the action that I've called for and to satisfactorily _ to satisfy us that those who were responsible will be disciplined, and condemn this specific act. It's not enough to simply reiterate one's concern on terror. Q: If I may follow up? Bush: Please. Q: Is there a danger, too, that those Palestinians who would put some hope in the dialogue between the PLO and the U.S. might now throw up their hands in desperation and resort to violence? Bush: Well, I hope that's not the case, and yet _ I would refer you to the very last page of my _ last paragraph or two of the statement, when I did call for no violence, and I think it's fair to say that at any time you're dealing with something as complicated as the Middle East, you worry about that. But I hope that's not the case, and I hope they'll see in my statement a rather temperate view here that, though we're specific in calling for the condemnation of this particular terrorist act, that once that is done, in keeping with the Arafat's _ Arafat's undertaking, that we can resume talks. DOC.HEAD: U.S. Barred From Holding Future AIDS Meetings
With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Future international AIDS meetings won't be held in the United States and other countries that restrict the entry of people infected with the AIDS virus, a top conference official said Wednesday. ``It's not appropriate to hold the conference in countries that have restrictions,'' said Dr. Paul Volberding of the University of California, San Francisco. Volberding is the incoming president of the International AIDS Society, which picks the sites for the annual AIDS meeting. He is also co-chairman of this year's gathering, the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, being held this week in San Francisco. Volberding said that Canada, Japan and Australia are among other countries that will be barred from being hosts of the meeting because of similar restrictions on travel by foreigners infected with the AIDS virus. While the United States has significantly eased rules on admitting people who carry HIV, the AIDS virus, the regulations have emerged as a major issue at this meeting, and about 100 organizations are boycotting because of them. ``It isn't fair. It's discriminatory. And it won't do anything to stop the spread of HIV infection,'' Volberding said. In 1987, the U.S. Senate voted 97 to 0 to add HIV infection to the list of medical conditions for which foreigners can be denied visas. In April, the Justice Department said it would issue special 10-day visas for people traveling to the United States to attend specific conferences, including the AIDS meeting, without requiring them to admit they are infected with HIV. Administration officials have contended they can't throw out the HIV restriction entirely, since it was imposed by the Senate. However, Dr. June Osborn, chairman of the National Commission on AIDS, said federal health officials should ``regrasp'' their authority to decide which diseases are contagious enough to be on the list. The 1992 AIDS meeting is scheduled to be sponsored by Harvard University in Boston. Last week, Harvard officials threatened to withdraw from the meeting unless the travel rules are changed. On Wednesday, Alan Fein, head of the Harvard AIDS Institute, said Harvard will pull out unless all restrictions on people with HIV infection have been eliminated by the time Congress adjourns in November. Volberding said that if the Boston meeting is abandoned, it may be too late to find another country to be host of the 1992 gathering. The meeting is scheduled to be held in Florence, Italy, next year and in Berlin in 1993. The international AIDS meetings are the principal forum for exchanging new information on the spread and control of the epidemic. An estimated 12,000 scientists, doctors, social workers and other AIDS professionals are expected to attend this week's meeting.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Fill Campaign Coffers With $1.5 Million
DOC.TEXT: Democrats collected $1.5 million for House, Senate and statewide candidates at a fund-raiser where they were entertained by several comedians and singers on Wednesday. The event was sponsored by the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, the Democratic Senatorial Campaign Committee, the Democratic National Committee and Democrats for the 90s. ``This is an evening for fun, entertainment and celebration,'' said House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash. The money raised by the $30 to $1,000-per seat tickets will give Democratic candidates funds at ``a critical time'' as the 1990 races heat up, said DCCC spokesman Howard Schloss. Performers for the evening at the concert hall of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts included singers Roberta Flack and Rodney Crowell, the rock group Crosby, Stills and Nash and the Gypsy Kings. Also on hand were comedians and comics Dana Carvey _ noted for his George Bush imitation _ and Al Franken from ``Saturday Night Live.'' The event was the brainchild of Pamela Harriman, widow of Averell Harriman, who until his death in 1986 served as a roving ambassador and adviser for every Democratic president since Roosevelt.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Sounding Out Allies, Soviets Over Western Aid Package
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with of Bush comments on Soviet aid proposal. Picks up 2nd graf pvs, `The West ...
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III will sound out U.S. allies on a proposed Western aid package to boost the faltering Soviet economy, but President Bush said Wednesday he sees ``formidable obstacles'' to such assistance. U.S. officials said Baker was expected to take up the proposed assistance package, being pushed by both West Germany and France, at negotiating sessions in East Berlin on the question of German unification. Direct aid to the Soviets is viewed as one way to overcome Kremlin resistance to NATO membership for a unified Germany. Asked at a news conference in Huntsville, Ala., about the Soviet aid proposals, Bush said he was willing to discuss the matter with U.S. allies but cautioned against looking for any ``bold new initiative'' coming from the upcoming seven-nation economic summit. ``I am not saying we are not interested, but I am saying that there are some formidable obstacles,'' Bush said. Bush mentioned the need for the Soviets to do more to reform their economy and alluded to congressional opposition because of the crackdown on the breakaway Baltic republics and continued Soviet assistance to Cuba. ``There are some political problems that we have that I have discussed very frankly with Mr. Gorbachev, not the least of them the $5 billion a year going down to Cuba,'' Bush said. The West German government several months ago took the lead in offering to help President Mikhail S. Gorbachev cope with his economic woes. The Bush administration approved the overture as part of a nine-point package Baker discussed two weeks ago with Soviet Minister Eduard Shevardnadze at a human rights conference in Copenhagen. ``One of the goals of the discussions is to see how we can assist the Soviet economy through some sort of economic package,'' a U.S. official said before Baker left for East Berlin. ``It's likely they will discuss it in Berlin.'' French President Francois Mitterrand said Tuesday he would ask the United States and five other major industrial democracies to consider extending financial and technical aid to the Soviets at an economic summit meeting in Houston next month. Baker, officials said, also was weighing other assurances to allay Moscow's concerns. Officials said those assurances included issuance of declarations by NATO and the Soviet-led Warsaw Pact designed to reflect the lowering of East-West tension and the prospective withdrawal of tens of thousands of U.S. and Soviet troops from Europe. The monthly ``2-plus-4'' talks bring together the four victors of World War II _ the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France _ and the two Germanies, who are set to merge their currencies July 2 and may hold all-German elections in December. Baker also will meet separately with Shevardnadze on Friday and on Thursday with Markus Meckel and Hans-Dietrich Genscher of East Germany and West Germany. Gorbachev's economic problems are apt to be compounded when East Germany is absorbed by West Germany. There are an estimated 380,000 Soviet troops in East Germany. Some would stay for a transitional period under a U.S. proposal Baker took up with Shevardnadze in Copenhagen. But the Soviets would be limited to no more than 195,000 soldiers in all of Central Europe, including what is now East Germany, under a treaty being negotiated in Vienna by NATO and the Warsaw Pact. The return of the troops would strain the Soviet budget both in terms of housing them and finding jobs for those mustered out of the service as part of a cutback of 500,000 men promised by Gorbachev in December 1988. The U.S. official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said the proposed aid package could include the possibility of having the West Germans pay for housing the withdrawn soldiers in the Soviet Union. But the official added: ``We'll hold off any serious decisions until the summit.'' Baker also is likely to discuss with Shevardnadze a renewed Soviet threat to suspend emigration of Soviet Jews if Israel keeps settling some of them on the West Bank and in Gaza. The Bush administration also opposes allowing Jews to live on land Israel seized from Jordan and Egypt during the 1967 Mideast war and that the Arabs hope to recover. But the threat to suspend emigration, which Gorbachev voiced here June 3, at the end of his Washington summit meeting with President Bush, is stiffly opposed by the administration. Baker told Shevardnadze in Copenhagen that he was concerned about Gorbachev's threat to end an exodus of Jews that has reached 20,000 people a month, a historic high. Shevardnadze told Baker that Soviet officials had no plan to change their immigration policy. But a U.S. official said that Gorbachev since then twice has raised the prospect of suspending exit permits unless Israel gives assurances the refugees won't settle in the territories.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela's Path Beaten by Fliers and Athletes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 10th graf to ADD parade by Apollo 11 astronauts; picks up 11th graf, `Astronaut Gordon ...'
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The ticker tape parade Wednesday for Nelson Mandela is the fifth in the last 10 years through New York's ``Canyon of Heroes'' on lower Broadway. There have been about twoscore such parades since Charles Lindbergh was lionized here in 1927. Aviators, athletes and warriors predominate. Among the notable parades: 1986 _ New York Mets, after beating the Boston Red Sox in the World Series. 1985 _ 25,000 Vietnam veterans, led by Gen. William Westmoreland and 26 Medal of Honor winners, in a 10-years-later welcome-home tribute. 1984 _ 221 athletes of the U.S. Olympic team are cheered, but 101 spectators are injured when a construction scaffold on the parade route gives way. 1981 _ Welcome home for the Americans hostages freed from Iran. 1979 _ Pope John Paul II. 1978 _ New York Yankees world champion team. 1969 _ ``Miracle'' Mets world champion team. 1969 _ Astronauts Neil Armstrong and Buzz Aldrin, the first men to land on the moon, and fellow Apollo 11 astronaut Michael Collins. 1963 _ Astronaut Gordon Cooper. 1962 _ Astronaut John Glenn, the first American in orbit. 1958 _ Van Cliburn, the only classical musician ever to get the ticker-tape treatment, after winning piano competition in Moscow. 1951 _ Gen. Douglas MacArthur, after his recall from Korea by President Truman. 1938 _ Douglas ``Wrong-Way'' Corrigan, for his air flight to Ireland while claiming his destination was Los Angeles. 1938 _ Howard Hughes and his plane crew, for breaking Wiley Post's round-the-world flight record. 1936 _ Beryl Markham, for the first westward trans-Atlantic solo flight, described later in her memoir ``West With the Night.'' 1928 _ Amelia Earhart, first woman to fly the Atlantic, as navigator, before making her own solo flight some years later. 1927 _ Lindbergh, after returning from solo flight to Paris. Several of the parades were larger in scope than the traditional route from Bowling Green to City Hall, a canyon about 16 blocks long formed by the office towers along Broadway in the financial district. Glenn's parade, which wended through midtown as well as lower Manhattan, produced the greatest fallout of paper in any ticker tape parade, 3,474 tons, according to Sanitation Department records. The most paper generated by a canyon-only parade was 1,262 for the Iran hostage parade. Official estimates of spectator numbers have been extravagant. The Mets' 1986 parade was reported as drawing 2.2 million people. That works out to 137,000 people per block, or enough to fill Shea Stadium 2{ times.

DOC.HEAD: Fierce Fighting Around Rebel Airbase in Sri Lanka, Dozens Dead
DOC.TEXT: Foot soldiers and government helicopters destroyed rebel bunkers around a key airbase Wednesday and naval gunboats blasted a seafront hotel housing guerrilla artillery. Officials reported dozens killed. Sri Lanka's soldiers also repulsed another attack on a garrison in Jaffna, the rebel stronghold in the north, fighting fierce hand-to-hand battles with rebel forces, the officials said. Rebels used bulldozers in an attempt to knock down the walls of the garrison, which is in a 200-year-old Dutch fort. At one point, military officials said, a young Tamil rebel strapped with explosives tried to scale the fort's walls but he was shot and killed, the military said. At least 29 militants and four soldiers were killed in fighting in the north, the main flashpoint of the 11-day-old war between government forces and the Tamil militia, a Defense Ministry statement said. Military officials said rebel resistance in the east, another flashpoint, has been overcome and guerrillas have retreated into jungles. But the officials added the retreat may be a tactical move and that the guerrillas appear to be digging in for a protracted jungle war. More than 1,000 people have been killed since the Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam rebels repudiated a year-long cease-fire with the government on June 10 and overran police stations in the Tamil-dominated north and the east. The casualties include 278 policemen shot to death by the rebels, said a senior military official who cannot be named under briefing rules. He said the victims were among the 850 policemen captured by the Tigers in the east since June 11. On Wednesday, the military launched a major attack from the Palali military airfield, pounding rebel bunkers and fortifications with helicopters gunships, armored vehicles and infantry. The Defense Ministry statement said at least 20 militants were killed. Four soldiers also were killed and 20 injured, it reported. The airfield is outside Jaffna, the headquarters of the militia, about 185 miles north of Colombo. In another attack, helicopter gunships and naval gunboats destroyed a seafront hotel in Kankesanthurai near Jaffna from where the rebels were pounding a vital naval port. The Defense Ministry statement said nine rebels died in that fight. The military says 130 security force personnel and 600 rebels have been killed since fighting began nine days ago. There has been no word on the casualties from the Tigers. In the east, troops were conducting mopping up operations and consolidating their position, said the ministry statement. Residents in Batticaloa, the largest population center in the east, said the town was tense and deserted and was being heavily patrolled by troops. The residents, contacted by telephone, said the troops killed a Tamil woman and her 10-year-old child while advancing into the city. The military official said civilian casualties in the east could be high because initially the army had to attack from the air to dislodge the rebels. There were also unconfirmed reports the rebels had killed a number of Sinhalese civilians before withdrawing into the jungles in the east. The Defense Ministry statement said 20 soldiers were critically ill with respiratory problems after rebels hit their camp in Kiran with mysterious chemical gas bombs. The military officials said this is the first time the rebels have used chemicals in their 7-year-old war for a separate homeland they want for the Tamil minority in the northeast. The rebels took control of all major towns in the northern and eastern provinces after Indian peacekeeping troops withdrew from Sri Lanka in March. The withdrawal, made at the request of Sri Lankan President Ranaisnghe Premadasa, followed an unsuccessful 32-month exercise to disarm the Tigers. Premadasa's government at that time was holding peace talks with the Tigers after calling a truce in May 1989. The talks had not made much headway when the fighting broke out this week. Before the latest hostilities, at least 11,000 people had been killed since Tamil militants began fighting for an independent nation in 1983. In 1987, India brokered a peace accord between Tamil rebels and the government and sent in peacekeeping troops. Sri Lanka's Tamils, who make up 18 percent of the country's 16 million people, claim they are discriminated against by the Sinhalese, who make up 75 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Mayors End Meeting With Fresh Attack On Washington, Signs of Potential Split
DOC.TEXT: America's mayors on Wednesday ended their annual meeting united in a rhetorical assault on Congress and the White House but divided somewhat over the best way to lobby for federal support. Republican mayors were installed in two of the top three posts of the U.S. Conference of Mayors. The new president, Republican Robert Isaac of Colorado Springs, spoke in a conciliatory tone in offering cooperation between the mayors and the White House. ``We want to restore the partnership,'' Isaac said. ``We're not going to get anywhere by continually bashing the administration and Congress.'' But several Democratic mayors, led by conference Vice President Raymond Flynn of Boston, said that, unless President Bush offers significant help to cities soon, it was no time for mayors to duck a confrontation. ``This is a time to rock the boat. This is not a time to go along to get along,'' Flynn said at a news conference after the mayors endorsed an array of policy statements calling on the federal government to make major new investments in city housing, education, anti-drug and other programs. The mayors also took aim at Congress, saying that the virtual lock incumbents have on their jobs has allowed the lawmakers to ignore the plight of urban America. ``They don't feel much vulnerablity,'' said Kansas City Mayor Richard Berkley, who was among the mayors who said that city leaders need to use their political might to win back the support of Congress. ``The power is in the ballot box,'' said Flynn. The most colorful rhetoric came from Altanta Mayor Maynard Jackson, who chastised Congress and the White House for using the federal deficit as an excuse to deny aid to cities. Jackson said programs enacted in Washington force mayors into the trenches to deal with drugs, homelessness and other problems but that the lack of federal money makes it a lonely fight. ``We get no paddles, no oars, no sails, no rudder, no nothing,'' Jackson said. ``We're entitled to help from the federal government. ... Weak leadership will have to be replaced.'' Isaac is widely respected among the Democrats but several this week expressed worries that partisan pressure will keep him from forcefully pressing the mayors' agenda. Isaac assured his colleagues that would not be the case, admitting he has differences with the big-city Democrats who dominate the conference but promising to rally behind the policies endorsed by the group. Democratic Charleston, S.C., Mayor Joseph Riley, a soft-spoken but powerful voice in the conference, offered praise for Isaac, who proved deft in addressing Democrats's concerns without directly criticizing the Republican Bush administration. ``You won't see Bob Isaac being strident or overly partisan in attacks on the administration,'' Riley said. ``But he will present the case strongly, in a gentlemanly fashion. We have others who can be more partisan if necessary.'' Flynn, who aggressively courts his fellow mayors for support, left little doubt he was happy to supply the partisanship. ``I will not sit idly by,'' said Flynn, who is in line to become president of the group next year. ``We're not going to sit by idly and allow the kind of lip service we receive from the Congress and read-my-lips service we receive from the administration to shatter our cities.''

DOC.HEAD: South Swelters, Rain in Many Parts of Nation
DOC.TEXT: The South sweltered Wednesday while many parts of the nation got saturated. Heavy rains caused flooding in Illinois, where a rescue worker was dragged off a collapsed bridge and was missing Wednesday, and vicious storms pummeled parts of Kansas, where 30 people were hurt, but only one seriously. Authorities in Shadyside, Ohio, urged about 150 people to evacuate because of approaching storms, and a body found in the Ohio River brought the death toll from last week's flash flood to 22. Heat advisories were posted across Louisiana and western Tennessee, and the mercury soared in Florida, where temperatures were expected to remain high during the next several days. Several cities tied or set record highs for the date. Daytona Beach, Fla., tied its 98-degree record, set in 1944; Macon, Ga., reached 102, breaking the 100 mark set in 1970; and Savannah, Ga., broke the 1984 record of 101 by one degree. Rainshowers and thunderstorms continued Wednesday afternoon, extending from central and northeast Oklahoma across northern Arkansas, much of Missouri, Illinois, southeast Wisconsin, southwest Lower Michigan, Indiana and central through southern Ohio. Showers and thunderstorms were scattered in west-central and southern Florida, northern and east-central New England, across eastern Lake Ontario, from northwest Minnesota into eastern North Dakota, and northwest Montana and the Idaho Panhandle. Wednesday morning's low for the nation was 32 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. The nation's temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 55 degrees at Caribou, Maine, to 111 degrees at Palm Springs, Calif.

DOC.HEAD: Egg Producers To Vote On Research Program Refunds
DOC.TEXT: Egg producers will vote next month on whether to eliminate refunds permanently under a federal research and promotion program, the Agriculture Department said Wednesday. Daniel D. Haley, administrator of the department's Agricultural Marketing Service, said ballots will be mailed by July 16 to all producers of record. All commercial egg producers owning more than 30,000 laying hens during the period Jan. 1 through March 31, 1990, except those producing mostly hatching eggs, will be eligible to vote. In 1988 Congress amended the Egg Research and Consumer Information Act to suspend refunds for 18 months beginning Jan. 1, 1989, pending results of a national referendum. For the new provision to be adopted, approval would have to come from at least two-thirds of those voting this summer, or a majority of producers representing at least two-thirds of the volume of eggs produced by all voters. If adopted, producers will continue to pay mandatory, non-refundable assessments of five cents per 30-dozen case of commercial eggs to the American Egg Board for research, promotion and consumer education programs. Exemptions would continue for producers with flocks of 30,000 or fewer hens, and for all Alaskan and Hawaiian egg producers. Currently, the assessments raise about $7.2 million annually, the agency said.

DOC.HEAD: PBS Studies Possible Cable Operation
DOC.TEXT: In what could prove public TV's first cable venture, The Discovery Channel, the Public Broadcasting Service and two major PBS stations said Wednesday they'll study the idea of starting a cable program service. The new service would be devoted to education, but show programs of its own and not those appearing on either Discovery or PBS, said Eric McLamb, a spokesman for Discovery. Discovery, based in Landover, Md., is a leading cable programming service. It serves 50.9 million homes, McLamb said. The public TV stations participating in the study are WNET-TV here and WGBH-TV in Boston. They, PBS and Discovery will make a feasibility study of a jointly-owned cable service and may have a report in 90 days, McLamb said. PBS president Bruce L. Christensen announced the study to public TV officials meeting Wednesday at the annual PBS affiliates' convention in Dallas. Discovery chairman John Hendricks, in a separate statement, said the goal of his company and PBS is to ``develop an educational service that complements and does not compete with the valuable broadcast service service provided by local public television stations.'' PBS says it has 337 affiliates.

DOC.HEAD: Australia, New Zealand Warn of Growing Damage to Ozone Layer
By SYDNEY RUBIN
Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: Australia and New Zealand on Wednesday presented new evidence of increasing damage to the earth's protective ozone layer at an international environmental conference. Scientists from the two countries have discovered a 15 percent drop in ozone during the last three years over Macquarie Island, 800 miles southeast of Tasmania. The conference, attended by senior scientists and officials from more than 100 nations, is considering a ban on ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs). The conference is preparing the groundwork for a June 27-29 meeting of environment ministers from 56 countries. Also Wednesday, Britain's Stratospheric Ozone Review Group said in a separate report that the fragile ozone layer is declining in mid-latitudes over North America and Europe. The report said major cutbacks in CFCs, which are mostly used in refrigerators and air-conditioners, would slow the damage. ``Stratospheric chlorine is expected to continue to increase at levels higher than previously experienced. There is a risk that these might trigger disproportionately larger ozone losses,'' the report said. The Australian results were released to ``inject a sense of urgency back into the proceedings,'' a conference source said. Dr. Mostafa Tolba, executive director of the United Nations Environment Program, appealed for international cooperation on the issue. ``No country, no region, no group will ever be capable of solving any of these problems alone. It is a must that north and south, east and west cooperate,'' Tolba said. ``Failure is not an option, success is imperative.'' The meeting is a sequel to the 1987 Montreal Protocol conference, which agreed to halve the world consumption of chlorofluorocarbons by the end of the century. Fifty-six countries have signed the protocol, considered a watershed in ``green diplomacy.'' It marked the first time nations agreed to protect the global environment against future dangers. It also committed nations to targets before the technology was available to achieve them. Five months after the agreement was reached there was mounting scientific evidence of the threat to the ozone layer and most signatories said the protocol was inadequate. ``If we had known in Montreal what we know in London, we would have then drawn up a much stronger treaty with much faster phase-out of CFCs and halons,'' Tolba said. Tolba on Wednesday proposed completely eliminating CFCs and halon by the end of the century; adding carbon tetrachloride to the list of ozone-depleting chemicals; and cutting production and use of methyl chloroform by the year 2000. Chlorine gases, used mainly in refrigeration systems and aerosols, damage the ozone layer that protects life from ultraviolet rays. A 1989 U.N. report confirmed ozone depletion had started, posing significant threats to food production, ocean life and human health. In addition to increasing the risk of skin cancers, exposure to ultraviolet rays could cause suppression of the human immune system and lead to a rise in infectious diseases, the report said. CFCs also are major contributors to global warming. But eliminating CFCs is costly for developing nations and many, including populous China and India, have not signed the protocol. A Chinese delegate said use of CFCs in his country was growing 12 percent yearly and would cost $42 million over three years to phase out the chemicals. Last week, the Bush administration announced it was willing to contribute $25 million to a fund to assist developing nations to eliminate CFCs.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Greeted by United Colors of NYC
LaserPhoto XNYC
DOC.TEXT: Nelson Mandela's admirers stayed away from work, skipped school and ducked out at lunch Wednesday to greet ``the last of the black heroes'' with clenched fists and open hearts. From Kennedy Airport to City Hall, hundreds of thousands of people of many races lined the streets to catch a glimpse of the black South African leader. ``Just look around, it's white-black-white-black-white-black,'' businessman Tom Kellerhals said of the crowd that turned out along Broadway in lower Manhattan. ``Sometimes the answer is in front of us.'' Mandela's ride through a storm of confetti in Broadway's ``Canyon of Heroes'' was the day's emotional apex. People who waited for hours after Mandela's parade was delayed could not contain themselves when he finally arrived in the early afternoon. ``The greatest freedom fighter ever!'' exulted Derrick Fuller as Mandela rolled by in his glass-enclosed ``Mandelamobile.'' ``We have him like a lion in a cage,'' chortled one man, as ticker tape and other debris piled up around his ankles. Fathers hoisted sons on their shoulders to catch a glimpse of the passing hero, and women thrust forward uncomprehending babies as if they were cameras. There were cries of ``Man-del-a!'' and ``Keep the pressure on.'' A group of elementary school children chanted ``Welcome Mandela,'' and across the street a group of adults would answer, ``No more apartheid.'' At City Hall, where Mandela accepted the key to the city, city employees hung a sign out a third-floor window: ``We Shall Conquer.'' ``I've seen people crying and shouting, but never anything like this,'' said Gov. Mario Cuomo. ``It was the single most memorable thing I've ever witnessed.'' Leslie Anderson, 27, of Plainfield, N.J., took the day off to see the man she called ``a legend. ... I was too young to see Martin Luther King and Malcolm X. He's the last of the great black heroes.'' ``We don't live in apartheid. But it's here. It's real,'' she continued. ``New York is a prime example. Think of Bensonhurst,'' where a black youth was slain by a white mob last year. She wore a T-shirt which said ``Free South Africa'' with an image of a black man with a noose around his neck pulled by a white man. On the back her shirt said: ``It's a Black thing you wouldn't understand.'' But standing a few feet away was Fred Marks, a white businessman who also had come out to see Mandela. ``I think any man who spent 27 years in jail deserves a look,'' Marks said. Referring to Ms. Anderson's T-shirt, he said, ``Something like this transcends color.'' A father-and-son guitar duo sat under a tree nearby, playing the blues. ``Me and my father wrote a little something about Mandela and Dinkins meeting, about the Mandelas in New York,'' said Ted Williams r. ``It's happy. It's nice. You can do the chicken dance to it.'' Most of those who skipped work declined to be interviewed for the record, but one man agreed to appear on television. Asked what he would tell his boss if he was spotted, he said: ``I'm gonna say two words: `Nelson Mandela.''' Sean Smith, a foreign currency options broker, saw irony in the parade's location: ``This is the biggest laughable thing that ever happened, that Wall Street supported apartheid and turned around and threw a ticker-tape parade.'' Not everyone was impressed with the visit. A young black man named Wayne Moore squatted at Broadway and Liberty Street, shining the shoes of a well-dressed white man. ``Shine 'em up!'' he yelled as he buffed. ``Shine em up!'' Moore had come to this corner, he explained, because ``I heard Mandela was coming down today, so there'd be a big crowd and I'd make more money.'' ``Do I think he could change my situation?'' he said, repeating a question. ``Kinda hard to think that.''

DOC.HEAD: Mandela Arrival Brings Praise, Encouragement
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The arrival Wednesday of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela prompted an outpouring of praise and encouragement from politicians and supporters. A sampling of their comments:

The Rev. Jesse Jackson: ``The presence of Nelson Mandela generates hope around the world. He emerged from the prison unbroken, unbowed and without bitterness, and he continues to struggle for human rights. Just as the walls came down in Berlin, they should come down in South Africa as well.''

Mayor David Dinkins: ``Our honored guest ... is a George Washington, a Bolivar, a King, a Herzl. He is like a modern-day Moses leading the people of South Africa from enslavement at the hands of the pharaohs. He and his people have endured their walk through the desert of deprivation. And now, his path is clear. He will not be deterred. He and his people have suffered their way into the leadership of South Africa.''

Former tennis star Arthur Ashe: ``For me, one of my fondest dreams and hopes is to see Nelson Mandela free. I never thought I'd see the day. I feel humbled by being part of his welcome to our country. He will do more good here than he will ever, ever know.''

New York Gov. Mario Cuomo: ``Today we are celebrating Nelson Mandela and honoring his commitment to mankind. This government ought to continue to support the needs of South Africa with its speeches, its prayers and its money.''
New Jersey Gov. Jim Florio: ``Today is a restatement of our commitment that all people are created equal.''

DOC.HEAD: Automakers, Insurers Clash On Copyrighting Auto Part Design
DOC.TEXT: Automakers and insurers traded accusations of greed and portrayed themselves as the consumer's friend Wednesday in a debate over copyright protection for product designs. The auto industry urged Congress to approve legislation that would prohibit independent manufacturers from copying a part's original design for a decade after it first appears on the market. The bills would protect consumers from shoddy imitation parts, auto lobbyists told the House Subcommittee on Courts, Intellectual Property and Administration of Justice. ``Imitation sheet metal parts are often of lesser quality in fit, finish and durability,'' said Kenneth W. Myers of Ford Motor Co. He spoke on behalf of the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association, which represents the Big Three U.S. automakers. Opponents, led by insurers, said the legislation was designed to squelch competition in the lucrative replacement parts industry, which generated $52 billion in sales in 1988. The price of parts will soar if the bills are passed, they said. ``American consumers will have to pay hundreds of millions of dollars a year in monopoly profits to ... auto manufacturers and they will get nothing in return,'' said C.A. Ingham, vice president of State Farm Insurance Co. The subcommittee is considering three bills dealing with intellectual property rights. But most of the testimony focused on a bill co-sponsored by House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Minority Leader Bob Michel, R-Ill. It would allow manufacturers to secure copyrights on their product designs similar to the protection available to artists and writers. The copyrights would be easier to obtain than design patents, which are granted only for ``new, original and ormantental design'' after a cumbersome application process that can last years, Myers said. Automakers invest heavily in designing and testing parts. ``Each part is designed to enhance overall aesthetics and also must function properly as part of the whole vehicle,'' Myers said. Competing parts manufacturers do not have to make such investments, he said. They just copy the original design and make imitation products that often are of poor quality, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Boat With Thatcher on Board Rescues Yacht Off Cornwall
DOC.TEXT: A rescue boat carrying British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on Wednesday dashed to the aid of a yacht battling high seas off southwest England. Thatcher had just witnessed a 10-minute Royal Navy air-sea rescue demonstration from aboard the 44-foot Faithful Forester when the lifeboat was called into action. She watched from the cabin as the crew delivered a salvage pump to the 32-foot sloop Slipshod, which was taking on water a half-mile from the entrance to Fowey harbor, in eastern Cornwall. ``There was a yacht in trouble with a loose keel so we went out to see if it was all right,'' Mrs. Thatcher said. Gary Heward, 24, from Southampton, one of the Slipshod's five-man crew, said: ``We did not know anything about the prime minister until afterwards. I did not even look in the lifeboat.''

DOC.HEAD: Flag-burning Rhetoric Turns Inflammatory in House
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS 2 grafs with comment from Gingrich and Dole.
DOC.TEXT: A House Republican accused Speaker Thomas S. Foley on Wednesday of ``kowtowing to ilk like the Communist Youth Brigade'' by refusing to delay until next week Thursday's showdown vote on a constitutional amendment to prohibit flag burning. Rep. Gerald Solomon, R-N.Y., later apologized for the remark and it was stricken from the record. But the exchange reflected the general bitterness and tension over the issue on the eve of the vote. Both opponents and proponents of the amendment said the proposal likely would not muster the necessary two-thirds margin. Supporters of the amendment, who since last year had been pushing Foley to allow the vote, sought a delay to give veterans' groups more time to organize a mass mail campaign in the amendment's favor. They also wanted the showdown to come closer to the Fourth of July. Republicans pressed the White House, meanwhile, to get President Bush to do more private, one-on-one lobbying in behalf of the measure, which he has repeatedly endorsed publicly. The Supreme Court a year ago ruled that flag burning was protected by the constitutional guarantee of free speech. It reaffirmed that decision last week in rejecting a congressional attempt to overcome the earlier ruling without resorting to changing the Constitution. ``We fail to see why it is so necessary to rush this legislation to a vote on Thursday,'' complained Walter G. Hogan, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars. Foley, D-Wash., an outspoken opponent of the amendment, said ``This bill has been before the Congress for over a year. It has been debated and discussed as much as any other legislative proposal in this Congress. I don't understand why that is a problem.'' Foley also cited a comment by Rep. Newt Gingrich, R-Ga., the House Minority Whip, who said for a Republican campaigner the best outcome might be to lose by one vote. That would keep the flag issue alive and more relevant in individual races. ``All this talk about being concerned about the flag, they are concerned, apparently, about the political issue and the political opportunities,'' Foley said. ``I don't think the American people are going to respond favorably to that.'' But Solomon, in a speech on the House floor, said Foley and the Democratic leadership were ``deliberately gagging 10 million veterans through this nation'' at the same time they were ``kowtowing to ilk like the Communist Youth Brigade to allow them to trample and desecrate the American Flag.'' Solomon's comments drew heated protests from the Democratic side of the aisle, forcing him to apologize and his words were struck from the record. Later, in a meeting of the House Rules Committee, Solomon and other Republicans pleaded for the scheduling panel to grant a delay but even Democrats who support the amendment seemed eager to get the vote done. Rep. Henry Hyde, R-Ill., said the expedited procedure ill behooved Democrats and he warned Republicans could make hay of the fact they ``hustled this bill through.'' ``You don't need that burden,'' he said. ``Justice delayed is justice denied,'' quipped Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, chairman of The House Judiciary Committee. If all 433 current House members vote Thursday, 289 will be required for passage or, conversely, 145 needed to block it. Leadership sources said Wednesday that Democrats were becoming more confident they could muster the blocking votes from their party, and between 12 and 15 Republicans might vote against the amendment as well. The Senate is also expected to consider the amendment before the end of next week, but it would be a moot point if the House rejects the measure. A two-thirds vote from both chambers, followed by approval by 38 states, is required for the amendment to become part of the Constitution. In addition to the constitutional amendment, the House was expected to vote Thursday on a new statute to ban flag burning. The statute, more narrowly drawn than the one overturned by the Supreme Court last week, would set jail terms and fines for destroying a flag belonging to the federal government or on federal land, or to promote violence by destroying any flag. The bill, introduced Wednesday by Reps. Jim Cooper, D-Tenn., Rick Boucher, D-Va., and Ron Wyden, D-Ore., would attack flag burning during the period before an amendment could take effect. It also fit into Foley's strategy on the amendment, giving those who oppose tinkering with the Bill of Rights an alternative they could support. Gingrich labeled the proposed statute was a ``liberal fig leaf'' which the American people would quickly see through. Meanwhile, Senate Minority Leader Bob Dole, R-Kan., said if the House rejected the constitutional amendment, he hoped the Senate would approve it and send it back to the House for a second vote, ``to give the House one more chance to come through for Old Glory.''

DOC.HEAD: JVC Jazz Festival Opens Friday
DOC.TEXT: Some call it the odd couple. ``What are Pearl Bailey and Wynton Marsalis going to do together?'' wonders George Wein, who paired the veteran singer and young trumpeter for a June 27 concert during the JVC Jazz Festival. Wein said he was interested in the concerts' content and pleased at ticket sales as this year's festival kicks off on Friday. ``I'm interested to see what Stan Getz does with a whole evening of his quartet and sextet,'' Wein says. ``He's such a genius; we've never presented him for a whole evening. It should be very interesting.'' Getz's June 29 concert is titled ``50 Years in Music.'' But Wein expects Getz, instead of starting with early colleagues, to play in the first half with his usual quartet and augment it with a few veterans in the second half. Miles Davis and the group Hiroshima will pack Lincoln Center's Avery Fisher Hall in two concerts on opening night, and Ella Fitzgerald is expected to sell out her June 29th performance, even though she gave a concert a few months ago at Radio City Music Hall. ``We always sell a lot of tickets the last week,'' Wein said. ``Everything seems to be going along very well. We're selling at the same speed as last year, which was a relatively good year. ``It's interesting that the two shows we're doing at Town Hall, bassist Milt Hinton celebrating his 80th birthday (June 23) and a salute to guitarist Jim Hall (June 26) seem to be doing better than any Town Hall shows we've ever done.'' Most of the concerts are at Carnegie Hall and Avery Fisher Hall. ``Where we have trouble is whenever we try something different, like (minimalist composer Steve) Reich is a problem,'' Wein says. Reich and the World Saxophone Quartet share a June 23 bill. ``The things that sell, sell,'' Wein says. ``The things that don't, don't.'' Pianist Oscar Peterson canceled his June 28 evening. ``The doctor told him he was exhausted and should take six weeks off,'' Wein says. Sarah Vaughan had been booked for the festival when she died this spring. There won't be a tribute to the singer this year, Wein said. ``We'll do something next year. I don't like to do those tributes so fast. I like to plan and do them so they're historic evenings.'' The JVC Jazz Festival, sponsored by the Japanese electronics firm for which it is named, runs in New York through June 30, then goes to Saratoga Springs, N.Y.

DOC.HEAD: Iliescu Takes Office, Pledges Reconciliation
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 2 grafs after 13th graf `Ambassadors from' to UPDATE with Iliescu reaction to U.S. boycott of inauguration. Pickup 14th graf pvs, `Ion Ratiu...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XBUC1,3,4
DOC.TEXT: Former Communist Ion Iliescu pledged Wednesday to be a democratic president of reconciliation, but the United States boycotted his inauguration to protest his role in violent attacks on opposition figures. The capital was generally quiet following a tumultuous week of anti-government riots, mob rule by loyalist miners and a crackdown on dissent. ``This is the happiest day of my life,'' Iliescu told reporters, before swearing ``faithfulness to the Romanian people and to their ideals of freedom and prosperity.'' He pledged ``to defend democracy (and) ... fundamental human rights and freedoms.'' ``I shall firmly militate for the safeguarding of civic liberties ... on our way to a genuinely free and democratic society,'' Iliescu said, pledging to be a ``president ... of reconciliation.'' Pro-Iliescu supporters cheered him when he emerged from the downtown, fin-de-siecle Atheneum music hall after his inauguration. Iliescu's inauguration came one week to the day after riot police brutally dispersed a 53-day rally of his opponents demanding that he and other former Communists be banned from politics for 10 years. Rioters subsequently assaulted and firebombed government buildings, and thousands of club-wielding miners from Transylvania descended on the capital in response to an appeal by Iliescu, attacking opposition politicians and anyone deemed a government critic. Numerous countries and international human rights groups condemned the violence and its links to the National Salvation Front-dominated government. Some governments have suspended non-humanitarian aid. Petre Roman, who was formally appointed prime minister by Iliescu after serving as interim premier since December, tried to ease foreign concerns. He told state radio: ``We want to prove to the international community that our way to a true democracy is irreversible.'' In Washington, State Department spokesman Richard Boucher said human rights violations in Romania are continuing. He said Romania has arrested 45 opposition figures in the past two days, and said the administration believes the purpose is to intimidate Romanians from exercising their rights. Ambassadors from Canada and countries of the 12-nation European Economic Community attended the inaugural ceremony, but echoed U.S. criticism. Iliescu expressed disappointment with the U.S. stance. ``We want to think it is an isolated incident and that the conclusions will be accordingly corrected following a lucid judgment on the events,'' he said in a statement to the state Rompres news agency. Ion Ratiu, the National Peasants' Party's presidential candidate who finished a distant third to Iliescu, applauded the U.S. boycott and called it ``the most eloquent way the U.S. could show its condemnation of the vigilante tactics that Mr. Iliescu generated last week.'' Commenting at length on last week's violence, Iliescu publicly distanced himself for the first time from the miners' subsequently vigilante tactics. ``There was over-reaction in the public order restoration process,'' he said. ``Institutions, (opposition) party headquarters and homes were broken into, and citizens unconnected with the earlier (violence) ... were roughed up. ``We unequivocally dissociate ourselves from all actions that transcended the legal framework,'' Iliescu declared. However, he also asserted that the anti-government violence that brought the miners was ``an organized coup d'etat.'' He described the events as a ``true rebellion ... aimed at discrediting the country's lawfully and democratically elected leadership at home and abroad.'' The 60-year-old Iliescu, a high-ranking Communist in the late 1960s, pledged to transform his formerly Communist nation into a full political democracy with a market economy incorporating mixed forms of ownership. He vowed to remove ``disgraced, corrupt and incompetent persons,'' in an apparent bow to an opposition concern that people compromised by serving deposed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu continue in responsible positions. Some critics have included in that category Iliescu and other former Communists in the National Salvational Front who were criticial of Ceausescu, despite their renunciation of communism and clear victory in free elections May 20. The government has appeared divided on the best course of action to quell further unrest. Officials were talking to opposition groups while detaining their leaders and authorizing police action to stop renewed protest. Bucharest was free of demonstrations during the day Wednesday, but about 80 protesters gathered as dusk fell at University Square. The chanted ``Down with Iliescu!'' and knelt briefly in prayer.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Faces Conservative Critics, Acknowledges He Could Lose Post
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDS one graf to UPDATE with Russian Parliament action.
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev came under fire from hard-line Communists on Wednesday and acknowledged that he could lose his party post at a national congress in less than two weeks. Critics at a party meeting castigated the national leadership. They did not mention Gorbachev by name but said they did not think one person should be Soviet president and general secretary of the Communist Party. Gorbachev holds both jobs. ``It is impossible to run the party, this guiding force, without devoting full time to it,'' said Yegor Ligachev, the most prominent Soviet hard-liner. He spoke at a meeting called to found a new Communist Party of the Russian Federation, the largest of the 15 Soviet republics. Another Communist leader said he expected Gorbachev to be nominated for the national party's top job at a party congress starting July 2, but he said he expects other candidates to surface as well. In recent months, Gorbachev has transferred some of the Communist Party's powers to elected legislative bodies, thereby protecting himself somewhat from personal political damage that could result if he lost the party leadership. Moreover, he was elected in March to a five-year term in the new post of president and has wielded considerable power in that job. The 28th Congress of the Soviet Communist Party is to consider structural changes and elect a leader when it convenes July 2. The 2,700 delegates to the current Russian conference will also attend the national congress, where they will form a majority of the 4,700 votes. The mood of the Russian congress was decidedly conservative and critical of Gorbachev. ``Really important miscalculations and serious mistakes were made in the tactics and methods and approaches to the transformations'' under way in the Soviet Union, said Ligachev. ``The Socialist community has disintegrated, while the positions of imperialism have been dramatically consolidated,'' said Ligachev. His remarks were reported by the state news agency Tass. Gorbachev has acknowledged making mistakes, but he said in a speech to delegates Wednesday that his accusers were poorly informed and disrespectful. ``The comrades seem to suspect the general secretary of the Communist Party of some vacillation, hesitation, and so forth,'' Gorbachev said angrily. ``Some of the comrades are being too casual with the general secretary, with the president of the country,'' he said. ``It is not a question of me, personally,'' he said. ``Tomorrow, or after 10 days or 12 days, there may be another general secretary or chairman of the party. Before expressing opinions, and especially accusations, you have to know a whole lot and understand it, and not just speak off the cuff.'' ``Otherwise, if that is going to be the attitude ... toward the people that we nominate at such turning points in history, then we will not get anywhere except to chaos,'' he said. One leading conservative, Ivan Polozkov, said the falling credibility of the party stemmed not only from ``mistakes made during the period of stagnation'' before Gorbachev came to power in 1985. ``There have also been mistakes made in the period of perestroika,'' he said, using the Russian word for Gorbachev's reforms. He singled out for criticism Alexander Yakovlev, a close Gorbachev ally on the party's Politburo. ``The crisis is not just in the Communist Party, but above all in its leading bodies,'' said Polozkov. Foreign reporters were not allowed to attend Wednesday's session, but portions of it were shown on closed-circuit television at the Foreign Ministry press center. The party chief for the city of Moscow, Yuri Prokofiev, told reporters that Gorbachev likely would be one of several candidates for the job once again of national party leader. He said he hoped that Gorbachev's comments did not mean he would refuse to run for the post. In another indication of the conservative mood of the congress, the delegates overwhelmingly condemned a proposal before the Russian parliament to liquidate party cells in the Armed Forces, the KGB security police and the regular police force. Nikolai Boiko, head of the political department of Soviet anti-aircraft forces, warned that such a step would ``weaken its defense potential.'' By a 2,008-to-398 vote, the congress passed a resolution calling the proposed liquidation of party cells in security organs ``a step toward the further disintegration of the party.'' Such a step ``would lead to a sharp fall in the influence of the party, would create an anti-communist attitude, and would heighten the political destabilization of the country,'' it said. Later Wednesday, the Russian parliament rejected a proposal to ban party membership for judges, prosecutors and officials of law enforcement agencies, Tass reported. Deputies also rejected a call to eliminate party cells in the Soviet army.

DOC.HEAD: Barry Sought to Hide Drug Use, Witness Charges
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new grafs 3-4, Defense attorney, and grafs 17-23, with more on cross examination; picks up 19th graf pvs, Lewis, who is; edits below to conform
DOC.TEXT: Convicted drug dealer Charles Lewis testified at Marion Barry's drug and perjury trial Wednesday that he and the mayor agreed ``to get our stories straight'' and hide their crack cocaine use when police began closing in on them. Lewis said Barry also told him to drink ``lemon juice and lots of water'' to obscure results of a possible drug test by police. Defense attorney R. Kenneth Mundy swiftly sought to undermine Lewis' effect on the jury. He displayed a notebook belonging to Lewis and said it showed the witness was a courier for a Washington cocaine ring. Then, under Mundy's cross examination, Lewis conceded he didn't begin to cooperate with prosecutors until after he was convicted of drug charges in the Virgin Islands, where he is awaiting sentencing. A key prosecution witness, Lewis has testified he and the mayor used cocaine frequently between 1986 and 1988 in the Virgin Islands and the nation's capital. Barry, 54, has pleaded innocent to 10 misdemeanor cocaine possession charges, one misdemeanor charge of cocaine conspiracy, and three felony counts of lying to a grand jury about his alleged drug use. The three-term mayor could face up to 26 years in prison and fines of $1.85 million if convicted on all counts at the trial, which is expected to last several weeks. Beginning his second day of testimony, Lewis said he and Barry used crack cocaine three times together in December 1988 at Lewis' Washington hotel room. He said he spoke with Barry by telephone Dec. 22, 1988, after learning that police were investigating Lewis' actions, about how to conceal their drug use. ``It was ... like fixing a dam,'' said Lewis. He said he and Barry agreed, ``We have a problem. We need to fix it. We need to get our stories straight.'' Lewis destroyed a crack pipe Barry had given him and flushed the remains down the hotel room toilet, he said. Lewis said that the next night Barry asked him on the telephone to lie to authorities about their drug activity. ``He wanted me to tell the police the same thing I had told the Post reporter,'' said Lewis, who earlier testified that he told a Washington Post reporter he and Barry had never done drugs. Barry also coached him on how to obscure evidence of cocaine use if police gave him a drug test. ``He told me, `Just use lemon juice and lots of water,''' Lewis told the court, adding, ``I used a considerable amount of lemon juice.'' Barry leaned back in his chair at the defense table and smiled broadly at the remark. Saying he had lied to police and a federal grand jury when he denied using drugs, Lewis said, ``It was my effort to protect myself and the mayor.'' In the days after Barry's visits to Lewis became public, the mayor denied in several statements to the press that he had used drugs with Lewis or at any other time. Mundy took aim at Lewis' motives in cross-examination. ``You didn't start looking around to make deals until you were convicted, did you,'' Mundy asked. ``You started cooperating with the government because you wanted to help yourself, didn't you?'' ``Yes,'' Lewis replied. And Mundy said Lewis' notebook showed he was involved in a cocaine ring with James McWilliams, another potential government witness. Lewis insisted he had not been coached by prosecutors and was not testifying ``to convict the mayor.'' Lewis, growing defensive, said he wasn't getting a free ride from the government. ``This agreement that was approved, it wasn't something like a present,'' complained Lewis, who served a seven-month prison sentence outside Washington on federal drug charges. Police began investigating after Lewis is alleged to have offered cocaine to a maid at the Washington hotel. Lewis said he learned from a reporter that city police had aborted a planned undercover drug buy from him the afternoon of Dec. 22, 1988 after they learned Barry was in the hotel room. Lewis testified that he and the mayor spoke in code about sticking to the same story because Lewis feared his telephone was bugged. He said he told the mayor that he had told a Washington Post reporter ``there were no drugs in the room. He (Barry) said, `No, that's right.''' Lewis then asserted he did not use drugs. ```No, none,''' Lewis said Barry replied. Lewis said he then added, ``You don't use drugs either, and he (Barry) said, `No, right, I don't.'''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Keeps Anti-Abortion Bill Alive
DOC.TEXT: A bill that could send doctors who perform abortions to jail for 10 years was sent to the Louisiana Senate without recommendation Wednesday after a committee deadlocked on the measure. If passed, the measure would be the toughest state abortion law in the nation. With only six members of the seven-member Health and Welfare Committee present Wednesday, motions aimed at approving or killing the bill failed on 3-3 ties. The full Senate later voted 35-4 to consider the bill in debate. The debate _ and a vote on final passage _ could come as early as next week. The bill has no exceptions for women who become pregnant as a result of rape or incest. Gov. Buddy Roemer has said he will veto the bill without those exceptions. The bill's author, state Rep. Woody Jenkins, said such exceptions would jeopardize plans to use the bill to attempt to overturn Roe vs. Wade, the 1973 Supreme Court decision establishing women's abortion rights. Jenkins said Louisiana abortion law has never recognized rape or incest as legal reasons for abortion. ``It's possible that the court might really recognize this as an inconsistent position,'' he told the committee. Much of the testimony at the committee hearing was a rehash of arguments made in more than eight hours of previous hearings. A woman who said she once operated an abortion clinic in Texas urged passage of Jenkins' bill. ``Abortion is not about rights, abortion is not about choices, abortion is not about rape or incest. Abortion is about money,'' said Carol Everette, who said she could have been a millionaire had she stayed on with the clinic. Dr. Diana Dell, a Baton Rouge physician, said making abortions illegal would only drive women to seek unsafe, illegal abortions. She said death rates from tonsillectomies and apendectomies far exceed deaths from legal abortions. Dell said she abhorred the use of abortion as simple birth control. But, she said, the health and welfare of a woman with an unwanted pregnancy must take precedence over that of a fetus. ``The fetus is the future. It does not have equal rights to the here and now,'' Dell said.

DOC.HEAD: Midway Fire Raises Questions for Navy
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to make it ``retired'' sted ``mothballed'' _ other options including museum ship are possiblities; INSERTS 15th graf: ``Following a,'' to note safety review last fall
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Carrier Fire
DOC.TEXT: The fire aboard the USS Midway, the Navy's oldest active aircraft carrier, raises haunting questions for the service about its safety record and the wisdom of keeping aging warships at sea, defense analysts said Wednesday. The 45-year-old ship, extensively overhauled during its career including a three-year renovation from 1967 to 1970, is scheduled to be retired next year. Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced during his visit to Japan in February that the Midway, whose home port is Yokosuka, would be replaced by the 31-year-old USS Independence, like the Midway an oil-burning carrier. The incident on the Midway, the last of three nearly identical sister ships still on active duty, could hurry that schedule along, Navy sources and independent defense analysts said. ``There may be an adjustment to the timetable, but they'll have to assess the damage first,'' said a senior Navy officer, who spoke on condition he not be mentioned by name. Joshua Handler, a research associate with the environmental advocacy group Greenpeace and a critic of the Navy's nuclear weapons policies, said fires aboard carriers are a particular concern given chances nuclear weapons are most probably aboard. ``They've had trouble with the Midway for so long, this may be the straw that breaks the camel's back,'' he said. ``It's time is well up, and I'm sorry that this sort of thing had to happen to make the point.'' After the 1970 overhaul, it was discovered that so much weight had been added in high-tech equipment that the 67,000-ton vessel rode dangerously low in the water. Six-hundred-foot-long compartments were added to each side to increase buoyancy and and let the ship ride higher in the water. This modifcation made the ship's natural roll quicker, making it harder to operate aircraft. The stability of a ship is crucial when the ship's F-14 jet fighters or A-6E attack planes slam onto its deck traveling at more than 100 mph. Navy spokesman Cmdr. Jim Mitchell said the Midway fire apparently was confined to ``a rather small area'' in compartments that store firefighting and emergency repair equipment. All sailors on board ship are trained to fight fires at special schools in Norfolk, Va., and San Diego, Calif., to help deal with such emergencies, he said. ``We train our people in damage control. It's not because we expect problems, but these things do happen given the hazardous nature of a ship's operations. At sea, you can't call for the fire department _ every sailor is the fire department,'' he said. The Navy's safety record has come under intense scrutiny in the wake of last year's explosion aboard the USS Iowa, in which 47 sailors lost their lives. Following a six-week string of mishaps last fall, the Navy ordered all ships and planes to undergo a 48-hour ``stand-down'' to review safety procedures. The service maintains that its safety record has improved over the past decade, with its best safety records compiled in 1988 and 1989. Five years ago there were 101 major accidents involving surface ships, aircraft and submarines. In 1989 there were 69 and in 1990 so far there have been 23, the Navy said. In calender 1989, the service recorded 104 deaths in training and operations, a number which includes the Iowa 47. So far this year, nine fatalities have occurred, the Navy said. During the Reagan administration, the Navy once had plans for a 600-ship Navy, and it did grow to 585. It has 15 carrier battle groups.
