Fourteen groups are deployed at any one time with one carrier always in overhaul. Now, a much smaller Navy is in store amid the lessening Soviet threat and budget pressures. One day before the Midway fire broke out, Cheney revealed that a possible 25 percent cut in the nation's force structure would reduce the Navy to 455 warships and an even dozen deployed carrier groups. Some on Capitol Hill have pressed for even deeper cuts in the carrier fleet. The influential chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., has recommended as few as 10. ``You hurt people by keeping men on these things,'' contended David Isenberg, an analyst with the Center for Defense Information who wrote a critical study of carrier battle groups for the independent research group, the Cato Institute, which generally advocates conservative positions. Isenberg argues that building new carriers at $3.3 billion each, plus associated costs for planes and escorts, is not the most efficient use of the Navy's funds in the post-Cold War era. ``Carriers have rendered enormous service to the nation and still have a role to perform,'' he said. But he argues that the Navy should make more use of attack submarines in order to ``achieve a mix of capabilities in which less emphasis is place on power projection and more on sea control.''

DOC.HEAD: Domestic Air Travel Levels Off, But Strong Growth Still Predicted
DOC.TEXT: The number of passengers taking domestic U.S. flights has leveled off over the last three years, after years of increasing travel, an industry report said Wednesday. The report, however, predicted huge growth in air travel by the end of the century. Passengers flying within the United States increased only 1 percent in 1989 while the number of passengers boarding international flights from U.S. airports rose 11 percent, the Airport Operators Council International said. ``Our traffic results for 1989 might indicate a slight weakening in the growth rate of aviation for the year, but we foresee a 61 percent increase in passenger traffic by 2000,'' said George Howard, AOCI president. An accompanying report by the Partnership for Improved Air Travel said aviation's contribution to the economy hit nearly $600 billion in 1989, a 13.8 percent increase over the last study which covered 1987. The most dramatic growth was in commercial aircraft manufacturing, where jobs, payrolls and other economic factors rose 22 percent. Aviation's share of the gross national product remained at 5.6 percent, said the partnership, a wide-ranging group set up to ensure that U.S. aviation meets future demands. Reports by the two aviation organizations were released at a joint news conference. Howard blamed slow overall economic growth, higher fares and the Eastern Airlines strike for the stalled growth in domestic passengers. He said tight capacity at larger airports also may be hindering growth in traffic. The AOCI's annual traffic report on each of the world's major airports showed three of the highest-density airports _ New York's Kennedy and LaGuardia and Washington's National _ actually lost traffic in 1989. Chicago's O'Hare had just a 0.6 percent increase but remained the world's busiest airport with more than 59 million passengers boarding flights last year, the report said. Dallas-Fort Worth surpassed Los Angeles and Atlanta for second place. Atlanta's Hartsfield Airport fell to fourth, primarily because of the strike against Eastern, which uses Atlanta as a hub, Howard said. The AOCI report showed New York, with three major airports, continued to be the world's most heavily traveled market, followed by Chicago and London. Altogether, six of the top 10 American airports lost traffic in 1989, while airports around the Pacific Rim reported a 13.8 percent increase and European airports a 7 percent increase, according to the report. Federal Aviation Administration figures compiled by AOCI show 415.6 million passengers for domestic flights in 1989 and 415.5 million in 1987. The figure dipped to 414.2 million in 1988. ``There is evidence of a shift in the growth of traffic to smaller airports, where capacity, while still a large concern, is still somewhat more available,'' Howard said. Aviation experts indicated they were surprised the growth was so flat, but said the number of passengers was still sharply up from the 1983 total of 290.7 million. And Howard said the AOCI predicts 76 percent of U.S. air travelers will face delays if the capacity of the nation's system of airports is not increased. The AOCI, which represents airports throughout the world, supports a Bush administration proposal to allow airports to charge a passenger tax to help build up the system. The Partnership for Improved Air Travel has taken no position on the passenger tax but opposes the administration's proposed increases in other aviation taxes. The partnership includes airlines, travel and tourism interests, unions, consumer groups and business organizations. It proposes spending more of the billions of dollars in the tax-fed aviation trust fund to help aviation.

DOC.HEAD: PLO Calls U.S. Cut in Dialogue `Blow to Peace Process'
With AM-US-PLO, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 17 grafs to UPDATE with reactions from PLO leaders, U.N. Secretary-General. Pickup 13th graf pvs, `The boats...'
DOC.TEXT: A senior PLO official on Wednesday called President Bush's suspension of the U.S.-PLO dialogue ``a blow to the peace process'' and predicted increased violence in the Israeli-occupied territories. But in Jerusalem, an aide to Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir praised the decision, saying it ``removed a major obstacle'' to peace. Jamil Hilal, director of the PLO's information department, said the U.S. move would encourage Israel's new hard-line government to ``escalate its repression against the Arab population under occupation.'' In Tunis, Salah Khalaf, regarded as the PLO's second-in-command, was quoted by the French news agency AFP as saying Bush's move would ``freeze peace efforts and reinforce extremist forces'' in the Middle East. In New York, U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar said he ``hopes that ways will soon be found of resuming a dialogue that can serve the great purpose of achieving peace in the Middle East.'' Hilal said in a telephone interview from Tunis that the suspension of the dialogue ``can be judged only as an unfriendly and colonial move. ... It's a blow to the peace process and a provocation to Arabs states.'' Hilal said he expects the Palestine Liberation Organization, in retaliation for the suspension of talks, to call on Arab nations ``to apply economic sanctions against the United States. I expect the uprising in the occupied territories to escalate.'' PLO chairman Yasser Arafat's chief advisor, Bassam Abu Sharif, said in another phone interview from Tunis that ``the PLO leadership has received the news transmitted through the media. The leadership is studying carefully the text of his (Bush's) statement.'' He refused further comment. Avi Pazner, a top aide to Shamir, praised Bush's decision to end the dialogue. It's ``an important and positive decision as far as the peace process in the area is concerned,'' he said. ``The PLO was a major obstacle to peace and now that obstacle is removed.'' In the occupied West Bank, Jamil Tarifi, a pro-PLO Palestinian leader who has been named as a possible peace negotiator, condemned the U.S. move. ``We are very sorry for this position because the U.S. as a superpower put itself under the pressure of the rightist Israeli government instead of pressuring the Israelis to move forward for peace,'' Tarifi said. ``Anyone who wants to talk to the Palestinians must talk with the PLO,'' he added. Bush suspended the 18-month-old dialogue Wednesday, saying the PLO had failed to forcefully condemn an unsuccessful May 30 terrorist attack against Israel. Bush had urged Arafat to disavow the assault and to discipline the PLO faction that sent two speedboats filled with fighters toward a Tel Aviv beach. Khalaf said the United States ``knows we have given all we can in this affair.'' He added that the United States and the PLO do not share the same ``interpretation of terrorism,'' Agence France-Presse reported. The boats were intercepted by Israel and four guerrillas killed and 12 captured. The dialogue began after Arafat renounced terrorism and accepted Israel's right to exist. In Stockholm, Swedish Foreign Minister Sten Andersson said he ``regretted'' Bush's decision. Andersson was instrumental in persuading the PLO to renounce terror and start its dialogue with the United States. Andersson said he was in contact with Secretary of State James A. Baker III earlier Wednesday and that Baker had urged Sweden to ``continue its efforts to bridge the differences between the parties'' in the Middle East conflict.

DOC.HEAD: House Adds $75 Million for S&L Cases
DOC.TEXT: The House voted Wednesday to give the Justice Department an additional $75 million to use in prosecuting fraud in the nation's savings and loan scandal in the coming year. With public outrage growing over the debacle that is expected eventually cost upwards of $300 billion, lawmakers voted 420-1 to provide money to pursue the more than 21,000 fraud cases that have so far been referred to the Justice Department. Rep. Phil Crane, R-Ill., was the lone ``no'' vote. Rep. Neal Smith, D-Iowa, who proposed adding $75 million for the Justice Department's S&L prosecutions, said even more money will be coming later. The amount would be an increase over the $50 million allocated for the prosecutions this year. ``There's a growing feeling in this country that not enough is being done to prosecute those who ripped off the savings and loan industry,'' said Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, chairman of the Judiciary Committee. ``There's no doubt these people deserve the maximum punishment under the law.'' The additional money was tacked onto a $10.5 billion bill providing about half the money needed for the coming fiscal year for the Commerce, Justice and State departments and for the federal judiciary. The rest of the needed funds for those agencies will have to be added later, after authorizing legislation is enacted by the appropriate committees and the full Congress. The House was expected to continue debate on the bill next week.

DOC.HEAD: New Combination of Drugs Approved for Advanced Colon Cancer
DOC.TEXT: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday approved a new combination drug treatment that has been shown to prolong survival for patients with advanced stages of colon cancer. The therapy combines levamisole, a drug previously approved only for eliminating intestinal parasites in animals, with fluorouracil, already approved for treatment of several types of cancer. FDA officials said the combination of the two drugs in patients who have undergone surgery for colon cancer that has spread to nearby lymph nodes has been shown to reduce tumor reccurence and death in some patients. Michael Friedman, associate director of the Cancer Therapy Evaluation Program of the National Cancer Institute, said the combination drug therapy is ``an important advance.'' But, he added, studies on it must continue to improve treatment and determine whether it is effective for other stages of the disease. Colon cancer that has spread to lymph nodes is classified as stage 3, also referred to as stage Dukes' C. About 21,000 of the 110,000 Americans diagnosed with colon cancer each year are in this stage. About 40 percent live for five years or more after surgery, the FDA said. The combination therapy was tested in two clinical trials sponsored by the National Cancer Institute that involved about 1,700 patients who had undergone surgery for stage 3 colon cancer. Researchers found that the treatment reduced the death rate for these patients by about one-third and the tumor-recurrence rate by about 40 percent. They don't know, however, how the five-year survival rate will be affected since they have not followed these test patients that long yet, said FDA spokeswoman Eva Kemper. More than 4,000 patients with stage 3 colon cancer have received the combination therapy since May 1989 when it was approved under the FDA's Treatment IND (investigative new drug) program that makes promising experimental drugs available to patients with no other hope, the agency said. The most common side effects of the treatment are nausea, occasional vomiting, headache, diarrhea, sores in the mouth and depressed blood count, the FDA said. Also, a blood disorder called agranulocytosis caused one death among patients in the cancer institute trials. The therapy, which lasts one year, consists of levamisole tablets given orally for three consecutive days every other week and fluorouracil given intravenously once a week.

DOC.HEAD: Reforming Armed Forces Tops Agenda in Salvador Talks
DOC.TEXT: The government of El Salvador and leftist guerrillas fighting that nation's leadership on Wednesday discussed reforms in the armed forces during the second day of U.N.-mediated peace talks. ``There is a good propect of reaching concrete accords at the end of this round of negotiations,'' U.N. mediator Alvaro de Soto said. ``I feel quite encouraged because the discussions are frank and constructive.'' Rebel leader Roberto Canas said the armed forces were a ``key point'' in conversations Wednesday between the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front and El Salvador's rightist government, led by President Alfredo Cristiani. The rebels want sharp reductions in El Salvador's 55,000-man military. They also want the army's ranks purged of soldiers linked to right-wing death squads and punishment of those responsible for political slayings. Most of the 73,000 people killed in El Salvador's decade-old civil war have been civilians, though thousands of those are believed to be victims of rightist death squads. The rebels have said they won't discuss putting aside their weapons until the question of the armed forces is resolved. The government would prefer to focus on a cease-fire. A rebel leader, Shafik Handal, said that despite the differences, both sides were ``working with respect and the disposition to reach a substantive accord.'' Salvador Samayoa, a member of the rebel delegation, said: ``It's important that, for the first time, the government has agreed to discuss the armed forces.'' David Escobar, a member of the government negotiating team, said six issues were on the agenda _ the armed forces, human rights, economic problems, and reforms in the judicial and electoral systems and in the constititution. He said the talks had been ``positive up to now,'' but played down the prospects of a major agreement. ``We don't expect to sign spectacular accords,'' he said Tuesday, after the initial session at this mountain resort outside Mexico City. ``Anyway, we have until September 15 to comply with the Caracas accords.'' The talks, expected to last at least a week, are the second round mediated by Soto, the personal envoy of U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. Last month in Caracas, Venezuela, both sides agreed to work toward a September cease-fire. Peace talks in June and September 1989 broke off after a major guerrilla offensive in San Salvador in November. Negotiations in 1984 and 1987 under late President Jose Napoleon Duarte ended in deadlock. The war has turned El Salvador into the largest recipient of U.S. aid in the Western Hemisphere. The Central American nation receives about $1 million a day from Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets: Other Nuclear Powers Must Join in Arms Reductions
DOC.TEXT: Moscow's chief negotiator in arms control talks with the United States said Wednesday the Soviet Union will press for Britain and France to follow the superpowers in cutting their nuclear arms arsenals. ``The question of involving other nuclear states in the bilateral process of nuclear arms reductions acquires ever greater urgency,'' Yuri Nazarkin said in a prepared statement. He noted the Soviet Union in 1986 agreed not to include the French and British nuclear forces in talks then launched with the United States. ``However,'' Nazarkin said, ``it appears obvious that nuclear arms reductions cannot proceed endlessly on a bilateral basis only.'' Nazarkin was speaking at a colloquium organized in preparation for an international conference next August to review implementation of the nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty. The treaty, signed in 1968, is designed to halt the spread of atomic weapons. There are 141 countries that are parties to the treaty.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. to Release Radiation Exposure Records
DOC.TEXT: Once-secret radiation exposure records for 200,000 nuclear weapons plant workers will soon be released to a group that monitors power plant safety, a lawyer said Wednesday. The records will be analyzed to determine the health effects of low-level exposure to radiation, said Daniel Berger, attorney for the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund. The organization represents people who live near the nuclear power plant that was the site of nation's worst commercial nuclear accident. Lawyers for the U.S. Energy Department agreed a month ago to turn over the information, but Berger said some paperwork remains to be worked out. ``There has never been access to this data other than by researchers in the Department of Energy,'' Berger said. ``It's been tightly controlled.'' The data, which is on computer tapes, will be analyzed by researchers at Birmingham University in England. Alice Stewart, who heads the the research team, took part in a project more than a decade ago that found a startlingly high incidence of cancer among workers at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington state. ``If the preliminary findings at Hanford are borne out, it seems to me the occupational safety standards will have to be heightened at nuclear facilities,'' said Berger. The first records are expected for 50,000 Hanford workers. The government has also agreed to turn over records for 90,000 workers at four more plants: the Savannah River Site in South Carolina; the Linde plant in Tonawanda, N.Y.; and the X-10 and Y-12 plants at the Oak Ridge reservation in Tennessee. The records include details about the sex and race of the workers and their age when they were exposed to radiation, the doses they received, and their job titles and occupational histories. If the workers have died, the records also list the cause and date of death. To protect the workers' privacy, their names are to be withheld. As soon as possible, the government has promised to turn over similar records for 60,000 workers from these plants: Rocky Flats, Colo.; Los Alamos National Laboratory, N.M.; Mound Laboratory, Miamisburg, Ohio, and the Pantex facility, Amarillo, Texas. By May 18, 1991, the Energy Department has pledged to turn over records for 20,000 workers at the K-25 plant at Oak Ridge, the Mallinckrodt Chemical Works in St. Louis and the Feed Material Production Center in Fernald, Ohio. Stewart, the Birmingham researcher, told The Philadelphia Inquirer she expects the new data to show three to five times as many cancer cases as most experts expect to find among people who have been exposed to low-level radiation. The Hanford study she worked on in the late 1970s found unusually high rates of pancreatic, lung and bone-marrow cancer among workers, even those exposed to radiation levels 30 times lower than the government safety minimum. The government discontinued funding for the study, and turned aside legal efforts to give the data to the researchers or others on grounds it was protecting the workers' privacy. The TMI Public Health Fund pursued the data as a source of information about long-term exposure to low-level radiation, Berger said. The Energy Department agreed last year to release the records. The fund will be first to get the records, but they also will be available to other researchers with the capacity to use the computer tapes, said Jeff Sherwood, an Energy Department spokesman. The fund was set up in 1981 as part of a settlement of a lawsuit brought by people living within 25 miles of the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant against the plant and its owners, operators and insurers.

DOC.HEAD: Elderly and Students to Get Choice of EC Residency
DOC.TEXT: The elderly and students who are citizens of one country in the European Community at the end of 1991 will be able to live in any other EC nation if they wish, it was decided Wednesday. The decision by the 12 EC nations gives jobless nationals in the European Community the same rights as wage-earners. An elderly citizen who has dreamed of retiring in sunnier southern climates will be able to obtain a five-year, renewable residency permit in the EC country of his choice. The retiree must show only proof of health insurance and that he or she will not burden the adopted nation's social security system. And a student who can show proof of registration at a university or college in another EC nation as well as sufficient income will receive a one-year renewable residency permit. Those who are unemployed by choice and do not classify as being either elderly or a student will have to prove they have sufficient income not to need assistance from the social security system in their new country. The 12 EC members are Belgium, Denmark, France, West Germany, Greece, Ireland, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands, the United Kingdom, Spain and Portugal. In 1992, the nations will drop trade barriers among themselves to create a unified Euromarket. In Brussels Wednesday the 18 nations of Western Europe's two trading blocs began talks to pave the way for the so-called European Economic Space. The move would bring the six nations of the European Free Trade Association _ Austria, Finland, Iceland, Norway, Sweden and Switzerland _ closer to the European Community. Frans Andriessen, an EC commissioner, said he hoped broad agreement would be reached near the end of this year and be fully implemented on Jan. 1, 1993, when the EC's single market comes into force.

DOC.HEAD: Mitterrand: African Nations Must Move Toward Democracy
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand told African leaders Wednesday they must move toward democracy, then announced new steps to ease the continent's debt burdens. ``Democracy is a universal principle. It's the direction that must be taken,'' Mitterrand said in his opening address to a summit attended by 35 African delegations, many from one-party states. ``Have confidence in freedom,'' Mitterrand said. He promised French support for countries that ``took the road to democracy.'' About 200 protesters calling for reforms in African nations marched as the summit formally opened. Mamadou Diouck, spokesman for the Panafrican Forum for Democracy, said it was necessary to ``cleanse the political morals of Africa to permit true development.'' King Hassan II of Morocco urged the West to help Africa's ``young democracies'' make a peaceful transition from one-party to multiparty systems. ``The countries of Africa have no need to be ashamed, but they have to learn,'' the king said. ``Time is needed, and patience even more so.'' Mitterrand said France would give outright grants, rather than loans, to the poorest African nations and would limit the annual interest charged on loans to middle-income countries to 5 percent. The opening speeches followed private talks late Tuesday in which Mitterrand, according to one of his aides, advised the African leaders to move away from one-party political systems. President Abdou Diouf of Senegal, speaking to a handful of reporters, said he favored rewarding nations that move toward pluralism. ``I think it is necessary to encourage us a bit, give us a little push.'' But Diouf warned: ``A democracy without development has no sense and, in the end, is dangerous.'' He said he would like to see an African Common Market or political federation ``because as small states we cannot advance. We need to be a big grouping.'' After 30 years of independence for many African nations, ``the illusions have disappeared,'' Diouf said. ``It is perhaps easier now to unite our weaknesses to become an economic and political force.'' Of the delegations at the summit in the Brittany beach resort, 22 are led by heads of state, some facing unprecedented political opposition at home. In his speech, Mitterrand said he intends to ask the heads of state and government at the seven-nation economic summit in Houston next month to join France in helping African countries alleviate their heavy debt loads. He has depicted France as Africa's most generous supporter and said the problems of developing countries would be eased dramatically if Japan and the United States gave equal support. French officials said the decision to limit the interest rate paid by certain middle-income African countries on their public debt with France means loan payments will be about halved. The measure chiefly applies to Gabon, the Ivory Coast, Congo and Cameroon, which collectively owe France more than $10 billion. Calude Arnaud, an aide to Mitterrand, said President Hissene Habre of Chad complained during the talks late Tuesday that Western lending institutions were making democracy more difficult by imposing economic austerity measures. The summit is to conclude Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Antitrust Exemption Repeal Approved by the Committee
DOC.TEXT: A bill repealing many of the industry's exemptions from antitrust laws was approved Wednesday by the House Judiciary Committee over unanimous Republican opposition. On a 19-17 vote, the panel voted to open insurance companies to antitrust lawsuits for price-fixing, attempted monopolizing, allocating territories among rival companies or forcing consumers to buy insurance they do not want in order to qualify for coverage that they do. Three of the committee's 22 Democrats, Reps. Dan Glickman of Kansas, Bruce Morrison of Connecticut and Edward Feighan of Ohio, voted with all of the 14 Republicans in opposing the bill. Insurance companies and their agents have enjoyed immunity from antitrust suits since 1945 under the McCarran-Feguson Act, which delegated regulation of the now $500 billion-a-year industry to state governments. Consumer groups and others have complained since the mid-1970s that lax oversight by some states has permitted the companies to use anticompetitive practices to both deny coverage and raise rates dramatically. ``Private individuals, local governments and businesses of all sizes have found their premiums skyrocketing and their coverage severely restricted,'' said Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, the judiciary committee's chairman. ``Congress can no longer ignore the widespread economic dislocation caused by unreasonably high premiums or policies that are unavailable at any price.'' The federal antitrust prohibitions would not apply in states with ``active'' regulatory programs, thus preserving the McCarran-Ferguson's basic policy to defer regulation to states, he said. He did not say which states would qualify. The bill would allow insurance companies to continue sharing raw data on claims. But after a five-year transition period, it would greatly weaken companies' reliance upon the Insurance Services Office, a New York-based industry organization that now ``advises'' what rates should be charged. A similar bill was approved by the panel's economic and commerical law subcommittee two years ago but died there under an intensive industry lobbying effort. Democrats said they hope to bring the new version to the full House in late summer or early fall. Although similar legislation has been introduced in the Senate, industry lobbyists say they are counting on Sens. Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz., and Howell Heflin, D-Ala., both members of the Senate Judiciary Committee, to prevent it from every reaching a floor vote there. ``If this bill is enacted into law, it may prove disastrous for consumers adn small insurance companies alike,'' said Lowell Beck, president of the National Association of Independent Insurors. ``Every litigated claim would subject to additional antitrust counts. Legal costs, which by necessity would be passed on to consumers, would soar.'' Consumer groups acknowledged they face an uphill fight, but voiced optimism that the committee's vote Wednesday opening the way for a fight on the House floor will put a public spotlight on the issue. ``This represents an important breakthrough,'' said Robert Brandon, vice president of Citizen Action, a grassroots consumer organization claiming 2 million members. ``It demonstrates that an informed and aroused public can break the insurance industry's stranglehold over legislators.'' Linda Lipsen, legislative counsel for Consumers Union, predicted the bill will become a major election-year issue once it reaches the House floor. ``Behind food and shelter, insurance is the single largest expenditure of the year for the average consumer,'' she said. ``Just like the gun lobby, the insurance lobby is no longer being perceived by Congress as invincible.'' Lipsen disputed industry claims that premiums would rise, citing a report by the General Accounting Office showing that rates fell by 30 percent in Michigan after its legislature in 1982 repealed a state antitrust exemption for workers compensation insurance. In addition to consumer groups, the bill has strong support from the American Bankers Association and other bank trade groups whose members are eager to jump into the insurance business through subsidiaries.

DOC.HEAD: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson Hospitalized
DOC.TEXT: Mormon Church President Ezra Taft Benson was in serious condition Wednesday after being hospitalized for treatment of a ``form of infection,'' the church said. Benson, 90, was admitted at about 7:45 a.m. after experiencing difficulties at his Salt Lake City apartment, according to a statement from church headquarters here. ``His physicians say preliminary tests indicate a form of infection, for which he is receiving treatment,'' the statement said. Benson's condition had stabilized by late afternoon, but there was no more information about the nature of his illness, said spokesman Don LeFevre. ``The doctors say he seems to be improving from this morning,'' he said. A former U.S. agriculture secretary under President Dwight D. Eisenhower, Benson has been president of the 7.3 million-member Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints since 1985. Benson was hospitalized briefly May 12 after experiencing a dizzy spell, but was released a few hours later, LeFevre said. Benson attended virtually all sessions of the Mormon Church's 160th Annual General Conference on April 5-6, but appeared feeble and did not speak.

DOC.HEAD: Government Agrees to Release up to $6 Million in Noriega Assets
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf, `The agreement ..., with 3 grafs to UPDATE with comment by U.S. attorney; picks up 8th graf, `Hoeveler, who ...
DOC.TEXT: Federal prosecutors agreed Wednesday to release up to $6 million from Manuel Noriega's European bank accounts, saying they wanted to move quickly with the drug trafficking case against the former Panamanian leader. Meanwhile, Panama's new government told the court it will file a $5.3 billion lawsuit against Noriega, accusing him of racketeering, including murder, theft and fraud against the Panamanian people. U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler took note of the civil lawsuit, to be filed in the next two weeks, but said he wouldn't allow it to interfere with the criminal proceeding against Noriega. Assistant U.S. attorney Michael Sullivan said the agreement to unfreeze $4.5 million to $6 million in assets solves a legal battle that began April 29, when defense attorneys threatened to withdraw from the case. They said the government's seizure of $20 million of Noriega's assets deprived them of fees and expenses. Sullivan warned that judges both in the United States and Europe would have to approve the releases. ``We have agreed to make our best effort to unfreeze accounts that are currently frozen in Europe,'' he said. Lead defense attorney Frank Rubino said his team of five attorneys was satisfied with the agreement. ``We feel we now will have the ability to go forward and give Gen. Noreiga the defense he deserves.'' U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen said the deal will allow prosecutors ``to focus on the true issues in the criminal case.'' ``This avoids distracting litigation and premature presentation of evidence that would only sidetrack us from the real issues,'' Lehtinen said in a statement released from his office. Rubino had vowed to fight a protracted legal battle to release and make public payments made by the CIA and other intelligence agencies to the former Panamanian leader. The defense has said the payments added up to $11 million, but the government claimed the amount was much lower. Hoeveler, who had warned prosecutors the government would have to justify its seizures unless it released funds for Noriega's defense, said he approved the deal. He added that it would allow the case to progress more quickly toward a planned Jan. 28 trial date. Noriega, who surrendered to U.S. troops Jan. 4, is being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center outside of Miami on a February 1988 indictment accusing him of taking $4.6 million in bribes from Colombia's Medellin drug cartel to turn Panama into a way station for cocaine trafficking. After Hoeveler's ruling, Gregory Craig, an attorney from the Washington law firm Williams and Connolly, addressed the court, saying he represented the new government of Panama installed after the U.S. invasion last December. Craig said the Panamanian government within two weeks would file federal and Florida racketeering lawsuits claiming $300 million in actual damages as well as $5 billion in punitive damages against the Panamanian people. Outside the courtroom, Craig said the lawsuit ``would include allegations of murder, grand theft, extortion,'' as well as breach of trust and other civil violations by Noriega. Craig said the lawsuit was being filed so that ``no irreparable damage be done to those funds that rightfully belong to the Panamanian people.'' Before the hearing, attorneys for both sides met at the federal courthouse to seek a solution, said defense attorney Jon May. Attorney Steven Kollin said Noriega would need as much as $5 million to counter the $37 million the defense estimates the government is spending on the trial. In a sharply worded opinion issued June 15, the judge said the government failed to give Noriega due process when it seized the 27 bank accounts around the world valued at $20 million, along with other assets such as the deposed Panamanian leader's homes, cars and personal property. During the invasion of Panama, troops also found $5.8 million in cash in Noriega's quarters, which it turned over to the new Panamanian government. Prosecutors and defense attorneys tried once before to resolve the dispute over defense attorneys' fees, but the deal was ruled illegal because federal law did not allow the government to pay $300-an-hour fees or reimburse the number of attorneys Noriega says he needs.

DOC.HEAD: Former Louisville Mayor, Congressman Dead at 83
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with details, color. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: Charles P. Farnsley, a colorful politician who for a time adopted Southern planter's garb and who as Louisville mayor invited ordinary people to air their gripes at City Hall, has died. He was 83. The Democrat, who died Tuesday at a nursing home here, was mayor from 1948 to 1953 and served in the U.S. House of Representatives from 1965 to 1967. He was a state legislator for four years in the 1930s. Officials at the nursing home and funeral home Wednesday evening were unable to give a cause of death. As mayor, Farnsley may have been best known for the ``beef session.'' Every Monday night he held court at City Hall, inviting any citizen with a problem or complaint to present it directly to him. He energetically attacked what he saw as the city's problems. Farnsley turned empty lots into parks, installed street lights, raised city workers' salaries, improved police and firefighters' pensions, converted old schools into community centers and replaced old garbage trucks. ``Charlie was really one of the great planners and builders of the city,'' said Frank Burke Sr., a lawyer who was mayor from 1969 to 1973. But he may be better remembered for his eccentricities. Farnsley was a history buff who went through a ``Confederate period'' in the 1930s, when his normal dress was a broad planter's hat, a swallow-tailed coat, a brocade vest and a black string tie. He published books under the Lost Cause Press label and bottled whimsically named brands of whiskey like ``Rebel Yell.'' He tried to name another brand ``Damyankee,'' but it was rejected by the copyright office as being in bad taste. He submitted a new brand name, ``Bad Taste.'' He abandoned Confederate garb in later years, except for the string tie, which became his trademark. But he frequently carried a carpetbag when he traveled to northern cities. Television came to Louisville during his stint as mayor, and he bought sets for the public libraries since few people had them at home. ``People might as well look in a library as in a bar. It makes business for the bar, why can't it make business for the library?'' he asked. Book circulation reportedly skyrocketed. Farnsley is survived by daughters Sally Bird of Arlington, Va., and Ann Farnsley of Vevay, Ind.; sons Alexander of La Jolla, Calif., and Burrel and Douglass, both of Louisville, and six grandchildren. Services were scheduled for Thursday in Louisville.

DOC.HEAD: Colombian Pleads Guilty in Plot to Export Anti-Aircraft Missiles
DOC.TEXT: A Colombian who claimed ties to the Medellin drug cartel has pleaded guilty to charges in what authorities say was a plot to buy Stinger missiles to use against the Colombian government. Alfredo Antonio Ramos-Tinoco, 48, pleaded Tuesday to conspiracy to buy stolen shoulder-held anti-aircraft missiles and other automatic weapons and trying to export them. Ramos-Tinoco, who faces up to 15 years in prison and a $500,000 fine, is to be sentenced Aug. 17 by U.S. District Judge William Terrell Hodges. Ramos-Tinoco struck a deal that was sealed following a motion to the court requesting secrecy. He was picked up May 5 in Tampa while shooting pool at a hotel bar. Luis Fernando Arcila-Giraldo, 28, was arrested on identical charges the same day in Miami. He has also agreed to a plea bargain and is expected to enter a plea in Miami within weeks, according to documents filed in Tampa. Neither Assistant U.S. Attorney Todd Foster nor Mark Pizzo, a public defender representing Ramos-Tinoco, would provide details. The Colombians, claiming to work for reputed cartel kingpin Pablo Escobar, told undercover agents during the sting that bribed officials would help them smuggle the weapons for attacks on the Colombian government. The 4-foot, 35-pound Stinger is a ground-to-air missile that hones in on engine heat. Ramos-Tinoco was videotaped telling undercover agents the weapons would be used ``to shoot down Colombian government helicopters ... documentation would not be a problem because he had government officials paid off in Colombia,'' FBI agent Charles A. Salemme told a magistrate at a bond hearing last month. But investigators knew of no specific plan targeting planes or helicopters of anti-drug Colombian officials, the FBI said. The suspects said they were willing to pay $5 million from the planned sale of cocaine for the plane and weapons, and $1 million to those who would steal the weapons from a U.S. military base, Salemme testified. The federal sting was the result of an undercover drug investigation in Polk County in west-central Florida. According to authorities, the men began negotiating in April to buy 124 Stinger missiles, 50 light machine guns, 3,000 assault rifles, 200 pairs of night-vision goggles and 200 pounds of plastic explosives on behalf of Escobar, the fugitive head of the Medellin cartel.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Summit Takes Turn for Serious
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS grafs 5-7 pvs, ``Sen. Pete,'' with 4 grafs, new details on numbers, inbcluding others saying package is really $50 billion
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration presented the first deficit-cutting proposal of the lagging budget summit on Wednesday, a $51 billion package of savings for next year that produced a lukewarm reaction from Democrats. ``It is a beginning,'' said House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt of Missouri, the lead Democratic at the closed-door talks. ``We have a good long way to go.'' The significance of the proposal was not so much its contents as its very existence. It was introduced in the tenth session of the talks, six weeks after the meetings began and barely three months from the Oct. 1 start of the new fiscal year. ``We today have succeeded in starting serious negotiations,'' said Gephardt. Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, a Republican bargainer, said the White House package would save $51 billion in fiscal 1991, and about $440 billion over the next five years. Others said the plan would save $50 billion in its first year. ``It's a good starting point,'' said Domenici, the ranking GOP member of the Senate Budget Committee. Participants in the talks said the package included $20 billion in new taxes and other revenues, $18 billion in cuts in benefit programs like Medicare, and $6 billion in defense reductions. The participants, who asked to not be identified, said the plan also contained about $4 billion in cuts to domestic programs and $2 billion in savings from reduced interest payments. But Gephardt said Democrats believe that greater savings are needed over the five years, in the range of $500 billion to $600 billion. ``Some had concerns, which they expressed,'' Gephardt said of Democratic negotiators. The majority leader said Democrats would have to study the proposal overnight before responding to it. Earlier in the day, Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser had said the White House proposal would go nowhere if it resembled Bush's January budget. That spending plan has been largely ignored on Capitol Hill, even by Republicans. ``Simply putting a new suit on that old corpse isn't going to revive it,'' said Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser, D-Tenn. The first real flurry of bargaining in the negotiations, which started six weeks ago, came as White House and congressional budget experts said the federal deficit looks even worse than it did a month ago. Amid the ever-gloomier expectations about the government's finances, White House Budget Director Richard Darman prepared to offer congressional negotiators a package that would pare next year's shortfall by nearly $50 billion, officials said. ``I assume there will be many proposals,'' Darman told reporters. Democrats have been pressing for about $60 billion in savings for fiscal 1991, which starts Oct. 1, and nearly $600 billion in budget reductions over the next five years. They have not specified from where the savings should come. Republicans have said saving $45 billion next ear and $450 billion over five years should be adequate. The apparent size of the problem the two sides are facing continued to grow Wednesday. Darman told negotiators that next year's budget gap will be $159 billion, excluding the costs of rescuing the savings and loan industry, participants said. That's $21 billion more than he projected last month. The budget director said the 1991 shortfall would reach $200 billion to $227 billion if thrift bailout costs are included. In May, the figure he used was $199 billion. The non-partisan Congressional Budget Office also boosted its deficit forecasts. CBO said next year's shortfall would be $164 billion without S&L costs and $232 billion with them. In May, CBO estimated those costs at $149 billion to $159 billion, and $196 billion to $246 billion, respectively. ``The problem is getting worse,'' Sasser said. The Gramm-Rudman law requires the president and Congress to reduce next year's budget gap to $64 billion. If they miss that target by more than $10 billion, the law imposes cuts in most government programs. CBO officials attributed the worsening numbers to less than expected tax collections and the growing size of the S&L crisis.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Criticized For Lack of Leadership on Bases
DOC.TEXT: Philippines Vice President Salvador Laurel said Wednesday his government's policy on military base negotiations with the United States is in disarray because of a lack of leadership by President Corazon Aquino. Laurel said in an interview that contradictory statements by government officials have created confusion about what Filipino policy on the bases is. ``This is the time to come out definitely, take a definite stance, and show leadership,'' Laurel said, referring to Aquino. He said Aquino has said only that her government should not rule out any option concerning the bases. The negotiations focus on U.S. operations at Subic Bay naval base and Clark Air Base and several smaller installations. Laurel, a political rival of Aquino's, is in the United States on a private visit. He met with senators and House members on Tuesday. With the current base agreement scheduled to lapse next year, the United States and the Philippines opened base talks last month in Manila. Laurel said he takes seriously statements by Bush administration officials that the United States will remove its military presence from the Philippines if it is no longer welcome. He said he advocates a gradual phase out of the American presence over a five to 10 year period. The pace of the withdrawal would be guided by geostrategic factors, such as Soviet military behavior in Southeast Asia, he said, adding that the Kremlin has indicated a willingness to reduce its presence in Vietnam. He also said that tensions between the United States and the Philippines could be eased if, during the course of the negotiations, a number of irritants related to the bases are removed. Among others, Laurel mentioned the lack of jurisdiction of Filipino courts over crimes committed on the bases. ``If we want a real smooth relationship, we should remove these irritants,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: World Bank Loans to China Could Cut US Contribution
DOC.TEXT: Loans to China by the World Bank for anything but basic human needs would bring a cut in U.S. contributions to the bank under a provision approved on Wednesday by a House subcommittee. The sponsor of the provision, Rep. Nancy Pelosi, D-Calif, said a bank loan to China of $300 million to help plant trees did not cover a basic human need. The Bush administration considered that it did and supported the loan. There is no agreement on what makes a basic human need. Spokesmen for the bank, the biggest source of aid to the Third World, say that is not one of its standards. The bank's charter says it must base loans on a country's economy. Many in Congress want to punish China for suppressing the movement toward democracy and want the bank and the Bush administration to join them. One member called the loan for the trees a ``first anniversary gift'' for the Chinese tank attack on Tiananmen Square. It was announced May 29, less than week before the anniversary. Rep. Pelosi's amendment to a bill on world financial bodies was approved, 10-9. The subcommittee on international development sent it to the House Banking Committee. An Appropriations subcommittee on foreign aid approved a similar provision last week. Pelosi's amendment was opposed by Rep. Jim Leach, R-Iowa, the ranking Republican on the subcommittee. ``Trees help us all to breathe,'' he said. The subcommittee also adopted an amendment by Leach urging reduction of debts owed to governments by eastern European and southern African countries that are moving toward democracy. There was no recorded vote.

DOC.HEAD: Agra Diamond Fetches Record Price in London Auction
DOC.TEXT: The exotic Agra diamond, once worn in a 16th century Mogul emperor's turban, became the most expensive pink diamond in the world Wednesday when it was auctioned for a record $6.95 million. The 32.24 carat Agra, the largest pink diamond ever auctioned, was sold to Siba Rare Jewels of Hong Kong after heated bidding at Christie's showroom in London. Siba made their successful bid by telephone. The sale of the Agra diamond easily eclipsed the previous record sale price for a pink diamond of $6.1 million, set in May 1989. Raymond Sancroft-Baker, senior director of Christie's jewelry department, said: ``I am delighted. I had expected it to fetch $4.2 million to $4.7 million. Its history obviously pushed up the price.'' The Agra, the world's seventh largest pink diamond, was mined in the Golconda region of India's Hyderabad province. It was seized by Babur, the founder of the Mogul dynasty, in 1526 when he conquered India and took the gem after defeating the Rajah of Gwalior. Along with the Agra, Babur also took the Koh-i-Noor diamond, now one of the principle treasures in Britain's crown jewels. He gave the Koh-i-Noor to his son Humayun, but kept the Agra for himself, wearing it in his turban. The cushion-shaped Agra was the centerpiece of a jewelry auction that brought in $22 million and broke a previous record of $9.4 million set at Christie's in June 1989. Other highlights of the sale included the 18.49 carat Golden Drop, a pear-shaped yellow diamond bought by London's Graff jewelers for $3.67 million, a record for a yellow diamond. Like the Agra, the stones came from the Winans Collection, and were offered for sale by a descendant of American collector Louis Winans. The Agra has also belonged to Britain's Duke of Brunswick, the eccentric 19th century collector, who bought it in 1944. It weighed 41.75 carats at that time, but was cut down to its present weight in the late 19th century to eliminate imperfections. It was later bought by Bram Hertz of Paris, who sold it in 1891 to the London jeweler Edwin Streeter. In 1905, the diamond was included in a sale at Christie's and was bought by Max Meyer. In 1910, Winans bought the gem with money inherited from his father, engineer William Winans, who built the railway that ran from Moscow to St. Petersburg in the mid-19th century. The stone was inherited by the current owner.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Uses NASA Speech to Push Mission to Mars
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts grafs 12-15: ``Before several,'' with material on North Carolina appearance
DOC.HEAD: With AM-US-PLO, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Bush lashed out Wednesday at members of Congress who say sending Americans to Mars is less important than other spending priorities. He likened the critics to the ``naysayers'' of Christopher Columbus. Touring NASA's Marshall Space Flight Center, Bush criticized the House Appropriations subcommittee for voting last week ``to pull the plug on this historic undertaking'' by axing $300 million in seed money Bush had requested for the project. Bush wants to return Americans to the moon and to land a manned space flight on Mars within 30 years. ``Some say the space program should wait, that we should only go forward once the social problems of today are completely solved,'' Bush said at the space center. ``But history proves that attitude is self-defeating. Had Columbus waited until all the problems of his time were solved, the timbers of the Santa Maria would be rotting on the Spanish coast to this day.'' The president said American schoolchildren reading about Columbus' doubters have ``shook their heads in disbelief that these naysayers could have been so shortsighted.'' ``We must not let the children of the future shake their heads at our behavior,'' he said. ``History tells us what happens to nations that forget how to dream. The American people want us in space.'' Bush, campaigning in Alabama and North Carolina for Republican officeholders seeking reelection, took time off for the trip to the space center. Bush spoke to a crowd that gathered outside the space center on a 114-degree day after he told a news conference he was suspending talks with the PLO. The president toured portions of the space center and met with a group of seventh and eighth graders participating in NASA's ``Class from Space'' program. They students will ask questions of astronauts when they are in space during an August mission. Bush also participated in a demonstration of how starlight is analyzed, touching liquid lithium to a flame to turn the flame red. ``It's kind of fun,'' Bush said. Bush stumped in Alabama for first-term Gov. Guy Hunt and in North Carolina for Sen. Jesse Helms. Before several hundred contributors in Charlotte, Bush praised Helms _ with whom he has had sharp differences _ as a man who ``isn't a trendy follower who flows with the current. He's a visionary who alters the tide.'' He said they agree on many issues such as a strong defense and ``value issues'' such as a right to prayer in the schools and the need for a constitutional amendment to protect the flag. ``Let's face it, people don't always agree with him but they respect him,'' Bush said of Helms. Spokesman Steve Hart said the Hunt even raised $450,000. He estimated the Helms event brought in about $1 million. In Huntsville, the president headlined a reception to help Hunt, who is considered in good shape as he faces the winner of a June 26 Democratic primary runoff. Bush used that occasion to make a pitch for the proposed constitutional amendment to bar flag burning and for his anti-crime package, which Congress has completely overhauled. Bush said that ``a carefully drawn amendment to make burning of the American flag a crime'' is needed because the flag is a unique symbol. At the Marshall space center, Bush pushed Congress to approve the $300 million he wants in the 1991 budget to get the moon-Mars project going. The sum is part of Bush's 1991 budget request for $1.27 billion in overall space-exploration money, out of a total NASA budget of $15.2 billion. The president has announced a goal of landing a manned spacecraft on Mars by 2019 and returning manned missions to the moon. Last week, however, the House Appropriations subcommittee that handles the National Aeronautics and Space Administration slashed the $300 million from its budget draft.

DOC.HEAD: All-Night Speechmaking Again in the House
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans began a marathon of anti-crime speeches Wednesday night, touting the GOP as the tough-on-crime party and accusing Democrats of stalling President Bush's bill to fight the problem. The speechmaking began at 7:15 p.m. and the Republicans planned to keep the House in session through 8 a.m. Thursday. The event was scheduled intentionally to be held exactly one year after Bush's presentation of his legislation. Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., earlier in the day called the session ``total nonsense'' and a ``politically motivated activity'' because he already has agreed to bring a major crime bill to the floor this year. And in another counter-attack, House Judiciary Committee Chairman Jack Brooks, D-Texas, announced comprehensive anti-crime legislation will be considered next week by the panel's subcommittee on crime. The GOP members arranged for citizens from across the country to call in crimes as they are reported to police, so the lawmakers could discuss them. Rep. Lawrence Coughlin, R-Pa., early in the session, announced in the first report that the Coast Guard had just made a major drug seizure. Coughlin is ranking Republican on the Select Committee on Narcotics Abuse. Rep. Bill McCollum, R-Fla., ranking Republican on the crime subcommittee, said the GOP traditionally has ``forced Democrats to pass crime legislation.'' ``Here we are again leading the charge,'' he said. ``There has been no major initiative by those on the other side of the aisle. Ninety percent of whatever product'' eventually passes, he said, ``will be based on the initiative ... that Republicans put together.'' Rep. Don Ritter, R-Pa., complained that ``much of the president's plan has been stalled right here in the Congress by partisan politics.'' ``It's time for Congress to deal with violent crimes and with drugs. They are priority issues,'' said Rep. Hamilton Fish, R-N.Y., senior minority member of the Judiciary Committee. The crime bill to be considered by the committee would expand use of the death penalty for federal crimes including presidential assassination; strengthen controls over chemicals needed to manufacture certain drugs and toughen criminal sanctions on those distributing anabolic steroids. The legislation also includes federal grants to state and local governments to relieve prison overcrowding and improvements in procedures for seizing criminal assets. Another subcommittee is considering provisions to streamline appeals by death row inmates to avoid inordinate delays. Among Bush's proposals were those to expand the federal death penalty for 30 offenses, including presidential assassination, and streamline the habeas corpus process by which prisoners challenge the legality of their arrests and punishment.

DOC.HEAD: Parade-Goers See `Greatest Freedom Fighter Ever'
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of ordinary Americans waited hours Wednesday to catch a glimpse of African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela and hear him speak. Here are some of their comments:
``The greatest freedom fighter ever!'' _ Derrick Fuller, as Mandela rolled by in his glass-enclosed ``Mandelamobile.''
``I was too young to see Martin Luther King and Malcolm X. He's the last of the great black heroes.'' _ Leslie Anderson, of Plainfield, N.J., who took the day off to see Mandela.

``I'm happy that Nelson Mandela is coming. I feel so happy.'' _ Jose Diaz, a 7-year-old elementary school student from the Washington Heights neigborhood of New York. ``He hates apartheid. ... That's when black people and white people are separated and can't live together. That's not fair.''

``I had tears in my eyes.'' _ Judy Richardson, 46, of Boston, who was involved in the civil rights movement in the 1960s. ``I never thought I'd live to see this. I never thought they'd let the brother out. He's too strong.''

``This is a day that will go down in history and I'm glad to be part of it.'' _ Joan Celestine of the borough of Brooklyn. ``He represents for each and everyone of us the struggle that we all endure in our lifetime as black people and as people of the world ... black and white, all struggling people. He is a symbol of hope and inspiration for all people.''
``Youth here in Brooklyn are in solidarity with the youth of the ANC.'' _Lumumba Bandele Marson, 18, a Brooklynite participating in the tribute to Mandela.
``I liked the way he said he was going to help free the kids in South Africa. I'm glad he's out of jail.'' _ Dominique Blot, 10, a Brooklyn fifth-grader.
``Everybody's affected by this _ by his thoughts, and endurance, what he stands for. You can't bypass that.'' _ Annie Gibbs of the borough of the Bronx.

DOC.HEAD: Virginian, Texan, Georgian Tapped
DOC.TEXT: President Bush on Wednesday announced his intention to name two members to the National Labor Relations Board: Atlanta attorney John N. Raudabaugh and board member James M. Stephens, who is to be reappointed and named chairman. The White House also announced Bush will name: _Earl Roger Mandle, deputy director of the National Gallery of Art, as a member of the National Council on the Arts. _Rep. Norman Sisisky, D-Va., as a member of the board of trustees of the James Madison Memorial Fellowship. _Washington attorney Edwin D. Williamson as legal adviser to the State Department, succeeding Abraham Sofaer. _C.M. Schauerte, vice president for American General Corp., in Houston, as federal insurance administrator of the Federal Emergency Management Agency.

DOC.HEAD: Police: Elaborate Security Preparations Paid Off
With AM-Mandela, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Weeks of security planning and drills paid off Wednesday, as 750,000 people welcomed Nelson Mandela to New York without incident, police said. ``We did a lot of planning, put a lot of police officers on the street, hand-picked the ranking officers on the scene and it all came to fruition,'' said Assistant Chief Thomas Walsh, commander of patrol officers in southern Manhattan. ``Things looked great. It was terrific,'' Walsh added. No arrests were reported during Mandela's stops at a Brooklyn high school or during the ticker-tape parade honoring the anti-apartheid leader. ``There was a point when the things got tense, a bunch of youths in their exuberance rushed the `Mandelamobile,' but we had 70 police officers on each side (of the flatbed truck) and they held them back,'' the chief said. Nobody was arrested in the incident, which took place as the bulletproof vehicle neared City Hall, the chief said. Officers also moved a small group of demonstrators to a spot near City Hall, but out of the march route. ``Everything went smoothly, from the beginning of the day right through,'' said police Deputy Commissioner of Public Information Suzanne Trazoff. Security for Mandela's three-day visit to New York exceeded the protection provided for Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and rivaled measures taken to protect Pope John Paul II during his visit in 1979. Three thousand police officers were assigned to protect Mandela on Wednesday, part of 12,000 officers slated to protect the 71-year-old civil rights leader during his New York visit. The elaborate security plans, code-named Operation Topaz, took State Department officials and police six weeks to develop, and ranged from the development of the ``Mandelamobile'' to deployment of 6,200 sawhorses for crowd control. Operation Topaz was also the largest safety effort ever mounted by the State Department's Office of Diplomatic Security, which provides protection to dignitaries who aren't heads of state, said spokeswoman Meg Ravnholt. One of the jewels of the security plan was the specially designed, $58,000 ``Mandelamobile,'' a flatbed truck with a bulletproof glass bubble that held Mandela, his wife Winnie, and four aides. The specially outfitted vehicle included such James Bond touches as an explosion-proof fuel tank and tires filled with bullet-resistant material, said Trazoff. State Department agents used electronic devices as well as bomb-sniffing Labrador retrievers to sweep the stops on Mandela's schedule. During his public appearances, police and federal agents formed a 75-foot security zone around Mandela to keep him at a safe distance from onlookers. Undercover police officers and detectives were among the crowds lining the parade route, and rooftops along the way were guarded by uniformed sharpshooters, said police sources who spoke on condition of anonymity.

DOC.HEAD: Parents of Kidnapped American Take Over Negotiations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT that kidnap victim said rebels were under impression family was rich, sted Fino.
DOC.TEXT: The parents of kidnapped American gold miner Scott Heimdal said Wednesday they have taken over negotiations with their son's abductors so they can personally work for his release. Roy and Marge Heimdal of Peoria, Ill., arrived in Quito late Monday in the hopes of winning the release of their 27-year-old son, who was kidnapped April 28 near the Colombia border by men believed to be Communist guerrillas. In a statement released Wednesday through the U.S. Embassy, the Heimdals said they were taking ``direct charge of all negotiations with the persons who have our son Scott. ``We have relieved all other persons that represent us in these negotiations. We're trying to establish direct contact with the persons that have Scott to try and obtain his freedom,'' the statement said. ``We're confident and optimistic that they will hear our pleas and deal directly with us and understand the suffering we're going through.'' The statement did not say whether Heimdal's parents planned to travel themselves to the jungled area along the Colombia border where it's believed Heimdal is being held, or who would help them with Spanish translations in the talks. The Heimdals speak no Spanish. Heimdal was kidnapped by a band of armed men while traveling in a canoe on the Bermeja River 100 miles northeast of Quito, where he worked for the small gold mining company IMINCO. The boat's pilot was killed. The company's general manager, Jeffrey Fino, has until now been closely involved in negotiations with the guerrillas, who are demanding a ransom of $612,000 paid in Colombian pesos. Attempts to reach Fino for comment Wednesday were unsuccessful. The Heimdals, a working-class family, scraped together $60,000, most of it in community donations, believing that was the price the kidnappers were asking. But they learned last week the ransom demand was $612,000, and that the $60,000 was only to guarantee their son's safety. Fino expressed in an interview last week his growing distrust of the guerrillas. He said they have behaved erratically and unpredictably in talks with Fino's negotiator. The kidnappers identified themselves as members of the People's Liberation Army, a Communist guerrilla group operating in the Colombian jungle. Wednesday's statement was the first made by the Heimdals since they arrived in Quito. U.S. Embassy officials have warned publicity about the negotiations could endanger Heimdal's life. In a four-page letter from Heimdal made public by his parents last week, the kidnap victim said the guerrillas was under the impression Heimdal's family was rich because they were able to see a Cable News Network TV report about the fundraising effort in Peoria, where the Heimdals live in a rented home.

DOC.HEAD: Cuomo Refuses To Extradite Blue Movie Broadcasters
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Mario Cuomo refused Wednesday to extradite four executives of a New York-based blue-movie satellite broadcasting company to face obscenity charges in Alabama. In a letter to Alabama Gov. Guy Hunt's legal staff, Cuomo counsel Evan Davis said state law doesn't allow the governor to comply with such an extradition request unless the alleged offense is a crime in New York. The March indictments name Home Dish Only Satellite Network Inc., four of its executives, the giant GTE Corp. and some of its executives. The charges resulted in Home Dish's American Exxxstasy channel and its related Tuxxedo channel being pulled off the air. The charges against GTE and its executives were dropped shortly after GTE pulled the plug on Home Dish. The indictments set off a debate over censorship in the high-tech era because the action in Alabama ended up cutting off the movies to subscribers nationwide. Home Dish's American Exxxstasy channel had broadcast hard-core movies for a $20-a-month fee to about 30,000 subscribers nationwide who owned satellite dish antennas, which often cost $2,000 or more. The Tuxxedo channel went to 1.2 million cable subscribers, who paid $5 in addition to the regular cable fee. The charges against Home Dish were brought by Montgomery County, Ala., District Attorney Jimmy Evans, who is running for state attorney general in Alabama. Evans was on the road campaigning Wednesday night, and couldn't be reached immediately for comment on Cuomo's decision. ``Our clients are very happy'' with Cuomo's move, said Paul Sherman, a New York City lawyer representing Home Dish's four executives. ``They do not believe they have done anything wrong.'' Sherman said Home Dish has been out of business since the indictments were handed up, and satellite owners refused to transmit the X-rated and R-rated fare supplied to subscribers of the American Exxxstasy and Tuxxedo channels. Sherman said he didn't expect the broadcasts to resume anytime soon because Alabama charges remain in force against Home Dish and GTE Spacenet, the satellite operating arm of GTE. Also remaining under indictment in Alabama is the U.S. Satellite Corp. of Utah, which operates a ground station to beam transmissions to communications satellites. The four Home Dish executives Cuomo refused to extradite were company Chairman Paul Klein; his wife Janet Klein, the company's vice president; President Jeffrey Younger; and Treasurer Robert Kramer. Klein, a former executive vice president for programming at NBC, is working as an independent producer, said Sherman. Evans' move against Home Dish has drawn fire from First Amendment activists. ``Without proving that anything is obscene, Jimmy Evans has succeeded in bankrupting this company (Home Dish) and keeping the rest of the country from seeing these movies in the privacy of their home,'' Martin McCaffery, vice president of the Civil Liberties Union of Alabama, said recently. Evans, however, called the satellite transmissions, ``a national scandal ... I know from experience that hard-core obscenity leads to the abuse of women and children.''

DOC.HEAD: Army Pursues Fleeing Rebels in Suriname
DOC.TEXT: Soldiers on Wednesday pursued Bush Negro rebels into the jungle, where they fled a day earlier after blowing up an aluminum company office building and a loading dock, the army said. After a three-day battle with Jungle Commando rebels, government forces on Tuesday recaptured the Suriname Aluminum Co. plant. There were only ``a few lightly wounded'' among the soldiers, said army spokesman Bradressein Sital. He said most of the rebels had fled after blowing up the plant's main administration building and dock facilities at Moengo, about 50 miles northeast of Paramaribo, the capital. The rebels had held the plant for two weeks. There was no word on rebel casualties. Sital said the army had ``succeeded in liberating Moengo'' and was ``mopping up'' and chasing rebels in the jungle bush Wednesday. Suriname Aluminum Company spokesman Ewald Refos said there were no injuries among the company's 330 employees at Moengo. He said a decision on resuming production would be made by company headquarters in Pittsburgh. The Suriname Aluminum Company is a subsidiary of the Aluminum Company of America (Alcoa). The plant processes bauxite, the main component in aluminum and alumina, which together account for 75 percent of Suriname's exports and 15 percent of the gross national product. The Jungle Commando, with 200 to 300 guerrillas, has fought a four-year insurgency to improve conditions for Bush Negroes, about 10 percent of the South American nation's 415,000 mostly Dutch-speaking population. Bush Negroes are descendants of runaway slaves. Rebels had seized the bauxite plant to pressure the government led by President Ramsewak Shankar into implementing a tentative peace accord signed in June 1989. Meanwhile, Jungle Commando leader Ronnie Brunswijk, a former army sergeant, remained in neighboring French Guiana under administrative detention. Brunswijk was detained by immigration officials Monday night at Rochambeau International Airport while trying to board a flight to the Netherlands with false identity papers, French officials said. The Netherlands is Suriname's former colonial ruler. He was quoted by French Guiana Television as saying he was tired of fighting and wanted to give up his guerrilla campaign.

DOC.HEAD: Ohio Congressman Collapses In Office
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Dennis Eckart, D-Ohio, collapsed in his office Wednesday and was admitted to Walter Reed Army Medical Center for treatment of a kidney stone, a spokeswoman said. ``His legs kind of went out from under him,'' said Louise Hilsen, Eckart's press secretary. Eckart was examined by a doctor and emergency medical team on duty at the Capitol and then taken to Walter Reed, where he was admitted around 1 p.m., Hilsen said. ``He is resting uncomfortably,'' she said. ``He is in a great deal of pain.'' Eckart, 40, had no previous kidney problems, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Iowa Senator Calls for New Pentagon Waste Probe
DOC.TEXT: A senator said he wanted another Pentagon investigation of procurement waste after learning the Air Force bought jet engine pliers for $999 a pair, just under a $1,000 ceiling implemented as a reform. U.S. Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, has asked the Pentagon's inspector general to take another look at acquisitions abuse over the custom-made pliers that contractor Pratt & Whitney sold to the Air Force, The Miami Herald reported Wednesday. The maker of the pliers, City Tool of Florida, charged Pratt & Whitney $669 a pair for the pliers, the newspaper said. The contractor added $330 to the price of each pair to the Air Force, the Herald said. The final price fell just $1 shy of a rule that requires the military to buy directly from manufacturers for items that cost $1,000 or more, the newspaper said. Other recent military spending includes $1,868 for toilet covers for C-5 cargo planes, $120 for cup dispensers and $117 for soap-dish covers, the Herald said. An Air Force official and a Pratt & Whitney spokesman defended the amount charged for the pliers. Pratt & Whitney, based in Palm Beach County, ``did warranty the item. They did make sure the item was made in accordance with the drawings, with all the necessary checks and compliance and whatnot,'' said Cliff Goodhue, a cost analyst at the Air Force Logistics Command headquarters in Ohio. ``Perhaps $999 was a bargain for this item after all,'' he said. A crackdown on military waste began in 1985 by then-Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger when a $435 hammer topped a list of costly Pentagon purchases. The effort produced the $1,000 rule, among other reforms. Pratt & Whitney decided the performance of 20-year-old F-111 engines could be improved by installing new exhaust gas deflectors, but unique curved pliers were needed to hold new clips in place, the Herald said. ``The Air Force concurred that the price was correct and appropriate for what they needed to do,'' said Pratt & Whitney spokesman Robert G.H. Carroll III.

DOC.HEAD: Truck Carrying Hazardous Chemical Involved in Wreck
DOC.TEXT: A truck carrying hazardous chemicals was involved in a highway crash and burst into flames, killing at least two people, authorities said. The flatbed truck carried 55-gallon drums containing various flammable and explosive chemicals from Exxon Chemical Co. of Houston, said fire Capt. Bud Gale. Firefighters decided to let the 82 drums and the vehicles burn because the blaze didn't pose a threat to the rural area, Gale said. Few details were availible, but it appeared that two other vehicles were involved in the crash, said Lincoln County sheriff's Cpl. Mike Dye. Firefighters at the scene reported two dead, Gale said. The crash took place about 5:45 p.m. on U.S. 83, 15 miles south of North Platte in central Nebraska. A half-mile area was cleared, but officials didn't know how many people in the sparsely settled area were affected by the evacuation, Gale said.

DOC.HEAD: Report Links Crack Cocaine Use to AIDS Spread
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf, `About 90 ...,' to reflect revised police count of number arrested.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos FX1,9
DOC.TEXT: The spread of AIDS is slowing among some gay men, but soaring among teen-agers, women, crack smokers and heavy drinkers, researchers reported Wednesday on the opening day of the international AIDS conference. ``In particular, the emergence of crack cocaine use as a risk factor for the transmission of HIV is a new and disturbing development in the epidemiology of AIDS,'' said Don C. Des Jarlais of the Mount Sinai School of Medicine in New York City. HIV is the virus that causes AIDS. About 80 protesters were arrested outside Moscone Center, where 1,800 reporters and 12,000 delegates to the Sixth International Conference on AIDS gathered for the presetation of new research. Demonstrators contended the federal government is dragging its feet in the search for a cure for AIDS. The arrests, mostly on misdemeanor charges of interfering with police officers, came after about 300 protesters gathered outside the center, chanting such things as, ``We're here, we're queer and we demand access.'' Some of those arrested hopped barricades and sat down on sidewalks. Others were arrested for blocking streets. ACT UP members have scheduled a series of demonstrations focusing on their contention that the federal government is dragging its feet in the search for a cure for AIDS. Inside the convention center, the conference opened with researchers criticizing the policies of the Immigration and Naturalization Service that allow foreigners with AIDS virus infections to be barred from the United States. More than 100 groups boycotted the meeting in opposition to that policy, said Dr. John L. Ziegler, chairman of the conference. ``The conference organizers also oppose the U.S. immigration policy in the strongest possible terms,'' Ziegler said. Peter Staley, an activist with the militant AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, or ACT UP, criticized President George Bush for staying away from the conference. Staley incited some of the delegates to begin chanting, ``Three hundred thousand dead from AIDS. Where is George?'' Mayor Art Agos noted that after last year's earthquake Congress gave San Francisco $4 billion and California passed a special tax to help the city ``retrofit our physical infrastructure.'' ``But where,'' said Agnos, ``is our retrofit for AIDS?'' A few hours earlier, a member of ACT UP disrupted a symposium on AIDS drugs when he stood in the audience at the Masonic Auditorium and refused to be silenced. The disruption prompted doctors discussing a report on a new AIDS drug to leave the stage. Their presentation later was televised to the audience from a room in the rear of the Nob Hill auditorium. ACT UP member G'dali Braverman of New York said afterward that he had ``no intention of disrupting this meeting. We wanted to get our information across'' about the drug DDC, developed by Hoffman LaRoche, which sponsored the symposium. Des Jarlais is one of the authors of ``AIDS: The Second Decade,'' an attempt to summarize all existing information on the likely future course of the epidemic. It was prepared by experts assembled by the National Research Council of the National Academy of Sciences. The report, presented earlier in the day, offered little ground for optimism. ``We believe the picture of AIDS and HIV infection in the foreseeable future is one of a continuing toll of sickness and death for a steadily broadening profile of individuals,'' Des Jarlais told reporters. Populations not previously thought to be at special risk for AIDS infection are suddenly becoming infected, he said. ``The disease is moving out of the large urban centers,'' he said. Women are being more seriously affected. The proportion of AIDS cases in women has grown from 6 percent in 1982 to 10 percent in 1989, Des Jarlais and his colleagues found. Younger gay men are putting themselves at risk by practicing unsafe sex at twice the rate of older gay men, said Thomas J. Coates of the University of California, San Francisco. Older gay men are more likely to use condoms, a safer sexual practice that cuts the risk of HIV being spread. ``New people are entering this pool and they consider themselves invulnerable,'' Coates said. In New York City, 1 percent of black and Hispanic teen-age mothers are infected with HIV, Des Jarlais said. Alcohol, too, is associated with the spread of AIDS because, like crack, it often leads to unsafe sexual behavior, the researchers said. The Rev. Cecil Williams of the Glide United Methodist Church in San Francisco's drug-plagued Tenderloin district, who has worked with crack users, said the panel's findings confirmed his observations. ``Women are the prime recipients of crack cocaine,'' said Williams, who was not connected with the report. ``It heightens sexual intensity.
