It gives sick people a feeling of being completely free.'' The blood supply is safer than ever, said Cladd E. Stevens of the New York Blood Center. She said infections from AIDS-contaminated blood are occurring at the rate of one for every 50,000 to 250,000 units of blood transfused. Some 4 million Americans get blood transfusions each year and 80 to 400 of them are getting AIDS from the transfusions, she said. The National Research Council also found that female prostitutes ``do not appear to be serving as a bridge for HIV transmission into the larger heterosexual population.'' The explanation may be that many are using condoms or engaging in oral sex, which could reduce the risk of transmission, Des Jarlais said. The panel endorsed efforts to educate the public to the dangers of AIDS and to tell intravenous drug users that using clean syringes can help prevent the spread of AIDS. ``The fears of some that explicit sexual messages or the availability of clean syringes may entice the uninitiated into sexual activity or drug use is not borne out by the facts,'' Des Jarlais said.

DOC.HEAD: Activist Network Gears up For Conference
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS lead and 5th graf, `Protesters outside ...,' to reflect revised police count of number arrested.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-AIDS Meeting, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 80 AIDS activists were arrested Wednesday on the opening day of an international conference on the deadly disease, part of a coordinated effort to make their concerns known to the public. The activists have created a polished organization for the Sixth International Conference on AIDS, with banks of computers, media advance people and a schedule of events complete with a theme for the day. Despite some earlier calls for riot and anarchy, the AIDS Coalition to Unleash Power, known as ACT UP, and several other groups have joined together to coordinate an agenda of protest and politicking before the 12,000 conference delegates and national media. ``Everybody is playing off the same sheet,'' said Paul Feldman, a member of Seattle's ACT UP chapter, one of the media coordinators during the five-day conference. Protesters outside the Moscone Center on Wednesday hopped barricades and sat down on sidewalks and streets. Most of the 80 arrested were charged with the misdemeanor of interfering with police officers, authorities said. While the conference headquarters are in lush digs at the Marriott and Moscone Center, Feldman and his crew operate out of a room at the Best Western down the street from the bus terminal. The room is a smorgasbord of Apples and other computers owned by individual activists, TV monitors and video recorders, fax machines and telephones. The group has issued a schedule for the week with times and locations for demonstrations. Each day has a theme: Wednesday was protests over restricted access to research, treatment and the conference itself. Thursday's activities will stress what protesters say are instances of government inaction and corporate profit. But there will be other activities not on information sheets faxed to various media. Feldman said many actions are expected by ``affinity groups,'' clusters of a dozen or so people who may decide on an impromptu move to disrupt a meeting or stage some show for the cameras. ``Very often they will decide to do an independent action to bring attention to their concern,'' he said. That happened Tuesday during a march of 1,000 people protesting U.S. travel restrictions placed on foreigners infected with the AIDS virus. Eight people broke from the crowd as it approached Immigration and Naturalization Service offices, climbed over barricades and were quickly arrested. Feldman said that action was not part of the plan for the march. No one has a count on the number of activists who have come to San Francisco for the conference. Feldman believes most of the 40 ACT UP U.S. chapters are already represented, along with members from 25 foreign chapters. He said the turnout for Tuesday's march was larger than expected. The degree of organization among the activists follows months of preparations among groups at times at odds over questions of policy and action. Some activists, like Larry Kramer of New York's ACT UP, called for riots at the conference. Others have argued against disrupting the conference and the flow of information about the disease. Feldman said although there is a degree of organization among the many voices, there is still great independence. ``I said we're all playing off the same sheet, it's just that there's no paper it's written on.''

DOC.HEAD: Report: Ex-Governor Trying To Back Out Of Plea Agreement
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Arch A. Moore Jr., who faces up to 36 years in prison, wants to renege on his guilty pleas to five federal counts involving political corruption, it was reported Wednesday. Moore's attorney planned to write U.S. District Judge Walter E. Hoffman indicating that Moore wants to back out of his plea agreement with the Justice Department, WSAZ-TV and the Herald-Dispatch of Huntington, reported, citing anonymous sources. The Charleston Gazette reported rumors of Moore's plans in its Thursday editions. Moore's wife, Shelley, said he wasn't at his Glen Dale home and wasn't available to comment Wednesday night. His attorney, William Hundley, didn't return a phone call to his Washington, D.C., office. The prosecutor, U.S. Attorney Michael Carey in Charleston, refused to comment, as did the judge. Moore, 68, pleaded guilty May 8 to extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice. The three-term Republican governor is scheduled to be sentenced July 10. He faces up to 36 years in prison and $1.2 million in fines. Moore, once a political powerhouse in West Virginia, admitted illegal acts during his 1984 campaign, his 1985-89 term and his 1988 re-election campaign. He admitted to extorting more than $500,000 from coal operator H. Paul Kizer while he was in office in return for a $2.3 million refund from the state's Black Lung Fund, which provides benefits to coal miners. He also admitted he tried to block a federal grand jury investigation into corruption in his administration. Under the deal with the U.S. attorney's office, Moore agreed to cooperate with federal investigators looking into political corruption in West Virginia. The federal probe so far has resulted in more than 10 convictions of former state officials and lobbyists. Moore was governor from 1969 to 1977. He was elected again in 1984, but was defeated in a 1988 bid for re-election by Democrat Gaston Caperton. Defendants who have pleaded guilty can seek to change their plea by petitioning the court before they are sentenced, but that is unusual. It isn't uncommon for a defendant to try to pull out of a plea bargain, but few succeed, said House Speaker Chuck Chambers, a lawyer and a Democrat. Defendants usually argue that they were coerced into entering the plea, or that they were inadequately represented by their lawyers, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mourners Remember Victims of Flash Flood
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS last graf to CORRECT number listed as missing to 11, sted 12, to reflect latest body found. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: About 900 people said prayers, sang hymns and hugged Wednesday night during a memorial service for 22 people killed in a flash flood last week. Gov. Richard Celeste told mourners the flood demonstrated the power of nature and the resilience of the human spirit. He offered a prayer for the victims. ``We have learned again of your power. Sometimes it's a dreadful power beyond our imagination,'' Celeste said. ``But in our shock and pain and grief we learn of the power of the human family. And we reach out, share a hand and warm embrace.'' The 45-minute service was held at Shadyside High School's football field under threatening skies. Earlier in the day, authorities urged about 150 people to leave their homes in this eastern Ohio village because of the threat of storms, but the call for an evacuation was later lifted. Only about 12 people had gone to a shelter set up at an elementary school, volunteer Barb Geer said. Vice President Dan Quayle offered his condolences to Shadyside in a letter read at the memorial service. Two roses, a red one for adults who died and a yellow one for children, rested on a pulpit in the middle of the football field. Members of the Shadyside Volunteer Fire Department received a standing ovation from the crowd. One evacuee Wednesday at the elementary school, 65-year-old James Saffle, said he was still shaken from last Thursday's flood. ``All these people are dead. All your friends are gone, and you don't understand how. You can't understand it unless you go through it,'' he said. A wall of water surged down the Wegee and Pipe creek valleys and the Ohio River, washing away houses, cars and anything else in its path. The dead have been found in debris along the creeks and in the river. The National Guard, Ohio Department of Transportation officials and volunteers have been working to clear the creek of debris that would cause runoff from a storm to back up and cause more flooding. Clearing efforts have been slow in some areas where obstructions were removed by hand in a search of victims. Local officials and volunteers, meanwhile, worked to reduce the number of people reported missing since the flood. Twelve names remained on the list Wednesday, down from 60 listed as possibly missing the day after the storm. Capt. Jim Boling of the Ohio adjutant general's office said it was questionable whether seven of the 11 still listed as missing on Wednesday were actually missing, ``but we're not going to remove their names until that is confirmed.''

Nelson Mandela, a freedom fighter who became one of the world's most celebrated political prisoners, headed for the United States today looking for money and moral support for his battle against apartheid. In New York _ the first stop on a 12-day, eight-city U.S. tour _ a hero's welcome was in store for the deputy president of the African National Congress, including a ticker-tape parade up Broadway and a rally at Yankee Stadium. Along with the festivities celebrating the end of Mandela's 27-year imprisonment in South Africa will be meetings with business, religious and political leaders. Mandela, making his first U.S. visit, is scheduled to speak at the United Nations and meet in Washington with President Bush. His message: keep the economic sanctions and international pressure in place until the white South African government gives up its monopoly on power and ends all vestiges of racial segregation.

House Democrats frustrated by a stalemate with President Bush over budget cuts and taxes are starting to appropriate spending for next year, beginning with $20.8 billion for energy and water projects. Ignoring the absence of an overall budget accord, the House voted 355-59 Tuesday to raise by $350 million what Bush would spend in fiscal 1991 to clean up the nation's atomic weapons complex. The House vote also would launch 25 water projects opposed by the administration. ``What the House has done is to flaunt or doom the (budget) summit,'' said Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., as several efforts to cut the spending were defeated. ``This is something that is going to get this house in great trouble.'' The measure is the first of 13 appropriation bills for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 to pass either the House or Senate. Until Tuesday, congressional leaders had stalled action in hopes of reaching an overall budget agreement with the White House.

A constitutional amendment against burning the American flag is speeding toward a House floor vote, with critics saying ``the momentum is with us'' and backers grumbling about too much haste. ``It's going to be close,'' Rep. Jack Brooks, D-Texas, said Tuesday as his House Judiciary Committee sent the measure to the full House for a vote Thursday. ``It would be close this week, it would be close next week.'' Speaker Thomas Foley, D-Wash., agreed with that assessment. Brooks said the 19-17 vote by which the panel sent the measure to the floor _ with no recommendation for or against _ was a sign that the final outcome also would be by a narrow margin.

The massacre of eight people by a man with a rifle could undercut the powerful gun lobby at a time when Florida voters are considering a constitutional amendment imposing a three-day wait on handgun purchases. ``Anytime you have a tragedy, those people with hidden agendas see any and every emotional opportunity to try to justify their erroneous position and try to deprive the people of their rights,'' said Marian Hammer, spokeswoman for the National Rifle Association's Florida branch. The debate over the amendment on November's ballot intensified after James Edward Pough, 42, a day laborer, killed eight people Monday with a semiautomatic rifle before taking his own life with a revolver at an auto loan agency. Police said Pough also killed two people on the street Sunday with the rifle. ``How many messages do we send to the Congress? How many to the state Legislature?'' Jacksonville Mayor Tommy Hazouri said Tuesday. ``If it means seeking changes ... we're going to do that.''

Despite the global thaw in East-West relations, the Cold War is chilling efforts to end Angola's 15-year civil war. Billions of dollars worth of Soviet and U.S. weapons have kept the war going between the Marxist government and Jonas Savimbi's UNITA rebels. Though the superpowers now want to spend less on regional conflicts, neither seems willing to see its client lose the struggle for power in one of Africa's potentially richest nations. When Portuguese colonizers pulled out in 1975 a tribal-based conflict between northern, central and southern Angolans soon became a surrogate war as the Kremlin battled the West for influence in southern Africa.

DOC.NOTE: $Adv25
For Release PMs Monday June 25 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Party's Over For Bride-Seeking Pyrenees Village
DOC.TEXT: This village in the Pyrenees needs eight brides for eight bachelors, but has decided it can't afford to pay $50,000 for them. Five years ago, in an attempt to keep the village from dying, the bachelors of Plan advertised a three-day party to which young, single women were invited. The event attracted international attention, became a yearly affair and led to more than 30 marriages, nearly all the couples moved away. Plan still has eight bachelors looking for wives. It also became very expensive and the village has decided to skip a year, said Miguel Angel Fumanal, president of the Plan Bachelor's Association. He said it does not have the $50,000 needed to bring in women from across Spain by bus, pay their expenses and throw the party. ``We'll take a sabbatical ... and use the time to think about what to do next year,'' he said. Plan is a picture-postcard town nestled among snowcapped peaks above a rushing river, 12 miles from the French border. Old stone houses line its narrow cobblestone streets. There is not much for young people to do except look at the spectacular scenery or drink beer in the village bar. On a recent evening, there were eight men in the bar and no women. The inspiration for the first party came to a similar crowd in the bar in January 1985. While watching the American movie ``Westward the Women'' on television, the bachelors decided to do just what the frontiersmen did: import women. In the movie, the goal was to create a new town. The plan in Plan, whose population had declined from 300 to less than 200, was to save an old one. ``The parties boosted morale,'' said the Rev. Jacinto Brallans, Plan's Roman Catholic priest, who presided at the marriages of several couples who met at the annual fiestas. ``Young men who have to live alone in a little town like Plan get discouraged.'' Brallans said similar problems could be found in many European villages, where farm families had to decide whether to break up their small holdings or pass all the land on to the eldest son. If the eldest gets it all, which is often the case, younger brothers and sisters move to the cities, he said. ``Many people have left this town,'' said Jose Prer, a 74-year-old farmer who has spent his life in Plan. ``There's no work here.'' ``Something important was happening here'' with the annual party, Brallans said. ``The people were fighting to survive.'' When they put the ad in a newspaper in Zaragoza, the nearest big town, Plan's bachelors thought few people would notice. They were wrong. The event was publicized as far away as China. It attracted 100 eligible women, who were brought to Plan by bus from Barcelona, Madrid and Zaragoza, and more than 1,000 other people came to watch. Outside interest slackened after the first year, however, and the donations needed to finance it began drying up. Of the couples married as a result of the five annual parties, two have remained in Plan, eight live in four neighboring towns of the Gistau Valley and the rest moved farther away, Brallans said. Benefits are visible. A new pharmacy, hotel-restaurant and beauty salon have opened in Plan, and Brallans said the population had stabilized at about 200. Jose Maria Fantova, a 35-year-old bachelor, feels optimistic. He's building a market and intends to stay in the village. The fiestas attracted enough tourists to fill the hotel in July and August, and a ski resort might show the way to a brighter future for Plan, Fantova said.

DOC.HEAD: Vanity, The Root of Evil
DOC.TEXT: When highly successful business people suddenly lose their magic touch, often at what seems the apex of their careers, you may find vanity plays a role in the drama. Vanity combined with financial leverage and economic cyclicality often drive their success. The trio are the heroes of the ascent. Ironically, they are also the villains of the decline. You can find them at work in stocks, bonds and commodities, in Las Vegas and Atlantic City, in real estate, merchandising, banking, politics. They are eager supporters in the ascent, savage enemies in the fall. You can find two or all three in the major downfalls of business history, in the savings and loan collapses, in the bankruptcy of the Hunt brothers who thought they could corner the silver market, in Ivan Boesky, the investor. They are current in the affairs of William Farley, who tried to expand his textile empire before he had the money to pay for it, and of Robert Campeau, who became one of the world's biggest retailers and then lost it all. The three bad actors are especially prominent in building and real estate and are on stage in most real estate collapses. They are visible and vocal in the affairs of several real estate gurus who rose from nothing and returned to it. Decades ago they helped bring down William Zeckendorf, one of the most famous real estate men of his time, the man who assembled the land on which the United Nations stands. And today they are involved in Donald Trump's problems. The scenario is deadly clear, whether it evolves on the smallest of stages or the largest. An example: In the 1970s, inflation raged. Those who kept savings in the bank saw them wither because interest rates earned were in the single digits while the buying power of money shrank at double digit rates. While inflation shriveled the value of money, it caused the prices of hard assets to soar. The value of money in the bank deteriorated; the value of money in real estate soared. Savvy people flocked to real estate. Bankers took notice. Not only did they lend money to building developers but they took a piece of the action themselves. Bankers sought out the more daring, dramatic and successful developers and shoveled money at them. Inflation continued. Developers succeeded. Lenders lent. How could you lose? Some developers believed they couldn't, and some of the lenders tended to agree with them. The borrowers borrowed more, the lenders lent them more. Leverage became the name of the game. The squeamish warned that it was dangerous to borrow so freely, especially with interest rates rising, but the daring ones were convinced they had mastered the magic formula. Then the economy began cooling, and as it cooled the inflation rates began falling. The jobless rate began rising. People couldn't buy houses and apartments, and they couldn't afford the high rents. The game was over. As the economy came plunging down into the recession of the early 1980s, it toppled those who felt they could do not wrong, who leveraged themselves, who allowed their vanity to violate their own good judgment. Looking back, almost every one of those involved in that debacle knew that the laws of good banking, the principles of business and the economic cycle had not been revoked. But they chose not to think about it. Instead, their successes inflated their confidence and their confidence allowed them to borrow beyond reason. In their clouded minds they knew it had to end someday, but they chose instead to be guided by their vanity. Hadn't that vanity given them the courage to build empires? Why, then, should they not rely on it just once more? Just one more time, they said, while they sought to put a crown on their achievements.

DOC.HEAD: Summary
An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: It's all right there in the fine print: nearly $6 trillion worth of credit and insurance commitments held by the federal government, potential liabilities that dwarf the savings and loan bailout. Every chance he gets, Richard G. Darman, the administration's budget director, tries to get people to pay attention to that accumulation of contingent liabilities. He hasn't had a lot of success so far. The commitments involved are arcane, complex and almost invisible, until something goes wrong. But the price of guaranteed credit and federally backed insurance has been going up, and not only in the savings and loan crisis. Darman says there should be tighter control and supervision of underwriting risks that now are outside the discipline of the federal budget system. He also has suggested an overall ceiling on government loans, guarantees and insurance. The dollar value of those commitments has increased nearly sevenfold over the past 20 years. The biggest single increase is in deposit insurance on accounts in banks, savings and loans and credit unions, now covered up to $100,000 a deposit. The total deposit insurance outstanding now runs to about $3 trillion. The credit and insurance programs have little visible impact on the budget, which has made them politically alluring in Congress, where budgeted funds are hard to find as the government grapples with its chronic deficits. There are loans and guarantees that benefit farmers, retired workers, students, veterans, home buyers, small businesses and other groups. In addition, there are government sponsored enterprises, created with federal backing to make it easier to get loans for houses, farming, and higher education. Those are broad and powerful constituencies. No president and no Congress would risk undoing the benefits they reap. But the Bush administration wants credit reform, tighter supervision, and a recognition of the liabilities, the risks that weren't acknowledged when the savings and loan crisis began to take shape. In the administration's budget, Darman wrote that the purposes of federal credit support are generally worthy ones. ``But there can be no denying that there is an enormous and increasing federal exposure _ approaching one trillion dollars in direct and federally guaranteed loans alone.'' He said that is virtually certain to involve tens of billions of dollars in future claims against the government. So are future claims against federal insurance programs. Darman says those costs will be manageable, so long as they are recognized and handled on an orderly basis. ``Too little attention was paid in the past to the scope and scale of these commitments, and often the government's potential exposure was understated or ignored,'' Darman said in his budget essay last winter. Ever since, at congressional hearings, in television appearances and in interviews, Darman has been trying to call all that to national attention, so that hidden liabilities do not swell into staggering costs until it is too late to do anything except pay them. While most of the guaranteed loans won't end up in default, and most of the insurance won't lead to claims against the government, federal losses have been increasing, largely, but not entirely because of the savings and loan crisis. In 1989, there were $14.4 billion in bad loan losses, compared with $3.7 billion in 1982. Insurance costs totaled $67.2 billion in 1989, almost all of that to cover losses at more than 400 failed savings and loans and banks. And that was only a down payment on the S&L bailout. There are other trouble signals. _The Federal Housing Administration, which insures home mortgages, lowering the down payment and making them available to people who couldn't get loans otherwise, has been losing money since 1988, for the first time in its 50 years. Facing the prospect of continuing losses that could bankrupt the government's mutual mortgage insurance fund by the end of the decade, the administration has recommended tighter rules and higher fees for borrowers. _Government insurance covers $1 trillion worth of pension benefits, and while that fund has been running a deficit, a Supreme Court decision on Monday eased the problem. The ruling broadened the power of the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corp. to force employers to restore terminated pension plans, instead of leaving the cost to the government insurance fund. The fund still has a $1 billion deficit, and its director told a House hearing last week that business failures could send that up sharply. In each instance, as Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah, said of the FHA mortgage insurance, losses will eventually have to be covered by the federal government. ``That means the taxpayers,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Moderate Middle May Lead Presbyterians To Brighter Future
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf to CORRECT spelling of millennium; PICKS UP 2nd graf, ``The Rev.''
DOC.HEAD: Associated Press Writer
DOC.TEXT: The Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.) appears ready to turn the corner on one of the largest membership losses in the history of Christianity by the next millennium, according to a new three-year study of the church. The Rev. John Mulder, president of Louisville Presbyterian Seminary and one of the directors of the study, said a group of people are emerging within the church to find a middle ground between the battle lines set up by strident liberals and conservatives. ``What we're seeing in the '90s is this mobilization of the moderate middle,'' Mulder said. ``I would look toward the middle or the late '90s as the point the Presbyterian Church would begin to reverse some of the losses, or at least stabilize.'' The Presbyterian Church, which reached a high of about 4.4 million in the mid-'60s, lost more than 43,000 members last year to fall to below 2.9 million. The church adopted evangelism and church development as its two priority goals at its General Assembly last year. At the recent General Assembly meeting here, Stated Clerk James E. Andrews, the denomination's chief executive, indicated the effort is starting to pay off. Declaring ``ours is a vital denomination,'' he reported increases in adult and infant baptisms. He also said professions of faith increased after years of steady decline, ``a preliminary indication that our steady loss of membership can be reversed.'' Newly elected Moderator Price Henderson Gwynn III of Charlotte, N.C., said the denomination could grow to 5 million members by the year 2000 as long as it stops the internal bickering. ``If we shoot ourselves in the foot because of internecine warfare or denominational myopia, we are going to have to answer for it,'' he said. The study entitled ``Presbyterians in the 20th Century: A Case Study of American Protestantism,'' involved 55 different research projects done by 65 researchers, Mulder said. The first volume of a projected seven-volume series on the study was released last month. The study was privately funded by the Lilly Endowment. In an interview at the General Assembly meeting, Mulder said demographics played a large role in the denomination's decline. The post-war baby boomers have delayed marriage and having children, and are having fewer children overall. But that doesn't fully explain the disproportionate losses endured by mainline churches, he said. He said the research showed many young people who grew up in mainline churches are not leaving for other churches, but are giving up on organized religion. Mulder said the ``porous'' kinds of religious traditions in the churches makes it ``easy to join, but it's also easy to leave.'' The study found an increasing pluralism in beliefs and moral behavior that puts the church at ``risk of losing a clear and well-defined identity,'' Mulder said. In addition, he said the church dealt itself some ``self-inflicted blows'' by reducing its support for new church development and campus ministry. But Mulder said there are hopeful signs within the denomination, which has gone beyond a ``massive denial'' of membership trends to a growing awareness of the problem. In the Presbyterian Church, where surveys have shown most members take neither extreme coservative or liberal positions, Mulder said over the last two or three years groups such as Presbyterians for Renewal have developed that offer an alternative to the special interest groups that he said have sapped much of the church's energies. ``One of the things that I think is going on is the emergence of a moderate middle,'' he said. The development of a new statement of faith is another sign the church is trying to develop a better balance between spirituality and social witness, and maintain its identity in a secular soceity, he said. ``I think the statement of faith is a reflection of the church's ability, even in the face of considerable diversity, we are still capable of forming a unified statement of Christian belief that is consistent with our tradition,'' Mulder said. The pessimism with which he and others approached the research project has been replaced with a more optimistic outlook, Mulder said. ``In the face of what are some obvious `problems,' this is still a remarkably strong and vital church.''

DOC.HEAD: Tartikoff's View from the Top
DOC.TEXT: Brandon Tartikoff, the child prodigy of television, is approaching middle age and so, say some, is his prime-time schedule. Like an admonishing father, the president of NBC entertainment recently accused upstart Fox Broadcasting Co. of pandering. At NBC's annual convention for affiliated stations two weeks ago, the 41-year-old former Wunderkind admitted his proud peacock had ``strayed a bit'' last season with bombs such as ``Hardball'' and ``Baywatch.'' NBC still is the No. 1 network and Tartikoff still is credited with bringing it from last to first place during his 10-year tenure. But things are not the same. The accolades that once flowed like an open faucet have slowed to a drip. Adjectives like ``genius'' and ``brilliant'' no longer precede almost every mention of his name. In the last two years, he has been accused of playing it safe, of introducing boring programs and relying too heavily on the handful of mega-hits, including ``Cheers'' and ``The Cosby Show,'' that blasted NBC into first place five years ago after nearly three decades at the bottom. Tartikoff knows why this is. ``The tired quotient has to do with columnists who are plain tired of having to write about NBC's prime-time successes,'' he says in his Burbank office on the behemoth NBC studio lot. ``There isn't an adjective you can squeeze out of a thesaurus that hasn't been applied to us.'' He admits NBC has made mistakes, but he doesn't want to go overboard. ``I think there were probably one or two or three more mea culpas than should be allowed by law,'' delivered at the recent affiliates convention, Tartikoff said. The upcoming fall season will be different, he promises. Nine new series will be introduced. He is especially excited about ``Fresh Prince of Bel Air,'' starring Grammy-winning rapper Fresh Prince, the medical series ``Signs of Life,'' brought to you by Emmy-winning ``Hill Street Blues'' writer and producer Jeffrey Lewis, and ``American Dreamer,'' starring Robert Urich and Carol Kane of ``Taxi'' fame. ``I feel like there's been a return to the kind of development that either got us into first place or kept us in first place,'' Tartikoff said. ``As opposed to the kind of stuff we had last year.'' In 1980, Tartikoff became the youngest entertainment president in NBC's history, following in the footsteps of mentors Grant Tinker and Fred Silverman. Seemingly, he could do no wrong. In a town full of executives with the depth of a puddle, Tartikoff is a nice guy. He thanks you for accepting his call. He doesn't wear Armani suits, call you ``babe'' or ask you to do lunch at Le Dome. He does speak his mind, however. And over the years, that has caused him a few problems. A few years back, he called Fox ``the coat hanger network.'' Two weeks ago, he was quoted as saying Fox shows ``pander to the worst aspects of the American TV audience. They assume people don't read _ every reference is to other TV shows. They don't ask the audience to aspire to anything.'' Some TV columnists had a field day with that one. Tartikoff, they reminded readers, was the man who brought you ``Manimal,'' a show about a guy who could turn into a snake, a panther or a wolf, and a Geraldo Rivera special on Satanism that included, among other gruesome nuggets, a segment on devil worshippers who skinned human babies. But back to the fall. With ``The Cosby Show'' beginning its seventh season in September (or thereabouts), ``Cheers'' turning nine, and ``The Golden Girls'' starting its sixth year, NBC has some of the oldest shows on prime-time television. When the Nielsen numbers came in for the 1989 fall season, NBC was on top, but it had won with the lowest prime-time ratings in its history. Tartikoff struggles to rise above this. NBC is the defending champ, after all, and No. 1 is No. 1, no matter how the deck is cut. He has been doing this job far longer than counterparts Bob Iger at ABC and Jeff Sagansky at CBS. In fact, no one in television history has been head of entertainment at one network longer than Tartikoff. But Iger has stolen Tartikoff's thunder _ most notably with the overwhelming success of ``America's Funniest Home Videos'' and the critical acclaim of ``Twin Peaks.'' Fox has been equally blessed with its runaway hits ``The Simpsons'' and ``Married ... With Children,'' both of which made television history this week by breaking into Nielsen's top five. ``I don't have a shadow of a doubt that we'll be continue to be the No. 1 network,'' Tartikoff said. ``There's nothing that I feel ashamed about. We played a good game last year. We've played better games, but we still won the championship. And no one else even came close.''

Elsewhere in television ... ``TODAY'' THINKS BIG BAND: NBC's revamped ``Today'' show, increasingly harking back to the musical spirit of its early days, is sparing no expense for Friday's scheduled appearance of singer-pianist Harry Connick Jr. He'll be backed by a 15-piece band, NBC says. Connick's segment will air in the show's 8:30-9 a.m. EDT period.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Fanciers Ask: What Inflation?
DOC.TEXT: You can't blame investors in gold and other precious metals right now if they have trouble understanding why the Federal Reserve is so worried about inflation. Traditionally, gold has been one of the most reliable ways to bet on inflation, and thus protect the purchasing power of your money from increases in the cost of living. So, by superficial logic at least, the price of gold should be mirroring some of the same worries that have prompted the Fed to stick with an inflation-fighting strategy licies of late.in its credit po Instead, gold has fallen to its lowest levels in four years, trading below $350 an ounce against slightly more than $400 just a few months ago. For the many American savers and investors who keep a part of their nest eggs in precious metals investments as a bulwark against disaster, this kind of experience has become familiar in recent years. After flourishing in the inflation-ridden 1970s, gold turned in a lackluster showing in the '80s as confidence revived in competing paper investments such as stocks and bonds. The peak gold price of around $875 an ounce in early 1980 now seems long ago and far away. In the eyes of many an analyst, there is no immediate rebound in sight. ``Given my optimistic ijor political changes in the two biggest gold-producing nations, the Soviet Union and South Africa. Also, periodic waves of selling have been reported from Saudi Arabia, apparently prompted by a need for funds that oil revenues hasn't been able to meet. ``The increase in the supplies of gold coming on the markets (or potential supplies) does not bode well for the price of gold in the near future,'' says Gray Emerson Cardiff in his advisory letter Sound Advice, based in Danville, Calif. But even with all the obstacles seemingly confronting them, the precious metals have by no means been given up for finished by everyone in the investment world. ``I believe the decade of the 1990s is going to offer opportunities for tremendous profits in the precious metals, just as in the 1970s,'' asserts Lawrence Heim, a Portland, Ore., investment advisor. ``I keep saying that eventually there will be a panic into gold again. I really do believe it will happen and it will reflect the outrageous amount of inflating (money creation) that has gone on over the past decade. ``The huge annual deficits that have caused the national debt to reach $3 trillion have not yet shown up as a corresponding gold price rise.'' Along with a sharp rise in gold, Heim is forecasting an even bigger percentage increase in its poorer cousin, silver. Of course, it is a much different thing to speculate on potential swings in the precious metals markets than it is to buy and hold gold or silver as a hedge against trouble. For people who turn to precious metals in this manner as a kind of insurance policy, there may be good reason to be pleased if that investment never pays off.

DOC.HEAD: Chelsea-BU Mark End of First Year of New Relationship
DOC.TEXT: All the symptoms are there: money worries, bickering, lack of trust, poor communication and half-hearted threats of divorce. After one year, the marriage between Boston University and Chelsea's schools is a little rocky. The idea was to give the private university control of this failing school district, with its high dropout rates, low grades and even lower budgets. BU would get the prestige of operating this unique and high-profile laboratory; Chelsea would benefit from BU's educational and financial resources. But after Year One of the 10-year program, the university's goal of stirring Chelsea's children _ as the public system could not _ is a long way off. Money still is short. It took more than eight tense months for the teachers union to settle a contract with BU. The experiment is being contested in the courts. Good intentions also have been tangled in the knot of advisory and oversight committees, and in the conflicting interests of the aldermen, school committee, Hispanic community groups and parents. ``The biggest thing is getting through the mine fields of the state in financial chaos, the city in chaos and all the petty bickering,'' said Peter Greer, BU's dean of education and overseer of the management project. BU installed Diane Lam as superintendent to engineer the 10-year experiment, and she uses the marriage metaphor. ``Hopefully, it will be a love marriage that can develop trust,'' she told the governor's committee appointed to watch over the unusual relationship. ``Or it can be dissolved.'' BU wants to remake the schools _ and attitudes about education _ in this working-class city of 26,000 people, many from Latin American and Asia. Nearly one-third of the system's 3,500 students come from families in which English is not the first language. Some programs were established this year, notably alternative courses for kids with failing grades and after-school programs in the elementary grades. Though 16-year-old Amy Sandelin endured a sometimes tumultuous year under the new system, she's eager for her senior year, when she will be in the new Renaissance School, which will allow her to study what interests her most. The arrival of BU, Sandelin said with a smile, ``is really a good opportunity to do something with this school. For a long time, kids with potential, they lost them. Now a lot of kids feel there's more opportunity.'' Other programs are being tried on a small scale, limited only by a lack of money. A literacy program, for example, teaches English to two generations at once by having parents read to their children. BU's aim to boost teachers' low salaries and professional opportunities was a hard-fought effort that seemed to take forever to resolve. On June 13, the second to last day of school, the teachers union finally accepted a contract that will increase their pay anywhere from 24 percent to 28 percent over three years. The top salary for teachers with bachelors degrees is now $27,813; with merit increases, it will go up to $35,620. The contract also includes an advancement program for teachers who are not interested in the administrative route. But the boldest, most expensive part of BU's plan _ to provide health, nutrition and dental care for children from birth _ has gone nowhere. Greer blames bad times in Massachusetts for a lack of money and commitment from big foundations. Efforts to raise $3 million have netted just $1.8 million in gifts and pledges, the biggest chunk for computers and software. The city now is being asked to give the schools a $1.9 million increase for the next school year over this year's $12 million budget, mostly for salaries and special education, expenses that BU donations are not allowed to pay. But money won't quell uncertainties among Chelsea residents and among some teachers who feel the changes have come too fast. As Lorraine Ruby, an art teacher at Chelsea for 27 years put it: ``We know BU can really do good things here. We want to make sure it's substantive. We're not a media event. We're real lives here.'' Lam said much of this unease can be traced to the fact that, ``It's a new type of partnership, so we have not had a road map of which direction to take. Change is always hard, and it makes people anxious.'' Fifty-one Chelsea residents and the Chelsea Teachers Union have asked the state Supreme Court to declare the arrangement unconstitutional. They say members of the Chelsea School Committee have lost their voices in school policy since the university began managing the school system a year ago. ``In all other cities and towns, the parents, voters and school committees decide questions such as who will be superintendent or the high school principal,'' said Juan Vega, a plaintiff. ``In Chelsea, top educators are terminated in secret; no public discussion is allowed, no reasons given. This is disrespectful to the people of Chelsea.'' Harold Raynolds, state commissioner of education, once criticized the arrangement on those grounds _ the school committee, he said, had abdicated its elected duty to a BU management team. But he notes happily that the school committee and the managers now meet monthly for a more cooperative effort. ``It is a major success that they are still there'' after a year in operation, said Tom Shannon, executive director of the National Association of School Boards in Alexandria, Va. ``To look for results in the first year is asking too much,'' said Shannon, whose organization represents the nation's 15,350 school districts and is closely watching the Chelsea project. ``What Chelsea will exemplify is what educators have known all the time _ the growing season of education is a long, long time. Don't look at your watch, look at your calendar.''

DOC.HEAD: The Leader Always Gets Bloodied
DOC.TEXT: There is no mystery to the especially sharp decline in building activity. The explanation is right there in the numbers, on the record, in the pattern of past economic cycles. All of those indicate that the building business in its many variations has a long history of anticipating ups and downs of the economic cycle, and of reacting more sharply than others to changes. Illustration: When the economy in general weakens, as now, the situation already is an old story to homebuilders. Their downturn began months earlier. And, as in the past, the impact on them is deeper than on other industries. May housing starts fell to their lowest since the 1982 recession, dropping to an annual rate of 1.207 million units, a level reached after percentage declines of 1.4 in May, 6.4 in April and 12.2 in March. Why should housing construction get the worst of downturns? Simply because it often gets the best of upturns. When economic times get better, they often get very much better in housing, and when they get bad they get very bad. Conditions are poor now for many reasons, but playing a prominent role is the inability of builders to obtain financing. Again, as in the past, when lenders become reluctant lenders they become especially so with builders. The reason lies in the nature of building, which is entrepreneurial and speculative. The smallest and largest builders borrow heavily to begin their projects, and all have the same grand hopes of immediate sale on completion. Too often, lenders have seen builders produce a glut of product at the very time the economy is beginning to tip into a new down cycle. Too often they have been unable to collect their loans. Too often they have seen bankruptcies. Reflecting unique conditions, loan officers are especially wary of making bad loans these days, with regulators and their own boards looking over their shoulders. High on their list of no-nos, therefore, are builders. While housing and real estate people have long complained about exaggerated impacts of economic policy, which periodically pushes them into depression, they are especially upset now. Two headlines in Realtor News, a weekly publication, suggest the mood. The first: ``Is unwarranted credit crunch unfairly hurting real estate?'' The second: ``There's money _ but will they lend it?'' In a survey of 1,142 members of the National Association of Home Builders, 60 percent said a credit crunch exists and that it is hurting them, in spite of denials by bank regulators that a credit crackdown has been imposed. Whatever the cause, the homebuilding industry once again has preceded other industries into recession, and once again the depth of the decline in housing is deeper than elsewhere. And because homebuilding has declined so much, you might say the conditions are being produced that will lead to the next exaggerated cycle. It goes like this: Because not enough houses were built during the downturn a shortage looms. Because of the downturn and because, after all, loans are what make profits for a bank, lenders begin looking around for customers. Homebuilding leads the economic cycle, whether up or down. Anticipating that the cycle will turn up, builders rush to get their products on the market. Lenders are eager to help. Eventually, another glut develops. Remember this: When it does, sometime in the future, know that the rest of the economy soon will be headed down.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, June 21.

DOC.HEAD: Outdoor Music a Staple for Summer Concert Season
With AM-AP Arts: Summer Festivals
LaserPhoto AB3 of June 15
DOC.TEXT: When the Saratoga Performing Arts Center opened 25 years ago, operators had a difficult time persuading rock and pop artists to play at the amphitheater. No such problem now. This granddaddy of summer amphitheaters can now pick and choose among the music business' biggest names to fill out a schedule of more than 40 summer shows. In the last decade, outdoor amphitheaters have become a staple of the concert business. Only this year, new outdoor arenas are opening near Chicago and Pittsburgh, with Cher hosting the inaugural shows in both places. The ``shed circuit'' has resurrected dormant careers and given consumers such a huge array of choices that it has some industry leaders worried about overkill. Among dozens of artists on the road this summer are David Bowie, Eric Clapton, the B-52s, Sinead O'Connor, Tears For Fears, James Taylor, Jimmy Buffett, Fleetwood Mac, Tracy Chapman, Bonnie Raitt, Little Feat and those summer perennials, the Beach Boys. ``I think it will be a good musical summer _ a good mix of styles,'' said David Hart, who books acts at amphitheaters in Detroit, Chicago and Washington for the Nederlander Organization. Most amphitheaters are built the same way, with a section of covered seats surrounded by an expanse of lawn for picnickers. In Saratoga, for example, there are 5,300 seats protected from the weather, but up to 25,000 people can sprawl on the lawns. Their growing popularity coincided with the aging of the '60s generation. Woodstock nation still likes its rock 'n' roll outdoors, but with a lawn chair and wine instead of mud and drugs. ``It's more a part of the show to be outside, sitting out on blankets, enjoying yourself and enjoying the weather,'' said Buffett, who's selling out sheds across the country this summer. ``The weather's definitely part of the show.'' Amphitheaters have sprouted like mushrooms in recent years. Along with its Pittsburgh shed, the Pace Entertainment Group has opened facilities in Houston, Dallas, Atlanta, Nashville and Memphis within the past five years. ``It's a natural setting for music,'' said Louis Messina, president of Pace. ``They're built for music, unlike an arena that is built for basketball and hockey.'' From a business point of view, musicians like the combination of covered and lawn seats. In Saratoga's opening years, their managers worried that a rainy night would wash out all their business, until they realized that at least some patrons would be kept dry, said Herb Chesbrough, the arena's president. The sheds _ with many booking acts that appeal heavily to young adult whites _ have helped keep alive the careers of '60s and '70s acts that otherwise might not do much business. James Taylor, years from his latest hit, is a summertime favorite. So are the Beach Boys, just as much annual fixtures in Saratoga as the thoroughbred racehorses that trot through each August. ``Their audiences feel more comfortable in a place like this than they do in an arena,'' Chesbrough said. ``If you took an artist like James Taylor and put him in an indoor arena, he'd probably sell about half the tickets.'' Buffett's taken a band on the road during the summer for 16 or 17 years now. It's reached the point where the ``Margaritaville'' man rarely performs during the other three seasons. Even Buffett, whose songs have been absent from the top of the charts since the late '70s, admits he's surprised at how well his concert tickets are selling this year. ``It shocks me,'' he said. ``I figured I might have two or three more years and then reach a cap.'' He's not alone in preferring to hit the road in the summer. Some industry experts are worried that the concert business is getting too reliant on the warm weather months. ``Because of the sheds, touring has become a four-month business primarily,'' said Carl Freed, executive director of the North American Concert Promoters Association. ``It's created a glut in the marketplace. You have more acts than the public can pay to see at the same time. Therefore, the ticket sales suffer for the borderline acts.'' Chesbrough said he doesn't mind having a lot of acts from which to choose. However, Chesbrough, who used to try and entice musicians into an area that was relatively unique, now said he's worried that amphitheater operators will be fighting among themselves for acts. A glut can be good news for consumers. To be competitive, promoters must specifically package together acts for the sheds. Ringo Starr, who went on the road last summer with an all-star band of musical vets, is an example. This year, Bonnie Raitt is taking along John Lee Hooker, the Jeff Healey Band, Dr. John and others on a blues extravaganza tour. Fleetwood Mac is teaming with British popsters Squeeze; the B-52s bring along up-and-coming reggae star Ziggy Marley; and Rickie Lee Jones and Lyle Lovett join on an eclectic bill. It's too early to declare winners and losers for the summer. Privately, promoters are especially bullish on the Stevie Ray Vaughan and Joe Cocker double bill, Bowie, the B-52s, the Allman Brothers and George Thorogood, Kenny G and Michael Bolton, and O'Connor. Some promoters said they were worried that Chapman, Australian rockers Midnight Oil and the Fleetwood Mac-Squeeze bill are some that could get lost in the shuffle. Other acts, such as Madonna, Paul McCartney and New Kids on the Block, are touring stadiums this summer. Amphitheater operators say these big-name shows are more a help than a hindrance, since they create interest in music.

DOC.HEAD: Hudson Valley Apple Growers Face Their Troubles
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Nine generations of Cosmans, six generations of Clarkes and four generations of Crists have worked the land of the Hudson River Valley. Sometimes, their apple orchards have been bountiful; sometimes, they have not. But generally, they have kept their problems to themselves. It is a measure of their fears for the future that they sought out reporters from the city to tour their farms and hear about their troubles. ``The last two or three years, apples have not made money,'' said Steve Clarke from Prospect Hills Orchard Inc. in Milton. Consumers, and farmers, worry about chemicals. Farmers can get more money selling their land to developers than farming it. Competition from the Northwest and abroad is squeezing their apples off store shelves. And bad weather and pests, of course, never go away. How do growers survive? ``We go from year to year and look at the future and hope we're going to be here,'' Larry Cosman said at his Mount Airy Farm in the hamlet of Middle Hope, where he grows 250 acres of apple trees. ``I think the odds are kind of against us in the sense that progress will prevail sooner or later and push out some of the farms,'' he added later. Not that the farmers are railing against progress. ``We brought you up here to show we don't have our heads in the sand,'' said grower Jeff Crist. Farmers are adapting by getting closer to consumers, like the pick-your-own orchards at Clarke's farm, and with dwarf trees, which can be planted more densely and pruned and picked more easily. They also are starting sales organizations that market fruit from a group of farms, and are selling directly to restaurants, at farm markets and stands, and abroad. ``Ten years ago, it was enough to know what was going on in the confines of your orchard. It's not enough anymore,'' said Mike Moriello of New Paltz, trying to be heard over Joe Porpiglia's water dump, which washes apples and sends them down to the waxer. Not all have adapted. Some have sold their land, lot by lot. ``It's like they're treading water,'' said Elizabeth Ryan, who owns a 35-acre farm with her husband and is compiling oral histories of valley farmers. ``In the '60s and '70s, farmers sold their land, but they sold it to farmers. Now they sell it to big real estate,'' said Porpiglia, 60, as he looked out at farms that have been redeveloped for houses. ``For sale'' signs are interspersed among the apple blossoms. Farmland preservation is fashionable, but Crist's wife, Joy, said that just saving land is not the point. ``The emphasis needs to be on supporting and strengthening the farm business,'' she said. That means more research and development, a good, steady labor force, and enough farmers so there's competition among businesses that support farms. ``I don't see a lot of good, active farms going out of business,'' she said. From the early 1800s, growers in the Hudson Valley shipped many fruits by sloop south to New York City and points beyond, including to South American countries now sending apples to the United States. When Larry Cosman was a child, wholesale buyers from New York City would travel the valley, haggling with each farmer on his route. In a 1938 booklet prepared for an apple blossom festival, growers noted they had ``the best market in the world close at hand,'' partly because city consumers cherished the fruits of upstate farms. Cosman's father sold Happy Bee Apples, with cheery, old-fashioned stickers plastered on wooden boxes. Most went no farther than metropolitan New York. In the 1930s, Ryan said, there were 500 farms in Ulster County, on the Hudson's western bank. In 1990, there are fewer than 200 family farms all along the valley, from New York City to Albany, a 140-mile stretch. In 1986, Cosman, 43, abandoned Happy Bee, because he didn't have the volume to market his own label. Now his apples, a dozen varieties from 40,000 trees, are Hudson Valley apples, like his neighbors'. ``Sometimes you talk about it and get a little choked up,'' he said. ``It's a family name. ... It's part of you. Farming is not really a job, it's a lifestyle. And most farmers live, eat and breathe what they're doing.'' But the bottom line must prevail over sentiment. ``It's an international business,'' Cosman said, and the Hudson Valley growers had to market their fruit together to compete with similar labels for Michigan and Washington state apples. Though exports remain a small slice of the U.S. apple business _ 13 million 42-pound bushels in 1988 _ the Cosmans sometimes export 75 percent of a crop. Foreign climes seem very far away during a walk along Latintown Road in Ulster County. McIntosh and lesser-known types of apple trees spread out on all sides, looking as if nothing could touch the serenity. But Alar did. ``If you grow apples, that changed your life forever,'' Ryan said. ``On an emotional level, it was a terrible upset. ... All those guys in Washington told us it was safe, and we believed them. We wanted to believe them,'' said the Cornell-trained pomologist, or fruit specialist, who did not use Alar on her farm. Alar, also known as daminozide, is a growth regulator that slowed maturation and improved color and storage, making it easier to manage harvests. But even in February 1989, when the Natural Resources Defense Council issued its report linking Alar and cancer, few growers were using it, said Ulster County extension fruit expert Warren Smith. Nevertheless, apple prices and sales fell. Growers still are trying to recover from losses estimated at $100 million. Like consumers, Cosman said, farmers have a hard time figuring out which experts to believe. But they respond to consumers and to costs, Moriello said, and for chemicals, the cost has gone up 30 percent to 50 percent in recent years, even though he's using less. Smith said all the valley's apple growers use integrated pest management, a system that combines ecological, non-chemical methods and natural predators with chemicals, ideally fewer and fewer of them. ``We have never recommended calendar spraying when other options are available,'' he said. ``Would you take an aspirin if you didn't have a headache?'' For these growers, migranes are reserved for coping with apple prices. Though supermarkets were selling apples for up to 99 cents a pound, Mike Moriello said he was paid 19 cents a pound wholesale. Preliminary figures for 1989 show Washington state alone growing 119 million bushels for eating and processing, a glut that many growers say combined with the Alar scare for a disastrous year. Michigan was second with 23.8 million bushels, and New York third with 22.9 million. Farmers who made it this far intend to survive. ``We have whittled away our farm population to 2 percent,'' Ryan said. ``The people who are in agriculture now are the people who really want to do it. They're very insightful. They balance an extreme number of risk factors that they don't control, unlike a lot of other businesses. ``There is one saying in the farm community: `These are the greatest gamblers in the world.' ''

DOC.HEAD: Snapshots of the War, and Now
With BC-Korea-Forgotten War
DOC.TEXT: Don Byers observed his 19th birthday in a foxhole 6 feet long, 6 feet deep and about 2 feet wide, and has the same plans for his 59th on Feb. 4, 1991. Lt. Col. Byers is the last active-duty soldier from the Korean War still serving on the peninsula. The birthday foxhole on a hillside at Chipyong-ni, southeast of Seoul, is half-filled with earth after nearly 40 years and a small pine tree grows out of it. Byers said his view of surrounding hillsides as a machine gunner was easily recognizable, although the terrain is green and forested now. ``I dug many foxholes in Korea,'' said Byers, whose family lives in Woodbridge, Va. ``This one was special. I didn't think I'd survive it.'' He has 42 years in the Army and is scheduled to retire next year from the 2nd Infantry Division, the outfit he started with and rejoined last year. ``I've made a complete circle, Korea and back to Korea, an Indianhead patch on both shoulders,'' he said.

Never mind the 12 tanks, helicopter, anti-aircraft guns and uniforms. The biggest draw at the Korean War Museum in Seoul is a Soviet-made olive drab limousine with jump seats. The car once belonged to Kim Il Sung, leader of North Korea then and now. The South Korean army captured it during the Korean War, which began June 25, 1950 with a North Korean invasion and lasted 37 months. It is driven out of a closed garage several times each day. Visitors to the museum are allowed to take photographs, climb inside, examine the upholstery and even check out the engine. About 1 million people visit the museum every year. Chi Kap-chong, chairman of the U.N. Korean War Allies Association, said if a car is what it takes to get people interested, he's all for it. Sgt. Blair Cooper of Summit, N.J., said of the old war machines: ``Lots of these relics look like they couldn't have made it. Now the car, that's something else.''

Rep. Ben Nighthorse Campbell, a Democrat from Colorado, served in Korea during the war and returned for the first time as part of a congressional delegation. The members were briefed before entering the heavily fortified demilitarized zone between the two Koreas. ``If gunfire starts, hit the ground!'' a colonel barked at them. ``Cripes!'' Campbell said. ``That's just what I was told the last time I was here, 38 years ago.'' Other things have changed, he said, and ``Seoul is like the phoenix itself, rising from the ashes. No one would believe it who was here in the war. It's like coming back to a different country, to a different place.'' ``Seoul was a smoking rubble with burned-out hulks of tanks, foxholes all around,'' Campbell said. ``There were hundreds of kids _ little tykes with no arms, no legs, no eyes. The biggest difference at first is, you don't see these kids.''

The Seoul city hall has an anniversary signboard two stories high. Thousands of school children have been invited to the Korean War Museum to line up at a small thatched hut and receive handfuls of free rice. The purpose is to remind young people of poverty and hunger during the war, when relief workers on roadsides dished out rice to hundreds of thousands of starving refugees and Korean soldiers. A new poll indicates many South Koreans know little about the war. More than 15 percent of those questioned didn't known it had occurred.

DOC.HEAD: Mistrust of Moscow Eases in Southeast Asia
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Suharto uses only one name
DOC.TEXT: Aeroflot's resumption of service to Indonesia in July is another sign of improving relations between the Soviet Union and Southeast Asia, which were sour throughout the 1980s. Flights between Moscow and Jakarta were halted in 1982 after two Soviet diplomats and the head of the Soviet airline's Jakarta office were accused of spying and expelled. Malaysia had ousted three Soviet diplomats for the same reason in 1981. Singapore expelled a Soviet diplomat and a shipyard technician in 1982, accusing both of espionage. Soviet warships and planes occupied former U.S. bases in Vietnam and military aid from Moscow sustained Vietnam's occupation of Cambodia. The Red Army was fighting in Afghanistan and posted along the border with China. Relations between the Kremlin and Japan were strained because the Soviets still hold the Kurile Islands, captured late in World War II. Suspicions remained even after President Mikhail S. Gorbachev promised in a speech at Vladivostok in July 1986 that the Soviet Union would mend its ways in the region. Mochtar Kusumaatmadja, then Indonesia's foreign minister, expressed the general attitude with this comment: ``It is a good beginning but there is a long way to go.'' Old perceptions of the Soviet Union have been swept away by recent events, however, and Abu Hassan Omar, the current foreign minister, announced a new policy in May. He told the International Affairs Forum in Kuala Lumpur that Gorbachev's reforms had changed Moscow's presence in the region from ``offensive'' to one of no particular threat. Some in Southeast Asia have been encouraged by the Soviet withdrawal from Afghanistan and its participation in diplomatic efforts to resolve the Cambodian conflict. Particularly welcome was the promise of reduced Soviet military presence in Vietnam. ``The Soviets are already in the process of unilaterally drawing down their offensive capabilities in Danang and Cam Ranh Bay,'' Abu Hassan said. ``My assessment is that the Soviet Union will now be more inward looking and will require a peaceful and stable international environment to pursue reform and economic development at home.'' Earlier this month, Gorbachev and President Roh Tae-woo of South Korea met in San Francisco. Diplomats said attitudes in the region began changing dramatically last year, when Gorbachev did not intervene to stop Communist regimes from falling in Eastern Europe. The Soviet Union's political image has improved dramatically, but its quest for greater trade and investment has been less successful. Japan and the United States dominate commerce in the Pacific basin. The Soviets also must overcome perceptions that they produce shoddy goods and pay slowly. Moscow's application to join the United States, Japan, Canada, Australia, New Zealand and the European Community as a ``dialogue partner'' with the Association of Southeast Asian Nations was rejected last year. ASEAN links Brunei, Indonesia, Malaysia, the Philippines, Singapore and Thailand to promote regional economic cooperation. Officials of the organization said the Soviet Union was told to apply again later, when its economic presence in the region was stronger. A Soviet request to take part in the new and larger Asia-Pacific Economic Cooperation Forum brought the same response. ``We look forward to the Soviet Union participating in the rapid growth of this region,'' said Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew of Singapore, a stalwart anti-communist. Within ASEAN, Western diplomats say, the Soviet Union seeks the closest ties with President Suharto's administration in Indonesia, also rigorously anti-communist. Indonesia has 178 million people and offers a large, relatively unexploited market. Thirty Years ago, the late Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev also saw Indonesia, not Vietnam, as the key to the region. Suharto made what Jakarta regards as a highly successful visit to Moscow in September. Since then, Indonesian ports have been reopened to Soviet shipping and restrictions have been eased on the entry of Soviet citizens. In January, President Mirza Olim I. Ibragimov of the Soviet republic of Uzbekistan became the highest Soviet official to visit in 25 years.

DOC.TEXT: The Christian Reformed Church's governing synod has voted to tentatively allow the ordination of women as ministers and elders. The vote followed eight hours of debate between progressive and conservative factions of the 314,000-member church. The action would allow individual congregations to ``use their discretion in utilizing the gifts of women members in all areas of the church,'' church spokesman Bob Meyering said. But the action remains subject to ratification by a 1992 meeting. ``It distresses me that we have damned the work of the Holy Spirit and not allowed our mothers, our sisters, our daughters to utilize the gifts God has given them,'' the Rev. William Buursma, a Kalamazoo, Mich., pastor said in the debate. The Rev. James Cooper of Zeeland, Mich., argued that there are ``no assurances that this won't be thrust on the churches in violation of their consciences.''

The Greek Supreme Court, acting on a complaint by two Eastern Orthodox priests, has ruled that ``Jesus jeans'' and ``Jesus T-shirts'' cannot be sold in Greece. Such commercial use of Jesus' name was termed an unacceptable abuse.
More than half of the 53 Southern Baptist missionaries in Liberia have left because of fighting between government and rebel troops.

The president of the National Conference of Catholic Bishops says the newly named papal envoy to the United States, Archbishop Agostino Cacciavilan, is a ``man of broad vision'' and wide experience. ``We forward to'' his ``sharing that vision with us'' and ``pledge to him our loyalty and support,'' said Archbishop Daniel E. Pilarczyk of Cincinnati. Cacciavilan, 63, a veteran Vatican diplomat, succeeds Archibshop Pio Laghi as the Apostolic Pro-Nuncio in this country. A main task is advising the pope on appointment of bishops.

The outgoing president of the Rabbinical Council of America has urged efforts to stop the ``suicide machines.'' Referring to a recent case in which a Michigan doctor helped a woman take her own life, Rabbi Max N. Schreier told an annual convention representing Orthodox rabbis that Jewish law forbids suicide. He called use of the suicide device ``symptomatic of the lessening of the sanctity of life in American society.'' Rabbi Marc D. Angel of Manhattan's Shearith Israel, a Spanish and Portuguese Synagogue, was elected the new president, the first Sephardic rabbi elevated to that post.

About 15,000 people are expected for the 33rd annual convocation of Bibleway Churches of the Lord Jesus Christ World-Wide June 28-July 5. It is to feature extensive pageantry, including a ``Youth March Against Crack And Crime,'' an ordination-consecration service of ``3,000 Women in White,'' an appearance of ``1,000 Men in Black'' representing male role models, and a closing ``Pentecostal Power Jubilee Celebration.'' Founded in 1957, the Washington-based Pentecostal denomination has about 300,000 members in this country and others. It is headed by Presiding Bishop Apostle Smallwood E. Williams.

A second printing of 100,000 copies of a new Presbyterian Hymnal has been ordered to meet demand. The first copies from an initial printing of 250,000 rolled off the presses in late May, and were used for the first time at the Presbyterian Church (U.S.A.)'s General Assembly in early June.

DOC.HEAD: Multitude Rallies Around a ``Perfect'' Bible
DOC.TEXT: Standing about 20 feet tall on a platform in the Louisiana Superdome was a huge replica of an open Bible. The book was the cynosure of last week's convention of Southern Baptists, who perpetuated a leadership that insists on a singularly defined view of the contents. Avowing that view is the new criterion for job security among the thousands of staff members, missionaries, executives and professors of the nation's largest Protestant denomination. The requirements elaborate details beyond any of the classic Christian creeds, specifying that acceptable belief for denominational personnel must include these spelled-out affirmations: That the world's creation occurred as the Bible recounts it, that Adam and Eve were real individuals, that all the biblically related miracles happened literally as described, that Moses wrote the first five books of the Bible, that all biblical narratives are historically flawless. ``It's the equivalent of a creed,'' said the Rev. John Lee Taylor, a Gainesville, Ga., pastor. And of an expanded kind. Baptists historically have shunned creeds, proclaiming ``no creed but the Bible,'' and emphasizing the ``soul competence'' of individuals to interpret Scripture as they understand it. But the new yardstick enjoins precise judgments. ``It's another example of the exclusivism being established in a denomination that historically has been open to diversity,'' Taylor added. The new prescriptions were approved by a 1987 convention dominated by a fundamentalist majority that has wielded influence since 1979, and which this time increased its hegemony, winning the powerful presidency for the 12th successive year. That bloc rose to power over the 14.9-million-member denomination on the basis of political-style organization and campaigning under the banner of biblical ``inerrancy'' and rightist social positions. ``Inerrancy'' is a relatively new term in Christian annals, meaning that the Bible is totally free of error about science, history, geography, biology, religion and all other fields. Considering the typical Baptist devotion to the Bible, any talk of threats to it is bound to set off alarm bells _ and that evidently is what happened from fundamentalist charges that denominational offices were infested with ``liberals'' downgrading the Bible. The canonading, directed at seminary professors and various other staffers, has brought out the troops. They swelled annual conventions to enormous size, with campaign buses and chartered planes bringing in the voters, more than doubling the numbers attending before the in-fighting began a decade ago. The affairs now involve vast multitudes, kept under tight restraints from the rostrum, this time a sea of 38,478 ``messengers,'' the third highest yet, next to 40,987 in 1986 in Atlanta, and 45,293 in 1985 in Dallas. Worked up by fiery oratory about internal ``enemies'' of a ``perfect'' Bible, the gigantic gathering gave the heaviest flood of ballots yet to the fundamentalist platform, electing the Rev. Morris Chapman of Wichita Falls, Texas, as president by a majority of 58 percent. Chapman, 49, a trim 6-foot, smoothly articulate man is personally gracious in manner but espouses a strict policy of insuring conformity of beliefs ``within the paramaters'' of the new specifications. ``What we believe about the Bible is a non-negotiable,'' he told a news conference, saying he would appoint only those holding the defined beliefs. The denomination's president, the most authoritative office in U.S. Christianity, has appointive powers that control choice of trustees governing the denomination's immense network of agencies and institutions. ``I've never advocated any wholesale housecleaning,'' Chapman said, adding that those ``out of line'' with requirements would be eliminated mostly ``by attrition'' _ retiring or impelled to resign. He suggested those not holding ``inerrancy'' positions would find a denominational ``home more in line with their convictions.'' Most all Southern Baptists are theological conservatives, but a moderate wing accepts both fundamentalist and other biblical approaches, such as seeing some miracles as imagery, their significance being in their meaning rather than in their literal occurrence. The moderate candidate, the Rev. Daniel Vestal, 46, of Atlanta's suburban Dunwoodie, lost this time with the weakest showing yet in the decade-long battle, getting only 42 percent of the vote. But that still represents a lot of Baptists in a denomination of nearly 15 million, and what they'll do remained uncertain under the tightened demands for conformity and the fundamentalist sweep. Some moderates foresaw an erosion of support to national denominational operations, and increased links to alternative groups, such as the Baptist Alliance, set up to resist fundamentalist ascendancy. In any case for the present, the multibillion-dollar institution, built up by Southern Baptists over 145 years of history, now was firmly in the hands of one side, and it saw no room for the others in denominational responsibilities. A chief fundamentalist strategist, the Rev. Paige Patterson of Dallas, an affable, mild-mannered man, eyed the now fortified position of his forces and observed, ``I think I'll hang up my holster and ride off into the sunset.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Friday AMs, June 22
