DOC.HEAD: Remembering the Veterans of the Forgotten War
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Mark Taynton was among the first Americans to die in the Korean War. He was thrown into the breach against North Korean invaders. Schuyler B. Cole was among the last. The war had bogged down roughly along the same line where it started, when soldiers died over map points named Pork Chop Hill and Heartbreak Ridge. Leslie Doyle Rader was killed at Inchon, when the Americans gained the offensive. Fellow Marine William G. Windrich died a hero at the Chosin Reservoir after Communist China entered the war. His tombstone notes he won the Medal of Honor. If the war didn't end with the clear-cut results some wanted, and if things aren't perfect in Korea today, well, nobody can fault these men. Yet the only national tribute to their deeds are their white marble headstones at Arlington National Cemetery. There is no patch of ground, no monument of carved black granite for Korean veterans. Only now, 40 years later, is a memorial in the works. Authorized by Congress in 1986, it will adjoin the Lincoln Memorial across the reflecting pool from the Vietnam Memorial if $11 million in private contributions can be raised by 1991. About $6.2 million has been raised so far. For the people who fought, bled or died in Korea, it's about time. ``It's an overdue thank you,'' said retired Col. John F.C. Kenney, a member of the Korean War Veterans Association and former executive director of the Korean War Memorial Advisory Board. ``The nation owes some form of recognition to those who, without all the fanfare of a war to save the world, marched off quietly to fight for freedom for a people they never heard of because their country asked them to do so,'' Kenney said. The memorial will have 38 statues of soldiers, each 8 feet tall, walking from a copse of trees toward an American flag. There will also be a retaining wall to honor the combat dead. ``We were the silent veterans of the forgotten war,'' says Frank Kerr, a Boston public relations executive who fought with the Marines at Chosin. ``Those who died enobled that time and place. It was like a rock thrown in a pond and there wasn't a ripple.'' That forgotten war began June 25, 1950, when North Korean tanks clanked southward across the 38th parallel. It ended July 27, 1953, not with a final peace, but an armistice. About 43,000 U.S. soldiers are still in Korea, serving as a trip wire in case the North invades again. Most Americans get their images of the Korean War from ``MASH'' reruns; 40 percent of the country is too young to remember it firsthand. Korea was a nasty war. More artillery fell on it than was fired in all of World War II. In 37 months, 54,248 Americans died _ 33,629 of them in combat, the rest in accidents or from sickness. In Vietnam, the U.S. dead reached 58,149 in more than 10 years of fighting. There are 8,177 MIAs and 389 unaccounted-for POWs, all of them presumed dead. Thirty-eight percent of American POWs died in captivity. Korea was a harbinger. Almost all the ingredients of Vietnam were present in Korea _ East Asia, an undeclared, limited war, a conflict between northern communists and a southern republic, and American war technology against a determined but ill-equipped foe. But mostly, Korea was a war unlike any the American public ever had been asked to support. Americans watched with some fascination as the U.S.-led United Nations troops were almost overrun, then counterattacked all the way to North Korea, then were beaten back by hordes of Chinese troops. One year after the shooting started, the lines stabilized at roughly the 38th parallel. Peace talks dragged on for two years, and 45 percent of the casaulties came after the stalemate on the battlefield. At first, most Americans in those communist-conscious times approved. But America soon was turned off by a no-win, stagnant war. There were no patriotic ditties by Irving Berlin, but no anti-war songs either. There were no parades, but no draft-card burnings or Kent States. ``It fell off the front pages. It just sort of petered out in a very negative way. Nobody wanted to think about this thing,'' said historian Clay Blair, author of ``Korea: The Forgotten War.'' ``When the war was over, people went back to their jobs and didn't talk about it. When your country asked you to do something, you do it,'' said Dick Adams, former member of the 25th Infantry Division and now president of the Korean War Veterans Association Was Korea worth it? Veterans say just ask anybody if they'd rather live in the North, one of the last vestiges of ironclad Stalinism, or in the South, a bustling, industrial power that was host to the 1988 Olympic Games. ``My view is we accomplished our mission in full,'' said Gen. Richard Stilwell, who commanded ground forces in Korea and now heads the effort to build the Korean memorial. ``Korea was the cornerstone for defense and foreign policy that provided the bulwark of what is happening in Eastern Europe.'' ``It was a complete victory. We did what we set out to do. We stopped the communists. It was worth every inch of it,'' said William Norris of Waterford, N.Y., founder of the Korean War Veterans Association. The veterans group was formed in 1984. Norris' daughter wanted to do a school paper but couldn't find any library books on Korea, the place where her father fought and his buddies died. ``It irritated me. I started it so nobody would ever forget,'' Norris said. The group already has remembered to remember. It placed a granite meditation bench near Arlington's Tomb of the Unknown Soldier on July 27, 1987. It is carved with this quote from Herman Wouk: ``The beginning of the end of war lies in remembrance.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Monday, June 25

DOC.HEAD: Workers Pose Dilemma for Bosses and New Government
DOC.TEXT: Vasile would like to crack down on his workers, who have slacked off since Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was overthrown, but he doesn't dare. ``If I punished them for not working hardwould ask me to leave,'' said Vasile, a chief engineer at the state-run Republica pipe factory. He gestured at an outdoor picnic table, where several workers sat smoking. Vasile's problem illustrates those of the newly elected government. It has i, tomorrow they nherited one of Eastern Europe's least efficient economies, but cannot change the system radically without risking a loss of support from workers. How important workers are to the government was illustrated June 14, when tens of thousands poured into Bucharest to show support after a day of anti-government riots. Blue-collar workers, about 40 percent of Romania's labor force, have benefited greatly from the revolution that began with the overthrow and execution of Ceausescu in December. Factory employees went on strike to force Communist managers out, then elected their own new bosses. ``Of course they are nicer to us, because if they aren't, we might fire them,'' said Alexandru, 25, a laminator. Likaking a break at the Republica pipe plant. The idea, he and his co-workers declared, was unthinkable.

DOC.HEAD: Vietnam Cracks Down on Dissidents
DOC.TEXT: Worry about domestic economic turmoil and the global crisis of communism is causing authorities to get even tougher with dissidents and people they don't trust, Vietnamese and Western sources report. The crackdown has included arrests, tightened surveillance and suppression of the only legal dissident group, the Club of Former Resistance Fighters. At least half a dozen foreigners have been detained since April and two Americans accused of anti-government activity were deported. Sources said conservatives appeared to have gained the upper hand over those in the Communist Party leadership who favor economic and other reforms. ``There is a tremendous sense of insecurity'' in top party ranks, said a source with access to many officials. ``There is a tightening up, and everybody is more cautious and afraid to say anything. They don't acknowledge it, but you can see it in their faces.'' On June 16, Hanoi radio said the Interior Ministry counterintelligence force and police, in coordination with the armed forces, had ``promptly cracked down on many troublemaking and sabotage activities.'' Security forces ``caught 30 persons violating Vietnamese law and discovered over 200 foreigners entering the country illegally,'' the radio reported. It said they ``destroyed five underground reactionary organizations and captured tens of their members,'' and seized publications ``with reactionary contents.'' Many people ``have taken advantage'' of international organizations investing in Vietnam to infiltrate and spy, according to the broadcast. Thirty of more than 100 enterprises involved in joint ventures with foreign companies were found to be operating illegally, it said. Hanoi radio said the crackdown was connected with major anniversaries, an apparent reference to the 15th anniversary April 30 of victory in the Vietnam war and the centenary May 19 of the birth of independence leader Ho Chi Minh. Authorities feared protests on both days, but none materialized. Sources say dissident activity in Vietnam is minimal and the actions reflect ``paranoia'' over the possible loss of political and economic support from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Another factor, they said, was the bold challenge by pro-democracy demonstrators last year in China. A Hanoi radio report May 23 claimed the CIA had subverted Eastern Europe and was trying to do the same in Vietnam by circulating leaflets and employing tourists, overseas Vietnamese, minority ethnic groups and Catholics. Many non-Communist nations halted aid to Vietnam after its invasion of Cambodia in December 1978. Washington also forbids commercial dealings, but businessmen from other Western countries have flocked to Vietnam in the increasingly open climate of the past two years. The crackdown appears focused on Ho Chi Minh City, a southern commercial center that formerly was Saigon, capital of South Vietnam. For the first time in numerous visits to Vietnam in recent years, a reporter's papers were searched before his flight left, by a uniformed man introduced as ``a cultural officer.'' When asked the reason for the search, the man merely chuckled. A government employee who was to help the journalist through customs appeared nervous and left early. Two well-connected sources, who demanded anonymity, said they believed the tightening was temporary and did not mean an end to ``doi moi,'' the Communist Party's 3{-year-old economic ``renovation'' program. They added, however, that it might last until a national party congress expected in mid-1991. Most of those detained were either close to the party or members of it, the sources said. The Hanoi radio report said some ``confused and utopian'' party members had aided the alleged CIA sabotage campaign. An early sign of trouble in the party was Tran Xuan Bach's expulsion in March from the ruling Politburo after he supported greater democracy. Security forces also feared the decentralization of the economy and some political affairs had increased public discontent, the sources reported. Farmers demanding land reform marched in Ho Chi Minh City last year. It was the first known street demonstrations under Communist rule. Students have held campus protests of poor conditions at the universities. Hundreds of people protested at the city hall, demanding repayment of money they invested in a perfume company that used liberalized rules to create a pyramid scheme. Smuggling, corruption and crime have become major issues. Authorities decided the presence of foreigners would complicate matters and tightened visa rules in late April, a Vietnamese official said privately. Western businessmen said officials who once pleaded for investment had slowed things down and were preoccupied with ideological matters. In interviews with The Associated Press, authorities said there were no mass arrests. No more than 10 Vietnamese were arrested with businessman Mike Morrow, one of the Americans deported, said Nguyen Son, vice chairman of the information and ideological department in Ho Chi Minh City. Gen. Tran Cong Man, vice president of the Vietnamese Journalists Association, said there have been no mass arrests, ``but many people were warned.'' Morrow said his interrogators were convinced he was a spy and that the United States was trying to ``create a Tiananmen in Vietnam,'' a reference to the Beijing pro-democracy demonstrations crushed a year ago. The American, who was held for three weeks before deportation, said those arrested with him included Do Trung Hieu, a respected intellectual who belongs to the Communist Party. Miriam Hershberger, an American teacher in the capital, Hanoi, was deported June 5 for allegedly trying to incite student unrest. Both Americans were considered sympathetic to the government, as was Chan Tin, one of two Catholic priests detained in May and accused of preaching anti-communism. Like Hieu, he was a leader of wartime opposition to the U.S.-backed government of South Vietnam. The Club of Former Resistance Fighters is made up of southern war heroes and revolutionaries who criticize the party's postwar performance but have not questioned its leading role. In March, the club's two leaders were expelled, apparently on orders from the authorities, a source reported. He said the club approved a resolution in January criticizing the government and demanding more political reform. Nguyen Son, the Ho Chi Minh City party official, denied the report. He said the club's executive board expelled the leaders after they ``wrote and distributed documents calling for protests against the government.'' Son said one of the men, Ta Ba Tang, was under ``temporary detention'' and the other, Nguyen Ho, was at home. He did not make clear whether Ho was under restrictions. A British journalist who reported the club's actions after interviewing Tang and other members was detained briefly and several of his Vietnamese contacts were reported arrested.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Wednesday AMs, June 27

For Release Sunday, June 24 and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Coming Back from `Most Hated Man in Richmond'
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto RM3 of June 18
DOC.TEXT: When Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev came to the United States and urged business leaders to invest in his country, it was ``music to my ears,'' said Reynolds Metals Co.'s William O. Bourke. ``We're already where he's telling them they ought to be,'' Bourke said. ``That ship has sailed.'' More precisely, the ship is a sled gliding across icy Siberia, where the Richmond-based Reynolds is a partner in a planned $200 million aluminum foil manufacturing plant that could make Reynolds Wrap a household name in Eastern Europe. The political changes that are shaking up the Soviet Bloc are creating vast business opportunities for American companies, said Bourke, Reynolds' 63-year-old chairman and chief executive officer. But when Bourke first came to Reynolds in 1981, the company would have been hard-pressed to jump at such a chance. ``We went through the most painful experience a company can go through, and that's one of shrinking, hunkering down, laying off a lot of people,'' Bourke said. ``I'm sure it was in the minds of a lot of our young people as to whether or not there was any future in our industry or in our company.'' A decade ago Bourke asked himself similar questions. Passed over for the presidency of Ford Motor Co., he retired in 1980 to his Albemarle County farm. He tried to adjust. As executive vice president of Ford's North American operations, he had supervised 280,000 employees; as a farmer, he directed a 120-acre cattle and orchard operation with no one but a farm manager to take orders. But after about 18 months, Reynolds Chairman David P. Reynolds ``called me out of the blue one day and invited me to lunch.'' Bourke thought Reynolds was going to offer him a seat on the company's board of directors. ``I had no idea he was going to offer me a job,'' he said. Reynolds, who was 67 at the time, wanted Bourke to become executive vice president for operations. ``That'll get your feet wet in a hell of a hurry,'' he told Bourke. Bourke drove back to his farm, about an hour west of Richmond in the foothills of the Blue Ridge Mountains, to talk to his wife, Elizabeth. She advised him to take the job because ``you're getting to be a real pain around here,'' the chain-smoking Bourke recalled her saying. Bourke came aboard in October 1981 at a time when the company had a staggering debt load and periodically was shaken by surges in aluminum prices and demand. In 1982, Reynolds reported a $24 million loss. Bourke set out to cut costs and pay off the debt, a streamlining that meant hundreds of job losses. ``That's a very painful, difficult process, and it went on here about 3{ years,'' he said. He remembered going to a dinner party one night and being told ``you're probably the most hated man in Richmond right now.'' ``Well, that's difficult to hear,'' Bourke said. ``I said, `I'm trying to save a company. The people who are still with the company I'm sure will see the day when they're thankful that we've done what we've done.''' After the debt and operating costs were brought under control, Bourke _ elevated to chief executive officer in 1986 and chairman in 1988 _ looked to improve efficiency by upgrading operations with the latest technology. He also looked at acquisitions to complement Reynolds' main consumer product, the food-packaging Reynolds Wrap aluminum foil. He settled, among other buys, on Presto Products, a maker of in-house grocery store brands of plastic food wraps. Last year, Reynolds set a record $6 billion in revenue and $533 million in earnings. Revenue has increased more than 50 percent over the past two years. Construction of the Siberian manufacturing plant, which will have a capacity of 47,000 tons of foil a year, is expected to begin next spring. Although Reynolds will hold only a 13.5 percent stake in the plant, it will supply the engineering and technical expertise to the six Soviet organizations that will own 70 percent. The joint venture should help give Reynolds a competitive edge in Eastern Europe, which has been steadily opening its doors to Western goods amid striking political changes. Reynolds is also trying to boost industrial sales of aluminum, primarily in automobiles. Once an auto industry insider, Bourke is critical of U.S. carmakers for being slow to develop engines that use light-weight aluminum parts. But he said the loss of cheap and plentiful gasoline, along with competition from abroad, have been generating ``big scale'' orders from Detroit. Louis Hannen, a securities analyst who follows Reynolds for Wheat First Securities Inc. in Richmond, said Bourke has done a masterful job in turning around the company. While boosting Reynolds' consumer line, Bourke lowered ingot production costs, Hannen said, and ``Now they can compete.'' Bourke said his objective is to make Reynolds ``as good as or better than anybody else in everything we do.'' Finishing that objective will take about 10 more years, and it will fall to his successors to complete the task. Bourke plans to retire in April 1992. ``I've often said to our people that my legacy will be written after I leave, not while I'm here,'' Bourke said. ``Just look at Reynolds Metals and how it performs through the balance of the '90s. Then you can tell me whether I did a good job or not.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Sunday, June 24

DOC.TEXT: Housing starts fell in May for the fourth consecutive month, dipping to their lowest level since the last recession, the government said. Analysts, who said Tuesday's report was further evidence that the housing market continues to weaken, attributed the 1.4 percent fall to high mortgage rates, tight credit, a large inventory of new and existing homes, wet weather and a sluggish economy that has sapped consumer confidence. The Commerce Department said starts of new homes and apartments totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.21 million units, the smallest number since 1.17 million units in October 1982.

Charles H. Keating Jr.'s use of Lincoln Savings and Loan Association amounted to a ``pure case of fraud'' costing taxpayers more than $1.5 billion, a government attorney said. Keating's lawyer, however, rejected the government's contentions and suggested that U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin must overturn the government's April 1989 seizure of the Irvine, Calif., S&L or risk unraveling the entire S&L bailout. Potential buyers of rescued thrifts won't trust the government if regulators' arbitrary and capricious takeover is allowed to stand, attorney Ronald Fein said Tuesday.

A senior House Banking Committee member demanded that federal regulators ``lift the veil of secrecy'' and spell out their charges against President Bush's son Neil in the collapse of a Colorado thrift. The Office of Thrift Supervision noted that it said in January it was bringing administrative charges against Neil Bush, and had since done so. But it would not give details. ``No law or regulation prevents the agency from revealing the charges,'' said Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., said Tuesday at the outset of the latest hearing by the House Banking Committee on the failure of Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver.

Chrysler Corp. stock rose again as speculation continued about talks over a possible major link between the struggling automaker and Italy's Fiat SpA. Neither company would confirm details of the talks, which various reports indicated could range from cooperation on a small sport-utility vehicle to Fiat acquiring a minority stake in Chrysler. Chrysler finished up $1.12{ at $16.62{ a share Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange. The stock rose 37{ cents a share on Monday, despite a sharp decline in the broad stock market.

Progress was reported in talks between Donald Trump and his bank lenders over restructuring the $3 billion debt load the developer ran up in assembling his empire. The banks and Trump's spokesman, Dan Klores, refused to comment on the status of the talks, or even whether the parties met Tuesday. But one source familiar with the talks, who asked not to be identified, said representatives of the Trump Organization and the banks _ Citicorp, Manufacturers Hanover Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp. and Bankers Trust Co. _ were meeting and had moved closer to an agreement.

In yet another move to give Northwest Airlines consumer-oriented leadership from outside the industry, the company named Frederick B. Rentschler president and chief executive officer. Rentschler, president and chief executive officer at food giant Beatrice Co., will join Northwest Chairman Alfred Checchi and three other airline novices in top management at the nation's fourth-largest carrier, airline officials said Tuesday.

The world's largest hotel _ a giant castle with court jesters, friendly dragons, slot machines and poker tables _ opened with medieval fanfare on the Las Vegas Strip. The 4,032-room Excalibur, which opened Tuesday, is the latest effort to lure middle America to this gaming capital. It was built for a modest $290 million, less than half the pricetag of the recently-opened Mirage hotel. Rooms start at $45 a night.

Rosa Parks, whose refusal to move to the back of a bus 35 years ago started a 381-day bus boycott in Montgomery, Ala., joined striking Greyhound drivers in their call for a boycott of the nation's only coast-to-coast bus line. Mrs. Parks and Jesse Jackson led some 300 protesters Tuesday in a three-block march from a Greyhound bus terminal to the capital's historic Union Station near Capitol Hill.

On Colorado Boulevard, where the little old lady from Pasadena terrorized other drivers, motorists no longer have to leave their cars to grocery shop. They can cruise instead to a drive-up window for the eggs, detergent or some of the other 1,400 grocery items at the Drive-Thru Express Store opened by the supermarket chain Vons Cos. The window is an example of how supermarkets are trying to compete with convenience stores, fast-food restaurants and vast ``hypermarkets.''

Stock prices posted moderate gains Tuesday as late bargain hunting and computer-program buy orders gave some direction to an otherwise lackluster session. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials rose 11.38 to 2,893.56. Bond prices slipped in lackluster trading. The dollar fell against major foreign currencies. Orange juice futures prices extended a collapse to three days; oil and pork futures continued recent losses; cattle futures advanced; grains and soybeans were mixed; and precious metals retreated.

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Oil Price Slide Temporary Before Prices Head Up
DOC.TEXT: A slump in U.S. oil prices to two-year lows has surprised analysts by its severity, but they contend the weakness is only a short-term blip and won't lead to much lower gasoline prices. Tuesday's close at $15.65 for a 42-gallon barrel of West Texas Intermediate crude oil ``is much lower than I thought it would go,'' said Maureen Allyn, chief economist at Scudder, Stevens & Clark Inc. in New York. But Ms. Allyn and other analysts don't see a repeat of the oil market crash of the mid 1980s, which saw prices drop below $10 a barrel. Most analysts are sticking with forecasts that predict the price of WTI, the benchmark U.S. grade, will average around $18 a barrel this year. WTI for July delivery lost 29 cents in Tuesday's trading on the New York Mercantile Exchange and has fallen $1.93 in the last week. The price hit a four-year high at $23.68 on Jan. 3, but has lost ground pretty steadily because of heavy production by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries. The posted price, what refiners will pay for oil on the spot market, has fallen from as high as $21 a barrel in early January to as low as $15. ``We would have thought that it would not have fallen as far as it did,'' said David Lee Smith, energy analyst at Eppler, Guerin and Turner Inc. in Dallas. Because of the slippage, Smith has dropped his estimate for the 1990 average price from about $19 a barrel to $18. Kent Hance, chairman of the energy industry-regulating Texas Railroad Commission, predicted the price will slip to $15 a barrel by next month's scheduled OPEC meeting. ``That's not all bad news for us,'' said Hance. ``OPEC does not do a good job in their meetings unless their backs are up against the wall. ``I still stay by my prediction of $24- to $25-a-barrel oil within the next 24 months,'' he said. The cartel has said it wants world oil prices around $18 a barrel, but members have flouted their own production limits designed to keep prices firm. Last week, OPEC president Sadek Boussena warned that oil prices would collapse unless cartel members adhered to a May agreement limiting production to between 22.1 million and 22.6 million barrels of oil a day. Estimates of OPEC production generally range above 23 million barrels daily, with several group members believed to be exceeding their quotas. Production also has been strong among some non-OPEC countries such as Norway, which announced over the weekend it would increase its output. ``That will add production to the worldwide supply, but we're seeing lower production from the United States, lower production from the Soviet Union, so I think that the slide in oil prices is a short-term event,'' said John Hilton, analyst for Argus Research in New York. Hilton said he is holding by his prediction of $18.50 for this year's average, but continued deterioration could change that outlook. Ms. Allyn said there is little to indicate a long-term price decline. Failure to invest in finding new reserves during the last decade, when oil prices were weak, means declining supply and rising prices, she said. ``In terms of the real things that will drive oil prices over the next three to five years, as a consumer I would feel no sense of security,'' she said. ``You can't bring new stuff on properly at these prices, there's no incentive.'' While the price has fallen much lower than she expected, Ms. Allyn said she did not anticipate the slump would last long enough to change her forecast of a 1990 average price of about $18, reaching about $20 next year. Hance said non-Arab oil producers such as Mexico and Venezuela have been using oil earnings to prop up otherwise struggling economies and have done little to replace oil. ``The result is going to be that we're gong to see dramatic declines'' in supply by 1993, he said. Hilton said the most recent drop could translate into retail savings of about 4 cents per gallon of gasoline, but Ms. Allyn doubted the price cut would find its way to the pump. Trilby Lundberg, publisher of The Lundberg Survey in California, said demand for gasoline in the prime summer driving season also should keep prices from falling much further.

DOC.HEAD: Wildcatter Win Comes In With Another Gusher
With PM-Oil Future, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Oil gushers continue to erupt in South Texas's Pearsall Field, where horizontal drilling has turned a played-out area into a oilman's playground. The newest discovery was announced Tuesday by Winn Exploration Co. Inc., which said its latest well tested at a potential of 19,568 barrels of oil a day. The average Texas well produces just 10 barrels a day. The well is the second in three weeks to come in at startling numbers, higher than any well recorded in the last 50 years of record-keeping at the Texas Railroad Commission. Meridian Oil Inc. said on May 29 it had a well with a potential of 12,254 barrels a day. Although far short of the 100,000-barrel Spindletop gusher that started the Texas oil industry in 1901 and the 200,000-barrel Yates Field finds in West Texas in 1926, the latest wells are far above recent average finds. Recent wells are considered good producers at 100 to 200 barrels a day, said Kent Hance, chairman of the Railroad Commission, which regulates the state's petroleum industry. The wells are in the Austin Chalk formation of South Texas Pearsall Field, whose fickle nature earned it the name ``Heartbreak Field.'' All that changed last year when Oryx Energy Co. showed that horizontal drilling could produce high rates of success. Although Oryx has drilled the most wells, Winn has had the best results. In November, Winn drilled a well with a 5,472-barrel potential. In December, the company added one at 3,600 barrels. Last week, another started producing with a daily potential of 5,388 barrels. ``That's not too shabby,'' said Michael Calley, Winn Exploration's vice president and general manager. All the wells have been on the same 8,891-acre lease in Zavala County, about 60 miles southwest of San Antonio. Wildcat oilman Charlie Winn said his latest find has produced 35,078 barrels of oil. The state eventually will limit the well's output to about 1,400 barrels a day, Hance said. Other Winn wells are easily meeting their ``allowables'' of about 1,300 barrels a day, he said. ``With the allowable being less, that well should produce a long time,'' Hance said. Texas has about 200,000 wells producing between 100 barrels and 200 barrels a day. The Austin Chalk contains oil in vertical fractures, narrowing the chance a traditional vertical well would strike crude. With horizontal drilling, wells take a 90-degree turn a mile or more underground, allowing the wells to tap into more than one fracture and increasing the chance of success. While the horizontal wells have produced startling initial flow rates, experts are unsure how long such rates can be sustained. ``My personal opinion is that it's still too early to tell,'' said Winn Exploration's Calley. There are about 100 horizontal wells producing in the Austin Chalk, said Railroad Commission spokesman Gary Garrison. ``We've just scratched the surface in that field,'' Hance said. ``It's going to be very interesting.''

DOC.HEAD: Rumors Fly About Fiat and Chrysler; Stock Rises Again
DOC.TEXT: Persistent speculation that Italian automaker Fiat SpA may link up with Chrysler Corp. has helped pump up the U.S. company's stock price. Talk about possible takeover bids for or stake purchases in Chrysler has been gaining steam as the country's No. 3 automaker battles with shrinking market share, slumping earnings and defections of top-ranked executives. Chrysler stock rose $1.12{ on Tuesday on the New York Stock Exchange to close at $16.62{ a share. The stock rose 37{ cents on Monday despite an overall decline in the market. Chrysler confirmed it was in discussions with Fiat but declined to give details. ``People are buying on speculation,'' spokesman Tom Houston said. The Italian automaker declined to comment on the rumors, although an official at the company's Turin headquarters called the reports ``purely journalistic hypotheses.'' A hookup with Fiat could provide Chrysler broader access to European markets already penetrated by Ford Motor Co. and General Motors Corp. The planned dropping of trade barriers within the 12-nation European Community in 1992 will create the world's largest single car market. Earnings from their European operations have helped Ford and GM weather the slump in the U.S. auto market. Chrysler sold its European operations to France's Peugeot a decade ago when it was on the brink of bankruptcy, but has begun to export to Europe modestly in recent years. A Chrysler-Fiat association also could provide a doorway for Fiat back into the U.S. market, which it left in 1983. But Fiat first would have to convince skeptical American consumers that its cars are of much higher quality than when the company left the U.S. market, analysts said. Fiat is Italy's largest automaker with a 60 percent market share. It was the ninth-largest automaker in the world in 1988, according to the latest figures available from the Motor Vehicle Manufacturers Association in Detroit. Chrysler ranked seventh. The companies already are involved in some component deals, and Chrysler markets Fiat's Alfa Romeo cars in North America. Some analysts questioned what Fiat would gain from a full merger with Chrysler _ a company facing severe financial pressure and no all-new car models until 1992. ``I could see an equity investment, but under a traditional definition of a merger, I just can't see it,'' analyst John Kirnan of Kidder, Peabody & Co. in New York. Some reports in Europe have speculated Fiat may be willing to purchase up to 40 percent of Chrysler. The U.S. company has about $4 billion in cash and marketable securities on hand, but confidence in its financial situation has been shaken lately. Chrysler reported an 80 percent drop in first quarter profits to $71 million. Last week, Standard & Poor's Corp. downgraded Chrysler debt securities to its lowest investment-grade level. Analysts said it would be easier for Fiat and Chrysler to form joint ventures on a project-by-project basis than for them to make an equity agreement. ``Cross-shareholding would certainly cement an alliance,'' said analyst Mary Anne Sudol of Fitch Investors Service Inc. in New York. ``But you certainly don't need cooperation like that to make any individual project go.'' Last week, Chrysler and the French automaker Renault canceled a joint project to build a small sport-utility vehicle in Europe. Chrysler said the project was no longer economically attractive but said it would consider seeking another European partner. Chrysler also needs a subcompact to sell in the United States. It stopped making its Dodge Omni and Plymouth Horizon in February. Company officials have said they are studying whether to design a new subcompact on their own or to associate with another automaker to build such a vehicle. Fiat's relies heavily on small cars, and there has been speculation about a possible tie-up with Chrysler to build a version of its Tipo hatchback. There also has been speculation about a link with Mitsubishi Motor Corp. of Japan, of which Chrysler owns 12.1 percent. Chrysler operations also have been dented by the recent departures of its vice chairman, Gerald Greenwald, and international operations vice president, Michael Hammes. Two other top executives have announced plans to step down.

DOC.HEAD: Checchi Says Northwest In Search of Acquisition
DOC.TEXT: Northwest Airlines is considering expanding by buying part or all of another carrier, Chairman Alfred Checchi said. Checchi has mentioned previously that Northwest would consider expanding by making acquisitions, but his remarks Tuesday were more direct. ``It's fair to say we have our eyes open and maybe our mouths a little bit open as we see what opportunities are there,'' Checchi said when asked whether any talks were under way. He declined to specify possible targets. Checchi made the remarks at a news conference to introduce Frederick B. Rentschler as Northwest's new president and chief executive officer. Rentschler was president and chief executive officer of Chicago-based Beatrice Co., where for the past three years he has been busy dismembering that company after it was purchased for $6.1 billion in 1986 by Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. ConAgra Inc. announced June 7 that it would buy Beatrice's remainingg businesses for $1.34 billion. Checchi said Northwest intends to grow as the industry continues to consolidate. He said the number of domestic carriers has fallen to 85 from 255 at the start of airline deregulation in the late 1970s. ``We are seeing, I think, some tremendous possibilities to expand the company outside of internal growth,'' Checchi said. ``This is an industry that is in the midst of substantial change and we like to think we have assembled an aggressive team that will be able to take advantage of some of the opportunities being presented in the marketplace to us.'' Pan Am recently said it would put its Northeast shuttle service up for sale, and Donald Trump has indicated he would consider bids for the shuttle service he bought from Eastern Airlines last year. Checchi said cash flows at Northwest have exceeded expectations since he and other investors completed their $3.65 billion takeover of the airline last August. He also said the carrier is ``substantially ahead'' on its repayment of takeover debt.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Orders Motorola Chip Off Market
DOC.TEXT: Motorola has earned a temporary reprieve allowing it to continue selling its popular computer chip, but analysts say continuing legal battles over patent rights could shake customers' confidence. The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on Tuesday granted the company a temporary stay of a federal judge's ruling that would have forced it to pull the chip from the market, Motorola spokesman Tim Kellogg said. The court is a special appeals court for patents in Washington. Earlier Tuesday, U.S. District Judge Lucius Bunton had banned the production and sale of Motorola's MC68030 microprocessor, and Hitachi Ltd.'s H8-532 microprocessor. The two companies, once partners, have been embroiled in a longstanding patent infringement battle over the microprocessor, the device that performs computations in a computer. Some analysts said Bunton's decision would pose greater problems for Motorola. Its chip has sold better than Hitachi's in this country, garnering 17 percent of the market for 32-bit microprocessor's, according to one analyst's estimate. ``It's certainly going to shake the confidence of companies that have been designing with Motorola's microprocessor all along,'' said Alice Leeper, associate director for Dataquest, a market research company based in San Jose, Calif. ``People who were considering doing a design based around the 030 would certainly be thinking twice, and possibly looking at an alternative product,'' said Ms. Leeper. Apple Computer Inc. is one of the companies that relies heavily on the 68030, using it in a number of its Macintosh computers. Apple spokeswoman Yolanda Davis said before the appeals court stay was issued that she did not expect Bunton's decision to have a ``material impact'' on the company's inventory. ``We are confident the two parties are working to resolve this issue,'' said Ms. Davis. Analyst Jack Quinn said the judge's order would pressure Hitachi and Motorola to settle the case. Indeed, Motorola said it would continue negotiating with Hitachi to reach a settlement. ``The main motivation that Motorola has for settling is not the immediate economic impact, but the confidence that customers in general have in their semiconductor suppliers,'' said Quinn, a senior analyst with In-Stat, a market research company in Scottsdale, Ariz. The injunction could cause companies to reconsider designing products around chips that can be supplied by only one company, he said. ``I've got to believe this matter is going to be settled. I can't believe that Motorola and Hitachi would stand by and see Apple devastated,'' Quinn said. Jerry Solovy, an attorney for Hitachi, said the stay would allow both companies to present arguments on Bunton's injunction to the appeals court. Motorola, based in Schaumburg, Ill., said the stay would allow it to continue to supply customers until a verdict is reached on its appeal of Bunton's ruling.

DOC.HEAD: Keating Sees Judge Returning Bankrupt Thrift
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Charles H. Keating Jr. says he believes a federal judge will return his bankrupt Lincoln Savings and Loan Association to him, but he promises to fight any adverse decision as long as he is alive. ``I think we'll get it back,'' Keating told reporters Tuesday after lawyers for both sides summarized their arguments for U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin. Keating is suing to overturn the government's April 1989 seizure of the Irvine, Calif., thrift. ``I don't know if it will work out for me. ... (But) we have at least gotten a trial and America has gotten a trial,'' he said. However, if Sporkin grants the government's motion to dismiss the suit, Keating said, ``We'll be fighting until the day I'm dead. I have no intention of being raped by the U.S. government.'' Sporkin has conducted 30 days of hearings over six months. He has about 1,000 documents and hundreds of pages of court transcripts to review and gave no indication when he would rule. The judge could uphold the seizure, find it invalid or order a full trial on the matter. He also could fashion some other solution, including putting the thrift under court administration. ``I guess it's up to me. I'm going to ponder it a little bit,'' Sporkin, a former enforcement director for the Securities and Exchange Commission, told a packed courtroom. Keating's attorney, Ronald Fein, suggested that a ruling in the government's favor risks unraveling the entire S&L bailout program. He said potential buyers of rescued thrifts won't trust the government if what he called the arbitrary and capricious takeover of Lincoln is allowed to stand. ``If the private sector can't rely on the government to apply the law in good faith ... rational businessmen are just not going to invest their money in these kinds of institutions,'' Fein said. The government maintains that Keating arranged for Lincoln to book false profits through land and stock deals. The profits, in turn, were improperly funneled to Keating's Arizona holding company, American Continental Corp., via a tax-sharing agreement, said attorney James Murphy, representing the Treasury Department's Office of Thrift Supervision. The agreement provided that American Continental would pay Lincoln's taxes, but $95 million was transferred to the holding company before the taxes were due and the company went bankrupt before it paid the taxes, Murphy said. The transactions amounted to a series of unrepaid, interest-free loans, he said. American Continental in 1988 promised the bank board it would inject $10 million in capital into its S&L, but used the tax-sharing agreement and a series of complex transactions so that ``Lincoln's money got put into Lincoln,'' Murphy said. That, he said, amounted to a ``pure case of fraud.'' Murphy noted that Lincoln's failure, perhaps the nation's costliest thrift collapse, will cost taxpayers ``in excess of $1.5 billion.'' The government already has pumped in $1.2 billion just to keep it afloat, he said. Separately, Keating is the target of a federal grand jury probe in Los Angeles and a defendant in a $1.3 billion civil fraud suit filed in Arizona by federal regulators. His case has attracted great attention because of Keating's involvement with five senators who met with regulators on his behalf after accepting political contributions. The five are Sens. Alan Cranston, D-Calif.; Dennis DeConcini, D-Ariz.; Donald W. Riegle, D-Mich.; John Glenn, D-Ohio; and John McCain, R-Ariz.

DOC.HEAD: Congressional Aides Call for Change in Mortgage Interest Deduction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Congressional tax advisers are proposing a simplified deduction for interest that would mean a smaller write-off on many home mortgages. On the other hand, the recommendation by the staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation could result in restoration of at least part of the consumer-interest deduction, which will expire at year's end. A simplified interest deduction was the most significant provision in a package of proposals by the joint committee for removing some of the complexity from federal tax law. The House Ways and Means Committee, which has launched a new simplification effort, released the proposals Tuesday, along with some from the Treasury Department and others from the Ways and Means staff. ``At the least, we will have hearings on the proposals in the fall,'' said a Ways and Means aide, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Those hearings will help determine whether the committee will try to write a simplification bill. Members of Congress don't like to tamper with the deduction for home mortgage interest, which generally is considered as close to a sacred cow as can be found in the tax law. About 25 million taxpayers claim the deduction, which will cost the treasury about $30 billion in forgone taxes this year. The staff of the Joint Committee on Taxation concluded that present law, with its different rules for mortgages, investment interest and consumer interest, is too complicated. The staff suggested three ways to simplify the law, two of which would water down the mortgage deduction. The law allows a full deduction of interest on a loan of up to $1 million used to acquire a principal or second home and on home-equity loans of up to $100,000. Investment interest is generally deductible up to the limit of income earned on investments. After this year, no consumer interest, including automobile loans and credit cards, can be deducted. The tax committee staff proposed these alternatives for writing off interest: _Combine all non-business interest, including that for mortgages, consumer debt and investment borrowing, and deduct a set percentage of the total, perhaps 75 percent. _Deduct interest equal to net income on investments, plus some additional dollar amount. _Retain the current law for mortgage interest and allow a separate write-off for other interest, limited to net investment income. The portion of other interest that could not be deducted in the first year because of the limitation could be carried over into future years. The joint committee staff said any of the recommendations would minimize complexity of present law. In addition, the first option would remove the ``incentive for individuals to structure loans as home-equity debt in order to avoid the present-law limit on the deductibility of personal interest,'' its report said.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks, Dollar Up
DOC.TEXT: The Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index ended higher today, while the dollar inched up against the Japanese yen in thin trading. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average regained 47.38 points, or 0.15 percent, ending at 32,087.86. The index, which had lost 336.42 points on Tuesday, ended the early session with a 140.27-point gain before easing back some in the afternoon. First section volume was estimated at 400 million shares, up from Tuesday's 330 million. ``Trading was almost equally mixed with selling and buying,'' said Kazuyuki Suzuki, a trader with Daiwa Securities Co. Other traders attributed the Nikkei's afternoon slowdown to market players' uncertainties over the foreign exchange and bond market movements. In currency dealings, the dollar closed at 153.98 yen, up 0.26 yen from Tuesday's 153.72-yen finish. It opened at 153.85 yen and ranged narrowly between 153.85 yen and 154.05 yen. The dollar-yen trading was inactive because participants just made technical adjustments, said Eiichi Seino, a dealer with Fuji Bank. About $69.96 billion changed hands in spot trading. Many participants tried to push up the dollar beyond the 154-yen line but the currency surpassed the line only briefly because of selling pressure above the 154-yen mark, he said. But he added that the dollar is ``basically in an uptrend.'' In bond dealings, the price of the No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds declined to 87.42 points at 4 p.m. from Tuesday's 87.46-point close. The yield was higher at 7.095 percent from 7.085 percent.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Higher at Midday
DOC.TEXT: The stock market was higher at midday Wednesday in the absence of sellers. Institutional investors were reluctant to sell shares in case the market rises further, dealers said. But a lack of news left the market without any strong direction, they said. British money supply figures, released at late morning, were broadly in line with expectations, and had no major effect on stocks, they said. Shortly after noontime in London, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index was up 9.5 points, or 0.4 percent, at 2,379.2, Volume was a moderate 229.6 million shares at midday, compared with 259.8 million shares at the same time Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: American Exchange President Leaving
DOC.TEXT: American Stock Exchange President Kenneth Leibler will leave the post to become president of the Liberty Financial Companies Inc. ``We are very pleased Ken has accepted the position,'' Sam Marinella, Liberty's chief executive officer, said Tuesday. ``He combines an exceptional operating background with wide-ranging expertise in financial services,'' Marinella said. Liberty Financial Companies, with assets of $21 million, is a wholly-owned subsidiary of Liberty Mutual Insurance Company. In his new position, Liebler will oversee eight companies, including the investment firms Stein Roe & Farnham and Liberty Asset Management, with combined assets of more than $15 billion. Leibler, 41, joined the American Stock Exchange in 1975 after managing the retail options department at Lehman Brothers. At the exchange, he served in options, marketing and finance operations before becoming president in 1986 at age 36, the youngest president of any exchange in the nation. ``Ken has made a vital and positive contribution to the exchange but we recognize that he was presented with a unique opportunity that he could not pass up,'' said James Jones, chairman of the exchange. Jones said no decision has been made on when Leibler will leave or who will succeed him. Liberty Mutual Insurance Company offers personal and business insurance and financial services. The company has more than 23,000 employees in 340 locations throughout the United States and Canada.

DOC.HEAD: OPEC President Expected in Saudi Arabia for Talks on Oil Market
DOC.TEXT: OPEC President Sadek Boussena is expected in Saudi Arabia Sunday for consultations on overproduction by cartel member states amid fears of an oil price crash, official sources said Wednesday. The sources, who spoke on condition they not be identified, said that Boussena will be arriving in the Saudi summer capital of Jiddah from Iran as part of a tour of OPEC member states to seek action to help stabilize erratic oil prices. Ministers of the 13-nation Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed in May to slash OPEC output by 1.4 million barrels per day to restore the cartel's overall production to 22 million barrels in support of the $18-a-barrel reference price. Saudi Arabia, the dominant party in the cartel and also one of the member states that had been overproducing, has cut back its excess output, but other violators have not done so and oil prices have been sagging. They are presently fluctuating in the range of $15 a barrel. Boussena recently warned of an oil price crash if all OPEC members did not adhere to their individual production quotas. The Saudi monarch, King Fahd, has also urged other OPEC members to adhere to their quotas in the interest of all. A stream of editorials in the pro-government Saudi media have since been lashing out at the production cheaters, with the latest in the leading Al-Riyadh warning that the resulting ``flooding of the market is creating chaos ... and an imbalance that will lead to a price crash.'' None of the overproducers have been named by either the king or the papers. United Arab Emirates oil minister Mana Saeed Otaiba on a recent visit to the kingdom has been pledging commitment, but the U.A.E. on principle insists on producing at a self-imposed quota almost double the 1.095 million barrel per day which OPEC has prescribed for it. Fahd has also said in a recent press interview that he saw the time ripe for a ``long-term agreement that would ensure a high degree of stability'' for OPEC and the world economy. The Saudi king's statements have been followed by renewed talk in some OPEC capitals, particularly Kuwait, of the 2-year-old proposal by Venezuelan President Carlos Andres Perez for an OPEC summit to discuss a fresh long-term policy for the cartel amid a developing upsurge in world demand for OPEC oil. The sources said the oil ministers of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, United Arab Emirates, Qatar, Oman and Bahrain _ members of the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council alliance _ will be meeting in Jiddah next week to discuss various developments related to the oil situation. The meeting would be held once Boussena had completed his trip through the Gulf region, the sources said.

DOC.HEAD: Door Problem Said Solved
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Saturn saying door problem fixed, schedule being met. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A swelling-door problem on General Motors Corp.'s new Saturn model has been fixed and the first marketable car should roll off a Tennessee assembly line later this summer, a Saturn spokeswoman said today. The Detroit Free Press reported today that the problem would delay the scheduled start of production at the plant in Spring Hill, Tenn. But spokeswoman Laurie Kay denied that this morning. ``We had a pre-production problem with the door material that already has been corrected,'' she said. GM Chairman Roger Smith said as recently as May 25 that he still was counting on driving the first production model of the Saturn car off the assembly line before he retires July 31. ``Our plans still anticipate that would occur prior to his retirement,'' Kay said today, adding, however: ``He has told us that he will not drive the car until the Saturn team has told him that the vehicle's high-quality standards have been met.'' The newspaper quoted unidentified sources as saying that it's possible that the car won't be ready before July 31 Smith's 9{-year tenure as GM chairman has been marked by controversy and declining market share. A success with Saturn would reinvigorate his claim for long-term automotive greatness. Saturn is a $3-billion GM project aimed at marketing a car to sell for less than $12,000 targeted specifically for import-car owners or likely import buyers. Much of the technology going into building the car is new to the auto industry, including the injection molding process for making large body parts, including the doors. Kay acknowledged that testing showed doors expanded under high temperatures, but she declined to give any details. The Free Press said the swelling was so bad that doors wouldn't close. She said the problem stemmed from the material used in making the doors rather than the injection molding process, which has been used in the past for parts no larger than bumpers. ``Saturn is not experiencing any more pre-production problems than normally encountered with the startup of an all-new vehicle,'' Kay said. Saturn is due to arrive in dealer showrooms on schedule this fall, she said. The Free Press quoted a source as saying: ``It's going to be a photo finish, there's no doubt in my mind.''
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 460.96 up .43 from the previous day's close.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rules Against Purported Heirs in Oilfield Case
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge has ruled that thousands of decendants of an early Texas resident have no claim to a share of the Spindletop oilfield fortune or the estimated $200 billion worth of oil pumped from it since the Lucas gusher spurted in 1901. U.S. District Judge Howell Cobb's ruling came in the latest of a long series of lawsuits brought by would-be heirs against oil companies. It was a summary judgment in favor of Amoco Production Inc., Mobil Oil Corp., Phillips Petroleum Co., Texaco Inc. and Chevron Inc. in a suit filed by four relatives who claimed kinship to Pelham Humphries and asked for $200 billion in oil, gas and mineral rights from the companies. The suit was filed in February in Tennessee by the four relatives who sought to have their case declared a class action suit on behalf of numerous other heirs. The case was transferred to Beaumont. ``This court desperately desires that the ghost of Pelham Humphries will no longer haunt the halls of the United States court system,'' Cobb wrote in his opinion. ``The Pelham Humphries litigation is over ... requiescat in pace (rest in peace).'' Brown Peregoy, a Tennessee resident representing 3,000 members of the Humphries Heirs Trust Association, contended Pelham Humphries received a grant to the Spindletop property from the Mexican government in 1835, and left no will. The judge said in his ruling, however, that Humphries conveyed the grant to William Inglish, whose heirs conveyed it to William McFaddin in 1883. The 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals held in favor of the oil companies in a trilogy of Humphries' claims litigated in the 1950s and 1960s. The appellate court last ruled on a Humphries suit in 1968, and found the ``Humphries heirs have no title in the league of land,'' Cobb said. The judge will hold hearings later to determine if he will order the plaintiffs to pay legal fees for the defendants because of claim by the defendants that the suit was brought on which issues which have been tried before. Lawyer Max Wilson said he believes his clients have a legitimate claim. ``We knew we had an uphill battle,'' Wilson said. ``We took a long look at it and really felt like we had an inside chance of doing something with this thing.'' Peregoy, 52, a retired pipe superintendent who devoted nine years to researching the suit, said thousands of would-be heirs want their day in court. ``We feel like it's unconstitutional that these people have not had their say,'' he said.

DOC.NOTE: $adv27
For release Wednesday AMs, June 27, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Latest Japanese Export Is Apples
With AM-Apple Orchards
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Toyotas on American roads and the Sonys in American rec rooms may soon be joined by Fujis in American lunchboxes _ a Japanese-bred apple that seems to be the fruit of the future. Growers say Japanese bud wood grafted onto trees in the central Washington apple belt produces an apple that is crisper, tastier and more durable than Red Delicious, the industry standard since the 1920s. The Fujis also are bringing much higher wholesale prices _ not a minor consideration after three consecutive years of poor prices that have caused many growers to reassess the heart-shaped Red Delicious. ``There will be more change in the apple industry in the state of Washington in the next 10 years than in the last 30,'' said Brooke Peterson, a Washington State University tree fruit extension agent in Yakima County. He likened Washington apple growers, who produce 60 percent of the nation's crop, to U.S. automakers who were ``so big and so successful for so long'' that they failed to respond to the Japanese challenge. ``All of a sudden they are nipping us in the heels,'' he said. As a result, growers must produce a better and more diversified product, he said. Currently, 70 percent of Washington's apple crop is Red Delicious. ``We're in a revolution in supplying the public with an apple more satisfactory to their needs,'' said Grady Auvil, a legendary grower from Orondo who pioneered Washington production of the tangy Granny Smith a decade ago. Auvil, 84 and still out in his Columbia River orchard every day, is planting only Fujis on his 500 acres now. ``Twenty to 30 percent of the time the Red Delicious arrives to consumers in poor condition,'' Auvil said. The Fuji, first bred in Japan 35 years ago, has a longer shelf life, and shrivels on the outside before it softens inside, Auvil said. Too often, consumers complain of biting into a good-looking Red Delicious that is mealy. Tastes in apples change just as tastes in clothing, music or other products change, some growers say. Where consumers once clamored for bright red colors and the heart shape, now they are demanding better taste. The oblong-shaped Fuji has dull red stripes over a greenish-yellow base. Red Delicious apples cover more than 120,000 of the state's 160,000 acres of apple orchards. Trees take several years to bear fruit, so it will be some time before a flood of Fujis hits supermarkets, said Chuck St. John, a spokesman for the Washington Apple Commission. He also said it is much too early to write off the Red Delicious. ``It is not an inherently bad apple. Otherwise consumers wouldn't buy it,'' he said. ``We can grow Red Delicious and Golden Delicious better than they can be grown almost anyplace else in the world.'' The Red Delicious first was produced in a Midwest orchard in 1870 and was transported to Washington soon after. By 1915, the state was the nation's leading apple producer. But growers are struggling. Two seasons ago, the crop was severely damaged by excessive heat, and last year's sales and prices were hurt by the Alar scare. This year, the record crop of 78 million 42-pound boxes of eating apples has been bringing prices beneath the cost of production. Where boxes of Red Delicious sell for about $10 per box wholesale, Fujis sell for up to $40, said Jeff Main of the Market News Service in Yakima. Market News Service does not officially record Fuji prices, because there are so few available, he said. But it is likely that will change in the next three or four years, he said. The Fuji craze is reminiscent of the rush to plant Granny Smiths a decade ago. That tart apple now accounts for 5.5 percent of the state's crop. When Granny Smiths debuted, they, too, brought much higher prices. Now they are bringing about $15 per box, still better than Red Delicious. Auvil predicts Red Delicious will go the way of the Winesap in the next 30 years, and will be replaced by the Fuji. ``It is the one sweet apple you can always deliver with good quality if it starts the trip in good quality,'' he said.

DOC.TEXT: Stock prices dipped slightly this morning as the stock market moved into its third day of light trading. Market watchers said the sluggish activity shows investors are waiting for movement on interest rates, but not anticipating what the Federal Reserve might do. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 0.24 to 2,893.32 by noon on Wall Street today. The Dow had gained 11.38 Tuesday as it rebounded from a 53.71 point drop Monday. Advancing issues were about even with losers on the New York Stock Exchange, with 638 up, 632 down and 572 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 64.76 million shares as of noon EDT today. Big Board volume totaled 134.93 million shares Tuesday, against 133.47 million Monday. Institutional investors have been largely absent from this week's activity as concern over interest rates and corporate earnings have slowed their buying, analysts said. ``It's a period of marking time and waiting for things to happen,'' said Edwin Kantor, chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ``They expect some easing (of monetary policy by the Fed) but nobody knows the timing. ... A lot of people are just sitting on the sidelines waiting for the other shoe to drop.'' Canadian Pacific was up [ at 18 as the most active stock on the NYSE this morning. Officials at the Montreal-based transporation company did not immediately return telephone calls seeking comment. Among other active stocks, TCBY Enterprises was down { at 18[, Abbott Laboratories was up ~ at 39~ and Navistar was down [ at 4. On the over-the-counter market, MCI Communications was the most active down } at 41}. The company today announced a long distance service designed to bring features normally reserved for larger companies to smaller businesses. DOC.HEAD: London Shares End Slightly Higher
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with closing prices.
DOC.TEXT: Share prices finished slightly higher on London's Stock Exchange Wednesday, as investors awaited the end of the quarter before opening any big positions. Dealers said institutional investors have indicated they are content with the profits they have made so far in the second quarter and are awaiting the start of the July-September period before making new investments. In addition, the Royal Ascot horse races kept many investors out of the market, dealers said, as did a mediocre start to Wall Street and an absence of major news. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index rose 1.5 points, or 0.06 percent, to close at 2,371.2. The index was off its session peak of 2,384.5. The minimum, reached in early morning, was 2,369.6. The Financial Times 30-share index was off 4.0 points at 1,903.4 at the close. The Financial Times 500-share index fell 0.46 point to close at 1,283.70. Volume came to a modest 436.8 million shares, compared with 408.3 million shares Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: TCI Offers to Become National Cable Affiliate for NBC
DOC.TEXT: Tele-Communications Inc. has proposed a union with NBC-TV that would make the cable giant a national network affiliate and allow it to deliver NBC programming to communities that lack hometown channels. ``This would serve the local issue more profoundly than any other business arrangement we can think of,'' TCI Vice President Robert Thomson said Tuesday. ``Nationwide, there might be thousands of small towns served by TCI that, if this were allowed, we would have the economic power to have a hometown channel,'' he said. The network is evaulating the proposal, NBC spokesman Richard Cutting said Wednesday. He had no further comment. TCI released the proposal Tuesday. Under the proposal, the Denver-based TCI would create a string of NBC stations in small communities that lack the money to become network affiliates. The cable company would bracket NBC programming, such as ``The Cosby Show'' and ``L.A. Law,'' with locally produced news and sports shows where economically feasible, John Malone, TCI president, said in a letter to NBC President Robert Wright. In the letter, Malone said TCI would comply with the same terms that an NBC affiliate must adhere to, but would not require an affiliate fee from the network in exchange for the use of NBC's signal. The firm also would continue to comply with Federal Communication Commission regulations requiring that cable companies carry regional networks. TCI would earn revenues by selling local advertising time on NBC shows. It also could add cable subscribers by offering a new local channel. ``It would be a win-win situation. Local advertisers would have a local channel to advertise on. Local subscribers would have a channel that emphasized local news, sports and current events,'' Thomson said. ``And the local cable operator would hopefully have better penetration in that community.'' A stumbling block to carrying out the proposal are network contracts that give existing NBC affiliates exclusive rights in regional broadcast markets. Thomson said TCI approached NBC because of its 23 percent market share, which leads all broadcast networks. In contrast, each of the most popular cable networks, CNN and ESPN, has a 2 percent share. NBC, a majority owner of the CNBC consumer cable channel, is also participating in a proposed direct broadcast venture called Sky Cable that will beam more than 100 channels to owners of small home satellite dishes. John Redden, an analyst with the Connecticut-based Moran & Associates Inc., said the proposal would open the local programming door to TCI. ``NBC would benefit because it would get its signal extended and become more entrenched in that community,'' he said. TCI has about 8.5 million subscribers nationwide.

Stock prices moved down moderately today in the stock market's third day of light trading. Market watchers said the sluggish activity shows investors are waiting for movement on interest rates, but not anticipating what the Federal Reserve might do. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials dropped 13.86 to 2,879.70 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street today. The Dow had gained 11.38 Tuesday as it rebounded from a 53.71 point drop Monday. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 552 up, 842 down and 541 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 98.74 million shares with two hours to go today. About midday, the Fed released its forecast for continued slow economic growth and little change in inflation. Although the forecast contained few surprises, it was followed by a quick drop in the Dow. Bond prices also fell. The forecast led some to think it was unlikely the Fed would lower interest rates soon. A lot of people are just sitting on the sidelines waiting for the other shoe to drop.'' Big Board volume totaled 134.93 million shares Tuesday, against 133.47 million Monday.
