DOC.HEAD: Pathe's Plan to Buy MGM-UA Shaky
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp.'s planned buyout of MGM-United Artists may fall apart because a major backer says Pathe can't rely on borrowed funds and must come up with millions in equity. Time Warner Inc. is insisting that Pathe must arrange $600 million in equity, $450 million of that itself, toward the $1.2 billion bid for MGM-UA, following guidelines of an April financing agreement. Pathe's ability to fund the acquisition is now in serious doubt, and the company will almost certainly need an extension on a Saturday deadline. Under the April agreement, Time Warner would loan $650 million toward the purchase, with Pathe contributing the rest. In return for the loan, Time Warner would receive distribution rights to the huge United Artists film library as well as future Pathe and MGM-UA movies, including ``Rocky V.'' Pathe officials said earlier this month that most of its share of the cost would come from loans, asset sales and possible resale of some MGM-UA stock. Though Time Warner officials initially seemed to approve of the plan, they later feared that Pathe was taking on too much debt. Money would come from companies affiliated with Pathe, said Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons, and therefore should not be called loans. ``We're paying (the money) back in shares of stock, so this is not a loan in the conventional sense,'' he said. ``It could be considered equity.'' Parsons also said Pathe had already put down $200 million in capital as a down payment.

DOC.HEAD: Preview of Luxury Auction Items from Failed Thrift
DOC.TEXT: More than 16,000 pieces of fine china, 1,450 Baccarat crystal goblets and a serving tray large enough to hold a roast pig are among the excesses from CenTrust Bank to be sold at auction. A preview of the luxury items that supplied an exclusive dining club set up by the bank's ex-chairman, David Paul, was held at CenTrust in Miami Tuesday. The whole batch goes up for sale Saturday as federal regulators try to recover at least part of the $2 billion cost of bailing out the thrift _ the state's largest savings and loan until it was seized in February. Regulators charge Paul with using the failed thrift as his ``personal piggy bank.'' The items for sale include small silver tongs for french fries and large silver tongs for ice cubes, a flat-slotted spoon for serving aspargus and a racked pan for holding asparagus. Silver-plated grape scissors, bone holders, lemon squeezers and pate spreaders are among the odder implements for sale. ``It's a bit much,'' said Eleanor Matthews, a contract administrator for Florida's Dade County. ``I have to say I never knew there were silver holders for paper plates and cups before.'' Gold-rimmed, five-piece Limoges china settings sell for $600 and each piece of crystal sells for $140, but no minumum prices have been set for most of the items at the auction. A signed copy of ``The Works of H.G. Wells'' will be offered for an undisclosed price, one of many leather-bound books that once lined the shelves in Paul's office.

DOC.HEAD: Enlarged Loss Linked to Writedown of Federated Goodwill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: All dollars are U.S.
DOC.TEXT: Financially distressed Campeau Corp. lost $1.7 billion last year, a huge deterioration from 1988's deficit of $34 million, the Canadian company reported Wednesday. A large share of the loss _ $958 million _ resulted from writing down the goodwill of one of Toronto-based Campeau's U.S. retail divisions, Federated Department Stores Inc. Federated and its sister retailing company Allied Stores Corp. are operating under U.S. bankruptcy court supervision. Goodwill is the value placed on a company's reputation typically due to the quality of its services or products. On the other side of the books, Campeau said it had revenue of $10.4 billion from its department stores, supermarkets and real estate operations in the 12 months ended Jan. 31, 1990. That compares with $8.7 billion for 1988. Last year's revenue gain for Campeau mainly was due to a contribution of a full year's results from Federated and Ralphs Grocery Co., bought in May 1988. The 1989 results also include the $101-million sale of Allied's Ann Taylor division and a gain of $104 million from the sale of a number of pieces of real estate in the United States. Campeau acquired Allied in 1986. Campeau's real estate operations, which are in Canada, posted 1989 revenue of $202 million compared with $169 million in 1988. ``Real estate revenues did seem to be very strong in the year, suggesting that Campeau can survive without the retail operations,'' said Janet Mangano, an analyst with Josepthal & Co. in New York. Earlier this month, Campeau debenture holders said they would defer certain interest payments until next year. The company has been struggling to cope with a cash shortage caused by heavy debts amassed in trying to build an extensive retail empire. A planned reorganizaion of Campeau would include asset sales. On Tuesday, Cincinnati-based Federated and Allied reported a combined loss of $99.5 million in the quarter ended May 5. The two U.S. divisions, which cited $7.7 billion in debts in filing for U.S. Bankruptcy Court protection from creditors in January, operate 260 stores in 28 states.

DOC.HEAD: Profit-taking Sends Corn Futures Lower
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices closed mixed in active trading Wednesday on the Chicago Board of Trade as crop damage concerns continued to guide the market. Trading of corn futures were particularly volatile as prices surged on reports of flooded fields in several key producing states. The surge in prices ignited a selloff by professionals and commercial houses looking for profits, said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. ``The people who bought into the market on Monday had more than a dime in profits,'' Biedermann said of the sellers. ``That's a heck of a profit to make.'' He said reports of extensive damage to crops in some areas of the Midwest continue to cause concern on the market. Thousands of acres are reported under water in Nebraska. And heavy rains in Iowa have reportedly damaged 340,000 crop acres in that state. Analysts say the crops in some areas must be replanted. Soybean prices also were buoyed by concern that soybean yield could be adversely affected by heavy rains. Reports that farmers in South America were not marketing their bean crop in hopes for higher prices also helped boost soybean futures. Wheat futures were helped by strong export demand, as well as indications of further yield reductions in the Midwest soft red winter wheat crop due to excessive moisture. At the close, wheat was unchanged to 2 cents higher with the contract for delivery in July at $3.34\ a bushel; corn was 2} cents lower to 1 cent higher with July at $2.85} a bushel; oats were } cent to 1 cent lower wtih July at $1.40{ a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 8 cents higher with July at $5.98{ a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Grand Jury Indicts Former S&L Executives in Mississippi
DOC.TEXT: A federal grand jury has returned a 12-count indictment against a former Jackson couple for their role in the failure of Republic Bank For Savings, officials said Wednesday. Philip K. Shunk, and his wife, Linda, are jointly charged with one count of conspiracy to misapply Republic's funds, three counts of making false entries in various bank reports, and one count of converting the proceeds of stock held by Republic to their own use. Republic Bank For Savings, F.A., is a federally chartered savings and loan institution. Philip Shunk faces a maximum penalty of $3 million in fines and up to 65 years in prison. Linda Shunk faces up to 30 years in prison and a $1.25 million in fine. ``Today's indictment is further proof that we are determined to pursue allegations of financial fraud in the savings and loan industry until we have punished those who have profited illegally at the expense of the American taxpayer,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburg said in a statement. Federal regulators were appointed two years ago to take over Republic, which reportedly had a deficit of $12.3 million, said U.S. Attorney George L. Phillips. ``As a result of federal investigations, we now believe that Republic's losses may be significantly higher,'' Phillips said. Philip Shunk was hired Oct. 28, 1985, as president of Republic, and Linda Shunk was named executive vice president and chief financial officer. Both served on Republic's board of directors. During the time of their employment, the Shunks served on Republic's loan committee. The indictment charges that one or both of them made false statements in Republic's records concerning meetings of the loan committee nine times in an effort to deceive S&L examiners.

The stock market dropped today in the third straight day of light volume after the Federal Reserve predicted continued slow economic growth. Although the Fed report contained few surprises, it led to a quick drop in the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials. The Dow fell 15.09 to 2,878.47 by 3 p.m. on Wall Street today. The Dow had gained 11.38 Tuesday as it rebounded from a 53.71 point drop Monday. Declining issues outnumbered advancers by about 3 to 2 on the New York Stock Exchange, with 557 up, 872 down and 532 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 113.15 million shares with an hour to go today. After the Fed issued its forecast for slow growth and little change in inflation, the Dow and bond market fell. Groping for any news available on the future of interest rates, some apparently saw the report as a sign that rates would not fall soon. ``A little bit of news one way or the other can turn this thing,'' said Alan Ackerman, senior vice president and market strategist at Gruntal & Co. The week's light volume has been attributed to slowed buying resulting from concern, particularly among institutional investors, over interest rates and corporate earnings, analysts said. ``It's a period of marking time and waiting for things to happen,'' said Edwin Kantor, chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. DOC.HEAD: Saturn Denies Report of Delay in Spring Hill
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. has fixed the problem of a swelling door on its new Saturn model, and the first marketable car should roll off a Tennessee assembly line on schedule this summer, the company said Wednesday. Officials from GM and its wholly owned subsidiary, Saturn Corp., have refused to say exactly when ``Job 1'' will be assembled. But GM Chairman Roger Smith has said he expects to drive the first car off the assembly line before he retires July 31. ``Our plans still anticipate that would occur prior to his retirement,'' Saturn spokeswoman Laurie Kay said Wednesday. Saturn is a $3 billion project to build a car with a base price of less than $12,000 to compete directly with those made by Japanese companies. About two-thirds of the project cost is tied up in the Spring Hill, Tenn., manufacturing complex. Kay acknowledged the car's plastic door panels swelled in high temperatures, a problem traced to materials. She refused to disclose the severity of the swelling, but said Saturn remains on schedule. ``Saturn is not experiencing any more pre-production problems than normally encountered with the startup of an all-new vehicle,'' Kay said. Much of the Saturn car's body panels will be made of plastics. The panels will be formed in a process called injection molding, which until now has been used in making automotive parts no larger than a bumper. GM has said repeatedly it plans to begin commercial production this summer with the vehicles first arriving in dealerships this fall. The automaker won't say exactly when production startup is scheduled at the factory south of Nashville. The company already has assembled some Saturn cars to test manufacturing equipment and processes. Those cars, which do not have vehicle identification numbers, will be used in crash tests and other research and training programs.
Stock prices dipped slightly today in the third straight day of quiet trading. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was down 2.47 points at 2,891.09.

DOC.HEAD: White House, Democrats Point Fingers in S&L Crisis
DOC.NOTE: EDs: ADDS top 7 grafs to include Bush quotes; picks up 5th graf pvs, ``Pointing to''. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The White House and congressional Democrats, drawing their political swords for an election-year battle, are bluntly blaming each other for the multibillion-dollar savings and loan scandal. But President Bush said today he wants to stay out of that debate. ``What I'm trying to do is not respond to individuals and to simply keep moving forward on this process,'' Bush told a news conference in Huntsville, Ala. The White House went on the offensive Tuesday, daring Democrats to try to turn the crisis into a campaign issue. ``There are a lot of battles that can be fought on this turf, and we're ready,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater warned. He said ``the Democrats have a big role'' in the collapse of the savings and loan industry. Returning the fire, Democrats accused the White House of moving sluggishly against those who looted thrift institutions. ``A spark seemed to be ignited there and I think more important than continuing to pour fuel on that spark is to work cooperatively with the Congress in trying to get this mess solved,'' Bush said. Pointing to 10 years of Republican rule in the White House, Sen. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., questioned, ``Who ran the government during this decade of mismanagement and negligence?'' Sen. Bob Kerrey, D-Neb., who was singled out for attack by the White House, called Fitzwater ``the mean-spirited little spokesman'' and accused him of trying to intimidate Democrats into silence. Referring to another sensitive political issue, Sen. David Pryor, D-Ark., said, ``Maybe Mr. Fitzwater has been so busy the last two or three weeks protecting us from the flag burners that he forgot to do his homework on the history of the last decade.'' In an apparent attempt to blunt criticism that his administration is not doing enough to prosecute S&L crime, President Bush is scheduled on Friday to address the nation's 93 U.S. attorneys. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh summoned the top federal prosecutors to the meeting at the Justice Department, said spokesman Dan Eramian. The charges and counter-charges did not shed any new light on the S&L scandal but put it into sharp focus as a key issue for the fall elections. Estimates of how much it will cost taxpayers to clean up the industry range anywhere from $130 billion to $500 billion and more. There were these other S&L developments Tuesday: _Rep. Frank Annunzio, D-Ill., demanded that federal regulators spell out their charges against President Bush's son, Neil, in the $1 billion collapse of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver. The Office of Thrift Supervision has brought administrative charges against Neil Bush, a former director of Silverado, but has not publicly outlined its case. ``No law or regulation prevents the agency from revealing the charges,'' Annunzio said at a hearing by the House Banking Committee. Neil Bush has denied any wrongdoing. _Charles H. Keating Jr. predicted that a federal judge will give him back his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, seized by the government in April 1989 in perhaps the nation's costliest S&L collapse. Lawyers for Keating and the government summarized final arguments in the case Tuesday before U.S. District Judge Stanley Sporkin. Fitzwater's attack against Democrats was notable both for the sharpness of his words and his willingness to point fingers. ``Take a look at Jim Wright and Tony Coelho and Mr. Kerrey and some of his Nebraska accounts and Don Riegle and DeConcini; take a look at all of them,'' Fitzwater said. ``I don't think you hear any serious analysis of this problem that doesn't point to Freddy St Germain and the changes that were made in the banking laws back at that point.'' Wright, the former House speaker, and Coelho, the former House assistant Democratic leader and a principal Democratic fund-raiser, resigned last year amid questions of ethical impropriety. Riegle and DeConcini are among five legislators being investigated by the Senate Ethics Committee for allegedly intervening with federal regulators after accepting political contributions from Keating. Fernand St Germain was chairman of the House Banking Committee during the adoption of a bill _ cosponsored by Sen. Jake Garn, R-Utah _ to overhaul the S&L industry. Fitzwater did not elaborate on his remarks about Kerrey. Asked if he would say if Republicans were at fault for the crisis, Fitzwater replied, ``No.'' He said Neil Bush was not involved in any S&L scandal. On Capitol Hill, Pryor said Congress' fault was one of negligence in not requiring regulators in the last years of the Reagan administration to take lie-detector tests. ``They simply were not telling us the truth. The truth was that the S&L crisis was here, it was happening and we were not being told the truth,'' he said. Senate Republican Leader Bob Dole of Kansas applauded Fitzwater and said he hopes he keeps it up. ``The president doesn't have to take it lying down just because some member of Congress attacks,'' Dole said. As for blame for the crisis, Dole said, ``In the final analysis, it lies everywhere.''

Stocks prices dipped slightly today in the third straight day of light trading. A midday report from the Federal Reserve that predicted slower economic growth and little change in inflation sent prices down quickly in the early afternoon. The report contained few surprises, but moved the waffling market. ``A little bit of news one way or another can turn this thing,'' Alan Ackerman, senior vice president and market strategist at Gruntal & Co, said. Investors have been groping for the slightest signal of where interest rates are headed, market watchers said. Late in the day stock prices began to recover. Many investors, also apparently concerned about corporate profits, have sat out. Volume has been down to what Walter Murphy, senior market specialist at Merrill Lynch & Co., called ``bordering on abysmal.'' Institutional investors have also apparently been sitting out, analysts said. ``It's a period of marking time and waiting for things to happen,'' said Edwin Kantor, chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. ``A lot of people are just sitting on the sidelines waiting for the other shoe to drop.''
DOC.HEAD: More
Crude Continues to Fall, Other Products Rebound
DOC.TEXT: Crude oil prices continued to slide Wednesday, remaining at levels not seen since late 1988, amid ongoing concerns about oversupply. The futures price of West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, for July delivery tumbled 35 cents to settle at $15.30 a 42-gallon barrel on the New York Mercantile Exchange. Other contract months also fell. The last time crude traded in that range was in November 1988, according to energy analysts. The July contract had fallen 29 cents on Tuesday and 68 cents Monday. Market watchers said the drop was due partly to the fact that the July contract was set to expire on Wednesday. But they said continued concern about overproduction among the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries was also a big factor. ``There's concern that OPEC is not willing to take steps to shore up the market,'' said Peter Beutel, an assistant director of the energy group at Elders Futures Inc. A report released late Tuesday by the American Petroleum Institute also didn't help. API said inventory levels of crude oil, an important factor in pricing, fell 1.2 million barrels last week to 384.4 billion barrels. But analysts said the drop was slight and, therefore, not enough to lift prices. ``They (the figures) were not bad. But they were not good enough to turn things around,'' said Beutel. The drop in crude oil Wednesday did help other protroleum products, as traders used some of the proceeds from crude sales to buy unleaded gasoline or heating oil. On the New York Merc, the July contract for wholesale unleaded gasoline settled up 0.55 cent to 60.47 cents a gallon, after tumbling 1.64 cents Tuesday largely on profit-taking. Wholesale home heating oil for July delivery settled 0.21 cent higher at 47.64 cents a gallon on the exchange, after losing 0.43 cent on Tuesday. In natural gas trading, the July contract closed at $1.510 per 1,000 cubic feet, down from $1.536 Tuesday.

DOC.HEAD: Kohlberg Kravis Plans Recapitalization of Food and Tobacco Giant
DOC.TEXT: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts & Co. said Wednesday it planned to recapitalize its RJR Nabisco Inc., an indication the giant company will not be broken up and eventually will return to public ownership. Under the tentative plan, Kohlberg Kravis would retire a large part of the $6 billion in junk bonds it used to buy the food and tobacco company in a record $24.53 billion buyout last year. Kohlberg Kravis also would issue preferred stock convertible into common stock in RJR Nabisco. By retiring some of its old junk bonds, which have fallen in value during recent months, Kohlberg Kravis would avoid having to pay a sharply higher interest rate on some of the securities next year. The sale of stock under the plan also would counter any notions that Kohlberg Kravis plans to systematically dismantle RJR Nabisco, as it did after it bought the consumer products conglomerate Beatrice Co. in 1985. Beatrice once owned such well-known businesses as the Avis car rental company, Tropicana juice products, Hunt and Wesson foods, Samsonite luggage, Swift meats, Playtex personal products and Culligan water softeners. Between its $6.1 billion acquisition of Beatrice in 1985 and this month, when the conglomerate's remaining food operations were sold, Kohlberg Kravis divested the company piece by piece. Some of the businesses fetched prices of over $1 billion. Kohlberg Kravis and its investors ended up reaping a fat 50 percent return on their original equity investment. RJR Nabisco also has a variety of food lines and a separate tobacco business. But analysts say that while Beatrice was ripe for an unbundling of its disparate businesses, RJR Nabisco is not. Beatrice ``had this and that _ a lot of things that didn't make sense to have together anyway,'' said Jack Maxwell, an analyst who follows RJR Nabisco for Wheat, First Securities Inc. in Richmond, Va. RJR Nabisco has product lines that conceivably could be pared, but Maxwell said he doubted Kohlberg Kravis would begin unloading food divisions and ``you can't sell bits and pieces of the tobacco business very well.'' Since its buyout, RJR has divested $5.66 billion in assets to pare its debt load, which now stands at $22 billion. Its Del Monte canned foods and fresh fruit businesses and some of its foreign holdings were among those sold. But, said Maxwell, ``They've sold pretty much what they want to sell.'' In its announcement Wednesday, RJR Nabisco said Kohlberg Kravis would invest an additional $1.7 billion in the company as part of the recapitalization, another move that points away from a breakup of the company. Analysts see RJR Nabisco returning to public ownership, beginning at some point in the next few years. That is the route taken by another Kohlberg Kravis holding, Safeway Stores Inc. After Safeway went private in a 1986 leveraged buyout, the supermarket company began hammering away at its debt and streamlined its operations. This past February, 3{ years after the buyout, the company announced a modest initial offering of 10 million shares. RJR Nabisco said it was negotiating new loans with banks as part of the recapitalization plan. The company said it expected to begin enacting the plan by the end of July. The recapitalization is intended to take off the market some of RJR Nabisco's junk bonds that have declined in value during recent months. A buyback of the bonds would allow Kohlberg Kravis to sidestep provisions requiring the firm to guarantee the price of the bonds by next April. The plan is likely to lower the return for Kohlberg Kravis and its investors. But without a recapitalization, RJR Nabisco would end up paying a higher interest rate on the bonds. RJR Nabisco bonds rose sharply Wednesday on word of the recapitalization, gaining as much as $6.25 per $100 in face value. Kohlberg Kravis' investors mostly are large pension funds that generally do not have an active voice in the management of the companies they own, including RJR Nabisco. Officials of several funds declined to comment on what they'd like to see happen to RJR Nabisco. But several said they were satisfied with the management of their investments. David Weig, executive director of the Washington State Investment Board, said he was ``absolutely happy,'' with the management at RJR Nabisco and with Kohlberg Kravis. Oregon state pension officials also said they were happy. ``We have had excellent returns from these kinds of investments,'' said Sheryl Wilson, executive director of the state's retirement funds.

DOC.HEAD: Oversupply Continues to Weigh on Crude Oil Futures
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures prices were mixed in trading Wednesday on the New York Mercantile Exchange as crude oil futures continued their plunge in a market plagued by oversupply. On other markets, grain and soybean prices were mixed, precious metals were higher, copper declined and livestock and pork futures were mixed. Heavy selling of the expiring July contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of crude oil, weighed on the energy market, analysts said. However, gasoline and heating oil prices rose. The decline in crude prices came in the wake of American Petroleum Institute figures, out Tuesday, showing U.S. crude inventories last week declined by 1.2 million barrels to 384.4 million. But despite the decline, crude stocks remain 44.3 million barrels above last year's level, analysts said. Gasoline stocks declined to 216.6 million barrels from 217 million. ``There is too much pumped crude for the refineries to handle,'' said James Fiedler, an analyst with E.D. & F. Man International Futures Inc. in New York. ``It (stocks) didn't build overnight. And it will take time for the refineries to work through it.'' There was some uncertainty in the market due to a shakeup in the Kuwaiti government that resulted in the removal of longtime oil minister Sheikh Ali Khalifa Al-Sabah. Named as oil minister was Rashid Salim Al-Ameeri. Sheikh Ali Khalifa was named finance minister. West Texas Intermediate crude settled 35 cents lower to 14 cents higher with the July contract at $15.30 a pound; heating oil was .03 cent to .21 cent higher with July at 47.64 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent lower to .61 cent higher with July at 60.47 cents a gallon. Grain and soybean futures prices were mixed on the Chicago Board of Trade as crop damage concerns continued to guide the market. Trading of corn futures were particularly volatile as prices surged on reports of flooded fields in several key producing states. The surge in prices ignited a selloff by professionals and commercial houses looking for profits, said William Biedermann, an analyst with Allendale Inc. in Chicago. ``The people who bought into the market on Monday had more than a dime in profits,'' Biedermann said of the sellers. ``That's a heck of a profit to make.'' Thousands of acres are reported under water in Nebraska. And heavy rains in Iowa have reportedly damaged 340,000 crop acres in that state. Analysts say the crops in some areas must be replanted. Soybean prices also were buoyed by concern that soybean yield could be adversely affected by heavy rains. Reports that farmers in South America were not marketing their bean crop in hopes for higher prices also helped boost soybean futures. Wheat futures were helped by strong export demand, as well as indications of further yield reductions in the Midwest soft red winter wheat crop due to excessive moisture. Wheat was unchanged to 3 cents higher with July at $3.34{ a bushel; corn was a 2} cent lower to 1\ cent higher with July at $2.85\ a bushel; oats were a { cent to 1 cent lower wtih July at $1.40{ a bushel; soybeans were 2 cents to 7\ cents higher with July at $5.98 a bushel. Livestock and meat futures were mixed on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Cattle futures were lower on concerns the fed cattle supplies will increase during the summer and reduce cash prices. Pork futures were higher on perceptions that the recent drops in prices were overdone. Live cattle were .18 cent to .70 cent lower with June at 76.65 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent to .52 cent lower with August at 85.30 cents a pound; hogs were .25 cent lower to .33 cent higher with June at 60.50 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were 1.30 cents lower to .70 cent higher with July at 63.40 cents a pound. Precious metals futures climbed on the New York's Commodity Exchange, although there was little news to stimulate the market, analysts said. Gold was $1 to $1.40 higher with June at $350.50 a troy ounce; silver was 1.4 cents to 1.7 cents higher wtih June at $4.832 a troy ounce. Copper futures declined sharply on the Comex on the perception that recent price gains were overdone. Also weighing on copper prices was a report from the Federal Reserve Bank that points to a slowdown in the U.S. economy and a decline in construction. Increased stocks in Comex- and London Metals Exchange-approved warehouses also helped push prices lower. Copper prices were 1.85 cents to 4.15 cents lower with June at $1.1045 a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Rises, Gold Mixed
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against most other major currencies Wednesday in light trading, boosted by concern about political uncertainty in the Soviet Union, traders said. Gold prices rose domestically after a mixed performance overseas. On the New York Commodity Exchange, gold rose $1.40 an ounce to $350.50. Later, Republic National Bank in New York reported a late bid of $349.60 an ounce, up $1.70 from Tuesday. The dollar was helped by a comment from Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev that soon he might no longer be leader of the Communist Party, traders said. At a party meeting in Moscow, Gorbachev acknowledged that he could lose his party post at a national congress in less than two weeks. The news caused a flight to the dollar in the currency markets, typical in times of uncertainty, said Andrew Hodge, vice president of corporate treasury services at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York. But the dollar retreated somewhat later in the day, Hodge said. The mark was the currency most affected by Gorbachev's comments, traders said. In Europe, the dollar closed at 1.6785 marks, up from 1.6712 Tuesday. Later, in New York, the dollar closed at 1.6783 marks, up from 1.6725 marks. The British pound lost ground against the dollar in New York after rising overseas. In London, the pound rose to $1.7225 from $1.7198 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound was quoted at $1.7220, cheaper than the $1.7225 it cost late Tuesday. In Tokyo, the dollar rose 0.26 yen to a closing 153.98 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a higher rate of 154.00 yen, and in New York it closed at 153.95 yen to the dollar, up from 153.485 yen late Tuesday. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Tuesday's prices, included: 1.4130 Swiss francs, up from 1.4090; 5.6410 French francs, up from 5.6230; 1,231.00 Italian lire, up from 1,227.25; and 1.1730 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17385. Other late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Tuesday's levels, included: 1.4155 Swiss francs, up from 1.4100; 5.6405 French francs, up from 5.6177; 1.8878 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8800; 1,231.00 Italian lire, up from 1,226.00; and 1.1723 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1738. Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $349.15 a troy ounce from $348.25 bid late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold fell to a closing bid of $347.25 from $347.80 late Tuesday. Gold in Hong Kong fell $1.60 to close at a bid of $348.85. Silver bullion fell in London to $4.82 a troy ounce from Tuesday's late bid of $4.84. In New York, silver closed at $4.832 a troy ounce on the Commodity Exchange, up from $4.815 late Tuesday.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.HEAD: Stock Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Stocks were mixed Wednesday as the waffling market looked for direction in its third straight day of quiet trading. A Federal Reserve prediction of continued slow economic growth and little change in inflation sent the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials down quickly in the early afternoon. Bond prices also tumbled. The report held few surprises, but analysts said investors were groping for any sign of where interest rates might be headed. ``It was just an excuse to bring this thing in a little bit,'' Alan Ackerman, senior vice president and market strategist at Gruntal & Co, said. The Dow industrials recovered later in the day to finish up 1.74 at 2,895.30. Broader indexes were down. The Dow average of 20 transportations was down 1.82 at 1,177.01 nd the average of 15 utilities was down 0.38 at 208.56. Declining issues outnumbered gainers by about 7 to 6 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 668 up, 777 down and 555 unchanged. ``I can describe the market in three sentences,'' Ackerman said. ``No trend. No volume. No clear-cut conviction.'' Volume has been light this week as investors, particularly institutions, wait for signs of whether the Fed plans to ease monetary policy, analysts said. ``A lot of people are just sitting on the sidelines waiting for the other shoe to drop,'' said Edwin Kantor, chairman of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. Volume on the floor of the Big Board came to 137.42 million shares, up from 134.93 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 166.12 million shares. Varity Corp. was the most active NYSE-listed issue, trading down [ at 3. Candadian Pacific was up [ at 18 and Banc One was down | at 28~. Among other active NYSE stocks, Upjohn was up 2 at 42, Citicorp was down ] at 22{ and Occidental Petroleum was down \ at 25}. Among blue chips, Chevron was down } at 70~, Diversified Energies was up 1\ at 32{ and General Motors gained \ at 49{. On the over-the-counter market, Telephonos de Mexico was the most active stock, up 1-32 at 1 23-32. MCI Communications was down ~ at 41| and TW Holdings was up 1-16 at 4{. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market rose $3.82 billion, or 0.11 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 0.23 to 195.84. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 1.11 to 421.12, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 0.63 at 359.10. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market rose 0.27 to 460.80. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 360.81, down 0.02.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Defends Administration's Prosecution of S&L Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 5th pvs ``Put those ...' to UPDATE with House voting for increased Justice Department appropriation. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush defended his administration's prosecution of savings and loan fraud and offered an olive branch Wednesday to Democrats critical of the effort. ``There has been an active prosecution under way,'' Bush told reporters at the Marshall Space Flight Center in Huntsville, Ala. His remarks came a day after he reviewed the Justice Department's anti-fraud effort with Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and after his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, attacked Democrats critical of the president's handling of the S&L mess. Bush, who is scheduled to address the nation's 93 U.S. attorneys in Washington on Friday, said Thornburgh offered ``impressive numbers'' on the S&L fraud cases being pursued, adding ``I expect we'll see plenty more.'' ``Put those that are guilty into the dock, where they belong, and see that they are, you know, brought to responsibility for what they've done,'' he said. Meanwhile, the House voted 420-1 Wednesday to provide the Justice Department with $75 million to fight white-collar crime in financial institutions during fiscal year 1991 beginning Oct. 1. At the administration's request, Congress had provided $50 million in 1990, an amount Democrats said was inadequate. On Tuesday, Fitzwater declared the administration ready to do political battle over the issue, citing several current and former Democratic members of Congress as vulnerable to criticism. The spokesman mentioned Sens. Donald W. Riegle Jr. of Michigan, chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Dennis DeConcini of Arizona and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska; former House Speaker Jim Wright of Texas; former Rep. Tony Coelho of California, and former House Banking Committee Chairman Fernand J. St Germain of Rhode Island. ``What he (Fitzwater) did was appropriate,'' Bush said. ``But what I'm trying to do is not respond to individuals and to simply keep moving forward on this process.'' Bush conceded that ``a spark seemed to be ignited there'' by Fitzwater's remarks, but added, ``I think more important than continuing to pour fuel on the spark is to work cooperatively with the Congress in trying to get this mess solved.'' Democratic criticism of Bush's management of the S&L bailout has been growing since last month, when the administration said Congress would have to provide a second bailout of $30 billion to $50 billion later this year. Meanwhile, an organization affiliated with consumer activist Ralph Nader issued a report criticizing the administration's ``anemic'' efforts to prosecute S&L fraud. The report, by Public Citizen's Congress Watch, estimated that the government's civil and criminal actions have recovered only $300 million in S&L losses. That's less than 2 percent of the $16.3 billion in losses attributed to fraud among the 440 S&Ls seized by the government since early last year, the group said. ``The Bush administration's efforts to pursue and punish S&L fraud have been anemic at best, irresponsible at worst,'' said Sherry Ettleson, an attorney who prepared a 23-page report on the issue for the group. The Nader organization faulted the administration for spending only an additional $50 million on pursuing thrift crime, when Congress had authorized spending of up to $75 million. The administration has responded that Congress eventually appropriated only $50 million and officials are spending that amount. It said the Justice Department is pursuing 891 cases actively, compared with a backlog of 6,993 cases. Yet, the department has added fewer than half the 425 additional agents requested by the FBI and only 118 of the 231 assistant U.S. attorneys requested by the department's field offices, the report said. ``Based on the record thus far, there is little evidence that the Bush administration is committed to catching and punishing white-collar criminals who largely caused the worst financial scandal in U.S. history,'' Ettleson wrote. The group recommended that the administration spend more on pursuing fraud, turn its attention to accountants and lawyers who aided S&L executives in committing fraud and drop its support of proposed legislation that would remove the threat of triple damages from civil racketeering suits. It said Congress should enact legislation that would permit whistleblowers to bring suit against alleged S&L criminals on behalf of the government and share in the damages if fraud is found to have occurred.

DOC.HEAD: USX Ends Offer Of Oil, Gas Wells
DOC.TEXT: USX Corp. on Wednesday withdrew its offer to sell oil and natural gas wells in the West and Southwest. The steel and energy giant last fall offered six groups of wells owned by its Texas Oil & Gas Corp. and has sold two of them. Atlantic Richfield Co. bought 175 natural gas wells in southwestern Oklahoma for $53 million, and Sonat Inc., an Alabama company, paid $140 million for Texas Oil and Gas properties in Arkansas. The sale of one of the remaining four will be announced by the end of the month, USX said. It is taking the other three off the market. The four packages are in eastern Texas, western Texas, Oklahoma and California. An oversupply of crude and refined oil made the Texas Oil & Gas properties less attractive, an analyst speculated. ``They're not changing their mind. The market's changing it for them,'' said Greg Drahuschak of Butcher & Singer in Pittsburgh. ``If you sell your house, but no one at the party meets your price tag, there's a point where you say, `No, I'm just not selling,' '' Drahuschak said. ``Today's announcement is a recognition that sale of all the properties was probably optimistic.'' Texas Oil & Gas accounted for 5.5 percent of USX's 1989 sales. The division posted losses of $21 million in 1986, broke even in 1987, lost $31 million in 1988 and earned $125 million last year.

DOC.HEAD: Penny Stock, Reform Bills Advance in House
DOC.TEXT: Bills that would crack down on penny stock fraud and increase the authority of the Securities and Exchange Commission to seek fines and halt alleged wrongdoing cleared a House panel Wednesday. The Penny Stock Reform Act and the Securities Law Enforcement Remedies Act passed a subcommittee of the House Energy and Commerce Committee by voice vote and now are subject to consideration by the full committee. The remedies act would give the SEC the power to issue ``cease and desist'' orders against suspected wrongdoers without having to go to court first. Unlike many other federal regulatory agencies like the Federal Trade Commission, the SEC does not have the authority to halt alleged illegal activity without a court order. The penny stock bill would give the SEC power to bar crooked promoters and consultants from selling highly speculative stocks which usually sell for a dollar or less. Penny stocks, low-priced and often risky securities, are traded over the counter rather than on a stock exchange. Because most information about them comes from the brokers who sell them, investments in penny stocks _ which typically are used to finance new or small companies _ are considered chancey at best. Penny stocks are not, in themselves, illegal but a 1989 study by the North American Securities Administrators Association, a Washington-based organization of state investment regulators, claimed that American investors lost about $2 billion a year in penny stock scams. ``For most of the last decade, the unscrupulous brokers and promoters in the penny stock market have preyed on unsuspecting investors in a cloudy atmosphere of regulatory neglect and public ignorance,'' said Rep. Edward J. markey, chairman of the finance and telecommunications subcommittee. Markey introduced the bill in April with the subcommittee's ranking Republican, Matthew J. Rinaldo of New Jersey. The version passed by the subcommittee differed from the original bill, however, which would have required all penny stocks to be listed on an automated stock price quotation system. The amended version only requires the SEC to facilitate at ``the earliest feasible time'' an automated quote system. The new version also watered down original restrictions on so-called ``blank check'' investments which seek customers' money without a specific business plan or purpose, and ``blind pool'' penny stocks, which seek mergers and acquisitions in a specific industry or line of business. Rather than an outright ban, the amended version would require the SEC to adopt rules calling for improved disclosure of information about companies selling penny stocks to the public.

DOC.HEAD: Electronics Firm Plans Global Cellular System
DOC.TEXT: Motorola Inc. plans to establish the first global, satellite-based cellular phone system at a cost of up to $2 billion, according to a report published Wednesday. The system would require the launching of a network of low-orbiting satellites that would extend cellular services into remote areas of the United States and around the world, the Chicago Tribune reported. The system would be used by international travelers and residents of remote areas of the United States where it would not be economical to build land-based transmitters of cellular signals. Analysts said the system's cost could total $1 billion to $2 billion. Telephone calls to Motorola officials seeking comment were not returned Wednesday. Motorola officials have scheduled a briefing on Tuesday in New York to unveil the system. Industry sources say it would involve launching about 70 small satellites to carry telephone signals around the world, and would be operating by the mid-1990s. Approval by the Federal Communications Commission would be required. John Pemberton, an analyst with Gartner Group Inc., a research firm in Stamford, Conn., said the system would represent a major change in cellular communications technology. Pemberton said he believes Motorola is planning a system that will use a ground-based and satellite system. He said as the user moves from an area covered by the ground system to a more remote area, the satellite system would take over without the user noticing any change in voice or data transmission quality. The Tribune reported that Motorola is finalizing agreements with a number of companies capable of launching its satellites, among them Washington, D.C.-based Orbital Sciences Corp. The company uses its Pegasus rocket to launch small playloads into orbit from airplanes. With the satellite system, Motorola would move into an area currently dominated by telephone companies. Pemberton said American Telephone & Telegraph Co. is one company in particular that could be hurt by Motorola's move. He said Motorola moved up an announcement of its plans for a satellite system from later this year to get a jump on competitors and to have it established as the standard for the industry. Reportedly, other communications companies also are moving into global cellular telephone technology. AT&T reportedly has teamed up with Washington-based Geostar Corp. to develop a system similar to the one being planned by Motorola. The FCC already has licensed American Mobile Satellite Corp. to launch and operate a mobile communications system for the United States, said Ruth Pritchard-Kelly, a company spokeswoman. Officials of American Mobile say the company has plans to launch its first satellite, a geostationary unit, in 1993 to provide voice and data communications to mobile telephone users in this country. Schaumburg, Ill.-based Motorola is the world's biggest supplier of cellular phone systems and mobile and portable phones. Pemberton said the company's system would stimulate sales of Motorola cellular telephone equipment.

DOC.HEAD: Getty Subsidiary, Official Accused of Excise Tax Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A Getty Petroleum Corp. subsidiary and one of its executives were accused Wednesday of conspiring with two customers to evade payment on $946,000 in federal gasoline excise taxes. Getty Terminals Corp., which distributes gasoline in the Northeast, and one of its managers, William Rea, were named in the four-count indictment returned by a federal grand jury in New York. The Justice Department said the indictment was part of a continuing investigation into what officials called the evasion of an estimated $1 billion a year in federal fuel excise taxes by gasoline wholesalers. The indictment charged that Getty Terminals and Rea, then the supply and trading manager, conspired with the owners of two New York City gasoline wholesale distributorships to evade payment of the excise taxes. John Pabone, owner of J & J Petroleum Inc., and John Quock, owner of Tun Yung Oil Corp., were also accused in the indictment of participating in the scheme. The two wholesalers are accused of agreeing to share in the proceeds of the unpaid taxes. Getty Terminals and Rea, now a Getty vice president, were accused of filing false invoices to disguise the sales of 10.4 million gallons of gasoline as tax-free transactions to evade payment of $946,000 in excise gases. Tun Yung had registered with the Internal Revenue Service as a producer and was therefore eligible to purchase gasoline from Getty Terminals without paying excise taxes. But Getty and Tun Yung were required to pay excise taxes of 9 cents for each gallon of gasoline sold to J&J, according to the indictment. The indictment charged that Getty Terminals had agreed to disguise sales to J&J as tax-free sales to Tun Yung. Getty Terminals said in a statement that it collected and remitted all taxes it was required to collect. ``Getty Terminals has absolutely no motive to refrain from collecting taxes inasmuch as all taxes collected are remitted to the IRS. In fact, Getty pays in excess of $200 million in taxes each year,'' the statement said. The company also defended Rea, saying it has ``the highest regard for (his) integrity, honesty and competence.'' The statement said he had volunteered for and passed a lie detector test. If convicted, Getty Terminals could be fined up to $2 million. Each of the three individuals could be sentenced to up to 20 years in prison and fined $1 million if convicted. In a separate indictment returned by the same grand jury, two brothers who own wholesale fuel companies in Westchester County, N.Y., were charged with participating in a complicated scheme to purchase untaxed gasoline. Richard Kennon and his brother, Robert Kennon, were charged with conspiracy to defraud the government and participating in the filing of false excise tax returns. The Kennons operate Jenny Oil Corp., Oil City Enterprises Inc. and Mount Vernon Energy Terminals Inc. The charges against each of the Kennons carry a maximum penalty of 14 years imprisonment and fines totaling $550,000.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Companies Seek Waiver of Breakup Provisions
DOC.TEXT: Ameritech and Bell Atlantic Corp. sought court permission Wednesday to carry phone traffic to New Zealand following their recent agreement to buy that country's phone company for $2.4 billion. The two regional phone companies, which were spun off from the old Bell system in 1984, are prohibited by a federal consent decree from carrying calls to or from the United States. Ameritech and Bell Atlantic said they were asking U.S. District Judge Harold Greene, who oversaw the Bell system breakup, for a waiver from the consent decree provisions. If Greene does not grant their request, the companies would have to form another company to carry the international traffic, said Hyde Tucker, president and chief executive officer of Bell Atlantic International. He said it would cost ``millions'' to perform such a reorganization. Thomas P. Hester, Ameritech vice president and general counsel, said he believed Greene would grant the waiver. ``Similar relief was previously granted by the court to Pacific Telesis, another of the Bell companies subject to the decree, when Pacific purchased an interest in a foreign overseas cable venture,'' Hester said in a statement. Tucker said the Ameritech-Bell Atlantic request was less problematic because the New Zealand company handles traffic jointly with U.S. carriers and won't be competing with U.S. companies. ``U.S. carriers compete among themselves at the U.S. end and the New Zealand telephone company does not seek authority to enter that competition,'' Tucker said. ``It only asks authority to continue to carry its own end of the calls.'' Ameritech and Bell Atlantic announced June 14 that they and two New Zealand companies, Fay, Richwhite Holdings Ltd. and Freightways Holdings Ltd., will purchase New Zealand's state-owned phone system. Under the plan, the two American companies will reduce their combined stake to 49.9 percent eventually but will remain as controlling shareholders.

DOC.HEAD: McDonnell Douglas Plans Layoffs; General Dynamics' Bond Ratings Dropped
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with chairman's comment; picks up 5th graf pvs, `Also on ...'
DOC.TEXT: The slump in the defense industry hit the Pentagon's two biggest contractors again Wednesday, with McDonnell Douglas Corp. announcing plans for major layoffs and General Dynamics Corp. getting its credit rating cut. McDonnell Douglas, the nation's biggest defense contractor, announced plans to eliminate at least $700 million a year from its cost structure, including laying off a ``substantial'' number of its 127,000 workers worldwide. ``The hard reality is that we must begin immediately to take further strong actions to reduce our costs,'' said John F. McDonnell, chairman and chief executive. McDonnell said the cost-cutting plan should be in place by early August, with immediate steps being taken on overtime, travel, new hiring, consultants, advertising and support activities. ``We have done a lot to downsize the defense cutbacks, including bringing aerospace work to St. Louis from Long Beach,'' said company spokesman Jim Reed. ``Despite that, we're going to have to reduce our size to improve profitability.'' Officals declined to reveal the number of planned layoffs, which will be made within the next few months. St. Louis television stations quoted unnamed company sources as saying the cuts could be up to 10 percent of McDonnell Douglas' workforce. Also on Wednesday, Moody's Investor Services Inc. dropped its credit ratings two notches for General Dynamics, nation's second biggest defense contractor. Both companies are headquartered in St. Louis. Moody's dropped General Dynamics' senior bonds from A2 to Baa1 and the company's subordinated debt from A3 to Baa2 because of the sagging conditions in the defense industry. The ratings put the company's bonds into the bottom category of investment grade issues. General Dynamics makes F-16 fighter jets for the Air Force, M1 tanks for the Army and SSN-688 submarines for the Navy. It also owns Cessna Aircraft Co. and makes a launch rocket used to put satellites into orbit. Moody's said it ``believes that the manufacturers of defense platforms (planes, tanks, submarines) will be the most severely affected by reduced defense spending.'' Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is proposing a 25 percent cut in the nation's military spending, wich would retire six active duty Army divisions, 111 Navy ships and 11 Air Force tactical fighter wings. Fred Pastore, associate director of the High Technology Group at Moody's, said another reason for the credit rating downgrade was the company's decreased amount of readily available cash. General Dynamics spokesman Pete Connolly said the company was disappointed with the downgrade. But, he said, ``we feel we have both a strong balance sheet and a strong balance of business which will sustain us through this period.'' In New York, industry analyst Paul Nisbet of Prudential-Bache said the McDonnell Douglas layoffs should not be regarded as a sign the company, which has a hefty backlog of commercial aircraft orders, is in trouble. ``It would stand to reason with the likelihood of somewhat lower activity on several of their military programs,'' said Nisbet. ``The company's probably going to have a 20 percent increase in sales next year, primarily because of increase in (commercial) aircraft.'' McDonnell Douglas, which has 10 plants in the United States, reported sales of $14.58 billion last year compared with $14.4 billion in 1988. ``We're projecting them at $16.2 (billion) this year, over $18 billion in 1991 and to $20 (billion) by 1992,'' Nisbet said. ``They've got a wealth of business, with over $50 billion in backlog.'' The layoffs represent ``just a shift in business from what predominantly was a military market in the '80s to a predominantly commercial market in the '90s,'' Nisbet said. ``They're just having trouble digesting it.'' Douglas Aircraft in Long Beach, its production behind schedule on the C-17 cargo plane, has lost $306 million the past 15 months. To trim its costs, the company has begun cutting 7,000 jobs, mostly white collar, at its plants in Long Beach and nearby Torrance, Calif. McDonnell Douglas programs that would be affected by Cheney's proposed cuts include the Harpoon and Tomahawk missiles and the F-15 and FA-18 jet fighters. Employees were informed of layoffs on Wednesday by closed-circuit television.

DOC.HEAD: Environmentalists Converge on Timber Mill; 44 Arrested
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with 44 arrested, shots fired at loggers in separate incident. Also on general wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto XEUR1
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of environmentalists demonstrated outside a giant lumber mill Wednesday and 44 were arrested in a ``Redwood Summer'' protest of logging that they say endangers California's ancient forests. About 350 protesters environmentalists and a sprinkling of labor union activists demonstrated at the coastal Louisiana Pacific mill as part of a summer of protests planned by the militant Earth First! environmental coalition. About 250 miles to the southeast in the Sierra Nevada range, a group of loggers was fired on Wednesday by gunmen with semi-automatic rifles, but no one was hit and authorities didn't draw a connection with the demonstration on the coast. Redwood Summer organizers hope activists from around the country will converge on northern California's redwood country to protest logging of ancient trees in an environmentalists' reprise of the 1964 ``Freedom Summer'' civil rights demonstrations in Mississippi. They demand an end to what they say is excessive clear-cut logging, and cutting of virgin redwood trees. Mainstream environmental groups, including the Sierra Club, have shunned the plans and disavow the tactics of Earth First! Followers of the loosely-organized group advocate what they call direct action to protect the environment, including standing between loggers and trees. The group renounced its old practice of driving spikes into tree trunks to make them useless as lumber after sawmill workers were hurt by the spikes. Wednesday's demonstration was the first in the redwood country of northern California's coast range, though a previous Redwood Summer rally was held in Sacramento. The protest outside the plant 275 miles north of San Francisco was largely peaceful except for name-calling between demonstrators and plant workers or passing drivers. After several hours, a contingent of protesters marched onto company property and approached officers in what they called ``a planned act of civil disobedience.'' Forty-four of them were arrested, most for trespassing, said Humboldt County Deputy Sheriff Leona Mendenhall. Most were issued citations and released. As the demonstrators gathered at the mill gate and across the street on coastal sand dunes, police said members of the Greenpeace environmental group in a small boat tried to approach a Louisiana Pacific freighter that was being loaded at the company's dock. Authorities ordered the boat away, according to a police dispatcher. No arrests were reported. At one point, a dozen Humboldt County sheriff's deputies were called out to head off a confrontation between the demonstrators and plant workers, who staged a pro-company rally during their lunch break. There were heated exchanges of epithets. Duane Plant, a lumber worker who carried a sign urging a stop to ``environmental terrorists,'' said Louisiana Pacific's logging practices were proper. ``They scare me,'' Plant said of the radical environmentalists. ``I am afraid of getting hurt. I am afraid of my kids getting hurt. I can't believe they're not violent.'' Demonstrator David Solnit, 26, a carpenter from San Francisco, said logging practices must be changed. ``We've got to save what's left of the forests,'' Solnit said. ``They (Louisiana Pacific officials) are acting like outlaws and we need to take direct action.'' In an apparently unrelated incident in the Sierra County, two or three people with semi-automatic rifles fired up to 300 rounds at a group of loggers Wednesday, said sheriff's dispatcher Fred Burns. Nobody was hurt, and two people were arrested, Burns said, adding that it appeared the gunmen were trying to scare the loggers rather than injure them. ``I think with 300 rounds they could have hit someone if they wanted to,'' Burns said. ``But that's a presumption.'' Fears of violence escalated in recent weeks after a bomb went off in a car carrying Earth First! leaders Judy Bari and Darryl Cherney. Earth First! members say the two were targets of a bomber, but police have booked Bari and Cherney on investigation of illegally transporting explosives. On Tuesday, more than 100 Earth First! followers camped in the woods near remote Honeydew, a two-hour drive south, and spent most of the day huddled in non-violence training sessions.

DOC.HEAD: Pathe's Buyout of MGM-UA Appears Shaky; Financing Talks Continue
DOC.TEXT: Pathe Communications Corp. continues to negotiate financing for its $1.2 billion offer for MGM-UA Communications Co., but seems unlikely to complete the deal by a Saturday deadline. MGM-UA officials were discussing extending the deadline for the $20-a-share tender offer, spokesman Scott Tagliarino said Wednesday. He noted that Pathe so far has fulfilled its obligations to MGM-UA, including delivering $200 million in down payments. Pathe, headed by Italian financier Giancarlo Parretti, has extended its offer several times past its original close date of April 30. Saturday is the latest possible deadline under the agreement between Parretti and MGM-UA's controlling shareholder, Kirk Kerkorian. Further extensions would require an all-new agreement, Tagliarino said. Pathe's problems are with its chief backer, Time Warner Inc., which has agreed to loan Pathe $650 million of the purchase price. Time Warner has insisted that the remaining $600 million must not come from borrowed funds and that Pathe put up $450 million of that equity itself. So far, Parretti's proposed patchwork of loans through European affiliates of Pathe has failed to meet Time Warner's criteria. Attorneys for both companies continued to negotiate Wednesday. Even Pathe's $200 million in down payments were made with borrowed funds, Time Warner spokeswoman Marilyn Harris said. ``The $200 million is not equity, it's a loan,'' Ms. Harris said. According to its agreement with Pathe, MGM-UA could pocket the $200 million if the deal falls apart in return for issuing 10 million new shares of common stock to Parretti. Pathe also has guaranteed MGM-UA $75 million in fees for distributing Pathe films. In exchange for providing financing, Time Warner would get a lien on the United Artists movie library, distribution rights to that library, and distribution rights to future Pathe and MGM-UA releases. Pathe spokesman Craig Parsons said discussions with Time Warner include whether the $200 million down payment is equity. An even bigger issue is a proposed $368 million loan from Parretti's Luxembourg-based holding company, Comfinance S.A., which in turn was to raise the money from a variety of asset sales and borrowings. Pathe plans to repay Comfinance in shares of stock, thereby converting the loan to equity, Parsons said. Time Warner also is concerned whether the loans and asset sales to finance the Comfinance loan will materialize as billed. For example, in a Security and Exchange Commission filing last week, Pathe said an affiliate would sell a 27 percent stake in a Milan bank for $52.5 million to Centro Nord Commissionaria, a financial company. However, The Financial Times, a British newspaper, quoted Centro Nord's president as saying no such deal had been agreed upon. Meanwhile Wednesday, Parretti aides said he will battle a French decision to block his efforts to acquire all of Pathe Cinema, a major French movie and TV producer with a 400-film library and a chain of about 400 theaters. Pathe Cinema is unrelated to Pathe Communications. Parretti asked the European Community Commission in Brussels to overturn French Finance Minister Pierre Beregovoy's decision to block the purchase of Pathe Cinema. He said the decision was arbitrary and an abuse of power. Parretti already owns 48 percent of Pathe Cinema.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules in Favor of Former Shell Shareholders
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 3rd graf to UPDATE with judge not setting date for hearing on award amount.
DOC.TEXT: A Delaware court has ruled that the Royal Dutch-Shell Group violated disclosure rules in its $5.7 billion buyout of minority shareholders in the former Shell Oil Co. five years ago. The Court of Chancery in New Castle County, Delaware, ruled in favor of a group of minority shareholders, who had sued over the terms of the buyout. Tuesday's ruling did not determine how much the former owners of 15 million shares of Shell stock should be awarded, said Houston attorney Ken McNeil, who represented the plaintiffs. The judge asked both sides to submit recommendations on the award but did not set a date for a hearing on the matter. The violation occurred ``because the defendant failed to disclose the existence of oil and gas reserves having a value of approximately $1 billion,'' the court ruling said. The class action lawsuit was filed by the former Shell minority shareholders against Shell Petroleum Inc., the Royal Dutch-Shell subsidiary that bought out Shell Oil's minority shareholders in June 1985. The Anglo-Dutch oil giant had owned 69.4 percent of Shell Oil. It initially offered $55 a share for the remainder, raised the bid to $58 and finally agreed to pay an extra $2 a share to settle a lawsuit by some minority shareholders. The Delaware trial was limited to the issue of whether adequate disclosure was made in materials sent to the former Shell stockholders advising them of their option to accept the Royal Dutch-Shell offer or seek an appraisal of the fair value of their shares, McNeil said. H.R. Hutchins, a spokesman for Houston-based Shell, said the company was disappointed with the court's decision. ``The court based it's decision on an inadvertent error which left out about 8 percent of the discounted future net cash flow from estimated oil and gas reserves,'' Hutchins said. ``The discounted cash flow analysis is `soft' data because it is based on numerous assumptions and estimates. In view of the voluminous information that was furnished to the shareholders, we believe they could readily have made an informed decision with respect to the 1985 merger proposal.'' In a separate proceeding, the same Delaware court is determining the appraisal value of the Shell Oil stock for former owners of 1 million shares, who rejected the $60-a-share offer. These former owners have claimed the shares were worth up to $110 each.

DOC.HEAD: Antique Auction Draws International Collectors
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 9th graf, `The previous ...' to UPDATE that previous record was held by same coin that was auctioned Tuesday.
DOC.TEXT: Two ancient Greek coins fetching more than a half million dollars each were among the record breakers Tuesday at an auction of the highly touted coin and antique collections of the one-time billionaire Hunt brothers. The auction also saw the rare ``Ides of March'' coin, struck by Brutus to commemorate the assassination of Julius Caesar in 44 B.C., sell for $99,000. The items sold Tuesday _ the first in a series of Hunt auctions _ brought a total of just over $20 million, far more than the presale estimate of $12 million. A Greek vase painted with a battle scene sold for a record $1.76 million. The 18-inch vase, circa 510 B.C., is black with red figures painted on it depicting the death of Kyknos in battle with Hercules. It was reconstructed from a fragment signed by Euphronius, one of the most important ancient Greek artists, said Sotheby's David Redden, an expert in the field. The buyer was identified only as a European dealer. Two silver Greek coins became the most expensive ever sold at auction. The Decadrachm of Agrigentum, dating from 410 B.C., sold for $572,000, followed by another decadrachm, circa 465 B.C., for $528,000. The second coin had held the previous auction record, having fetched $272,000 in 1974. All prices include the auction house's 10 percent commission. The first coin sold Tuesday is one of eight known specimens of its kind, Sotheby's said. It shows an eagle and four horses being driven by sun god Helios on one side and two eagles perched over a dead hare on the other. The other has the head of the goddess Athena on one side and an owl on the other. Nelson Bunker and William Herbert Hunt, heirs to an oil fortune, lost more than $1.5 billion speculating in the silver market a decade ago. The Dallas businessmen emerged from bankruptcy court protection earlier this year under a reorganization plan that called for them to sell off their antique collections and some personal possessions. The New York auction has attracted collectors from around the world and was one of several planned in the coming year involving the Hunt estates. R. Carter Pate, trustee in charge of liquidating Nelson Bunker Hunt's estate, said before Tuesday's auction that he expected all of the asset sales to raise between $20 and $25 million. Most of the money will go to the Internal Revenue Service, the largest creditor in the brothers' bankruptcy cases. This week's sale likely will be the most spectacular of the auctions because of the strength of the collection, he said.
